Unity and Determination: Castilonium’s Guide to the Path of War Zealot

Or: How to Weaponize your Dissociative Identity Disorder

Feel free to buy me a coffee!

https://ko-fi.com/castilonium

Table of Contents

  1. Introduction
  2. Ability Scores, and Picking your Fighting Style
  3. Races
  4. The Chassis
  5. Class Features
  6. Archetypes
  7. Feats and Traits
  8. Dipping, Multiclassing, and Prestige Classes
  9. How to Keep Track of Everything
  10. Equipment
  11. Disciplines & Maneuvers
  12. Third Party Material (Spheres of Power/Might) (Under construction)
  13. Sample Builds

Introduction: What is a Zealot?

The Zealot is a psionic initiator from the Path of War series by Dreamscarred Press!  This versatile class specializes in party support and tanking, but is bursting to the brim with bonus feats and abilities that allow it to take on different roles, depending on your choices.  Zealots have impressive party buffs, some of the best damage mitigation, and one of the best maneuver recovery mechanics in the game.  {Paizo Discussion} {GITP Discussion}

Q: Why not play a warder if you want to tank?  They have d12 HD, Aegis to buff allies, Armiger’s Mark, and Extended Defense for limitless counters.

A: Zealots can directly reduce the damage their allies take with Martyrdom, grant them maneuvers with Echoes of Steel, and move them out of harm’s way with Improved Path of Dedication.  Zealots also grant their party offensive and utility benefits as part of their class features, while Warders do not.  Warders are more of a direct, defensive, personal tank, while Zealots are more indirect and party-focused.

Q: Why not play a mystic if you want to support?  Their Glyphs are ridiculously good, especially after level 13!  They grant their entire party huge buffs as a move action!

A: Support from Mystics is more proactive than reactive.  Many of a Zealot’s support abilities can be done as immediate or free actions outside of their turn.  Also, Zealots can recover maneuvers whenever they want and always have access to their best ones.

Rating System

Red*: Don’t pick this.

Orange**: Not very good, or situational.

Green***: A decent choice that won’t go amiss.

Blue****: Magnifique!

Purple*****: The best of the best!

Reference Websites

d20pfsrd:  General-purpose reference.  Contains Path of War info, but is often out of date.

Archives of Nethys:  A completely up-to-date reference for all 1pp Paizo material.

Library of Metzofitz:  Up-to-date for all Dreamscarred Press material.

Spheres of Power Wiki:  Up-to-date for Spheres of Power and Spheres of Might by Drop Dead Studios, and Akashic material, including Dreamcarred Press, Lost Spheres Productions, Cobalt Sage Creations, and more.

Ability Scores, and Picking your Fighting Style

In Pathfinder, it pays to know what type of weapon you’re going to be using for your career, and which stat you want to use for attack rolls.  This will determine how you should pick your feats and ability scores.  Zealots can potentially use strength, dexterity, constitution, or charisma for attack rolls.  A Zealot is proficient with all simple and martial weapons and with all armor (heavy, light, and medium) and shields (except tower shields).  Your weapon choice should fit with how Zealots optimally play.

As a Zealot, it’s often best to use your standard actions on strike maneuvers, your move actions on Aid Another, and your swift/immediate actions on boosts and counters.  Zealots are the only class that can recover multiple maneuvers without a swift/standard/full round action or cooldown timer, and can recover exactly the ones they want, regardless of circumstances.  This means they can use their best strikes and boosts/counters every single round.  Zealots are poor at full attacking compared to other classes because they lack class features that give bonus damage on each hit like barbarians, fighters, rangers, rogues, paladins, cavaliers, gunslingers, inquisitors, slayers, swashbucklers, stalkers, warlords, harbingers, etc.  Full attacking also denies you the ability to use a move action for Aid Another.

Sword & Board w/o TWF****:  In conventional Pathfinder, this is considered a terrible style, and people will tell you to pick up TWF, Improved Shield Bash, and Shield Master.  But Zealots aren’t the best TWFers.  This style is for maximum durability and party support at the expense of a small amount of damage.  Your standard action Strike maneuvers deal damage mostly with bonus dice, meaning that the die size of your weapon and static damage modifier aren’t as important.  Also, the main purpose of your Strikes as a Zealot is to inflict secondary effects, AKA riders.  Martial Power is a great feat to take with this style, because the more temporary HP you give yourself, the less PP you use with Martyrdom.

Two Handed****:  Very effective right out of the gate, and doesn’t require any feat investment.  Add Power Attack to have the highest damage and lowest investment fighting style in the game.  This is the best for AoO builds, especially with a reach weapon, making it the best for actively protecting your party.  If you use other Dreamscarred Press products like Akashic Mysteries, Bloodforge, and Lords of the Wild, you can very easily stack size increases, even at low levels.  Not only do you block off exponentially more squares of the battlefield with your body, but you also increases your threatened area.  A medium Zealot threatens a 3x3 square, while a large one threatens 6x6.  Some GMs (and other players) don’t like dealing with gargantuan or colossal PCs clogging up their maps, so be considerate before doing that.

Reach & Shield*****:  This combines the advantages of the Sword & Board and the Two Handed fighting styles!  Get the Pikeman’s Training feat, Shield Brace feat, or dip 1 level of Fiendbound Marauder Warder to enable this, or be a maenad and wield a scorpion whip.

Archery****:  This is considered the best fighting style in conventional Pathfinder because it does the most damage, and can do so from anywhere on the battlefield.  The downside for Zealots is that it relies on full attacks.  Zealots have Solar Wind, which makes use of full attacks, but if you’re full attacking, you’re not using your support abilities to their fullest.  Luckily, you can avoid the usual Rapid Shot line of feats and opt for a lower strength than most archers take, have lower constitution since you’re not in harm’s way as much, have higher charisma (more PP), use standard action Strike maneuvers, and support your party from afar quite well.  The downside is that you won’t make as many AoO’s as your melee counterparts.

Finesse Melee****:  Zealots have Heavy Armor Proficiency, but dexterity is still a powerful option to pick over strength.  It improves your touch AC, reflex, initiative, ranged attack rolls, and far more useful skills than strength does.  However, it requires the Weapon Finesse and Deadly Agility feats to make the most of it.  Once you can afford Celestial Armor or Celestial Plate Armor with a sufficiently high dexterity, this style offers more AC than a strength-based one.  Polearm Dancer is a great alternative to Weapon Finesse.  Many GMs who allow PoW also use the popular Elephant in the Room Feat Tax houserules, effectively giving you free Weapon Finesse and Agile Maneuvers, and making dexterity-based builds much more powerful.

Unarmed***:  Zealots lack any class features that help them with this fighting style.  You need to spend 2 feats (Improved Unarmed Strike and Greater Unarmed Strike) to deal as much damage as a longsword.  An Amulet of Mighty Fists is twice as expensive than an equivalently enhanced weapon Handwraps exist now and put unarmed strikes at the same price as other weapons.  But since you can summon high enhancement weapons with Sleeping Goddess maneuvers, there’s little point in being unarmed.  You can dip into other classes to make this fighting style work, though, like Steelfist Commando Warlord 3, Primal Disciple Barbarian 2, Bloody-Knuckled Rowdy Bloodrager 1, Master of Many Styles Monk 1, or Aberrant Aegis 1.  A Wayfinder with a Cracked Deep Red Sphere will give you Improved Unarmed Strike for 700 gp.

Two Weapon Fighting*:  This fighting style requires a lot of feat investment, and requires you to full attack to get the most out of it.  Full attacking isn’t always the best option for Zealots for the reasons listed at the start of this section.

Throwing*:  Everything this can do, Archery does better, even with the nice throwing-related feats that Dreamscarred Press invented.  For throwing weapons to even equal archery, you need to be able to not spend an action drawing your weapon, increase your range increment, and not lose your weapon after throwing it.  You need to invest a tremendous amount of gold or feats to accomplish this.

Firearms****:  If you’re a pure Zealot, don’t even think about it, Ralphie.  You’ll shoot your eye out.  But if you dip a level of Privateer Warlord, then GASP!  Suddenly a wealth of options open up!  Firearms make ranged touch attacks within the first range increment, and pistols are one-handed, letting you use a shield for more AC.  The downside is that you need ways to deal with reload actions and misfires.  See the Dipping section for more details.

Shooting Star****:  This is based off of the Desna’s Shooting Star Divine Fighting Technique feat.  It lets you use your charisma for attack and damage while wielding a starknife!  This can let you maximize your charisma while dumping both strength and dexterity to a degree.  If you dip a level of Lore, Lunar, or Nature Oracle, you can dump dexterity even more.  Grab Noble Scion (War) for a massive boost in initiative.  You can be completely SAD (single ability dependent) with this build!  And luckily, you do NOT need to be compatible with Desna’s alignment in order to worship her and use this feat, thanks to the prerequisite text in Divine Anthology superseding that in the Weapon Master’s Handbook.  So Paladins can take this, legally!

Crimson Totem***:  This is based off the Crimson Totem veil from Akashic Mysteries.  It lets you create a free greatclub that uses constitution for attack and damage!  That lets you dump strength and stack constitution for more HP and fortitude.  The downsides are that greatclubs don’t have reach, deal less damage than other two-handed weapons, and can’t be used with shields.  Since Crimson Totem is a blood veil, the only ways to get it are via a dip in Aegis, Daevic, or Veiled Lord Warlord.

Laser Beams****:  Some disciplines have maneuvers that shoot laser beams pew pew, ranged touch attacks!  And some even have area-effect strikes.  This fighting style lets you eschew weapons and not worry as much about your own attack bonus.  Black Seraph has 4 lasers, 2 cones, and 2 PBAoEs (point blank area of effect).  Riven Hourglass has 1 laser and 2 cones.  Veiled Moon has 1 laser and 1 cone.  Elemental Flux has 5 lasers, 1 line, 1 PBAoE, 1 ranged burst (requires an animus augmentation), 1 chain lightning-like strike, and 1 stance that lets you shoot lasers at will!  This stance, Enter the Vortex, lets you use any other ranged weapon strike as a laser beam!  Currently, there are no 1st level laser maneuvers in the game, and Enter the Vortex is a 5th level stance.  But the Radiant Dawn discipline allows you to use any ranged weapon maneuver you can invest essence in as a laser beam called Sun’s Gleam.  And you can even use your strength rather than dexterity!  It gives strength-based characters an excellent, accurate ranged touch attack and way to land strikes.  In order to use Sun’s Gleam with non-Radiant Dawn maneuvers, you need one of the three feats that lets you do so:  High Noon, Sunrise, or Sunset.

Mounted*****:  This is a fighting style that can be combined with any of the others.  It’s almost like cheating because you can freely use your move action to Aid Another while your mount moves for you, and likely with a much greater speed than you.  Dipping a class with a mount or animal companion as a class feature isn’t worth it in the long run, because your mount’s HP will quickly fall behind and it will become a liability.  One way to get a scaling mount is with Nature Soul + Animal Ally.  Small characters have a vastly better option than medium characters in the form of a Mauler familiar, especially a fast flying one like a hawk.  If you’re medium, you can still ride a Mauler familiar by taking the Undersized Mount feat.  A familiar’s max HP is always equal to half your own, regardless of the class level used to get the familiar, and with your Martyrdom and counters, there’s little fear of it dying.  If you don’t want to dip a class for a familiar, you can get one with Skill Focus + Eldritch Heritage; Iron Will + Familiar Bond + Improved Familiar Bond; or simply Wasp Familiar if you worship Calistria.  Of course, there’s Leadership, but many games ban that feat, and for good reason.

Q: So which is the best?  There are a lot of blue options!  Gimme a TL;DR!

A: AoO builds: Two Handed (strength).  Maximum durability: Sword & Board.  Best of both worlds: Reach & Shield.  Long range: Archery.  Mid/short range: Pistol & Shield with 1 level of Privateer Warlord.  Charisma SAD: Shooting Star.  All: Mounted.  Dexterity-based builds have better AC, reflex, initiative, skills, speed due to light armor, and switch-hitting, but strength-based builds have better CMB, less reliance on feats, and better size-stacking potential.  If your GM uses Elephant in the Room Feat Tax houserules, dexterity-based builds are even better.  If your GM limits size-stacking, strength-based builds are even weaker.

Q: What stats should I pick for each build?

A: Depends on whether you take feats and class dips that let you dump more stats.

Strength:  Sword & Board***, Two Handed****, Reach & Shield***, Archery**, Finesse Melee*, Unarmed***, Two Weapon Fighting***, Throwing****, Firearms*, Shooting Star*, Crimson Totem*, Laser Beams****

Dexterity:  Sword & Board****, Two Handed**, Reach & Shield****, Archery****, Finesse Melee****, Unarmed****, Two Weapon Fighting****, Throwing****, Firearms****, Shooting Star**, Crimson Totem**, Laser Beams****

Constitution:  Most melee builds***, Ranged builds**, Crimson Totem****

Intelligence:  All builds*

Wisdom:  All builds**

Charisma:  Shooting Star*****, All other builds****

Q: Why is constitution lower priority than charisma in most builds?  Zealots are tanks!

A: Each PP can be used to negate at least 3 damage from an ally via Martyrdom.  More PP means more effective HP for your party.  Also, the higher your charisma, the higher your DCs are, and the more likely you are to successfully affect enemies with strikes that disable them with daze, nauseate, stun, etc.  Such disabled enemies can’t attack, so they can’t deplete your party’s HP.  Finally, you can get temporary HP from various ways like Martial Power, and that has nothing to do with constitution.

Races

Something important to note is the Favored Class Bonus that some races grant.  Duergar, Dwarves, Elves (and Half-Elves), Half-Giants, Halflings, and Half-orcs gain one-fourth of a new conviction every level.  That is GOOD.  Better than other classes with similar FCBs, such as the Warlord who only gets one-fifth of a new combat feat per level.  Convictions are as good or better than feats, and there are convictions that let you take combat or psionic feats.  This FCB means you will get a conviction every 2 levels rather than every 4 levels.  As such, the races listed above are some of the best.

A note on size:  Medium is the least optimal size for Zealots.  Being small grants several advantages while keeping your reach the same, with the only downside being a lower weapon damage die, which Zealots don’t care about.  Strength-based Zealots want to be as large as possible for more reach and size bonus to strength, and dexterity-based Zealots want to be small.  Being tiny or smaller is useful for ranged Zealots.

Paizo Races

Dwarf**: Sadly, they have a penalty to charisma.  But they’re one of the races that has the godly FCB, and their defensive racial abilities are quite respectable.  They also go well with heavy armor classes since they’re stuck at 20 ft speed all the time.

Elf***:  These pointy eared ladies and gentlemen are for Archery or Two Handed Zealots with Polearm Dancer and an Elven Branched Spear.  They have a nice selection of alternate racial traits including a 35 ft move speed, Skill Focus, or +2 initiative, and they have the best FCB.  Too bad they don’t have a bonus to charisma.

Gnome*:  No benefits whatsoever over a halfling.  Simply having a bonus to charisma doesn’t warrant them a rating higher than red.

Halfling*****: The absolute best dexterity-based Zealots of all.  Perfect stat modifiers, the best FCB, small size (+1 attack and AC is definitely worth the smaller weapon damage size), +1 to all saves, +2 perception, and a variety of juicy alternate traits!  Their only downside is that they’re not naturally psionic, which means they lose out on 2 power points and possibly 2 HP if they’re taking Psionic Body.

Half-Elf****:  A flexible +2 to one stat, the best FCB due to being able to use the Elf’s, Skill Focus, +2 perception, +2 saves vs enchantments, and Multitalented make this quite a potent race.  You could grab Kindred-Raised for another +2 to a stat with no negative stats.  Weapon Familiarity and Ancestral Arms let you use weapons like the Elven Branched Spear.  Round Ears gives you more skill points.  A versatile race for whatever build you could want.

Half-Orc*****: They have a flexible +2 to one stat, darkvision, the best FCB, and phenomenal alternate racial traits like Sacred Tattoo and Shaman’s Apprentice, letting them sleep easily in medium armor.  They’re also great at intimidation.  They can even get more bonus skill points through their race than humans can.  Prime candidates for any Zealot build.

Human*:  Humans are overrated.  Seriously.  All they get is bonus skill points and a bonus feat, of which Zealots of better races have many.  That’s all they have to work with when trading out things for alternate racial traits.  And they don’t have the best FCB.  The reason why most other guides give Humans high ratings is because most other classes value feats greatly at low levels just to make their builds “come online,” IE able to do what they’re meant to.  Zealots don’t have that problem.

Aasimar, Tiefling, and Skinwalker*****:  These are usually good at everything.  Except they don’t have the best FCB, alas!  If you don’t care about that, then they’re one of the best choices you can make.  They have the option of being medium or small, and can look like a celestial/fiendish/bestial version of whatever other humanoid race you want.  A halfling-heritage aasimar would be small-sized, look like an angelic halfling, and have the same racial features as an aasimar, with no halfling racial features.  If you play with Akashic Mysteries from Dreamscarred Press, these races can now be large because of the Gamla race.  Gamlas on their own make poor Zealots because of their racial traits, but large versions of these three races have no such downsides (Credit to upho!).  Fanglord Skinwalkers are particularly interesting for Archery Zealots because they have See In Darkness, so they can snipe from long ranges in pitch blackness.

Catfolk***:  Despite being incredibly attractive and having great stats for dex Zealots, they’re not as good as halflings.  You don’t need claws if you have Sleeping Goddess boosts or Sun’s Gleam.  They’re also medium-sized rather than small.  However, a climb speed can be useful if you don’t want to take Unbroken Stride, and the +8 bonus to climb is great for Fool’s Errand.

Drow****:  They have the elf subtype, so they have the best FCB.  Best used for Archery Zealots because of their incredible 120 darkvision and racial darkness and faerie fire SLA.  +2 perception, +2 intimidate and stealth in darkness, and SR 6+level are lovely benefits too.  You can sacrifice your darkvision to get rid of light blindness, or you can ask a kind caster for Protective Penumbra (or the overpowered cantrip version if your GM allows it).

Ifrit***: +Dex and +Cha are nice, but lacking in that delicious FCB.  However, they get bonus points for two things: An alternate racial trait that gives them +4 initiative, and the Fiery Glare trait which is wonderful for Eternal Guardian users.

Psionic Races

Your GM will probably be fine with you playing one of these since they’ve existed since 2010 and Zealots are already psionic.  These races gain a bonus 2 PP, which might not seem like much, but that alone means a few more saved hitpoints for your allies.

Dromite****:  Great stats, small size, natural armor, and they’re naturally psionic.  But alas, halflings are better because of that FCB.

Duergar**:  A little better than dwarves due to Expansion and being naturally psionic, but they also have the same problems as dwarves, and are dazzled in bright light.

Elan*: Their self-defense racial abilities require an immediate action.  Guess what also requires immediate actions.  Counters.

Half-Giant*****:  The best strength-based Two Handed Zealots in the game if Lion Catfolk or Gamla-heritage aasimar, tieflings, and skinwalkers are not allowed.  +2 str, naturally psionic, best FCB, and powerful build.  Half-Giants picking up the Primal Fury discipline will enjoy their +4 bonus to Survival.  Their one and only shortcoming is a lack of a charisma bonus.

Maenad****:  These highly emotional gem-encrusted seafarers have two particularly interesting racial traits.  The first is Outburst, which is like a weaker Rage, but uses power points, doesn’t require a dip in Barbarian or Bloodrager, and doesn’t carry an AC penalty.  If you have enough PP to fuel it, like at higher levels, it might as well be a permanent +2 bonus to your strength.  The second interesting trait is proficiency with flails.  It’s unclear if this means they are proficient with all weapons in the flail weapon group, or if they’re only proficient with the one-handed martial weapon called flail.  Assuming it’s the former, this means they can use the Meteor Hammer (reach weapon with a +1 shield bonus), the Flying Blade (reach weapon that has +2 attack on AoOs but -2 attack on other attacks), the Urumi (1d8 18-20 x2 one-hander), and the Scorpion Whip (one handed reach weapon).  Their lack of the best FCB is painful, however.  And if maenads aren’t actually proficient with the entire flail weapon group, they’re sadly not as great.

Xeph***: A decent choice for Mithral Current users, as they can get Quick Draw for free.  They also get either +1 to saves against spells or +1 dodge to AC.  Overall, worse than Dromites.

Bloodforge and Other DSP Races

Bloodforge by Dreamscarred Press provides a ludicrous number of new races and ways to mix bloodlines.  With a race trait called Mixed Blood, you gain one of many subtypes and additional bonuses.  This includes subtypes like dwarf, elf, halfling, and orc to get the best FCB.  That alone increases the ratings of all other races.  The races listed above were rated under the assumption that you’re not allowed to pick this trait, but the races below are rated assuming you can.  It’s less likely that your GM will allow you to use these options, and they can prove to be MUCH more powerful than the other races.  Look at the Library of Metzofitz for details on these.

Alicorn****:  The FCB for Alicorn Zealots is “Add +1/3 conviction point to the zealot’s pool.”  I have no idea what that means.  Convictions aren’t points and don’t have a pool.  Does it mean that you get one third of a new conviction?  That’s the best yet!  But it probably doesn’t mean that.  In that case, it’s not quite as good since it has no charisma bonus, but still has the elf subtype.  Poke a friend with a pin, then use Touch of Tranquility and Clarity of Pain prior to battle to buff your saves and AC by 2.  You can get a gore attack or +2 bonus to saves vs poison and mind-affecting effects.  Dipping a level of Rajah is crucial as an Alicorn because you gain 1 essence and an additional veil shaping slot.

Catfolk (Lion)*****:  From Bloodforge Infusions: Feathers and Fur.  +2 str, +2 cha, -2 dex.  Like Half-Giants, they have Powerful Build, but with way more charisma!  The kings of the jungle, and of strength-based builds!  They even get a +2 to diplomacy and intimidate as gravy, for all of your Fear the Reaper (Eternal Guardian 2) needs.

Catfolk (Tiger)****:  From Bloodforge Infusions: Feathers and Fur.  +2 str.  They’re large sized, but they wield medium-sized weapons.  A Lion Catfolk will do more damage and have more charisma, but a Tiger will cover more of a total area with their space and reach, which is good for protecting squishy teammates.

Doggo***:  From April Augmented 2018.  +2 str (or dex), +2 cha, -2 int.  These adorable puppers have 50 speed, swim speed, scent, and either +1 natural armor or Skill Focus.  Nothing especially spectacular for Zealots, and their lack of hands is a big problem in general.  But they can still wield two-handed weapons in their mouths, and thanks to telepathy, can still communicate!  Doggos aren’t optimal for Zealots, but Zealots are optimal for doggos, if you want to play one.  2 levels of Rajah are useful for getting unseen servants to handle handsy stuff.

Gamla*:  A race from Akashic Mysteries.  They don’t have a charisma bonus, and their racial features aren’t very useful for a Zealot, with one exception.  They are LARGE-sized playable humanoids!  So why the red rating?  Because you can use this fact to play a large-sized Aasimar, Tiefling, or Skinwalker!

Grendle*****:  +2 con, +2 cha, -2 int.  Heritage for the best FCB, +2 natural armor to AC, gain +4 strength when shaken or sickened, and most importantly, Imperious Bearing lets them demoralize all enemies within 30 feet anytime they attempt to demoralize!  Now instead of fear-locking just one enemy at a time with Enforcer + Soulless Gaze, you fear-lock the entire enemy team!  And it makes Fear the Reaper (Eternal Guardian 2) even MORE powerful!  You can also gain a climb speed, +8 climb for Fool’s Errand goodness.

Kestrel*****:  +2 dex, +2 cha, -2 int.  Halfling heritage for the best FCB, small size, safe falling and gliding, flight at level 9, +2 to all charisma checks involving their voice (which, let’s face it, will almost always be applicable), +1 dodge bonus to AC (or +1 to all saves), aaaand finally…  Increase the attack bonus of your Inspire Courage by 1 if you dip a level of Rubato Bard.  Holy.  Hell.  This race is better than halflings in every way!

Kijin*****:  +2 con, +2 cha, -2 wis.  Elf heritage for the best FCB, darkvision, a few SLAs, gain THP when damaging non-good creatures, and Sin Soaked which lets you shape one [evil] veil that doesn’t count towards your limit.  Pick The Fallen from the Rajah's veil list.  Not quite as ludicrous as other Bloodforge options, but still a fantastic option for a durable charisma-heavy build, like a Laser Beam or Shooting Star Zealot.

Kitsune (Huli Jung)****:  From Bloodforge Infusions: Feathers and Fur.  +2 dex, +2 cha, -2 str.  They get a bite attack and, like Alicorns, a free veil shaping slot to use with a Rajah dip, but have better stats.  You’ll need Mixed Blood for the best FCB.

Tengu (Bearded Vulture)****:  From Bloodforge Infusions: Feathers and Fur.  +2 wis, +2 cha, -2 str.  They don’t get anything that’s particularly incredible for Zealots, per se, but they do get a +2 racial bonus to saves and AC, and it even increases in certain circumstances!  That’s insanely good for anyone, as far as racial traits go.

Tengu (Pigeon)*****:  From Bloodforge Infusions: Feathers and Fur.  +2 int, +2 cha, -2 str.  Small size, +2 diplomacy, an additional +2 attack when flanking, and most importantly, they increase the bonus of aid another by +2!  They can either be good at languages or glide, as well.  The 20 ft speed is troublesome, but less so if you’re a ranged Zealot.  Now all you have to do is be adopted by an old granny halfling feeding pigeons at the park, and you’ll be set for aid another mastery!

The Chassis

HD****:  d10.  Only Warders and Barbarians are tougher than Zealots.

BAB*****:  Purple means best of the best!

Fort****/Ref**/Will**** Saves: It’s a good thing Zealots have a good will save, because they lack save-boosting features to make up for their low wisdom like Warlords and Paladins.  

Skill Points***: 4+INT modifier is plenty of skill points to do your job, even with 10 intelligence.

Class Skills: Autohypnosis** (Wis), Bluff**** (Cha), Craft* (Int), Diplomacy**** (Cha), Heal* (Wis), Intimidate***** (Cha), Knowledge (history)* (Int), Knowledge (martial)** (Int), Knowledge (nobility)* (Int), Knowledge (psionics)**** (Int), Knowledge (religion)*** (Int), Perception***** (Wis), Profession* (Wis), Sense Motive**** (Wis).

When deciding which skills to put ranks into, go to the maneuver page of every discipline you have access to, and use ctrl+f to find how often each discipline’s skill is used in its maneuvers.  Read each of these maneuvers and judge whether or not investing skill points just to use them would be worth using them over other maneuvers that don’t require skill points.

Autohypnosis** is used in 1 bad Riven Hourglass counter, 1 bad Riven Hourglass strike, 2 decent Sleeping Goddess counters, and 1 good Sleeping Goddess strike.  There are other good options to take in place of these maneuvers.  The big problem with Autohypnosis is that it’s wisdom-based, which is a dump stat for Zealots.  It’s nice to have 1 skill point in it to access the Memorize ability, or 4 points for Psionic Meditation and Deep Focus.

Diplomacy**** is only used in 1 Golden Lion counter, and it is inferior to Fear the Reaper (Eternal Guardian).  If you want to use Diplomacy in roleplay, put your skill points into it.  Otherwise, don’t.

Intimidate***** is used a LOT in both Black Seraph and Eternal Guardian, and the maneuvers that use it are very good.  Intimidate is very easy to improve through feats and items, and you can fear-lock enemies in a rather game-breaking way without much difficulty or investment.  In addition, it’s a social skill for roleplaying.

Knowledges: History*, Martial**, and Nobility* are fluff skills, but Martial may come in handy for identifying what maneuvers enemy Initiators use.  Still, you don’t need to know the names of their maneuvers in order to Counter them, so it’s of marginal use.  Psionics*** and Religion*** are used to identify creature types, which is very useful when figuring out how to fight them.  Psionic enemies aren’t used as often as undead by most GMs.

Initiating Modifier****: On its own, Charisma is worse compared to Intelligence and Wisdom.  Intelligence grants more skill points and better knowledge checks, and can use traits like Student of Philosophy, Clever Wordplay, and Pragmatic Activator to make charisma utterly obsolete.  Wisdom benefits perception, sense motive, and will saves, which are important for not being ambushed, tricked, or mind-melted.  HOWEVER!  With some handy dandy dipping with classes like Paladin, Bard, Oracle, and Warlord, charisma can be a stat to be reckoned with.

Maneuvers Known***: Zealots have the lowest number of maneuvers known out of all pure initiator classes, on par with Warders and Harbingers.  Still, it’s sufficient.  Their disciplines are Eternal Guardian, Golden Lion, Piercing Thunder, Sleeping Goddess, and Solar Wind.  Zealots can freely trade out these for Chimera Soul, Fool’s Errand, or Radiant Dawn.

Maneuvers Readied***: Zealots have the lowest number of maneuvers readied, too.

Stances: All Initiators learn stances at the same rate.

Maneuver Recovery*****: The Zealot has one of the best recovery mechanics out of all the Initiator classes!  They use Aid Another as a move action to recover a number of maneuvers equal to their cha mod.  A move action.  And their Aid Another benefit (for AC and skills, not attacks) gains a bonus equal to the intensity of their Zeal, which means you can grant your allies ludicrous amounts of bonuses easily every round.  On top of that, with Compartmentalized Aid, you can use Aid Another on yourself!  This means that you can reliably recover all of the maneuvers you used in the previous round and use them again and again -- your best strike and boost/counters, round after round.  Holy Sarenrae.

Q: What about Warlords?  They recover maneuvers as a swift action, doing a Gambit!

A: Gambits have particular criteria they need to fulfil before you can use them, whereas a Zealot can use Aid Another at any time.  Also, using a swift action means you have to forego using a boost or counter.

Q: What about Bushis?  They recover maneuvers as a FREE action!

A: Only one per round.  A Zealot can recover multiple per round, and they need to, because they can use multiple per round.  This is especially true with action-economy improving maneuvers from Riven Hourglass, the 8th level augment of the Protection Mission, and the Eternal Hourglass feat.

Q: What about Mystics?  They recover maneuvers as NO action!

A: They have to wait 4 rounds (or 3 with Extra Granted Maneuver) before their maneuvers recover.  This means they can’t use their best maneuvers every single round.  Zealots don’t have to wait at all.

Class Features

Power Points/Day***: Zealots have far fewer PP than other psionic classes, but gain bonus PP from charisma at the exact same rate:  0.5 PP per level per point of charisma bonus.  The bonus PP from charisma scales linearly, while the PP from Zealot class levels scales quadratically.  IE, you get relatively more PP per level as you get more levels.  You also gain bonus PP from the number of Sleeping Goddess maneuvers you know.

Collective****: Just to be clear, this only lets you tell whether or not someone is still a member, and doesn’t tell you their position, emotions, or status.  Much more awesomely, it lets you use teammate-friendly maneuvers on your allies from way further away than you otherwise could.  That means that right at level 1, you could be 100 feet away from your party but still use Encouraging Roar (normally a 30 ft range) on them.  When you reach higher levels, you can yank buddies across entire planes with Reunion in Dreams (Sleeping Goddess 4).

Zeal****: This gives your entire team a morale bonus to attack for 1 round, and it can be activated one of two ways:

  • Hit with a Strike maneuver
  • Use Aid Another to recover your maneuvers

The Community-Minded trait makes this last 3 rounds instead of 1!  But if your GM thinks that’s too cheesy and won’t allow you to take it, don’t worry.  Zeal is very easy to activate every round.  Alas, since this is a morale bonus, it doesn’t play well with Encouraging Roar or Golden General’s Attitude from Golden Lion.  It works perfectly fine with a Bard in the party, though, because Inspire Courage is a competence bonus.

Compartmentalized Aid****:  This allows you to recover your maneuvers whenever you want, even if you don’t have a single friend for miles around.  It also allows you to be quite the respectable solo fighter, help you land a crucial debuffing strike maneuver, or survive the front lines with better AC.

Burning Contemplation**:  There aren’t many psionic feats requiring wisdom that are especially amazing for Zealots.  Speed of Thought, Unhindered Way, and Psionic Meditation are of questionable value when you consider that you can do better with maneuvers.

Conviction: Convictions are handy abilities on par with feats, and sometimes better.  It is definitely worth picking a race with the FCB that gives you 1/4th of a conviction per level.

  • Combat Conviction***: A bonus combat feat!  Useful for fleshing out builds.
  • Enduring Zeal**: Do better than this conviction by taking the Community-Minded trait.  If you can’t spare the trait for it, or your GM won’t let you take it, well, I guess it’s orange!
  • Hearten the Mindless**:  You can apply your Zeal bonuses to mindless creatures.  Quite handy if you have a necromancer, golem crafter, or sneaky android in your party.
  • Improved Zeal****:  Increasing the attack of your teammates by a further +1 for a mere 2 PP is definitely worth it.  Save it for a higher level if you’re seriously worried about running out of PP at low levels.
  • Impulsive Reactions*****:  Gain Combat Reflexes and use charisma instead of dexterity to determine your number of bonus AoO’s!  Exquisite for two handed AoO builds and Bodyguard users, great for other melee builds with increased reach from size increases or the Protection mission, and pointless for ranged builds.
  • Path of Dedication**:  This is a nice option for moving your teammates around, but losing your own move action is painful.  You need those to Aid Another and recover maneuvers.
  • Path of Dedication, Improved*****:  Look how much our little conviction has grown!  It allows your entire team to reposition at the cost of 3 PP and your psionic focus as a free action.  Sadly, the granted move action can only be used to move.
  • Personality Fragment*****:  This effectively gives you +3 to a skill (or +2 to a save), +2 perception and sense motive, an extra set of eyes which means it can roll perception, sense motive, and knowledge checks too, a sneaky little scout with a +18 stealth bonus right off the bat, and limitless roleplay potential with an adorable crystal mascot!  Take the Psicrystal Containment feat to get a second psionic focus.  One of the most amazing things you can do with your psicrystal is use Echoes of Steel to give it ally-assisting boosts and laser beam (ranged touch attack or AoE) maneuvers.  Check out Psionics Augmented: Psicrystals for an expanded list of personalities and bonuses.
  • Psionic Conviction***:  Like Combat Conviction, but for Psionic Feats.  If there are psionic feats you wish you could take, but have trouble justifying, consider this as an option.
  • Strike of Unity****: You can now initiate your maneuvers by using your allies to do it for 5 PP.  Expensive cost, and not always useful, but it can open up some fun and interesting tricks.  You can send your sneaky little psicrystal ahead to sit in a bandit lord’s pile of gems, and then unexpectedly SMACK the villain through your psicrystal with all of your might and zealous fury!
  • Tempered Body*: Pathfinder is notorious for not having many good armor or shield enhancements, which makes Fortification the go-to enhancement.  Since it doesn’t stack with Tempered Body, that means this conviction is worthless.

Martyrdom****: You can redirect damage from your teammates to yourself, and negate the damage by spending PP.  As a free action.  The downsides are that you can only use it once per round, and you can’t use it on yourself.  If you have a source of temporary hitpoints, like from Martial Power, this can be a delightfully efficient way of soaking up damage!  The exchange rate of damage to PP also means that having a higher charisma is better than having a higher constitution, as long as you yourself are not taking too much direct damage.

Commitment***:  Aid Another for your party members, no matter how far, and delicious maneuver recovery for you!  It’s a wonderful option, but you’ll often use Aid Another on yourself.

Telepathy****: This makes language barriers moot!  No more need for your wizard or cleric friend to carry around a scroll of Tongues!  No more need to plop a bunch of points into Linguistics!  It’s also nice for secretly plotting with your party and doing recon.  Just be aware that communicating via telepathy is just as difficult as verbally talking to multiple people at once.  That means that an NPC your party’s conversing with might feel a little awkward if your entire party goes quiet for a few seconds to plot silently right in front of him.

Echoes of Steel*****:  You can let your allies copy your maneuvers and use them as well!  Is your Stalker friend running out of high level strikes and can’t stomach using a full round action to recover?  Grant him a vicious boost or beefy strike to finish off the enemy!  Is your Inquisitor friend sitting around doing nothing with her swift action because she’s already activated her Judgment earlier?  Grant her a timely Fear the Reaper to put her intimidate bonus to good use preventing damage to the party!  Did your big dumb fighter friend who put 5 different feats into his highly specialized weapon just get it disarmed and/or sundered?  Give him a new weapon with Armory of the Sleeping Goddess!  But the real treat comes when you echo maneuvers to your psicrystal, especially ally-assisting boosts and laser beam (ranged touch attack or AoE) maneuvers.

Mission: These are the big class features that distinguish different Zealots from one another, aside from fighting styles and maneuver choices.  Missions have 4 parts:  A passive benefit that works while you’re psionically focused, an active benefit that works when you expend your psionic focus, and two new augments for your maneuvers.

Creation***:  This is the only class feature that allows Zealots to directly heal people’s HP.  It winds up being very expensive in terms of PP.

  • Eternal Rebirth (passive)*:  If your teammates are killed, they can be healed within 1 round to bring them back to life before actually dying.  You still have to make a fort save, and your teammate still gains a negative level, regardless.  It’s better to prevent a death from happening in the first place rather than trying to desperately slap a bandaid on something after a disaster has already occurred.
  • Eternal Rebirth (active)***: Expend your psionic focus to heal your teammates for 4 HP per PP, up to your level.  It’s a free action, which is lovely, and at first it’s more efficient than Martyrdom.  But Martyrdom catches up at level 7, and surpasses Eternal Rebirth at level 12.  On the plus side, you can use both Martyrdom and Eternal Rebirth in the same round, and if you have a good way of regaining your psionic focus (like with the Overpowering Optimism boost), this is a decent form of in-combat healing.  But there may be better uses for your psionic focus that don’t require PP expenditure.
  • Impossible Epiphany (1st augment)****: Interesting, battlefield control!  You create a wall of ectoplasm.  This can be used to block off baddies, create choke points, create useful bridges outside of combat, anything that other standard wall spells can do!  Not only that, but one side of the wall radiates a fear effect, which combos nicely with Eternal Guardian.
  • Impossible Epiphany (2nd augment)***:  Suppress a condition on one of your allies.  Handy, but you can’t suppress Stunned or Nauseated, which are a couple of the more serious conditions that need to be suppressed.

Destruction****:  For the Zealots who believe that the best defense is an overwhelming offense.

  • Crushing Blows (passive)***: Ignoring a decent amount of hardness and DR is nothing to sneeze at, but you’re not exactly the star damage dealer.
  • Crushing Blows (active)****: Your party ignores hardness and DR for one round!  All of it!  Outstanding for ganging up on a pesky iron golem or errant Epic monster.  Or just for demolishing a brick wall with nothing more than your bare fists and a scream of zealous wrath!
  • Storm of Steel (1st augment)***: Deal +1d8 damage per PP you spend and +1 DC per 2 PP.  Most Sleeping Goddess strikes have a similar augment, but for +1d6 damage, so this augment is a slight damage improvement.  It also can be applied to non Sleeping Goddess maneuvers.
  • Storm of Steel (2nd augment)*****: Turn your strikes into areas of effect!  Either 20 foot lines or 15 foot cones!  Damaging, debuffing, and disabling multiple enemies with a single strike maneuver is fantastic.

Protection****: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure!  This is the best Mission for AoO builds, and unquestionably the best at reducing damage to your party.

  • Living Bastion (passive)*****: Increase your reach by 5 feet.  Yeeeeeesssss.
  • Living Bastion (active)****: Reduce the damage an ally takes by half.  This scales with the amount of damage the attack deals, and doesn’t cost any PP, which means it scales wonderfully into higher levels, unlike Eternal Rebirth.
  • Unbreakable Fortress (1st augment)****: Grant your team a healthy, scaling chunk of DR/- for a very low PP cost.  Let’s do some math!  If you use this with 1 PP and a 4th level maneuver, and your party takes 5 total hits in the next round, you have just prevented 20 damage.  For just 1 PP.
  • Unbreakable Fortress (2nd augment)*****:  Use a counter as a FREE action instead of an immediate action!  The more counters you can use per combat, the less damage your party takes!

Defiance**: Diehard is a nice feat, but it has some serious problems.  You’re staggered, so you can’t do your Aid + Strike combo, only one or the other.  You can still counter to your heart’s content.  More dangerously, you’re still standing in front of the thing that just smashed you into negative hitpoints, letting it know that you’re still a threat, and you risk taking more attacks that will kill you.

Unshakable Will***: At first glance, this doesn’t seem very impressive.  We’re pretty much succeeding automatically on Aid Another checks already by this level.  But this lets you succeed even when you roll a natural 1, since Aid Another checks are attack rolls.  It also lets you add expendable redshirt NPCs to your collective without worry of backlash when they die!

Stalwart****: Evasion, but for fortitude and will saves rather than reflex!  Fantastic at making you tankier, beefier, more bodacious, and indefatigable!

Metaphysical Transcendence*:  Thematically, it’s awesome to be immortal by living on in the hearts of the people you meet.  Mechanically, it’s pointless.  Death is cheap to overcome at this level, and it’s best to not die in the first place.

Archetypes

Discordant Crusader**:  [Link] This archetype is the only class in the game that can use both Silver Crane, a Good-aligned discipline, and Black Seraph, an Evil-aligned discipline.  Thanks to errata, anyone can now use Silver Crane and Black Seraph.  They don’t have alignment requirements, they just have the [good] or [evil] descriptors on a few maneuvers.  As for this archetype, it has interesting themes for roleplay, from dichotomy and dualism, to Nietzsche’s Ubermensch whose driven personality rises beyond conventional morality.

Maneuvers*****:  Lose access to Piercing Thunder, gain both Silver Crane and Black Seraph.  Having access to six total disciplines is an advantage over other Zealots.

Gray Aura****: Shielding your alignment is handy in intrigue-based campaigns, and using the damage type you need is handy in campaigns where you will fight an even spread of good and evil enemies.  In more standard campaigns with little intrigue or only one moral alignment appearing as enemies, this is worse than all of the standard Zealot missions.

Paired Weapons*: You lose some survivability for the ability to use a few more weapon types as discipline weapons with Black Seraph and Silver Crane.  Not a good trade.

Divided Focus****:  You get 2 feats for the price of 1, and they’re not bad feats!

Twofold Fire (1st augment)*: Deal +1d6 profane or sacred damage per PP.  It’s worse than the Destruction Mission’s first augment in terms of damage, but thanks to errata, it does allow you to beat up incorporeal foes and ignore DR.  But you already have strikes with profane/sacred damage.  Also, this doesn’t increase your save DC, unlike Destruction Mission.

Twofold Fire (2nd augment)***: Inflict a -4 AC or attack debuff for 1 minute.  The debuffs are significant and lengthy, but they don’t offer any new functionality that the Zealot previously lacked like other Missions do.

Twinned Avatar*****: You lose a terrible class feature to gain the ability to use two stances at once!  A magnificent trade!  It’s just too bad that you have to suffer through 16 levels of an otherwise poor archetype before getting this.

Final Ruling**: The flaw behind this archetype is the idea that simply having access to both Black Seraph and Silver Crane is somehow powerful.  It’s not.  They don’t synergize well with one another the way other disciplines do.  And after errata, that’s a moot point, because now everybody can use both.  Almost all of the replacements this archetype has are downgrades or too situational, and the Missions of regular Zealots are better.

Void Prophet***:  [Link] Like the Discordant Crusader, this nihilism-touting archetype is bursting with philosophical flavor that can make any Planescape fan squee!  It forcefully pulls unwilling targets into its Collective, inflicts severe debuffs on them, and drains their souls when they expire!

Maneuvers****:  Lose Golden Lion and Solar Wind, gain Cursed Razor and Riven Hourglass.  Cursed Razor is full of sadistic debuffs, and Riven Hourglass is one of the best disciplines for action economy.

Maneuvers Readied**:  Now you recover 1 maneuver by yanking people into your Collective, and recover more by having them die!  Honestly, this is a downgrade from the standard Zealot’s maneuver recovery mechanic, because you can’t use it to recover all your maneuvers whenever you want.  You need enemies to be around, and you need them to fail their saves.

Bonus Feats*****:  You get Unwilling Participant (which you can use as a move or swift action) and Expanded Collective, but lose the ability to Aid Another yourself.  Since these are Psionic feats, this means 4 free HP if you pick up Psionic Body!

Hollow Faith****:  Void Prophets give up their Mission for these abilities.

  • 4th Level Ability****:  Inflict devastating debuffs on your captives as a free action with no save!  A -2 penalty to just about everything!  This would be mind bogglingly good if not for the fact that it must be activated at the beginning of the Void Prophet’s turn.  You can’t pull someone into your collective and immediately debuff them.
  • 8th level ability (1st augment)***:  Debuff everything that your target currently has an insight or morale bonus to, which could be quite a lot of things!  If an enemy cleric casts Bless, it’s a perfect invitation for you to turn that bonus into a big penalty.  It even debuffs a barbarian’s strength and constitution.  Sadly, it does nothing to targets that don’t have insight or morale bonuses active at the time.
  • 8th level ability (2nd augment)****:  The attacks you successfully counter now target your victimized enemies!  This makes it much easier to recover your maneuvers and end the fight more quickly.

Preach the Silence****:  Replaces Zeal.  Unlike Zeal, it also grants a bonus to allies’ saves, and lasts a number of rounds equal to your cha mod.  This is important, because a Void Prophet can’t always add a new victim to their collective every round.

Endless Hunger****:  Lose an irrelevant ability to gain another way to gobble targets into your collective, recovering a maneuver!  Now your strikes capture creatures as well as your move actions.

The Consuming Void*****:  You never shall want for your psionic focus again.  This redeems the terrible class feature that is Metaphysical Transcendence by letting your collective act as a repository of yummy souls that replenish your psionic focus as a free action!

Final Ruling***:  The Void Prophet isn’t as reliable at supporting their party as a standard Zealot because of its inferior maneuver recovery.  It offers a unique and effective but riskier playstyle that emphasizes debuffs and keeping your enemies as close as your friends.  There is also one big critical flaw: The Void Prophet does not have anything that protects it from having to make a DC 15 fortitude save to become sickened when a collective member dies.  It’s unknown if this is an oversight.  Hollow Faith prevents you from losing PP, but you still might get sickened.

Feats

Fortuitously, Zealots don’t require a great deal of feats to be particularly effective the way other classes do.  This means that you have plenty of room to customize your build, and more feats are always welcome.

Path of War and Expanded Feats

Advanced Study*****:  As you level up, you will only know 2 maneuvers from each level.  That’s a tad frustrating, considering how many excellent ones there are.  This feat helps alleviate that problem.  Zealots can use a lot of maneuvers in a single round, so it pays to have those maneuvers all be high level ones.

Animus Healing*:  Heal yourself for a negligible amount once per encounter.  And you have to use your animus to do so.  Just buy a wand of cure light wounds or infernal healing, toss 1 rank into Use Magic Device, and heal up outside of combat like a normal adventurer.  Or do it completely for free with Silver Crane or Radiant Dawn maneuvers.

Awakened Animus****:  Animus pools gained from the Tap Animus feat or a dip in Mystic grant you 2 animus per round, which this feat uses as 2 free PP per round for augmenting Sleeping Goddess maneuvers.  For most strikes, that equals +2d6 damage and +1 to the save DC.  A dip in Rubato Bard grants you only 1 animus per round for free, but it can go up to 4 per round: Rubatos can convert 1 round of bardic performance into 2 tempo as a free action, and maintain the Metronome performance for another 1 tempo per round.  

Deadly Agility***:  Useful for dexterity-based Zealots, but not mandatory.  Remember that you probably will only be attacking once per round.  Feats that add to your damage are best with playstyles that use multiple attacks per round, and such playstyles are better with classes that already have features that improve their damage.

Defensive Expertise***:  A lovely increase in tankiness for people with shields.  More touch AC and more reflex!

Discipline Expertise*: At first glance, spending 1 feat to gain a total of 10 bonus points around various skills sounds like a nice deal.  But then you realize that most of the skills won’t see much use.  And then you realize that this feat gives a competence bonus.  Those don’t stack, and are easily found on cheap magic items.

Discipline Focus****: +2 DC from a single feat is fuhmazing, twice as good as Spell Focus for a caster.  And on top of that, you get +2 damage.  That’s as good as Weapon Specialization!  The damage bonus is merely gravy for Zealots, but the DC increase is great for many disciplines.

Discipline Mastery****:  Taking 10 on a skill whenever you want is quite handy, especially with Intimidate.  This lets you steal the effect of Fiery Glare only available to Ifrits, as well as apply taking 10 to your other discipline skills.

Electrum Manticore***:  While improving your action economy is spiffy, the opportunity costs implicit in using this feat are questionable.  If you want to use this feat regularly in the middle of combat, you need to center your build around boosts and stances from Silver Crane and Golden Lion, and those might not be as good as stances and counters from other disciplines.  Additionally, if you’re using your swift actions for boosts, you have to forego using a counter in the previous turn.  The most cost-effective use for this feat is on the first round of combat, when you’re switching from a utility stance to a combat stance, hopefully with the Fuse Styles feat and a Style feat at the same time.  Then you accomplish what 3 swift actions can do with just 1.

Elemental Current*:  There are only four strikes and one stance that work with setting this up, and the lower level ones aren’t very good for Zealots.  If you make heavy use of these maneuvers, you probably already have a mithril (or silversheen) weapon and gain the benefit of the regular silver vulnerability.  Then, next round, you need to go out of your way to use strikes that deal heavy energy damage instead of weapon strikes, or be in a party that uses more of the same type of energy damage than than they use weapons.  A silversheen weapon only costs +750 gp, easy to buy for your party members.

Elemental Focus*:  Ignoring some energy resistance and energy immunity is something that dedicated damage dealers will want to spend feats on, but not Zealots.  Besides, the Destruction Mission lets you do that better if you really want to.  Another huge problem this feat has is that it only applies to one energy type, and you can’t change it.

Elemental Sun***:  It reduces your target’s resistance by only half as much as Elemental Focus, but applies to every energy type (except sonic), and lets your entire party benefit.  If you have even one damage dealing ally who mostly uses energy damage like a mystic or sorcerer, they will appreciate you helping them.  If you mostly use Solar Wind strikes, and thankfully there are some good ones for Zealots, then this feat effectively equates to a damage buff for your whole party as long as they deal some energy damage themselves.

Enduring Protector***:  The problem with this feat is that you need to land killing blows with AoOs.  Only one person in your party can land a killing blow on each enemy.  That gives this feat anti-synergy with your party.  The bigger your party is, the less likely you are to land kills.  Also, the less often you fight large hordes of weak enemies, the worse this feat gets.  But if you’re the strong beefy sole frontliner of your party and your GM regularly throws hordes of mooks at you, this feat becomes much shinier.

Eternal Hourglass*****:  This lets you get off another counter every combat for free.  Riven Hourglass stances and Eternal Guardian counters are some of the best in the game, too.

Extra Conviction***: Some convictions are feats-plus-a-little-extra, so picking this feat is never a bad choice!  Unless you’re high level and drowning in convictions already.

Extra Readied Maneuver***: This lets you keep your best strikes and counters ready for use.  As you level up, this becomes less important, because you will have more readied maneuvers anyway.

Feral Goddess and Forge of the Goddess*:  These are for Psychic Warriors, not for Zealots.

Flowing Mithral Fist*:  Being an Unarmed Zealot already requires that you spend some investment and jump through some hoops outside of what normal Zealots do, and weapons are generally better than unarmed strikes for Zealots.  The only thing this feat does is allow you to use a sub-par fighting style a little better for one specific discipline, something that a mithral sword could do already.  You still need to “draw” your unarmed strike in order to gain the draw benefits of Mithral Current maneuvers, whether with a move action or the Quick Draw feat.

Fuse Styles****:  This is flat out inferior to Combat Style Master.  The main advantage Fuse Styles has is that it has no prerequisites, so you can take it early on without needing a dip in Master of Many Styles Monk.  One particularly good use of this feat is with Stance of the Sunlight Shield (Radiant Dawn 5) to enter your style feat and summon a large number of shields at the start of combat.

Giant Slayer**:  By the time you’re facing large monsters frequently enough to justify taking this feat, you already have enough ways of closing the distance to melee range.  Chargers like Primal Fury and Black Seraph users have ways of avoiding AoOs anyway.

Haft Strike***:  There are other ways around the problem of enemies scampering around in your reach dead-zone, such as by wearing armor spikes, using teleportation strikes, or dipping a level of Zweihander Sentinel Warder or Fiendbound Marauder Warder.  This feat frees you from worrying about those things and lets you use your primary weapon all the time regardless of positioning or dips.

Hone Weapon*****:  If you’re only allowed to use this feat on your own weapons, it’s a pretty decent scaling damage increase.  It already matches a fighter’s Weapon Specialization at level 4, and quickly exceeds it.  If you can use this feat on your party’s weapons, it’s a ludicrous force multiplier.  In the one hour that it takes casters to prepare their spells every day, you can hone six weapons easily.

Improved Quick Draw****:  Mandatory for Mithral Current users, unless you stance-lock yourself to Ready the Draw or Mithral Current Stance, or take a level of Landsknecht.  If you don’t focus on Mithral Current, there’s no reason to take this.  One reading of the line "You are considered to be threatening all squares within reach of your weapon even if it is sheathed" could mean that you can threaten with any sheathed weapon, including a whip.  If so, that’s great for AoO builds.

Lightning Recovery*:  Zealots already have one of the best recovery mechanics in the game.

Lurker in Darkness**:  Stealthing generally isn’t the job of a Zealot.  Unlike Stalkers and Hidden Blade Rogues, they don’t have an easy way of stealthing in the middle of combat, and use their move actions for Aid Another rather than moving and stealthing.  But this feat, combined with a high stealth bonus easily achievable through small size and magic items, makes you completely undetectable by most creatures.  It’s ludicrously powerful, but doesn’t make you better at doing a Zealot’s job, so its use is niche.

Martial Charge**: There are several low level maneuvers that increase your mobility better than this.  Fading Strike (Veiled Moon), Leaping Dragon (Thrashing Dragon), Hastened Leap (Piercing Thunder), Fluctuation Movement (Elemental Flux), and Relentless Warden’s Strike (Eternal Guardian) are some examples.

Martial Power*****: Purple for shield users, green for archers, and orange for most other builds.  Archers make good use of it because they’re the least likely to take direct damage, and can use the THP they gain from Martial Power to soak damage with Martyrdom, saving PP.

Ranged Martial Power***: From Psionics Augmented - Psychic Warriors III.  You need this as well if you want to use Martial Power with ranged attacks.  But if you can squeeze in the feats, it may be worth it.  This is also listed as a psionic feat, so that’s another +2 HP if you have Psionic Body.

Mirror of the Moon****:  The benefits of this feat work with all teleportation maneuvers, including the ones from Sleeping Goddess and Eternal Guardian!  Major Images that you don’t need to concentrate on are spectacular for messing with your opponents’ minds.  You just have to hope that your GM doesn’t metagame.

Molten Silver Strike*:  Serious design problem with this feat.  All of the Solar Wind boosts either lessen the difficulties associated with ranged attacks and thus don’t do anything useful for the Mithral Current strikes which are still considered melee, or they increase the damage of your attacks for one round.  The Mithral Current strikes only make a single attack, and the Solar Wind boosts are best used with multiple attacks.  Spending a feat and a swift action just to increase your Silver Wave by a small amount of fire damage is pitiful for anyone, not just Zealots.

Pikeman’s Training*****:  You get the best of both worlds of a reach weapon and a shield.  Note that you don’t get the 1.5x strength bonus to damage.

Pinning Arrow*:  Archer Zealots will probably pick up Tempest Gale and have plenty of crowd controlling maneuvers already like Dustcatching Breeze and Sudden Gust.  This feat is best on other classes that use full attacks and exchange one of their attacks for a pinning shot.  Those classes have static damage bonuses, unlike the Zealot, so their DC for pinning shot is better.

Polearm Dancer****:  Weapon Finesse, but for polearms and spears!  Reach weapons are better than non-reach weapons for getting AoOs and protecting your friends.

Seize the Opportunity****:  It should be noted that without this feat, you already have the ability to disarm and trip with AoOs.  This feat lets you use other handy combat maneuvers like dirty trick, one of the best.  Dip one level of Privateer Warlord and take Salt in the Wound to gain both Improved and Greater Dirty Trick.  Alternatively, you can use this to be exceptionally tanky and damaging in an AoO build by taking the Vital Strike feats, Pikeman Training to use a 1d12 polearm and shield, and Martial Power and Enduring Protector to gain tons of temporary hitpoints!

Silver Fang Initiate*:  To make the most of this, you either need to stance-lock yourself permanently to Mithral Current Stance, or you need to use a vulnerability-inducing strike every other round.  Why not just use two Steel Serpent strikes back to back?  This feat is alright for other classes who can’t reliably recover the same maneuver every round like a Zealot.

Tap Animus****: See Awakened Animus.

Tactical Rush*: Instead of this, take Advanced Study and pick up one of the maneuvers listed up with Martial Charge.

Victorious Recovery**:  This can be useful if you really need to use a full attack to finish off a weak enemy, but the combat isn’t yet over.

Weaken the Prey****:  The penalty works for all of your maneuvers, not just the ones listed in the prerequisites.  So if you curse someone with Eternal Guardian, they’ll be more susceptible to your Sleeping Goddess maneuvers as well.  You don’t even need to be the person who applied the initial debuff to your target to benefit from this feat!

Weapon Group Adaptation****: You can safely avoid this for the most part if you use a Heavy Blade or don’t care too much about maneuvers with saves.  But one amazing thing the errata added was that this lets you use Weapon Mastery feats, like Cut from the Air!

Zealous Blade****:  There are two optimal ways to use this feat:  Dipping 1 level of Augmented Blade Soulknife, or dipping 3 levels of Psychic Armory + War Soul Soulknife and 1 level of Daring Hero.  See the Dipping section for more details.

Style Feats

Style feats can’t be activated outside of combat, so you need to spend a swift action every combat to use these.  But you can get past this limitation with the following feat!

Combat Style Master*****:  Activating a style feat is a free action and can be done in surprise rounds!  Now you can use your precious swift action for something better!  The prerequisites could be hard to get unless you dip a level of Master of Many Styles Monk.

Black Seraph Style****:  You get a scaling profane bonus to AC against feared enemies!  Inflicting fear effects is very easy, so thus huge defensive bonus almost always applies to you.

Black Seraph Malevolence*:  As of the errata, this feat does nothing at all.

Black Seraph Annihilation****:  Now you don’t need to use a particular stance or other special ability to ignore an enemy’s fear immunity!

Broken Blade Style**:  Unarmed strikes ignore ½ your level in DR and hardness.  Better for actual damage-dealing classes.

Broken Blade Crush**:  Punching people’s armor into scrap is fun, but a lot of monsters don’t wear armor.

Broken Blade Rhythm**:  Very nice if you regularly use Broken Blade strikes, but there are less costly ways of being a combat maneuver master.

Chimera Soul Style*:  [Playtest Link] Your natural weapons bypass one certain type of DR.  You don’t need to punch through DR to apply the riders of your strikes, which is what you really care about.  And if you do care about damage, you have the Destruction Mission.

Chimera Soul Spikes*:  Shoot plain ol’ spikes as a standard action.  Know what else you can do with a standard action?  Use a useful maneuver.

Chimera Soul Dominance*:  Same as Chimera Soul Style, but now you ignore THREE types of DR!  And three times as underwhelming, because it costs so many bad feats.

Cursed Razor Style***:  For a single feat, this actually isn’t a bad chunk of damage, and works well with the Zealot playstyle of using standard action strikes.

Cursed Razor Plague*****:  You literally double the number of curses you throw around, making followup combos all that much better!

Cursed Razor Massacre***:  A free additional attack every round when fighting multiple foes is nice, but really all it does is increase your damage per round by a bit, not utility.

Elemental Flux Style****:  You can switch your active element as a free action, vastly increasing your in-combat versatility with Elemental Flux maneuvers and stances.  But if you have Psicrystal Reservoir or another good way of quickly regaining your psionic focus, you don’t need this.  Regaining your psionic focus lets you also change your active element.

Elemental Flux Shift***:  You get a modest chunk of damage, but have to switch your active element to gain it.

Elemental Flux Explosion**:  A free +2 weapon enhancement, but this is better for full attackers, not Zealots.

Eternal Guardian Style**:  This is really only useful with the 6th level Inescapable Grasp stance on AoO builds.  There are a lot of ways to curse creatures, but not many Eternal Guardian maneuvers that benefit from a creature’s cursed status.  Most of them are in Cursed Razor, and you would want to be using Cursed Razor Style if you care about curse combos.

Eternal Guardian Oath*:  Good counter maneuvers are better than this, and this still requires you to spend an immediate action and a readied counter.  And it only works on cursed creatures you threaten.

Eternal Guardian Endurance*:  You already have an easy time recovering your maneuvers, and a hard time landing killing blows.

Fool’s Errand Style**:  [Link] Forego an attack to make a locked creature entangled or sickened for 1 round, and you can make a lock attempt against an adjacent creature once per round.  Considering how you can do much more devastating effects with standard action strikes, it’s a bad trade.  The free lock is useful, but doesn’t benefit from reach.

Fool’s Errand Scholar*****:  You now have a Brawler’s Martial Flexibility once per encounter as a swift action (or free with Combat Style Master).  Pays for itself!

Fool’s Errand Sensei**:  You can turn a boost into a terrible counter after you get hit and damaged, or expend a counter as a swift action to stand from prone and make an enemy flat-footed against your next attack.  Overall underwhelming.

Golden Lion Style***:  Take an AoO when your teammate misses a flanked enemy, once per round.  It’s effectively just some not-very-often-triggered extra damage.

Golden Lion Charge**:  Zealots use counters and immediate actions for protecting allies, not for thwacking enemies who can’t hit in the first place.

Golden Lion Command*****:  Now this…  Is interesting.  Spend a swift action and a boost to give your party 5 temporary HP every time you make an attack, lasting 1 round.  Normally, I’d say to leave this to full attacking classes.  But this directly turns your full attacks into a defensive benefit for your whole party.  At level 11, if you use two weapon fighting, you can have 5 attacks per round.  Broken Blade stance adds 2 more.  Haste adds 1 more.  Add on some natural weapons like a bite, tentacles, and hooves, and you can get OODLES.  And AoOs count as well.  Some strike maneuvers even allow you to make a full attack as a standard action, like Frenzy Strike (Primal Fury 3) and Thrashing Blades (Thrashing Dragon 8).  Potentially, this feat could single-handedly make full-attacking Zealots one of the most powerful builds!

Grabbing Style***:  [Link] You don’t take a -4 penalty for grappling with one hand.  This is for Zealots who’ve taken a 1 level dip in Fiendbound Marauder.  Since there are a lot of good styles to use, and you can only be in one at a time (or two with a dip of MoMS Monk), you have to decide whether this is worth it.  Ignore Grabbing Drag and Grabbing Master.

Iron Tortoise Style*:  Increase your shield bash damage die by one size.  A negligible damage increase on a class that isn’t the best for damage.

Iron Tortoise Shell***:  Gain evasion whenever you use a counter.  Not bad at all!  You can get a better reflex score with Defensive Expertise to take advantage of this.

Iron Tortoise Snap**:  Make a free attack with a different weapon when you successfully shield bash.  It requires you to invest in two weapon fighting.

Mithral Current Style:  Feint as a swift action with Perform (Dance).  Leave this to the Rogues and Bushi Stalkers.

Mithral Current Flow****:  Take a free 10 foot step whenever an attack misses you.  This is magnificent for mobility, and can even save you from taking the remaining attacks in a full attack if an early attack in the sequence misses!

Mithral Current Slice***:  Carry a mithral or silversheen weapon, and this increases your standard action strike damage by 50%.  It doesn’t work with other attacks like AoOs, and you can’t pick a different material like adamantine or deep crystal.

Piercing Thunder Style****:  You take AoOs against enemies who enter your threatened squares while you have a reach weapon.  This lets you get off a lot more AoOs than you otherwise would when facing enemies who have reach themselves.  It also works against teleporting enemies!  Smack a Veiled Moon user the moment she tries to bamf in to shank you!

Piercing Thunder Push**:  Push charging enemies 5 feet back when you ready and brace for a charge.  Stopping a charge attack from going through is excellent, but this tactic really only works on mindless enemies consistently, or intelligent enemies once.  Too situational to be higher than orange.

Piercing Thunder Trample**:  You get a free bull rush and overrun attempt when you charge.  By level 13, you’re not likely going to be fighting things that have a CMD low enough to be bull rushed or overrun, or that are susceptible to being knocked prone.  You also need to pick up Improved Overrun if you don’t want your target to simply avoid you.

Primal Fury Style*:  You can use survival instead of acrobatics to move through threatened squares, and charge through enemies and difficult terrain.  I guess this is important if you’re a dedicated Primal Fury user, but Zealots already have a lot of teleport maneuvers which ignore those problems.

Primal Fury Slash**:  Make a free attack on an enemy adjacent to you along your charging path.  Free attacks are nice, and Primal Fury Style makes it so you don’t have to perform complex geometric calculations to figure out a charge path that works.  But why are you charging as a Zealot?

Primal Fury Leap*:  Now this is stylish and awesome!  It lets you charge up into the air to smack an airborne enemy!  Buuuuuuuut…  If you’re level 11 and don’t have a reliable way of dealing with flying enemies by this point, I don’t know what to tell you.

Radiant Dawn Style***:  [Link] A decent amount of free healing every round, and you get another essence on top of it.  While it not be a showstopping degree of additional functionality, you can never look down on free healing!

Radiant Sunlight*****:  Now, any time you heal someone by any means, even if it’s not with Radiant Dawn, you give them stacking THP instead of wasting the healing!  A great way to preemptively heal your allies before they even get hurt!

Radiant Daybreak****:  Give +2 AC and saves and +10 to all movement speeds to allies who have THP from you!  It’ll be difficult to always keep up the THP granted from Radiant Sunlight on your allies, since they’ll have to already be at full health in order to gain THP from it, but there are plenty of other ways to give allies THP.

Riven Hourglass Stance**:  Spend an immediate action and a readied maneuver to reroll an attack roll.  This could be worth not using your immediate action for a counter if the reroll will ensure you finish off a dangerous enemy who’s about to have its turn.

Riven Hourglass Eternity*****:  Spend a readied maneuver as a free action to extend the duration of a spell or boost by 1 round.  Since Zealots can recover multiple maneuvers reliably every round, this is practically free to use!  You can make your favorite boost last all combat, or use this every round while out of combat to make a buff spell effectively not expire its remaining duration!

Riven Hourglass Rewind*:  Spend a counter and immediate action to suppress a negative condition on yourself for 1 minute.  Instead of this, pick up Temporal Body Adjustment (Riven Hourglass 4).  That lets you completely ignore a condition before it even affects you.  Riven Hourglass Rewind only suppresses things that are currently affecting you.  If you’re paralyzed or stunned, you don’t have any actions to use it!

Scarlet Throne Style*:  This lets you do a tiny bit more damage with Power Attack while wielding a single one-hander.  At least it still allows you to use a buckler.  The only characters who would really enjoy this feat are strength-based Maguses (Magi?) and Landsknechts.

Scarlet Throne Dignity*:  Expend a maneuver and immediate action to do an opposed attack roll to negate an attack and take a 5 foot step.  It’s on par with many 2nd level counters, except it uses an opposed attack roll instead of a skill check, and it’s much easier to get a high skill bonus than it is to get a high attack bonus.  You have enough counters as it is, as a Zealot.

Scarlet Throne Riposte****:  Make an AoO whenever you negate an attack, and only once per round against a particular enemy.  It’s difficult to benefit from this more than once per round, making its use limited.  Zealots who dip Swashbuckler for Opportune Parry and Riposte will like this.

Shattered Mirror Style****:  A stacking +2 shield bonus to AC that’s very easy to maintain.  Twice as good as the Dodge feat.

Shattered Mirror Waltz***:  Ignore movement penalties from difficult terrain.  Simple and useful.  But if you have good teleportation maneuvers, you might not need this.

Shattered Mirror Duality*:  Expend a boost and swift action to roll all attack rolls twice and take the better result.  Useful for full attacker classes, but not so much for Zealots.

Silver Crane Style****:  Sacrifice AC and reflex to grant the same amount to your allies within 30 feet.  Lovely for support!  It works better on midliners and backliners like Firearms and Archer Zealots, because they’re not in harm’s way and are less likely to suffer from the lower AC.

Silver Crane Feathers***:  Expend a counter and immediate action to take a friend’s ability damage in their stead.  Pretty useful if you don’t have other counters that can prevent the damage, and you can save your Wizard’s intelligence to keep her casting her best spells... or your Barbarian’s to prevent her from going comatose.

Silver Crane Wind****:  Now you get to make a save to negate ability damage altogether when using Silver Crane Feathers!  Protect your Fighter from cha damage without fear!

Sleeping Goddess Style**:  Recover psionic focus as a standard action and recover a maneuver at the same time for free.  Zealots already recover maneuvers easily, and recovering psionic focus as a standard action isn’t much better than recovering it as a full round action.

Sleeping Goddess Slumber****:  Expend your psionic focus when you hit something to potentially confuse it for 1 round.  The effect and duration aren’t good enough for the cost.  But Destruction Mission Zealots can get more mileage out of it by using their augment to hit multiple enemies simultaneously!
