Sleeping Goddess Strike****:  “Whenever you hit an opponent with an attack, they take a –2 penalty on saving throws against your maneuvers until the end of their next turn.”  depending on how you read this, it’s either excellent or not so great.  If they suffer the -2 penalty on the effects of the same strike you hit them with, then it’s excellent and effectively equals a +2 DC increase to all of your maneuvers.  But if you need to hit them with a different attack first, and then hit them again with a maneuver that demands a save, it’s less useful.  The penalty ends at the end of their next turn, giving you no chance to hit them again before it wears off, so only your allies whose turns come up between you and your target can benefit from it.

Solar Wind Style****:  Your ranged attacks inflict faerie fire on your targets!  This negates invisibility, blur, displacement, and similar effects.  There are very few things in all of Path of War that help combat these effects.  As gravy, your ranged attacks deal extra fire damage.

Solar Wind Flash**:  Shoot an enemy, spend a swift action and readied boost, and potentially blind your target.  Blind is a good status effect, but you should be able to use your swift/immediate actions for better things.

Solar Wind Inferno**:  Ignore a certain amount of fire resistance and fire immunity.  It’s not worth trying to shore up a shortcoming that you don’t even specialize in.

Steel Serpent Style*****:  Debuff an enemy’s AC and attack when you hit them with a Steel Serpent maneuver for 2 rounds, no save, no questions asked.

Steel Serpent Fangs**:  Spend a swift action and boost to treat enemies suffering from ability damage as flat-footed.  This is for Stalkers and Rogues.

Steel Serpent Venom****:  Hit enemies suffering from ability damage to nauseate them.  It allows a save, but that’s free crowd control!

Tempest Gale Style**:  You can use combat maneuvers with a ranged weapon.  Great for classes who can’t reliably recover their maneuvers, but you’re a Zealot!  Most of your Tempest Gale strikes already inflict combat maneuvers on enemies, and more!

Tempest Gale Haze****:  Ranged attacks against you suffer a 20% miss chance.  Now enemy archers have a tougher time fighting you back!

Tempest Gale Storm**:  Now Tempest Gale Style inflicts 2 different combat maneuvers at once.  Your strike maneuvers are still better, though.

Thrashing Dragon Style*:  Make a free attack with another weapon whenever you make an attack as standard action or attack action.  It doesn’t work with AoOs.  You’ll almost never be doing this, because you’ll be using strike maneuvers, not regular attacks.  It also requires you to invest in two weapon fighting.

Thrashing Dragon Pounce:  Now you get a free attack when you use a strike maneuver that only has one attack.  This fits much better with the Zealot playstyle!  But one free attack per round with an offhand weapon isn’t that impressive.

Thrashing Dragon Whirlwind**:  Whirlwind Attack, but you attack every enemy around you with both weapons.  Interestingly, you don’t take any two weapon fighting penalties!  Still, it’s too situational.  It requires enough targets and good positioning to be worthwhile, and does nothing but deal damage.  Zealots have better things to do.

Veiled Moon Style****:  Whenever you move, 10 feet of your movement is teleportation!  A delightfully unique ability with all sorts of applications.  You can slip into or past an enemy’s threatened area without risking AoOs, you can zip through a fence or grate, you can hop over a 10 foot pit, you can hop up to a ledge 10 feet above you, the list goes on!

Veiled Moon Shunt*****:  Incredible.  You can forcibly teleport a target 30 feet as a free action in any direction, even up or into a dangerous area, whenever you hit.  And all you need to do is expend a maneuver as a free action.  Zealots have an easy time recovering their maneuvers, so you’ll never be out of ammo for this.  Tactically rearrange the battlefield like a chessmaster, or if you can’t think of anything better, just toss the target into the air to make them take 3d6 falling damage and fall prone!  You can even punch (or gently poke) a teammate to teleport them, increasing the utility!

Veiled Moon Warp**:  Expend a strike as a standard action to potentially make your target incorporeal for a round.  A decent form of crowd control, but your target still has all of their actions even if they can’t hurt you, and if your team doesn’t have Ghost Touch weapons, they only deal 50% damage to the target.

Wolf Style, Trip, Savage*:  Wolf Trip used to be incredible and was labeled as a style feat, allowing you to grab it with a second level of MoMS Monk.  All of these feats were nerfed into the ground in Ultimate Wilderness and aren’t worth the feat slots anymore.

Psionic Feats

Access Psionic Talent***:  You learn 5 talents, which are like cantrips, but thanks to Dreamscarred Press’ generosity, they are a tad more powerful and versatile than most cantrips!  Standout selections are Create Sound, Conceal Thoughts (+10 to bluff, holy Calistria), Ectoplasmic Trinket, Empathy, and Trick Shot.

Aligned Attack**:  More useful in campaigns where you’ll be fighting more of single type of foe like devils and demons.  If you have the Destruction Mission, you don’t need this at all.

Cloak Dance*: The action economy does not agree with Zealots, and the benefit is too small for what can comparably be done with Veiled Moon and Shattered Mirror maneuvers.

Cushion the Blow, Improved, Greater*: JOKE’S ON YOU!  Zealots can’t take these, because their effective manifester level doesn’t qualify them for feats or prestige classes.  And even if Zealots could use these, counters are better for immediate actions.

Deep Focus, Psicrystal Containment, and Collective Focus****:  These all give you a second psionic focus.  Collective Focus is from the Highlord playtest.  If you’re grabbing Psionic Body and don’t want a psicrystal, go with Deep Focus.  If you have a psicrystal and don’t want Psionic Body, get Psicrystal Containment.  If you like both having a psicrystal and Psionic Body, go with Deep Focus, because your psicrystal could get separated from you.  Collective Focus doesn’t have skill point prerequisites like Deep Focus, but it only works with abilities that affect your collective members, so you can’t use it on offensive abilities like augmented Sleeping Goddess strikes.

Psicrystal Reservoir*****:  (credit to TiaC!)  From Psionics Augmented: Psicrystals.  Your psicrystal can now refocus its own psionic focus!  That means you can expend your focus once per round effectively for free!  Imagine using Deep Impact, your Mission abilities, or Improved Path of Dedication every round!  And it doesn’t interfere with Overpowering Optimism (Sleeping Goddess 6)!

Enlarged Collective**:  Medium range is already very big.  This is for Archery Zealots who spend most of their adventuring outdoors in wide open spaces.  Note that you can’t take it unless you have ML 3, which Zealot alone does not give.

Expanded Collective**:  You shouldn’t need this unless your party is humongous.  Remember that you and your psicrystal don’t take up collective slots, and your Zeal intensity increases your number of slots.

Psionic Body****:  For other psionic classes, this feat is fairly bad.  You have to pick up 1 psionic feat every 2 levels in order for it to even match the Toughness feat.  But thanks to Convictions and the best FCB, Zealots can get tons of psionic feats!  You can also wind up with a surprising number of psionic feats at character creation.  Naturally Psionic races get Wild Talent, and Void Prophets get Expanded Collective and Unwilling Participant at level 1.  A half-giant Void Prophet who takes Psionic Body as their first feat ends up gaining 8 HP total from it at level 1.

Psionic Meditation***: Using a move action instead of a full round action to regain your psionic focus is decent.  If you’re in a position where you don’t need to use your move action to Aid Another and you have a good use for your psionic focus, go ahead and expend it, then regain it.  But, it will be made obsolete by Overpowering Optimism (Sleeping Goddess) at level 11.

Psionic Talent***:  You gain progressively more PP every time you take this feat.  More PP = more damage prevented from your party with Martyrdom and more augments on your maneuvers!  If you can’t think of anything else to do with your feats, taking this several times isn’t a bad idea.

Psionic Weapon or Psionic Shot**: For when you really need ~7 more damage to finish off a monster before its turn comes up.  You usually will be using your psionic focus for Sleeping Goddess augments and your 4th level Mission active ability, though.

Deep Impact or Fell Shot***: Situational, but exactly what you need when you really need to land a hit on a big fat monster with +30 natural armor.  With full BAB and the ability to Aid Another yourself, your accuracy is already quite good when you need it to be.

Ready Response****:  You can act during a surprise round!  Combine this with the cheap Sandals of Quick Reaction for more actions.

Speed of Thought***:  +10 speed with an option to increase it to 30 isn’t bad at all.  If you wear light or medium armor, you can stop here, but you need Unhindered Way as well if you wear heavy armor.

Unhindered Way****: Handy dandy for heavy armor users.  This, along with Speed of Thought, changes your speed from 20 to 40 in heavy armor.  But if you have mobility-enhancing maneuvers, this might not be necessary.  If you get this, try to get it at the same time as Speed of Thought so that you won’t be stuck with a dead feat for a level or two.  Retraining is an option.

Unlocked Talent****:  You learn a power and get 2 PP as delicious gravy.  Naturally psionic races can take this even though their Wild Talent gets replaced with Psionic Talent.  Pick Minor Metamorphosis, and you get phenomenal cosmic versatility!  Growing a size, shrinking a size, and gaining new movement modes early, including burrow, are things that Zealots normally cannot replicate.  What’s more, you even get a +2 circumstance bonus to intimidate, and circumstance bonuses stack.  Amazing for Eternal Guardian users, amazing for AoO builds, amazing for dexterity builds, and amazing for things like scouting and infiltration!  The only reason this isn’t purple is because you could simply pick up a dorje of minor metamorphosis and a rank in Use Magic Device.

Unwilling Participant**:  This is difficult to get mileage out of unless you’re a Void Prophet, but it can be fun to forcefully move people around with Reunion in Dreams (Sleeping Goddess 4).

Looming Presence****:  From the Highlord playtest.  Members of your collective have a -2 penalty to attack and AC against you!  Excellent for Void Prophets who want to lay down more punishment without taking it back.

Opportunistic Conscription***:  From the Highlord playtest.  Use Unwilling Participant as an immediate action against a creature that fails a save against one of your collective members.  Improves a Void Prophet’s action economy, but you need to have an ally who regularly uses abilities that force saves on enemies in order to make good use of this.

Paizo Feats

Bodyguard****: If you have a decent charisma and Impulsive Reactions, you’ll often have more attacks of opportunity than you can use on actual attacks.  Now you can use them to protect your friends, and since your Zeal increases the amount of AC your Aid Another provides, you’re one of the best Bodyguard users in the game!

In Harm's Way*: This uses an immediate action and offers no damage negation.  Why would you not use a counter instead?

Combat Expertise*: Martial Power is better.

Cornugon Smash****: Smack someone while using Power Attack and demoralize them for free!  Great for setting up enemies for Eternal Guardian shenanigans.

Dazzling Display**:  This takes a full round action, but if you stack enough improvements to your intimidation game, this can go from a minor and inefficient debuff to a devastating fight-changer.  It will also improve the efficacy of your Eternal Guardian and Black Seraph maneuvers.  A level 1 dip of Privateer Warlord gets this for free.

Dirty Fighting***:  This makes it much easier to use combat maneuvers and lets you pick up related feats while ignoring several annoying prerequisites.

Divine Protection*:  This got nerfed.  When it was first printed, it gave you your charisma mod to your saves.  Yes, Paizo seriously took the Paladin’s best class feature and made it a feat.  Now, it’s not worth taking for anyone.  If you see someone trying to use the original version in the year 2017 and beyond, slap them with a rainbow trout tell them “you do you, buddy.”

Eldritch Heritage*****:  A feat that’s so versatile, it needs an entire guide dedicated to it!  Look at this guide by Cartmanbeck.  It requires Skill Focus, but thankfully, some races give that for free, and it’s not an entirely useless feat.  The best uses for Eldritch Heritage are to get a familiar, or Improved Eldritch Heritage with the Abyssal or Orc bloodlines at level 11 for a scaling inherent bonus to strength.  Grab a Robe of Arcane Heritage to improve your level scaling by 4.

Enforcer****:  Demoralize enemies for free when you hit them with nonlethal damage!  An alternative to Cornugon Smash, and goes well the Blade of Mercy trait.

Graceful Athlete***:  For dexterity-based Zealots who use Fool’s Errand.  Add dexterity instead of strength to your climb and swim checks!  If you have a climb speed, you already get a +8 bonus to climb, so this probably won’t be needed.  If you’re tiny or smaller, you automatically use dexterity instead of strength for climb and swim.

Harrying Partners (Teamwork)*****:  This makes the benefit of your Aid Another last for an entire round, rather than just for one attack!  If you have a way to share teamwork feats, your teammates will love you.  Even if you can’t share teamwork feats, you can use this on yourself via Compartmentalized Aid to gain a ludicrous amount of AC and hold the front line.  But there’s one little problem.  It has a prerequisite of another teamwork feat.  If your party has a cavalier, inquisitor, hunter, or (non privateer) warlord, just pick one of their teamwork feats.  Otherwise, see if you can convince someone to take a good teamwork to use with you.

Paired Opportunists****:  The choice for frontliners.  Get an AoO whenever your partner takes one.

Outflank****:  Pick this if your favorite stance is Golden Commander’s Stance.  Increase the bonus from flanking from +2 to +4.

Collective Recollection***:  Give the smartie of your party +2 to knowledge checks and automatically learn everything that they learn.

Lookout***:  Use with your party’s diviner wizard, sohei monk, or time oracle.

Crowd Control***:  Get +2 CMD to prevent enemies from using Acrobatics to get by you.  This is the only teamwork feat in the game that has a benefit for you if no other teammates have it.  If all else fails, get this to qualify for Harrying Partners.

Improved and Greater Dirty Trick****:  Dirty tricks are the best combat maneuver.  They inflict a variety of different debuffs, and nothing is fully immune to dirty tricks.  A 1 level dip of Privateer Warlord with the Salt in the Wound ploy grants you both of these feats, and you don’t even need the prerequisites!

Dirty Trick Master*****:  Notice something about the prerequisites?  That’s right, they don’t include Int 13 or Combat Expertise!  Dip that level of Privateer Warlord and you can nab this at level 11, easy peasy!  But that’s not the best part.  You can inflict conditions on enemies that make them completely harmless, and because those conditions suppress the enemy’s actions, they can’t use a standard action to remove them.  (I don’t actually recommend doing this in a game.  Hardcore lockdown every combat makes the game boring.)

Improved and Greater Trip**: Tripping with AoOs and a reach weapon is a good way to protect your team at early levels, but soon you’ll come up against things that trip simply doesn’t work on.  Flying things, multi-legged things, legless things, gigantic things, etc.  It’s better to pick up Seize the Opportunity and use dirty tricks instead if you want to go the AoO combat maneuver route.

Martial Focus*:  +1 damage, and you get access to Weapon Mastery feats.  Take Weapon Group Adaptation instead, as it gives you much more versatility with your strikes.

Cut from the Air*****:  Use AoOs to negate ranged attacks on yourself and adjacent allies!  Wonderful for your action economy, letting you save counters for other things.

Smash from the Air***:  Now you can chop down massive ranged weapons and spells that use attack rolls!  Granted, they’re not as common as offensive spells that don’t.

Noble Scion (War)***:  Use cha instead of dex for initiative.  Very handy for strength-based or cha-SAD Zealots, but sometimes difficult to fit into builds if starting at level 1, since you can only take it at 1st level.  Shooting Star Zealots will have to struggle until level 3!

Pageant of the Peacock*****:  For Zealots taking a dip of Rubato Bard.  This Bardic Masterpiece lets you use bluff in place of all intelligence-based skill checks with a +4 bonus, and more!  Outstanding if your party needs someone with knowledge skills.

Point Blank Shot/Precise Shot/Rapid Shot/Deadly Aim****: For reasons discussed countless times in this guide, Zealots are best at single attacks, not machinegunning.  But a full salvo might be what’s needed to finish off a fight in some cases.

Power Attack**:  Your job as a Zealot isn’t to deal damage, because other classes do that better.  Reducing your attack bonus means your strikes are less likely to hit and thus you will lock down fewer enemies.  Ensuring a powerful rider effect lands is much more important than dealing a few more points of damage.  If you regularly fight enemies that you can hit on a natural 2, it might be worth taking, but you could also be using Martial Power.

Shield Focus**:  +1 AC is +1 AC.  Low value for a feat, but at least it’s useful 5% of the time.

Shield Brace*****: An alternative to Pikeman’s Training, and the real reason you took Shield Focus.  You need to get Shield Focus as well, but you get to have 1.5x strength to damage, as you can actually two-hand your weapon.

Stumbling Bash****:  Your target suffers -2 AC until the start of your next turn when you shield bash.  That’s like giving your party +2 attack.  Especially nice in combination with the ranged attacks from Iron Tortoise like Ricochet Shell.

Unhindering Shield***:  Another alternative to Pikeman’s Training, but not as good for Zealots as it is for other classes.  This is for characters who want an actual free hand for class features, TWFing, Archery Zealots with Martial Power, or simply those who use a two-handed weapon that isn’t a spear or polearm.

Soulless Gaze*****:  (Credit to upho!) It’s very easy to get a high Intimidate bonus.  This feat lets you frighten or panic enemies instead of merely make them shaken.  Frightened and panicked enemies do zero damage to you and your party.  Combine this with something that lets you intimidate enemies for free, like Cornugon Smash, Enforcer, or Black Seraph’s Glare, and suddenly you’re crowd controlling everything you hit.  It requires another Damnation Feat, so pick Fiendskin for some energy resistance, or Mask of Virtue if you’re playing an intrigue-heavy game.  You’ll also have the other drawbacks of being damned, but that’s a small price to pay.  (Like with Dirty Trick Master, I don’t actually recommend doing this in a game.  Hardcore lockdown every combat makes the game boring.)

Snap Shot, Improved, Greater**:  Archer Zealots really shouldn’t be in melee range.  As it’s written, Snap Shot is nearly useless, because it only protects you from provoking AoOs when you make AoOs.  It doesn’t protect you from provoking AoOs when you use regular attacks.  You only threaten 5/10 feet, and this range doesn’t extend with size increases.  The only thing it arguably could work with is Intruder’s End (Eternal Guardian 3).

Stand Still*: Read this closely.  It only works when enemies provoke AoOs by moving through your adjacent squares.

Swift Aid*: You can use Aid Another as a swift action, but your base bonus is reduced to +1.  Zealots only recover maneuvers if they use Aid Another as a move action, not with any other type of action.  You also want to use your swift/immediate actions for boosts and counters, not this piddly bonus.  Don’t be fooled into taking this.

Undersized Mount**:  For medium-sized Zealots with a Mauler familiar to use the Mounted fighting style.  Hey, at least the existence of this feat makes it possible.  Being small means you won’t have to spend a feat slot on this.

Wasp Familiar*****:  If you worship Calistria, get this.  You get a flying familiar that gives you +4 initiative!  Now you don’t need to dip a level of Bloodrager.  It’s much more efficient than the Iron Will + Familiar Bond + Improved Familiar Bond feat chain.

Other Dreamscarred Press Feats

Always ask your GM if you’re allowed to pick up feats from this section.  A lot of people aren’t even aware that many of these options exist, and some GMs might be blindsided if you pick the more powerful options.

Altered Life*****:  From Bloodforge.  Use charisma instead of constitution to determine your bonus HP.  This lets you use constitution as a dump stat, freeing up even more point buy and letting you be even more SAD!  If you don’t have one of the types in the prerequisites, the Mixed Blood trait comes to the rescue by letting you pick a subtype to qualify for this feat!

Dancing Shield Step***:  From Divergent Paths: Medic.  While in a Mithral Current stance, don shields as a free action, and take a free 5 foot step whenever you successfully shield bash.  This will help you get into flanking positions, but it’s not as useful for Zealots since they don’t need to be adjacent to collective members to protect them with Iron Tortoise counters.  Free movement is always nice, though.  This will be fine during early levels, but will start to fall off when you reach level 9, because the higher level Mithral Current stances aren’t great for Zealots.

Essence Focus*****:  From Akashic Mysteries.  Invest 1 essence as a move action and regain your psionic focus, but you can’t reinvest it for 3 rounds.  Sounds like a more restrictive version of Psionic Meditation so far, right?  But you can also activate two abilities simultaneously that require you to expend your psionic focus if they use the same action.  That means you can use Deep Impact AND an augmented Sleeping Goddess strike at the same time!  Or Improved Path of Dedication and your 4th level Mission ability!  There are a lot of excellent possibilities for combinations, and this improves your action economy by letting you do more things with your psionic focus at once.

Fang and Fury****:  From Lords of the Night.  Once per round, you make a free bite attack against a target you also initiated a strike maneuver on.  For most Zealots, this would just be a bland bit of bonus damage.  But if your bites have good rider effects like trip or grapple, it becomes much better.  Grab the Hold Prey feat to achieve just that.

Gungnir Technique**:  From Divergent Paths: Medic.  While in a Silver Crane stance, your polearms and spears have ghost touch and you can attack possessing creatures without hurting the possessee.  Thanks to the errata, all Silver Crane strikes can deal with possessors, and any strike that deals sacred damage deals full damage to incorporeal creatures, making this feat mostly redundant.  At best, you could use it if you want to attack such creatures with non-Silver Crane strikes.

High Noon, Sunrise, and Sunset****:  From the Radiant Dawn playtest.  These feats are mutually exclusive and let you invest essence into any maneuver.  High Noon increases your damage, Sunrise increases your AC, and Sunset grants an ally temporary HP.  Getting one of these feats is required if you want to use Sun’s Gleam with non-Radiant Dawn maneuvers.

Hold Prey****:  From Bloodforge.  Your bite and tentacle attacks gain the grab special attack!  Now you can automatically crowd control enemies whenever you hit them!

Imposing Shield*:  From Divergent Paths: Medic.  While in an Eternal Guardian stance, shield bashing enemies gives them -2 attack against anyone who isn’t you until the start of your next turn.  But one little problem!  It doesn’t stack with other attack penalties you inflict, like from shaken or sickened!  And what kind of Eternal Guardian enthusiast doesn’t have reliable ways of fearing enemies upon hitting them?

Mighty Frame****:  From Bloodforge.  You gain Powerful Build.  Very good for AoO builds to be more threatening, but rather pointless for all other builds.

Nemean Lion Hide***:  From Divergent Paths: Medic.  While in a Golden Lion or Iron Tortoise stance and use Martial Power, you gain your cha mod to DR/- until the start of your next turn.  Very useful indeed at low levels if you’re the designated tank of your party, but its effectiveness will quickly dwindle as you level up.

Overflowing Life*:  From Bloodforge.  Gain fast healing 2.  It requires Toughness, a low-value feat, and the amount of healing it gives you is insignificant in the middle of combat after the first low levels of your career.  There are other ways of healing freely outside of combat.

Powerful Throw***:  (prereq: Power Attack, Str 15, BAB +1) From Akashic Mysteries.  Use strength instead of dexterity for throwing attacks.  The throwing fighting style is bad in general, but this works well for strength-based Zealots who like the ranged shield bash strikes from Iron Tortoise and the Enter the Vortex stance from Elemental Flux.

Quicksilver Grip*:  From Fool’s Errand.  It’s like Improved Quick Draw, but only applies against locked creatures, and makes your supernatural Mithral Current maneuvers extraordinary.  Just take Improved Quick Draw instead.  Unless your GM really, REALLY likes antimagic fields.

Sadism*:  From the Highlord playtest.  Expend your psionic focus as an immediate action when a collective member takes damage, and gain temporary HP equal to half the damage dealt.  The action and resource cost is too high for the benefit.

Scrambler’s Gift***:  From Bloodforge.  You gain a climb speed equal to half your land speed.  The main benefit of this is for Fool’s Errand users, as having a climb speed gives you +8 climb.

Shape Veil****:  From Akashic Mysteries.  The main problem is the 13 wisdom prerequisite.  If you can stomach that, there are several useful veils that are more than worth a feat.  If you get one that forces enemies to make saves, you’ll want to dip a charisma-based veilweaving class like Rajah.  Some good veils are Crusader’s Shield, which lets you create durable cover and choke points as a move action; Cuirass of Confidence to make diplomacy easier;  El’s Utterdark Shield, which lets you shield bash with bonus negative energy damage as an AoO whenever you or an adjacent ally are missed by an attack and remove an enemy from the fight for at least 1 round; Eyes of the Hawkguard for Firearms Zealots to increase your vision and range increment by 10+; and Stare of the Ghaele, which gives you a 30 foot gaze attack to make enemies shaken for 1d6+1 rounds.

Vortex Rush*:  From Fool’s Errand.  Create energy trails that deal cha mod damage whenever you move or force a target to move as part of a maneuver.  The damage is pitiful even against mooks, the utility is nonexistent, and you might even damage your allies.  It could be fun to literally turn your enemy into a comet by hurling them with Sky-Shattering Throw (Fool’s Errand 8) and leaving a fiery/icy/lightning/acidic trail 1500 feet long, but it’s not useful.

Willful Throw*:  From Akashic Mysteries.  You can use charisma instead of dexterity for attack rolls with throwing weapons, with a few other small bonuses!  How exciting!  Except, you need 5 essence, and throwing is a terrible fighting style.  If you’re digging deep into Radiant Dawn, just use laser beams instead.

Traits

There are several traits that stand out for Zealots specifically.  You might even want to consider asking your GM if you can take a drawback for another trait and taking the Additional Traits feat.

Campaign

Fools for Friends (Campaign)*****:  Improves your Aid Another by +1 as a trait bonus, so it stacks with Helpful.  And you even get a +1 will save vs charms and compulsions!  Your GM might not allow it since it’s a campaign trait.

Combat

Battlefield Disciple (Combat)****:  Increase your bonus to Aid Another for attack rolls by 1, and +2 heal checks to stabilize dying creatures.  Stacks with everything!

Combat Training (Combat)****:  Grab an out-of-discipline utility maneuver to get some functionality that you otherwise couldn’t.  Good candidates are Leaping Dragon (Thrashing Dragon), Fluctuation Movement (Elemental Flux), Clockwatcher (Riven Hourglass), and Dizzying Venom Prana (Steel Serpent).

Helpful (Combat)***:  If you or your GM feel that improving your defining class feature so drastically with a trait is too cheesy, or that it doesn’t make sense for your character to be adopted by halflings, maybe this trait will fit better.  It changes your base Aid Another bonus from +2 to +3.

Practiced Initiator (Combat)*****:  This is mandatory for dipping and multiclassing.  See the Dipping section for details!

Faith

Fate’s Favored (Faith)*****:  Increase luck bonuses by 1.  Incredible if you have a Warlord dip and use gambits, which provide a luck bonus.  Also amazing for half-orcs with Sacred Tattoo, giving them another +1 to saves.  Some items give luck bonuses as well, like the Four-Leaf Clover.  Dip a level of Oracle, and your Divine Favor’s bonus increases too!

Irrepressible (Faith)****:  Use charisma instead of wisdom for will saves vs charm and compulsion!  Not needed if you dip Paladin 2 or Warlord 3.

Race

Fiery Glare (Race, Ifrit)***:  Take 10 on Intimidate whenever you want.  You can get the same effect and more by taking the Discipline Mastery feat.

Helpful (Race, Halfling)*****:  Change your base Aid Another bonus from +2 to +4!  Just another reason why halflings are one of the best races for Zealots.

Mixed Blood (Race, Any)*****:  From Bloodforge by Dreamscarred Press.  You gain one of many subtypes and additional bonuses.  This includes subtypes like dwarf, elf, halfling, and orc to get the best FCB.  Some of these options even give you +1 natural armor to AC or a 10% stacking fortification bonus.  Ludicrously powerful for a trait!

Regional

Community-Minded (Regional, Rahadoum)*****:  Extends the duration of your morale bonuses, like Zeal, from 1 round to 3 rounds!  It also works with some maneuvers like Encouraging Roar and Defending the Pride (Golden Lion).

Unorthodox Method (Regional, Any)****:  Trade out one of your known disciplines for another.  Before you use a trait on this, you should do it by joining a Martial Tradition, which is free.  If your GM will let you.

Voices of Solid Things (Regional, Witchmarket)***:  Use charisma for Appraise, Craft, Disable Device, or Spellcraft, and get it as a class skill.  Good for Cursed Razor, Elemental Flux, or Shattered Mirror users.

Religion

Blade of Mercy (Religion, Sarenrae)****:  You don’t take a -4 penalty for dealing nonlethal damage with slashing weapons, and deal +1 nonlethal damage with them.  Fantastic in combination with the Enforcer feat leading up to Soulless Gaze.  It saves you a feat in comparison to Power Attack > Cornugon Smash.  You’ll just have to hope the Goddess of Redemption can forgive you for making a deal with a fiend and turning true neutral!

Deadeye Bowman (Religion, Erastil)****:  For Archery Zealots.  When using a longbow, if only a single creature is providing soft cover to your target, your target doesn’t get the +4 bonus to AC!  This is almost as good as Improved Precise Shot, which has huge prerequisites.

Defensive Strategist (Religion, Torag)*****:  You aren’t flat-footed during a surprise round that you don’t get to act in or before you get to act at the start of a battle.  Now you can use counters whenever you want!  Initiative becomes much less important if you have this.

Scarred by War (Religion, Dalenydra)***:  [Link] +1 diplomacy outside of combat, and your abilities heal +1 hp.  It’s not much, but every little bit helps for combat healing builds!

Social

Adopted (Social)*****:  If you’re not a halfling, be adopted by some!

Agile Dancer (Social)****:  If you’re a strength-based Zealot, this is vital if you want to use the skill-using maneuvers of Piercing Thunder, Thrashing Dragon, Broken Blade, and Mithral Current.  Or if you just want to do the regular things Acrobatics does.

Dipping, Multiclassing, and Prestige Classes

It’s highly recommended that you pick up the Practiced Initiator trait if you plan on multiclassing.  Thanks to the fact that non Zealot levels count as ½ of an initiator level, you can take up to 4 non-Zealot levels and still have full progression on maneuvers if you have this trait!

Base Class Dips

Aegis 3*****:  [Link] (Credit to Felyndiira!)  With 3 levels in Aegis and the Student of the Astral Suit feat, you will have 10 customization points, and many customizations are on par or better than feats!  And they can be changed out every day!  Remember the Unlocked Talent feat?  An Aegis can get the same effect and more for a mere 2 customization points by taking Power Stone Repository and Harness Power Stone.  Take Harness Shard and buy a few cheap 1000 gp shards to get +10 to whatever skill you want.  You can get permanent flight with a paltry 2 customization points, and 5 ft more reach with 3.  You can even grab more of whatever maneuvers you want with Initiator’s Soul, making Advanced Study obsolete.  The Hardened Strikes customization plus a Monk’s Robe gives you a 1d8 unarmed strike that doesn’t provoke AoOs.  The Custom Psicrystal customization from Psicrystals Expanded gives you Psicrystal Affinity, Psicrystal Containment, and Psicrystal Reservoir for 1 customization point each.  You can cast Mount at will by taking Lesser Chakra Bind and Lesser Shape Veil, 1 customization point each, to bind Horselord’s Greaves, enabling the mounted fighting style without a familiar or animal companion.  Other great veils are listed in the feats section under Shape Veil.  Take the Aberrant archetype for some more natural armor, intimidate, and the ability to gain natural attacks.  Tentacles have the grab ability with a stacking +2 bonus.  All of this is on top of the DR 2/- and the 3 free customizations you get for your suit choice.

Aegis (Host of Heroes) 3*****:  (Credit to Mithral Leaf!) Pick the Marshal legendary role.  In addition to all of the juicy customizations a regular Aegis gets, you get a slew of new ones, +2 to bluff and diplomacy, the ability to share a teamwork feat with allies for a swift action, and the ability to take 10 on Aid Another and increase the bonus of your Aid Another by +2!  Get the Beacon customization to grant your allies +1 attack and damage against whatever enemy you hit and make the enemy unable to use stealth!  The only downside to choosing this archetype is that you’ll be stuck in masterwork chainmail and can’t use better armor.

Barbarian (Primal Disciple) 1 or 2***:  [Link] (Credit to upho!) You get 4 maneuvers, 1 stance, rage, 1 rage power, a free feat from PoW, uncanny dodge, and the ability to regain your rage rounds.  Take the Brawler rage power as a way to enable the Unarmed fighting style, or Superstition to get +2 morale to saves against spells, SLAs, and supernatural abilities.  Uncanny dodge lets you use counters whenever you want!  Add on the Savage Technologist archetype to add dexterity instead of constitution when you rage and take no AC penalty.  You lose uncanny dodge, but get Sword & Gun.  If you have the Defensive Strategist trait, though, that’s fine.

Bard (Rubato) 1*****:  [Link] You gain 3 maneuvers, 1 stance, whip proficiency, bardic performance, +1 to all knowledge checks and the ability to use them untrained, and animus (AKA tempo).  Unlike a regular bard, you can activate a bardic performance in the same action as initiating a strike by spending another round of bardic performance, improving your action economy.  Fortunately, Rubatos can replenish their bardic performance rounds by spending 2 tempo per 1 performance round!  You can also gain 2 tempo by spending 1 performance round as a free action.  By managing your tempo and bardic performance rounds well, you can gain up to 4 tempo per round by maintaining the Metronome performance.  Get Awakened Animus, and now you have a ton of effective PP to play with!  Get Lingering Performance to extend the duration of your performances and make your rounds easier to manage!  Get Pageant of the Peacock to use bluff in place of all intelligence-based skill checks and know absolutely everything, in addition to having a hefty +4 bonus to bluff!

Bloodrager 1****:  [Link] You get bloodrage, fast movement, and a familiar.  Yes, a familiar!  Characters with bloodlines can trade out their 1st level bloodline power for a Bloodline Familiar.  Why does this matter?  In addition to the bonus to a skill, save, initiative, or natural armor a familiar can give you, it can have an archetype, and one of the best is Protector.  Your familiar can use Bodyguard on you, and you can split half the damage you take with each other.  This effectively increases your AC by 2 and HP by 50%.  It doesn’t matter what your caster level is, because your familiar’s HP will always equal half your own.  Keep your familiar inside a familiar satchel, and you need not fear it being fireballed!  If you’re a small-sized race, or medium with Undersized Mount, pick Mauler so you can ride it and freely use your move actions on Aid         Another while retaining incredible mobility.  Grab the Bloodrider archetype if you’re using a Mauler familiar as a mount.  If you wear heavy armor, take the Steelblood archetype to replace fast movement with +1 CMB and other bonuses.  If you wanted to be unarmed, choose Bloody Knuckled Rowdy for Improved Unarmed Strike.  Dexterity-based Zealots should pick Urban Bloodrager.

Monk (Master of Many Styles) 1 or 2*****:  [Link] (Credit to upho!)  A MoMS Monk 1 gets Improved Unarmed Strike, +2 to all three saves, Stunning Fist, a free style feat that ignores all prerequisites, and the unique ability to enter two styles in the same action!  This makes for an easy way to get into a style feat chain from PoW:E without needing a stance from that discipline.  You still need to meet the prerequisites of the mid and upper level feats in those chains, and can’t use the free bonus feats from MoMS to take them because they lack the (Style) tag, but they don’t list a stance as a prerequisite!  You still need to have the base style feat active in order to use its mid and upper level feats.  Take a 2nd level for another prerequisite-less style feat and evasion.  The Combat Style Master feat will be a wonderful boon for your action economy at the start of combat.  To get rid of that useless Stunning Fist, add on the Sohei archetype for +1 initiative and the ability to act in surprise rounds, or Kata Master for a charisma-based panache pool.  Kata Masters alone can’t use Opportune Parry and Riposte, but their panache pool will stack with a Swashbuckler’s.  If your GM does NOT use the 7/22/2015 errata to the Advanced Class Guide, then Kata Masters can use Opportune Parry and Riposte on their own.

Monk (Nornkith) 1*:  Don’t be fooled by the shiny cha-to-AC.  It only works if you’re unarmored.  Wearing armor is almost always better, and there are other classes that give cha-to-AC, like Oracle.  The bonus to initiative is nice, but you can get the same thing via MoMS + Sohei Monk.  Incompatible with MoMS.  Nothing else about this archetype helps a Zealot do its job.

Monk (Scaled Fist) 1*:  [Link] Another cha-to-AC option, but bad for the same reasons as Nornkith.  Also incompatible with MoMS.

Monk (Silver Fist) 1****:  [Link] Only dip this if you’re also dipping Fiendbound Marauder Warder.  You get Improved Unarmed Strike, +2 to all three saves, Weapon Focus (Gauntlet), another bonus feat, and most importantly, Shielding Fist, which gives you a shield bonus to AC and lets your gauntlet’s enhancement bonus also increase your shield bonus.  That means you won’t need to spend any of your wealth on an actual shield, and don’t have to devote a hand to holding one.  Since Fiendbound Marauder Warders also use a gauntlet, this little dip will give you a tremendous amount of numerical bonuses and save you money.

Mystic 3-4****:  [Link] Only consider this dip if you’re taking the Animus Adept or Daring Hero prestige class.  Pick Aurora Soul to lose a bonus feat and mystic artifice in exchange for Improved/Greater Unarmed Strike, or Gunsmoke Mystic to lose a bonus feat in exchange for firearm proficiency and firearms-based animus augments.  A significantly different alternative is Knight Chandler.  See the Prestige Classes section for more details.

Oracle 1***:  [Link] For charisma SAD or strength Zealots who want to get their charisma to AC.  The Lore and Lunar mysteries also give you cha to reflex, and Nature gives you cha to CMD.  Take the Seeker archetype for trapfinding.  If you can spare a feat for Extra Revelation, then take the Warsighted archetype instead of Seeker to gain 4 uses of Martial Flexibility per day, and use Extra Revelation to get your Cha-to-AC revelation.  Martial Flexibility makes you vastly more versatile, and one of the best uses of it is to pick up Advanced Study for just the right maneuver you need in a pinch.

Paladin (Holy Tactician) 3****:  [Link] Instead of Smite Evil or Mark of Censure, you gain Weal’s Champion, which isn’t very impressive at Paladin level 3, but it’s a decent party-buffing tool to have in your back pocket against a big single target.  You get Lay on Hands and a Mercy for some healing and status curing.  Take the Fatigued curing mercy, and you never have to sleep again, because the only thing sleep deprivation does is make you fatigued!  You also get the delicious Divine Grace.  But best of all, you get a free teamwork feat and the ability to share it with teammates within 30 feet forever.  No action needed.  And your teammates don’t even need to have the feat’s prerequisites!  Pick up Harrying Partners and don’t look back.

Paladin (Knight Disciple) 2 or 4****:  [Link] You gain 4 maneuvers, 1 stance, a full round action buff for your party that increases their AC and saves by your cha mod, a Crusader’s Training of your choice, Detect Evil, Guardian’s Shield to give a teammate 4 temporary hitpoints as a free action every round, the ability to use paladin magic items, Mark of Censure 1/day which makes it very difficult for a creature to hurt anyone other than the Knight Disciple for 24 hours, and last but not least… Divine Grace!  Charisma to all saves!  Get 4 levels for another Crusader’s Training, a Mercy, and the ability to increase all healing you do with maneuvers by 50%.  That’s wonderful for Silver Crane and especially Radiant Dawn.  Unfortunately, many of the Knight Disciple’s abilities have a limited number of uses per day, but they will save your party a lot of pain.  It benefits from having a very high charisma, and you can even take Shooting Star.  Yes, you can worship any deity regardless of alignment as long as you’re not a class that is specifically required to be compatible, like Cleric.  Paladins are not such a class.

Rajah 1 or 2*****:  [Link] You get 5 maneuvers, 1 stance, 2 Title veils, 1 essence, Vassalage which allows you to originate your attacks from allies you put your Titles on with +1 attack, Royal Mandate which lets you move or buff an ally while reallocating essence, and The Crossroads which gives you one of three abilities.  Crown of the Sky Sovereign lets you use charisma for attack and damage when you use Vassalage, allowing you to be more Cha-SAD.  Crown of the Sun King makes your Vassalage attacks create weak damaging cones or lines.  Crown of the Moon Queen lets you expend a maneuver to use a particular counter once per round with Vassalage for no action!  That in and of itself is already amazing, but you gain an incredible degree of flexibility and supportive power with your Titles, too.  The essence capacity of your receptacles (titles, feats, maneuvers, etc) increases with character level, not veilweaver level, and you gain more essence as you learn more and higher level Radiant Dawn maneuvers.  You can also use an Amulet of War which is cheaper than purchasing an actual weapon, but the downside is that you can’t use it to make AoOs.  A second Rajah level gives you another veil, unseen servants, and neatly evens out your BAB.  Unseen Servants are rife with useful possibilities, such as picking up disarmed weapons, opening/closing doors, and handing off items in battle.

Soulknife (Augmented Blade) 1****:  [Link] This archetype qualifies for the Zealous Blade feat at level 1 because of the Psicrystal Augment feature.  Having a weapon that scales as you level up saves you a lot of money, and there are 3 Sleeping Goddess boosts that further buff up your weapon: Call the Soul’s Blade (1st), Armory of the Sleeping Goddess (4th), and Perfect Distillation of the Soul (7th).  However, you can easily get by with just the weapons produced by these boosts and not dip Souknife at all.  They create a masterwork, +3, and +5 weapon, at initiator levels 1, 7, and 13, respectively.  In comparison, a Soulknife’s mind blade reaches +3 enhancement at level 9 and +5 at level 15.  You can even keep your Sleeping Goddess summoned weapon active at all times out of combat, because maneuvers recover every round for free out of combat.  Here’s a link with the proof.  If you want a customizable weapon with a ton of extra features, take this dip.  If you just want a weapon with the bare essentials, don’t.  Stick with the Sleeping Goddess boosts, or buy a regular magic weapon.

Soulknife (Brutality Blade) 3*:  A cha-based Soulknife!  Sadly, it’s not great for Zealots.  Brutality Blade benefits from having a lot of levels in it, but Zealots will only want to have a maximum of 3 Soulknife levels to qualify for Zealous Blade.  The only Soulknife features that use wisdom are blade skills, and you'll only get one at level 2.  The best one you can get is Focused Offense, which gives cha to attack and damage instead of str, but you might as well just use the Shooting Star fighting style at that point.  So the cha synergy between Zealot and Brutality Blade is nearly nonexistent.  Also, the slower mind blade scaling makes it bad for the Zealous Blade feat.  You need 7 Brutality Blade levels to see an improvement in your Rage Blade.  Also, manifesting your rage blade before you have 5 Brutality Blade levels takes the same action as manifesting a mind blade, so for most people, that's a move action.  The benefits for having a level 3 Brutality Blade's rage blade do not outweigh the downsides and costs.

Soulknife (Psychic Armory + War Soul) 3****:  [War Soul Link] This requires 3 levels to qualify for Zealous Blade, and you need to take a 1 level dip of the Daring Hero prestige class to make the most of it.  That changes your Soulknife class features from being wisdom-based to charisma-based, allowing you to use charisma for attack and damage.  You can also take the Discipline Blade Shapes blade skill to create and be proficient with any of your discipline weapons, including firearms, making this an alternative to a Privateer dip for Firearms Zealots.

Spiritualist (Exciter, Fractured Mind) 1***:  [Exciter Link] [Fractured Mind Link] You get a couple psychic spells based on charisma, access to occult skill unlocks, +10 land speed, Skill Focus in 2 skills, +4 on saves vs mind-affecting effects, the ability to ignore a failed save against a mind-affecting effect once per day, and rage that lets you have +4 dex/cha or +2 str/dex/con/cha.  An interesting choice for dexterity-based or charisma-SAD Zealots.  It’s limited by small pools of daily resources, making it better for short adventuring days.

Swashbuckler 1****:  [Link] You get swashbuckler finesse, some deeds, and a panache pool.  Opportune Parry and Riposte is why you want this dip, as it lets you turn your AoOs into attack-negating counters.  The best builds that make use of this dip are Shooting Star Zealots, Privateer Firearms Zealots, and Finesse Melee Zealots.  Starknives are light piercing weapons and can replenish panache, and cha-SAD Zealots will have a lot of panache to use with Opportune Parry and Riposte.  Privateers use one-handed firearms as melee piercing weapons and have an extra point of panache from Amateur Gunslinger.  Finesse Zealots can pick the Inspired Blade archetype for Weapon Focus (Rapier) as a bonus feat and possibly more panache from a higher intelligence.

Warlord 3***:  [Link] This is for Zealots who want to share Harrying Partners but don’t want to be a Paladin or Aegis.  You gain 8 maneuvers, 2 stances, 2 gambits, 1 bonus combat or teamwork feat, Indomitable or Warning Presence, a free teamwork feat with the ability to share it, and charisma to will saves.  If you take Warning Presence, get Lookout before reaching level 3 to qualify for Harrying Partners when you get Warleader.  A warlord needs to use a standard action to activate Warleader, unfortunately, so Holy Tactician Paladins win the action economy contest.

Warlord (Bushi) 2-3****:  [Link] An alternative to the regular warlord dip for Zealots with at least 20 charisma.  You lose your bonus feat and tactical presence, but gain Iaido, Quick Draw, and 1 Bushido at level 2.  Pick Respect to change the base bonus of your Aid Another to equal your cha mod.  This does not stack with other things that change your base bonus like the Helpful trait, but it does stack with things that directly increase the bonus like a Ring of Tactical Precision.

Warlord (Privateer) 1*****:  [Link] You gain a TON of stuff from this dip.  6 new maneuvers, 1 new stance, Dazzling Display which recovers your Warlord maneuvers, firearm proficiency, 1 bonus combat or teamwork feat, and 2 gambits!  Oh, and +1 to several minor skills as gravy.  You can trade Warlord bonus feats and gambits for ploys, so you can get up to 3 ploys right off the bat.  Here are some good ploy selections.

  • Daring Gambit (Flanker’s Gambit)****:  For melee Zealots.  As a swift action, you gain flanking against your target regardless of your positioning and add half your cha mod as a luck bonus to your attack roll.  Use this to ensure landing a hit with a disabling strike and activate Dazzling Gambit.  You also recover one maneuver for allies within 30 feet, and since few classes can recover maneuvers as well as Zealots, your martial initiator teammates will love you!
  • Daring Gambit (Dastardly Gambit)****:  Works for both ranged and melee Zealots, but best for ranged thanks to maneuvers like Dust-Catching Breeze (Tempest Gale 2).  Add half your cha mod as a luck bonus to your dirty trick check, and grant your party a hefty damage buff.
  • Daring Gambit (Pinhole Gambit)*:  Destroyed by errata.  It used to be a huge AC debuff for your target, but now it just increases your own AC.
  • Dazzling Gambit****:  Combine with another gambit.  Demoralize all enemies within 30 feet when you successfully use a gambit.
  • Gun Training + Sea Combat*****:  This is what makes Firearms Zealots possible, and amazing.  You get Amateur Gunslinger, max grit based on charisma, a bonus grit feat, the ability to melee with guns, and the ability to reload with your hands full!  You don’t need to take Gun Training if you also get the Desperado archetype, though.
  • Salt in the Wound*****:  You gain Improved and Greater Dirty Trick and can ignore their terrible prerequisites.  Two excellent feats with an extra perk for the price of one gambit!

If you want more ploys, you can take the Extra Gambit feat, but only if you have 3 or more Warlord levels.  If you want to be a Firearms Zealot, grab the Desperado archetype as well to trade your bonus feat for Gunsmithing, Amateur Gunslinger, and a free battered firearm.

Warlord (Steelfist Commando) 3***:  [Link] One option for being an Unarmed Zealot.  It loses the free combat feat, but gains Improved and Greater Unarmed Strike, and +1 dodge to AC.

Warlord (Veiled Lord) 1**:  [Link] Lose your bonus feat, but gain one veil of any kind. That means you can get veils that the Shape Veil feat doesn’t give you access to, like ring or blood veils!  If you pick Crimson Totem, now you have a free greatclub that you use constitution to attack with!  You also gain 1 temporary essence whenever you perform a gambit.  An Aegis dip can also get Crimson Totem.

Warder (Bushi, Zweihander Sentinel) 1****:  [Bushi Link] [Zweihander Link] You gain 5 maneuvers, 1 stance, a +1 shield bonus to AC, grant +1 AC and Will to allies within 10 feet of you, the ability to use your two-hander like a light shield bash, Combat Reflexes based on intelligence, the handy Defensive Focus ability, Quick Draw, and the ability to recover 1 maneuver by sheathing a weapon.  This dip is for Zealots who use a reach weapon.  Shield Armament lets you attack enemies inside your reach easily.  It probably still will be worth taking the Impulsive Reactions conviction to make your combat reflexes use your charisma instead of dexterity or intelligence.  The aegis and armament shield of the Zweihander Sentinel might even count as a shield for the purpose of benefiting from Martial Power, making you the tankiest two-handed weapon user around!

Warder (Fiendbound Marauder) 1*****:  [Link] (Credit to upho!) A good alternative to the above Warder dip.  Instead of your aegis and Quick Draw, you gain a 1d8 one handed reach weapon with the grab monster ability, and can use it to attack inside your reach deadzone.  The grab ability gives you +4 to grapple checks and lets you attempt to grapple for free when you hit, making you exceedingly sticky, disruptive, and hard to ignore.  You can even take a -20 penalty to your grapple check to avoid suffering the grapple condition yourself.  To escape from a grapple, enemies need to spend a whole entire standard action to escape.  Combine this with Steel Coils (Steel Serpent) or an Anaconda’s Coils Belt to gain constrict and do hefty damage to everything you grapple!  If your wisdom is higher than your intelligence, add on the Ordained Defender archetype to make your Warder maneuvers and Combat Reflexes use wisdom.  Combine with Monk of the Silver Fist for impressive synergy.

Wilder 1*****:  [Link] Only consider this dip if you’re taking the Awakened Blade prestige class.  It’s the best manifesting class for Awakened Blade as it has 9th level manifesting progression, is charisma-based, and has good class features at 1st level like Wild Surge and Surge Bond.  Pick Raging Surge to get rage which lets you manifest powers while using it.

Prestige Classes

The errata makes levels in prestige classes increase all of your initiator levels!  And at IL 4 and every even level thereafter, you replace an old maneuver with a new one!  Spectacular if you multiclass with other initiator classes!

Animus Adept****:  [Link] An animus user that scribes intricate drawings to buff and debuff in the blink of an eye!  The most significant thing about this prestige class is that you can apply Martial Glyphs as a free action, giving you extra buffs or debuffs with excellent action economy.  You have an important choice to make when deciding to take this prestige class:  Mystic dip, Knight Chandler dip, or just Tap Animus?

Prerequisites**:  You have to take the absolutely awful Animus Healing feat no matter what.  You can enter with an animus pool via a Mystic dip or the Tap Animus feat, but Rubato Bard will NOT qualify you, because tempo is not the same as animus.  Luckily, when Tap Animus becomes Extra Animus when you enter the prestige class, you can retrain it out.

Chassis**:  d8 HD, medium BAB, 2 skill points/level, no proficiencies.  Certainly worse than a Zealot.  At least you gain the yummy Use Magic Device as a class skill.

Animus****:  It works the same as a regular Mystic, but uses your charisma instead of wisdom to determine how much you get at the start of each encounter.  It’s certainly a step up from either a Mystic dip or the Tap Animus feat alone!  If you have a 1-3 level Mystic dip, Animus Adept levels stack for Mystic-only animus augmentation effects, so you can use Anima Burn or Increased Potency, or spend a second point of animus on Enhance Maneuver or Increase DC.  If you have 4 levels in Mystic, then 5 levels in Animus Adept lets you augment with 3 animus, and you gain access to Animus Rush and Increased Range, excellent for Zealots who like moving without having to use move actions.

Martial Glyphs*****:  Over the course of 5 levels, you’ll gain 8 basic glyphs, 6 advanced glyphs, and 3 master glyphs.  That’s a lot of flexibility and utility!  And since you can use them as a free action whenever you initiate a strike, that’s a lot of extra free power as well!  Their durations are long enough to last for most combats, and the DCs scale with your level.  Sadly, using the same glyph on the same target doesn’t extend its duration, so you need to wait for the first application to wear off before applying it again.  Since you’re psionic, you have both an active energy type and an active element, so you can pick one of two different energy damage types to use with your damage-dealing or resistance-granting glyphs, further increasing flexibility.

Mystical Prowess***:  You’re better at identifying martial maneuvers, powers, spells, and glyphs, and your Animus Adept levels stack with Mystic levels for elemental glyphs and candle magic.  If you have a 3 level dip in Mystic, 5 levels in Animus Adept will give you access to the 8th level elemental glyphs or candle lantern effects!

Mass Martial Glyphs**:  Using a full round action to apply one glyph to allies within 30 feet generally isn’t worth it.  In most cases, you should use a standard action strike, a free action glyph, and a move action Aid Another like normal.  It’s nice to have the option to give everyone mirror images or ghost touch, if that’s what’s seriously needed.  But remember that you can’t do this while out of combat, because you don’t have any animus until you enter combat.

Runic Singularity*****:  You gain an extra +1 animus per turn, and can use another glyph whenever you use a boost or change your stance.  There are a lot of good boosts that rival the power of counters in the hands of a Zealot, especially Golden Lion boosts, and further buffing your allies with glyphs for free is awesome.  More animus means more augments!

Final Ruling****:  If you chose to go the Mystic dip route, your class features will no doubt be more powerful, and give you more options, support, and mobility via Mystic-only animus augments.  But by doing so, you miss out on 4 levels of Zealot or other class dips, which could give you potentially better features.  You will also need to devote a move action every combat and have a decent wisdom modifier to use elemental glyphs as a Mystic dipper, but due to the sheer combined power of the 3rd + 8th level elemental glyphs, that’s not so bad.  A Knight Chandler’s candle magic has much better action economy, always has at least 1 illumination, is active even out of combat, has utility that no elemental glyphs have, and has much less reliance on wisdom than elemental glyphs.  This prestige class is for Zealots who want to increase their support ability to the max, at the expense of their direct tanking and damage negation ability.

Awakened Blade*****:  [Link] A prestige class that advances both manifesting and maneuvers with full BAB!  It also has several features that help you stack your bonuses to the high heavens and improve your action economy.

Prerequisites*:  You have to burn 15 skill points to qualify, so you’ll want to watch how low you dump your intelligence.  You still want to have a decent bonus in certain skills like Intimidate to use some of your best counters, after all.  Psionic Meditation becomes dead weight, sadly, once you get Hypercognitive Focus.  For the powers known, the best choice is Wilder, as it’s a charisma-based full manifester.  Take the Extra Power Known feat to qualify, then retrain it out when you reach 2nd level in Awakened Blade.  You’ll need to keep those powers known, which will forever be dead weight as well.

Chassis***:  d10 HD, full BAB, 4 skill points/level, no proficiencies.  You gain acrobatics and stealth as class skills, and since acrobatics is a prerequisite, it’s not unwelcome.  You do lose some fortitude save, though.

Powers Known***:  You get 8/10 manifesting progression, so you will end with a ML of 9 in Wilder, giving you 4th level powers and a huge amount of power points.

Situational Awareness****:  Insight bonus to initiative, AC and reflex vs traps, uncanny dodge, and eventually improved uncanny dodge.  More initiative is good for anyone, especially people who focus on crowd control.  Uncanny dodge is especially good for Zealots because it ensures you can use a counter on the first round of combat no matter what!

Deep Focus****:  For almost all Zealots, this is a very welcome bonus!  But if your GM lets you use Psicrystal Reservoir from Psicrystals Expanded, Deep Focus becomes depressingly much less useful.  At least you still have it if something bad happens to your psicrystal.  And hey, it’s +2 more HP because of Psionic Body.

Path of the Warrior*:  Psychic Warrior and Soulknife are not good for qualifying for this prestige class as a Zealot.

Stance of the Inner Eye*****:  A stance that gives you +1 insight bonus per 3 IL to AC, attack, damage, CMB, and saves, and +1d6 to +2d6 precision damage!  Those bonuses are, like, everything you need!  With such fast progression!  And who can say no to a free damage cherry on top?  The bonuses are so huge and numerous that this stance is already better than most other stances, and you’ll get to enjoy it all the time at level 10!

Bonus Feat****:  At levels 4 and 8.  How could we complain?

Precognitive Defenses*****:  You get to use another counter per round as a free action, as long as you can quickly regain your psionic focus, and one such way is generously provided in this prestige class!  The more counters you can use, the safer your party is.

Hypercognitive Focus*****:  Regain your psionic focus for free whenever you recover maneuvers.  And Zealots are one of the best in the game at recovering maneuvers!  Use this to power Precognitive Defenses, your Mission, Improved Path of Dedication, Sleeping Goddess augmentations, or psionic feats like Deep Impact.

Clairsentient Counter****:  Spend a maneuver, psionic focus, and immediate action when attacked to take a standard action in response.  The resource cost is high, but the potential effect can be devastating if you use a standard action strike that will lock down your attacker and make them unable to attack in the first place.

Pretercognitive Mind*****:  You can use whatever stance you want, and still get the benefits of Stance of the Inner Eye, with all its insanely powerful bonuses!

Final Ruling*****:  Awakened Blade gives huge bonuses.  It gives action economy.  It gives resource management.  It gives bonus feats.  It gives full maneuver and almost full psionic power progression.  It gives the sun, the moon, the kitchen sink, and a bouquet of roses.  And it’s waiting for you to give it your undying affection and zealous devotion, like only a Zealot can. The ooooonly downside to taking all 10 levels of this prestige class is that you won’t be able to take 10 levels of Zealot and get Improved Path of Dedication.

Battle Templar****:  [Link] A prestige class the progresses divine caster level and provides some spiffy healing, defensive buffs for your party, and improved action economy for spellcasting.  There are a few options for qualifying for the caster portion:  Oracle, Elder Mythos Cultist Cleric,or Feyspeaker Druid.  Oracle offers some useful revelations and ways to get Cha-to-AC or channel energy; Elder Mythos Cultist Cleric gives you a domain, knowledge bonuses, Cha-to-Will saves, and an altered channel energy; and Feyspeaker Druid gives you a few extra skill points and lets you add wizard enchantment/illusion spells to your spell list.  If you go with Druid, you can pick a domain or Druidic Herbalism instead of an animal companion.

Prerequisites**:  Martial Power is nice, and Golden Lion is a fantastic discipline.  But Golden Lion has almost no maneuvers that force saving throws, so you’ll need to take Discipline Focus (Iron Tortoise) which is much less impressive overall.  If you do use Iron Tortoise strikes, you’ll also need to pick up Improved Shield Bash.

Chassis**:  d8 HD, medium BAB, 4 skill points/level, no new proficiencies you didn’t already have.  Strangely, it has only a good fortitude save.  Why is its will save bad?

Spellcasting****:  Progress your divine casting at levels 2 through 9.  To make up for the lost levels, you’ll need to take Favored Prestige Class and Prestigious Spellcaster.

Ordained Knight***:  Bonus to diplomacy when “preaching to the choir,” IE talking to people the same faith as you, and advance Warder’s aegis, channel energy, domains, lay on hands, Inquisitor’s bane, inquisitions, and Oracle’s curse.  Sadly, this list of abilities is exhaustive, and if it’s not listed here, you don’t get to advance it.  Feyspeaker Druids can benefit from this by picking a domain.  Dipping a level of Warder will give you a +3 aegis by class level 8.

Reach of the Divine****:  Cast a spell on yourself or an ally within touch range as a move action when you use a strike maneuver.  This is difficult to rate for Zealots, because it steps on the toes of the Zealot’s ability to use Aid Another and recover maneuvers.  Casting spells as a move action is naturally an incredible boon to action economy, though, as you’ll be able to lock down an enemy with a strike and buff an ally simultaneously.  However, note that you can only use this to cast spells on yourself or allies, so you can’t use it to quickly deliver offensive spells and take down enemies more quickly.

Martial Healing**:  Heal an ally in close range for 1d4*maneuver level + class level as a swift action when you initiate a strike maneuver.  The healing is honestly very low, and there are better things you can do with a swift action as a Zealot.  Since Zealots can recover their best maneuvers so easily, you’ll likely be able to prevent more damage with a counter than this ability can heal.  The point of this ability is to allow classes with worse maneuver recovery to support their allies without expending maneuvers.

Divine Recovery*:  Spend a spell slot and swift action to recover a maneuver up to the level of the spent spell slot.  Spell slots are much more valuable than maneuvers, swift actions are precious, and Zealots can recover their maneuvers easily already.  Horribly inefficient.

Guardian of the Faith****:  A stance that gives you DR 10/adamantine and allies within 20 feet other than you gain +4 sacred/profane AC, CMD, and saves.  A rather humongous defensive bonus to your party’s frontline, but it still leaves you rather squishy by comparison.  The DR can be bypassed by more things than you might think.  The sheer magnitude of the AC and saves bonus still makes this stance worth it in many situations.

Shepherd of the Flock*****:  When you use Reach of the Divine, your target gains a +4 sacred/profane bonus to AC for 1 minute.  On one hand, this is redundant with Guardian of the Faith, so it’s a bad idea to use that stance while casting buffs on your allies.  On the other hand, this lets you turn into a mega tank by buffing your own AC in combination with whatever spell you cast on yourself.  The duration is incredible and will definitely last all combat.

Wrath of the Faithful*:  When you cast a divine spell, your next strike maneuver gains a morale bonus to damage equal to the spell level.  It’s a piddly, negligible increase, and it’s unfortunate that this is the only class feature you get on Battle Templar level 7.

Divine inspiration**:  Use an immediate action to let an ally recover a spent maneuver.  I’m honestly not sure if you’re supposed to spend a spell slot as well.  Even if you don’t have to, the effect isn’t incredible.  It’s probably not worth spending your immediate action just to allow an ally to use their highest level strike again when they have other options.

Bolstering Channel*:  Spend a standard action to recover a maneuver and channel energy.  Useless if you’re a Feyspeaker Druid or a non-Life Oracle.  And if you’re spending a standard action to channel energy, you might as well use your move action to Aid Another.

Battlefield Invocation**:  Expend a level 4+ spell slot while using a strike maneuver, and allies within 60 feet except for you heal 10*spell level HP, and gain +4 morale to attack and damage for one round.  While healing your allies for 40+ HP can be nice, enough Zealot levels will already give your party a big morale bonus to attack, and the bonus to damage isn’t as important at this level.  The worst part is that you need to spend a precious higher level spell slot in order to perform this underwhelming capstone.  Surely you can think of more impactful things to do with a 4th level spell slot than Cure Critical Wounds.

Final Ruling****:  Up to 6th level, it’s not too bad, even considering the action economy incompatibilities with Aid Another and Reach of the Divine.  High level spell casting is the most powerful thing in Pathfinder, after all.  You might not want to go past level 6, though, as the rest of the class features are not worth the levels, unless you really want to progress both maneuvers and casting.  This prestige class is best suited for classes that don’t have maneuver recovery as dominant as the Zealot, like Ordained Defender Warders.  If your goal is to heal and prevent damage to your team in combat, a straight Zealot build will likely be better since you’ll have a better chassis, more PP, better Martyrdom, and Improved Path of Dedication.  However, a Battle Templar can do all of the useful out-of-combat troubleshooting that typical full casters can do.

Bladecaster****:  [Link] A prestige class that progresses both maneuvers and arcane spellcasting.  Your choices for entering this are Sorcerer and Seducer Witch.  Sorcerers have slower progression and spontaneous spellcasting, but a superior spell list compared to Witches.

Prerequisites**:  Improved Counterspell is almost completely dead weight.  If you want to counter the wicked wiles of spellcasters, Path of War has many options in general for doing so, and a lot of maneuvers will let you counter spells without having to ready an action or spend a spell slot.  Combat Casting is useful since you’ll still need to cast defensively.  Consider getting the Voices of Solid Things trait to use cha instead of int for spellcraft.

Chassis***:  d10 HD, full BAB, 4 skill points/level, no proficiencies.  You’ll benefit from spellcraft as a class skill since you’ll need to identify spells.  Bad will save, for some reason.

Spellcasting****:  Progress your casting at levels 2 through 9.  To make up for the lost levels, you’ll need to take Favored Prestige Class and Prestigious Spellcaster.

Martial Caster (light):  No ASF in light armor.  Strap on your Celestial Armor and go to town!  This prestige class is better for dexterity-based builds than strength-based builds, since you’re limited to light armor.

Stance of Arcane Steel**:  A stance that lets you sacrifice a spell slot as a free action to gain a bonus to attack (insight), damage, AC, fortitude+reflex (insight), or energy resistance for 1/2/3 rounds.  Not worth using as a stance at low levels because the bonuses and duration are low, and you’ll have to expend precious resources to get any benefit.  Many 3rd level stances offer much greater benefits at all times.  It might be worth using once you reach level 9 and the bonus lasts 3 rounds, though.

Arcane Steel***:  Gain 2*spell level stacking THP when you cast a spell.  It’s not much, but it’s better than nothing.  Being tougher is good for anyone.

Arcane Recovery****:  Expend a spell slot as a free action to recover a maneuver of equal or lower level, and gain +2 caster level to your next spell.  Leaps and bounds better than the Battle Templar’s divine recovery ability, with better action economy and an additional benefit that any caster would love.  You might even use this for recovery purposes as a Zealot if you’re in a situation where you can’t Aid Another.

Battlecaster’s Strike****:  Cast touch range spells as a swift action when you use a strike maneuver against the same target.  It’s like Quicken Spell for free, and you don’t even need to use a stance like Mage Hunters do!  It’s too bad that you still have to cast defensively despite the spell being a swift action, and that it has a daily number of uses.  What’s more, this really only works on offensive spells, unlike what the Mage Hunter can do with buffs and utility spells.

Arcane Ruin***:  Damaging an enemy with a strike maneuver gives them a -2 penalty to AC and saves against your spells until the end of the encounter or until you recover maneuvers.  Oh dear.  It was looking so good up until that point.  But not to worry!  You still benefit from this thanks to Battlecaster’s Strike, because you’ll hit your foe with your strike right before using a swift action to cast a spell on them.

Martial Counterspell*:  Expend a counter as an immediate action when targeted by a spell to identify it with spellcraft and then negate it with an initiator level check.  If you’re fighting a caster who’s the same level as you, your chance to succeed on the check are 50% or less, because many casters increase their caster level beyond the norm.  And you might fail the spellcraft check to begin with if you’re especially unlucky.  There are a lot of counters that will help you defend against spells, and they’re especially worth taking if they let you protect allies rather than just yourself.  This ability is just too unreliable and poor compared to good counters.

Improved Battlecasting****:  Now you can use ranged touch spells with Battlecaster’s Strike.  This lets you use a ranged combat style which has certain benefits over melee.  Even if you’re a primarily melee character, this gives you a great option to fight at range, especially in combination with something like Sun’s Gleam.

Arcane Assault*****:  Add the effects of a maneuver to a spell with an attack roll as a free action.  This does a couple of amazing things.  First, it lets you effectively use a strike with a standard action, cast an attack spell as a swift action with Battlecaster’s Strike, and then use another strike all in the same turn.  That’s three separate effects all at once.  Second, it lets you turn melee-only strikes into ranged strikes with a 30 foot range!  This meshes incredibly well with the Zealot playstyle of using move actions for rapid maneuver recovery.

Final Ruling****:  It has some questionable design decisions and effectively wasted class features, but a strong chassis and arcane casting + initiator progression are enough to make this a great prestige class.  You’ll only lag one or two levels behind pure full casters while still gaining all the deliciousness of full initiator progression, and some disciplines like Riven Hourglass are utterly ludicrous for caster synergy.  

Daring Hero***:  From April Augmented 2016.  A quixotic protagonist that subconsciously rewrites reality to be more dramatic and yielding to their personal story!  It might seem like a joke (probably because it is, being from April Augmented), but it enables new builds and playstyles that are perfectly well suited to normal gameplay.

Prerequisites****:  Very reasonable, and Razor Wit actually is a decent feat.  While Zealots don't care much about damage, getting 1/2 cha mod to attack rolls on occasion is great.  And it's just fun to use!

Chassis****:  d10 HD, full BAB, 6 skill points/level, no proficiencies.  Look at that, with just one level, you've already recouped your skill rank investment!  You also get Acrobatics and Use Magic Device as class skills.

Cutting Words*****:  This lets you make any other PoW class charisma-based!  This opens up a tremendous number of new possibilities for dips.  Here are a few!

  • Harbinger (Omen Rider) 1:  1/2 cha mod to attack rolls and an extremely reliable mount.  The Mounted fighting style is great for any Zealot.
  • Mystic 3:  Every archetype is useful.  Gunsmoke Mystic lets you reload firearms as a free action, Aurora Soul gives you cha-to-AC in light armor and I/GUS, and both let you use a 3rd level Elemental Glyph to buff your whole party.  Knight-Chandler has a different array of buffs and lets your attacks inflict faerie fire.
  • Soulknife (Psychic Armory, War Soul) 3:  One place where the Zealous Blade feat can truly shine.  Now your panoply of blades uses charisma for attack and damage.
  • Stalker (Brutal Slayer) 2:  A ki pool, a stalker art, +4 profane bonus to strength when you crit, +cha to initiative and reflex, +1 natural armor to AC, and 1/2 strength-to-AC and reflex in place of dexterity.  This dip is best if you wear heavy armor, completely dump dexterity, and use a nodachi or fauchard.  Strength is very easy to increase compared to other stats because of size-stacking.
  • Stalker (Vigilante) 1:  Inspiration, sneak attack, trapfinding, and a stalker art or rogue/investigator talent.  For skillmonkey Zealots, if that tickles your fancy.
  • Unchained Rogue (Hidden Blade) 1:  Weapon Finesse, sneak attack, trapfinding, Quick Draw, and two gambits, one of which lets you turn invisible at will as a swift action.  You can get another archetype that trades out trapfinding like Rake or Thug for more debuffing capability or utility.
  • Warder 1: Great for all of the reasons in the Dipping section in addition to charisma-based Combat Reflexes.  If you wear light armor, you can get Dervish Defender for cha-to-AC, but you'll need to use a buckler + spiked gauntlet in one hand and a one-handed weapon in the other.  Good for Finesse Melee Zealots, Firearms Zealots, and Shooting Star Zealots.

Dramatic Entry***:  You're immune to damage from glass, falling damage when entering a scene from above, and add your Daring Hero level to Acrobatics, Disguise, and Strength checks for breaking doors and windows.  The main benefit is the bonus to Acrobatics, but skydiving into any scene safely without a parachute has merits!

Fame and Fortune***:  Plus or minus one initial attitude step with people who've heard of your reputation.  It makes diplomacy easier on NPCs who like what you do, but harder on NPCs who don't.  That means it'll be more difficult to seduce many enemies to your side.  It has upsides and downsides and is highly situational.

Effortless Parry*****:  Use 1/2/3 counters per encounter with no action!  The more counters you can use in a round or encounter, the safer your team is!
