No One Could Survive That**:  You auto-stabilize at negative HP and are immune to falling damage.  Honestly, this will almost never be useful.  Falling damage is a joke at high levels, and almost never comes into play.  You really should have some method of flight at higher levels.  But it'll save you a bit of damage against a high level Fool's Errand user.

Plot Armor****:  A stance that gives you 25% miss chance against attacks and abilities, or 50% if the enemy is an unimportant mook, and +class level damage against enemies significant to you.  It's inherently better than stances that give you a 20% miss chance like Inarguable Presence of the Sleeping Goddess, and since the vast majority of enemies will be nameless mooks, vastly better!  Note that it works against abilities too, not just physical attacks, meaning you can sometimes ignore spells.  Also, the range of "unimportant mook" broadens as you gain more levels and power.

In the Nick of Time*:  You always arrive on a scene at the most dramatic moment unless you or a potentially disadvantaged BBEG makes a will save.  This is almost completely bad for you.  You can't willingly make this work to your favor.  All you can do is try to prevent it from hindering you.  Good GMs already will pace stories and challenges in an appropriately dramatic and interesting way, and bad GMs can use this to screw you over.  The only benefit this has is that it allows you to unconsciously foil the plans of even the most thorough mastermind, even Ozymandias from Watchmen, provided they fail their save.

Fan Fiction**:  You gain 1000 * cha mod gold.  That's around 4000 to 7000, give or take.  At character level 13, that's around 4% of your 140,000 gp WBL.  A piddly drop in the bucket.  But at least it's better than nothing.

A True Hero Never Dies**:  You can't be killed by anything outside of a climactic moment, you gain cha-to-AC against unimportant mooks, and you're immortal until you decide otherwise.  The first part is too situational to rate as it depends entirely on the attitudes of the players and GM towards game lethality.  More AC is nice, but it only works against things that are incapable of killing you anyway.  If you're actually allowed to play this class up to level 10, it's likely safe to say that your GM isn't trying to end your character's life, development, and storyline with unimportant mooks.

Final Ruling***:  Take only 1, 3, or 5 levels in this prestige class, and don't bother with the rest.  A level 1 dip is incredible for poaching useful dips from other PoW classes you otherwise wouldn't be able to.  Effortless Parry and Plot Armor are great for being the best tank you can be, but you'll have to spend 4 more levels past 1st in order to get them, with little else to show for it.  There are many other good stances to use.  Just 1 level is the best bang for your buck.  Your GM might not allow this prestige class because it came from a book released on April Fools' Day, but at the end of the day, foolish or not, we're just here to have fun!

Dragon Fury*:  [Link] A dual wielding full-attacker that focuses on nothing but pure damage.  Big numbers might look impressive at a glance, but does it provide anything useful to a Zealot for helping their party?

Prerequisites*:  Two extremely weak feats.  Taking Discipline Focus for Thrashing Dragon is almost a complete waste because it only has two maneuvers that force a saving throw.  Those two maneuvers are very good, but certainly not worth spending a feat to focus on.  And they don’t even work with full-attacking, the focus of this prestige class.

Chassis****:  d12 HD, full BAB, 4 skill points/level, no proficiencies.  More hitpoints to tank more damage!  But it has a good reflex save and a bad will save, which is less ideal.

Dragon Fury Training***:  Progress your uses per day for bardic performance, ki, and rage.  Moderately useful if you dip a level of Rubato Bard or Bloodrager.

Dual Fang Focus*:  Gain a competence bonus to attack and damage when two-weapon fighting.  A couple problems with this.  When you use “two-weapon fighting,” it doesn’t mean whenever you attack while wielding two weapons.  It means using a full attack to fight with two weapons.  That goes against the grain of your Zealot playstyle of using standard action strikes.  Also, it’s a competence bonus, so it doesn’t stack with things like Inspire Courage.

Sharp Fang*:  Get Power Attack for free, and your offhand weapon has full damage bonus from strength and power attack rather than half.  This is just a pure damage increase and only when two-weapon fighting.  It doesn’t offer any utility and is difficult for a Zealot to use efficiently.

Dance of Thrashing Claws***:  While in a TD stance and using a BB, PF, or TD counter, you can use that counter twice per round.  Incredible!  Being able to use more counters is exactly what Zealots want!  But there’s a huge problem.  Thrashing Dragon stances are kind of awful for Zealots, and none of the compatible counters can be used to help allies.  If you dip a level of Rajah, you could use your counters for allies via Vassalage, though.

Dragon Fury Defense*:  Gain a shield bonus to AC when wielding two weapons and in a BB, PF, or TD stance.  This shield bonus doesn’t stack with other shield bonuses, and the stances from those disciplines are mostly damage-oriented rather than utility-oriented.  Getting Improved Shield Bash and using a shield as one (or both) of your weapons gives you more AC.

Vicious Fang*:  Your weapons have a 1.5x damage bonus from strength and power attack.  Another boring damage increase with no utility.

Deadly Fang Recovery**:  Recover 1 maneuver when you kill an enemy while using an in-class discipline strike or full attack.  It’s useful for instantly recovering the godly standard action full attack strikes from Primal Fury, especially Cornered Frenzy Strike which is a full round action.  Otherwise, it’s terrible, because Zealots are already great at maneuver recovery.

Dragon War God’s Dance*:  A stance that lets you, as a full round action, perform a full attack with +4d6 damage and move twice your speed while attacking.  It has a fairly lengthy time limit that’s unlikely to be reached, but it’s always possible if your GM creates a long encounter.  This stance offers no passive benefits and discourages you from using strike maneuvers.

Final Ruling*:  Utterly terrible for Zealots.  It gives you damage damage damage when using a very particular playstyle: full attacking with two weapons while in a Thrashing Dragon stance.  It’s almost not worth being called a Path of War prestige class because it focuses so hard on using full attacks rather than maneuvers.  This exists for Dervish Defender Warders and Warlords who want nothing more than to faceroll encounters with large throbbing numbers.  Great for encouraging Barbarian players to try Path of War, I suppose!

Landsknecht**:  [Link] A soldier who focuses on using a single one handed weapon and dealing with huge crowds of enemies without breaking a sweat!  A strange combination of themes, but tanking and controlling hordes of enemies is something Zealots should be good at, so this should be an easy choice to take, right?  Let’s see...

Prerequisites****:  Not difficult at all!  You’ll almost certainly have Combat Reflexes one way or another, and though Quick Draw isn’t desired by everyone, it’s easy to get with a dip of Bushi Warder or Bushi Warlord.  You don’t even need to spend any skill points!

Chassis***:  d10 HD, full BAB, 4 skill points/level, no proficiencies.  You gain acrobatics and perform as class skills, and have a good reflex save, but a poor will save.

Threatening Demeanor***:  You threaten with sheathed weapons.  A slightly less powerful version of Improved Quick Draw, which also lets you sheathe after making AoOs.  Still, useful for a Mithral Current user, and could save a feat.

Strength of Arms**:  You get 1.5x strength damage when using a single weapon in one hand.  A decent damage increase, not that Zealots particularly care about that.

Never Outnumbered****:  A bonus to attack and damage when threatening +2 opponents.  More accuracy is always a good thing!  This encourages you to plop yourself into the center of the fray as much as possible, which tank characters should be doing already.  Too bad it doesn’t work against single enemies.

Uncanny Dodge****:  With this, you can use a counter on the first round of combat, which could be crucial for saving your allies from a great deal of pain!  And since the Landsknecht likes to be threatening as many enemies at once, being immune to flanking is very helpful.

Surprising Strike***:  You can use a standard action strike maneuver in place of an AoO, but only  a few times per day.  Stopping enemies dead with debuffing strikes is excellent, but you can already accomplish this with your AoOs by using Seize the Opportunity.  However, many strikes have effects that not even the ever-useful dirty trick maneuver can compete with, so this gives some nice utility, though the daily usage limit is unfortunate for a PoW class.

Superior Reach*****:  +5 reach!  It doesn’t work with every fighting style the way the Protection Mission does, but it stacks with all other reach increases.

Mobile Attacker****:  Once per round, you make a free attack when you move as part of a maneuver or move action, up to cha mod times per encounter.  This gives you several free attacks every encounter if you make judicious use of teleportation strikes, or counters that move you!  Even something as small as the 5 foot step from Flowing Creek (Mithral Current 1) will trigger the bonus attack.

Silver Crown Strike**:  A standard action strike that does a full attack with Pummeling Style applied.  When Pummeling Style was released, forums were abuzz declaring it the most powerful combat feat in the game, as it and its upgrade Pummeling Charge allowed Paizo martials to effectively pounce and not worry about damage reduction.  But we’re not playing with only Paizo material, that’s kiddy stuff!  We’re playing with Path of War!  And we’re Zealots, not full attackers!  If you want a multi-attack standard action strike, grab Frenzy Strike (Primal Fury 3).  You’ll get it much earlier, and can have many more attacks.        

Bait the Dragon**:  Spend a swift action and suffer -4 AC, and you can make an AoO against melee attackers after they finish their attack.  It’s like Come and Get Me with worse action economy, and you can’t kill the enemy before they finish attacking you.  This kind of playstyle is fine for Barbarians who are focused on dealing massive damage and soaking hits right to their face, but is antithetical to Zealots who prefer to tank by applying debuffs and negating damage.

Stance of Assured Victory*****:  Your allies gain cha mod circumstance bonus to attack, and enemies provoke an AoO from one of your allies within 30 feet.  The circumstance bonus to attack stacks with everything, and you give your heaviest hitters many more attacks per round, provided they have Combat Reflexes or some other way to get more AoOs.  Even your ranged allies can take AoOs!  An absolutely amazing, universally useful stance, but it’s too bad you had to suffer through an otherwise mediocre prestige class for so long to get it.

Final Ruling**:  The Landsknecht gets a lot of nice little class features that many martials will find useful, but there are a few problems.  The rate at which you get the class features are pretty spread out, and for every level you take in Landsknecht, that’s a level you CAN’T take in something else, like, say, Zealot.  So the individual power of each Landsknecht level is fairly weak.  Another problem is that it focuses on damage, not a strength of the Zealot.  A regular Zealot with a lucerne hammer, a heavy shield, Shield Brace, Seize the Opportunity, and minor metamorphosis honestly would be better at damage, AC, and reach, and wouldn’t sacrifice the progression of Zealot class features.

Mage Hunter****:  [Link] An anti-magic specialist who gets 6th level spells in only 10 levels!  They’re perfect for stripping magical defenses off of enemies and preventing them from teleporting, and have great action economy with powerful spells.

Prerequisites**:  You need to waste a feat on Step Up, which requires an immediate action, and is largely completely useless considering all of the other useful mobility tools you have with Path of War.  At least Improved Initiative is always good.

Chassis**:  d8 HD, medium BAB, 4 skill points/level, no proficiencies, good reflex save, poor will save.  But you do gain some good class skills like Use Magic Device.

Spells*****:  You get 6th level spells with only 10 levels in the prestige class!  Medium casting base classes like Bards and Magi have to wait until they’re level 16 to get 6th level spells!  And you use the Magus spell list, which has a ton of excellent buffing, offensive, and battlefield control spells!  That’s right, you can have 6th level Magus spells at level 15, one level BEFORE an actual Magus does!  And your caster level equals your initiator level, so multiclassing doesn’t hinder you nearly as much as it would a regular Magus!

Arcane Tenacity***:  +6 to the DC to dispel your spells.  Your buffs and debuffs are much harder for enemies to get rid of, and the bonus is absolutely enormous!  Enemies that actually try to make extensive use of dispelling are rare, though.

Martial Arcanist****:  No ASF with light (eventually medium) armor or bucklers, and you get Disruptive and Spellbreaker.  A mithril breastplate (or celestial plate armor) and buckler are perfectly serviceable for armor, and you also have your spells to protect yourself.  The feats go a long way in ruining the day of casters, as casting defensively isn’t a guaranteed thing in PF.

Anchoring Point****:  Expend a spell as a free action when you hit with a strike to use dimensional anchor.  Saving throw: none!  For the mere cost of a 1st level spell, you can completely ruin the day of an outsider with Greater Teleport, a Veiled Moon user, or obviously a spellcaster, for the huge duration of 10 rounds, and suffer no blow to your action economy.  

Strike of Dispelling****:  Normal damage, and you use a targeted dispel magic on your target with +1d6 damage per effect dispelled.  It’s nice that this doesn’t take up one of your maneuvers readied and can be used at any time.  You can dispel virtually anything at will now, from enemy wizards to traps to illusions, and can do it with the safety of ranged weapons!

Arcane Endurance***:  Your spell durations are doubled.  It likely won’t be of much use in the short length of most combats since your CL = your IL, but it’s great for improving the efficacy of your long-duration buffs over the course of an adventuring day.

Stance of the Mage Killer*****:  You can cast a spell as a swift action as part of a strike, and take no effect from spells when you save against them.  The first part is incredible for action economy and effectively gives you Quicken Spell to everything for free.  Combined with Arcane Endurance, that’s +5 levels worth of metamagic on every spell you cast.  You can quickly and easily throw up useful buffs like Haste and Mirror Image, or battlefield control spells like Glitterdust and Stinking Cloud, or even offensive spells like Chill Touch.  I’m fond of Bladed Dash, letting you move and attack with a big circumstance bonus.  The second part of this stance is wonderful for helping you take less damage and fewer debuffs overall.

Mage Hunter Concentration****:  +4 to cast defensively, and +2 insight to saves.  If you’re using Stance of the Mage Killer, you’re casting spells as swift actions, so you probably will almost never need to cast defensively.  Better saves are always welcome, though.

Tethering Point**:  Normal damage, and for 1 minute per spell level, your target must make a will save whenever it tries to teleport, and you can either negate the poofaport or go along for the ride.  Since Anchoring Point inflicts dimensional anchor with no save, there’s little reason to use this.  If you go along for the ride, there’s no telling where your enemy will take you, but it’s probably not going to be a good place for you.  It could be miles away from your allies, be in an inhospitable environment for you, or have other enemies hostile to you!

Strike of Magic Rending*****:  Replaces Strike of Dispelling.  Normal damage, you use a targeted greater dispel magic on your target, and can choose to use an area greater dispel magic on everyone within 10 feet, with +2d6 damage per effect dispelled.  Same juicy functionality as its predecessor, only now with more damage, a higher chance to succeed, and lots of collateral dispelling!

Mage Harrier Stance*:  Enemies in reach can’t cast defensively unless they make a DC 21 knowledge (martial) or spellcraft check, you have 15+IL SR, and you gain THP whenever you resist a spell.  The DC is so laughably low that any spellcaster worth their salt is going to ignore the primary function of the stance and then pelt you with spells that ignore SR.

Final Ruling****:  The biggest benefit of this prestige class is the incredibly fast spellcasting progression.  6th level spells with only 10 levels of investment.  The other class features offer good utility that is difficult to replicate with maneuvers or magic items.  You can easily throw a wrench in a BBEG’s plans if they were planning to try and escape with a teleport, or rely on lots of buffs to fight you in combat.  Make sure to get Gloves of Arcane Striking to vastly increase the amount of AC you grant when using Aid Another!

Phoenix Champion****:  [Link] An angelic archer who combines unmatched ranged support with incredible crowd control, not to mention decent damage and great mobility.  It lacks the complexity of other prestige classes like Awakened Blade, but it provides a straightforward and powerful improvement to what makes Zealots great, and the reduced complexity can be an attractive selling point to many players!  Don’t mistake that for a lack of versatility, though.

Prerequisites****:  No skill point requirements, and the feats required are all good.  Discipline Focus might seem like a bit of a tax if you prefer to use combat maneuver strikes over save strikes, but it benefits Phoenix Wing Strike from this prestige class.

Chassis***:  d10 HD, full BAB, 4 skill points/level, no proficiencies, good reflex save, poor will save.  Ever so slightly worse than a regular Zealot, but not a big deal.

Burning Bow***:  Your ranged attacks as part of a maneuver deal +1d6 fire damage.  The fact that you only get the damage bonus as part of a maneuver means that it is perfect for Zealots compared to full attacker classes!  Sure, Zealots don’t care much about damage, but every little bit helps, especially when the class feature goes out of its way to benefit the Zealot playstyle.  Sadly, this doesn’t seem to help area attacks like Phoenix Wing Strike, because it’s not a ranged attack roll.

Eye of the Heavens****:  Darkvision, blindsense, and truesight!  No matter who you are, better senses are good for everyone!  This will help you shoot invisible enemies and outline them with Solar Wind Style’s faerie fire to help your team.

Phoenix Wing Strike*****:  A standard action strike that shoots a 30 foot cone for 1d6*IL damage, half fire and half sacred, and creatures inside must make a reflex save for half damage.  Well, an area-effect strike certainly is nothing to sneeze at when you’re up against swarms or hordes of mooks.  But at 6th level, it upgrades to something much better, and lets you heal, blind, or trip people in the blast!  The versatility means that it will be useful in a great many situations.  It only recovers when you recover maneuvers, but that’s what Zealots do best!

Phoenix’s Cunning****:  Add ½ your Phoenix Champion level to combat maneuver checks with ranged weapons.  Your versatile debuffing abilities become all that more reliable!

Rising Phoenix Dance****:  A stance that grants a fly speed and an aura that grants protection from evil and +1 attack and damage vs evil creatures to you and your allies within 30 feet.  Absolutely incredible if you regularly fight evil creatures, giving an even bigger offensive boost to your party than a level 20 bard using inspire courage.  Which it stacks with.  You’ll probably want to switch to a different stance if you know you won’t be fighting evil enemies, though.

Cleansing Flames*****:  When you initiate a maneuver that uses a ranged attack, an ally within 60 feet gets to reroll a saving throw for free!  Let’s face it, you can’t always save your allies from every negative condition that comes their way before it affects them.  Removing their debuffs as quickly as possible is crucial to getting them back into the fight at top performance.  It can also save a lot of lives if you remove dominate person from your party’s heavy hitter.  Note that this ability doesn’t have a limit on how many times you can use it per round, and you can use it even with maneuvers that aren’t strikes, as long as they use a ranged attack.  Deflecting Shot (Tempest Gale 2), False Wind (Tempest Gale 5), and Intercepting Shade (Solar Wind 2) are perfect counters for this.

Solar Inspiration****:  +10 insight to diplomacy and perception, and the sacred portion of your Phoenix Wing Strike always deals full damage!  I can’t think of anyone who wouldn’t want such a massive perception boost.

Final Ruling****:  The Phoenix Champion’s class features mesh perfectly with the playstyle of a Zealot, and all of them are excellent.  You will want to use a strike and counter maneuver every round and recover them as often as possible to grant two rerolls per round with Cleansing Flames.  Zealots are the best class for recovering multiple maneuvers on demand.  If you’re a non-evil Ranged Zealot, strongly consider hopping into this prestige class.  It’s safe, simple, reliable, reactive, and still versatile.  The only problem is that the class features come slowly.  Level 1 is nearly a dead level, and so is 2 if you already have darkvision.  Stick with Zealot for a couple more levels instead of immediately entering Phoenix Champion, and retrain your class levels later.

Umbral Blade***:  [Link] An assassin who specializes in using darkness to ambush with burst damage.  Oddly for the concept of an assassin, this prestige class is incredibly durable.  It has d10 HD and several class features that improve its defenses.

Prerequisites***:  Not as painful as others.  6 knowledge (planes) ranks isn’t too thrilling, but at least Discipline Focus (Veiled Moon) isn’t totally useless.  You have to be level 6, but only need 4 BAB, giving you the opportunity to get a couple useful dips of classes with less than full BAB.

Chassis***:  d10 HD, full BAB, 4 skill points/level, no proficiencies, good reflex save, poor fort and will save.  Ever so slightly worse than a regular Zealot, but not a big deal.

Shadow Blade***:  Your Veiled Moon weapons can be used with Weapon Finesse, deal +1d6 cold damage, and can use your charisma instead of strength for damage.  It takes a swift action to activate this, so it’s better for melee rather than throwing weapons.  Poor throwing weapon users.  They just can’t catch a break.  The functionality of Shadow Blade isn’t too impressive, as light weapons are already finessable, double weapons aren’t good for Zealots, and you can simply pick up a COWPIS and elven branched spear if you use a spear.  The rest of the ability simply gives you a bit more damage.

Umbral Sight****:  Darkvision 60, or +30 feet to existing darkvision.  Better senses are always a good thing!  And darkvision is nigh mandatory for stealth users.

Blade of Night**:  You steal a class feature from the Soulknife.  Charge your weapon for a bit more damage on a successful strike.  It encourages you to use it during a full attack since it applies to all attacks you make in one round.  As such, it meshes horribly with the Zealot playstyle, and will only wind up adding a tiny amount of extra damage per combat.

Embrace the Shadows*****:  A Veiled Moon stance.  Your Steel Serpent, Thrashing Dragon, and Veiled Moon DCs increase by 2, and you get +2 intimidate and stealth per class level, +2 natural armor, and +2 saves.  It used to have a time limit, but that was removed in the errata!  That greatly improves your action economy since you don’t need to spend actions entering it and using Shadow Consumption to turn incorporeal every combat.  The skill bonuses are absolutely massive and useful both in and out of combat, and the other bonuses make you a better tank and debuffer.

Shadow Consumption*****:  Your Embrace of the Shadows stance gains more benefits!  You get to use cha instead of con for HP and fortitude, use blink at will, and eventually become incorporeal at will as a standard action.  You can be completely and totally cha-SAD and get cha to HP and deflection to AC, and be nigh invulnerable.

Shadowblind****:  Hide in Plain Sight in dim illumination or darkness.  Unlike a Ranger, it doesn’t matter what type of terrain you’re in, as long as it’s dark enough!  Unless the entire area is well lit, this is effectively invisibility at will.

Terror in the Dark***:  You can use the stealth skill as a swift action!  Well, it would be more exciting if you were a class that could really benefit from it, rather than a Zealot.  You can use it to escape from combat or make it easier to hit a now flat-footed enemy, but it means you won’t be using a more supportive boost or counter to help your allies.

One with the Dark*****:  Change type to Outsider (native), gain the benefits of Embrace the Shadows at all times, and gain cold resistance 10 and DR 10/silver.  A suitably awesome capstone!  Embrace the Shadows is a great stance, and any ability in general that lets you be in two stances at once is worth a lot.  Now you don’t have to worry about spending a swift action at the start of every combat, and can also use any other stance you want!  And you become even tougher, as if you weren’t tough enough already.

Final Ruling***:  Not a bad prestige class by any means.  The bonuses it provides are respectable and make you incredibly difficult to kill.  But it does nothing at all to help you protect your teammates, who are the ones in real need of your protection.  In a conventional party, a durable assassin prestige class on a low-damage support class doesn’t have much of a place.  It would be a better pick in campaigns that focus on winning through strategy rather than through tactics.  Notably, you can be completely charisma-SAD and get cha to damage, AC, and HP with this prestige class.  A spooky dark chaotic neutral Desna worshipper would fit well!How to Keep Track of Everything

Hokay.  So.  Zealots have a lot of resources and effects to keep track of.  A LOT.  Even experienced Zealots can get caught up in the heat of the moment and forget to use one of their many free actions or account for one of the bonuses they applied to their party.  And the more experienced they become, the more they have to keep track of!  Luckily, I’m here to help organize those pesky things and provide useful tips on playing a Zealot efficiently with a minimum of tearing your own hair out.  First, let’s list out the resources to keep track of.

  • Hit points and temporary hit points
  • Power points
  • Maneuvers, possibly from multiple classes
  • Your current stance
  • Standard action
  • Move action
  • Swift/Immediate action
  • Attacks of Opportunity
  • Psionic Focus
  • Deep Focus or Psicrystal Containment
  • Martyrdom, free action once per round
  • Echoes of Steel
  • At level 12, Martyrdom once per Collective member per round
  • Improved Path of Dedication once per round
  • Activatable Mission abilities like Eternal Rebirth (Creation), Living Bastion (Protection), and Unbreakable Fortress’ second augment (Protection)
  • Resource points from class dips, like grit/panache, animus/tempo, bardic performance rounds, lay on hands/guardian’s shield, rage rounds, protector familiar’s HP, etc

The list goes on and on.  And that’s not even counting the buffs you provide for yourself or your party.  You need to remind your party members of buffs you’ve applied to them, like Zeal and Aid Another.  If you use boosts that have a duration like Time Skitter or Armory of the Sleeping Goddess, you need to keep track of them too!  Zealots have to be attentive for the entirety of combat in order to do their jobs well.  Right now, if you’re thinking “finally, a tank/support class with meaningful choices and a high level of engagement,” then yay!  The Zealot class is for you!  But if you’re thinking “good gravy, this is too complex,” then hold on a minute.  Don’t panic.  With a bit of organization and preparation, you can make everything run seamlessly.

First, get a little dry erase board checklist.  It’s easier to keep track of a lot of moving parts if you can simply modify a name or erase a number or checkmark.  Write down the resources that regularly fluctuate from round to round, and things that you find yourself forgetting.  You don’t need to write down every single resource.  This is just a tool for helping you keep things straight.

Next, get some note cards and write down your maneuvers on them.  You can either write just the names down, or the descriptions and effects as well.  Color code them based on whether they’re strikes, boosts, or counters.  If you’ve multiclassed with another initiator class, you’ll need another set of colors to differentiate them.  When you expend maneuvers, flip them over or put them in a pile to the side.

Also with the note cards, write down the buffs you commonly apply to your party like Zeal, Aid Another, and Encouraging Roar, and debuffs your party should be aware of like Harmony-Shattering Strike.  Put them on the table in view of everyone or hand them to the player you’re buffing, and put them away when not in effect.

If you’re playing in an online tabletop program like maptools or roll20, there are loads of features you can use to keep track of everything.  You can put status symbols on tokens to mark buffs and debuffs, use the drawing tools to mark areas of effect, and even write text right on the playing field so that everybody knows how many plusses you’re giving them.

Here is an example screenshot of it in action with a heroic Zealot and Paladin battling a vile cornugon!  The Zealot keeps track of her power points with her blue bar.  There’s also a 3rd bar in roll20 you can use to track another number that goes up and down, like temporary HP or animus/tempo.  She uses the status symbol that looks like an ioun stone to keep track of her psionic focus, and in this case, it has a 2 because she is both psionically focused and using Deep Focus.  The cornugon’s status symbol shows that he’s Shaken.  The text in the upper left, written by the Zealot’s player, helps her remember what stance and buffs she has active and what abilities she still has available.  Finally, the box in the lower left tracks initiative.  Just remember that other players can see your writing, so don’t clutter up the entire battlefield!

Equipment

Just like other martial characters, Zealots need The Big Six™ to keep up with Pathfinder’s math as they level up.  These are a magic weapon, magic armor, cloak of resistance, amulet of natural armor, ring of protection, and stat belt/headband.  Steelforge 1 by Dreamscarred Press introduces a Variant Rule: Combating Christmas Trees, which allows you to put numerical bonus enchantments on any equippable magic item.  The numerical bonuses available include enhancement to ability scores, deflection to AC, armor to AC, natural armor to AC, energy resistance against one element, resistance to saving throws, and competence to skill checks.  You can even add many of these bonuses onto the same item without multiplying the cost the way something like a Belt of Physical Might does.  This variant rule gives you a lot more options to select for your belt, headband, neck, shoulders, and ring slots.  Ask your GM if you may use it.  The ratings below are rated with the assumption that you can’t and are using the normal rules.

Weapons

Obviously, your choice of weapon will be determined by your fighting style.  It’s also possible to not have to buy a weapon at all, and rely on laser beams, Sleeping Goddess boosts, or a Soulknife dip to create weapons.  Check the Soulknife part of the Dipping and Multiclassing section for more info.  Now, let’s look at what the best weapons for each fighting style are!

One-hander:

  • Gandasa, Nine-Ring Broadsword, Trident, or Warhammer***:  The highest damage martial axe, heavy blade + monk, spear, and hammer one-handers, respectively.  No additional investment needed.  Check the Discipline Weapon Group Cheat Sheet below to see which is best for your disciplines.
  • Armor Spikes****:  A hands-free weapon you should get if you mainly use a reach weapon so that you can attack enemies who are inside your reach deadzone.
  • Bastard Sword, Broken-Back Seax, Dwarven Waraxe, or Urumi****:  The highest damage exotic heavy blade, light blade, axe, and flail + monk one-handers, respectively.  Though Zealots don’t care much about damage or crits, having a Cracked Opalescent White Pyramid Ioun Stone (or COWPIS for short) in a Wayfinder gives you an additional +1 attack, which Zealots love.
  • Scorpion Whip*****:  A one-handed flail reach weapon!  If you’re also proficient with regular whips, you can initiate strikes from 15 feet away with it.  Great for Maenads.  If you’re not a Maenad, you need a COWPIS to wield it, since it’s exotic.  Dip a level of Rubato Bard to also become proficient with regular whips.
  • Any polearm or spear with Pikeman’s Training or Shield Brace*****:  Now you can have reach with a shield and a high weapon damage dice all in one!

Two-hander:

  • Earthbreaker or Greatsword**:  A 2d6 martial hammer and heavy blade, respectively.  If you don’t want a reach weapon for some reason, these are the highest damage martial two-handers.
  • Lucerne Hammer****:  A martial polearm with reach, 1d12 damage, 2 damage types, brace, and is a discipline weapon for Eternal Guardian and Radiant Dawn.  The 1d12 is significant because it scales better than weapons with lower damage when you gain size increases.  A large lucerne hammer will deal 3d6 damage, whereas a large bardiche will deal 2d8.  Polearms are great because they can be used with Polearm Dancer, Pikeman’s Training, and Shield Brace.  Excellent weapon from level 1 to 20.
  • Nodachi***:  A 1d10 martial heavy blade and polearm.  Though it lacks reach, it’s an interesting choice because it has the advantages of both weapon groups.  
  • Tri-point Double-Edged Sword***:  A 1d10 martial reach monk weapon.  Unfortunately, a lot of disciplines like Sleeping Goddess don’t use polearms as a discipline weapon, so this is the next best thing.
  • Butchering Axe*****:  A 3d6 exotic axe.  For the highest damage Zenith Strikes!
  • Elven Branched Spear*****:  A 1d8 exotic spear that gives +2 to attack with AoOs!  This is a better option than other weapons for AoO builds because accuracy is more important than weapon damage dice.  Elves are automatically proficient.
  • Flying Blade****:  A 1d12 exotic flail reach weapon that gives +2 to attack with AoOs but -2 to attack otherwise.  Combines the damage of the Lucerne Hammer, the AoO bonus of Elven Branched Spear, and the free proficiency of being a Maenad!  Because of the penalty, it might be best to use this as a secondary weapon purely for AoOs, and otherwise use a different fighting style like Laser Beams to deliver your strike maneuvers.

Archery:

  • Adaptive Composite Longbow****:  No muss, no fuss, a gold standard.
  • Orc Hornbow*****:  A 2d6, 80 range exotic bow.  Half-Orcs are automatically proficient.  More damage is nice, and usually the decrease in range isn’t a problem.
  • Light Crossbow with a Least Autoloader Magazine****:  An interesting alternative for saving money as long as your campaign doesn’t run over 45 adventuring days.  See Wondrous Items sections for more details.

Finesse melee:

  • Handaxe, Light Mace, Rapier, or Tonfa***:  The highest damage martial axe, hammer, light blade, and close + monk finesse weapons, respectively.  No investment needed.
  • Estoc****:  An incredible 2d4 18-20 x2 exotic heavy blade!
  • Any polearm or spear with Polearm Dancer*****:  Now you get to enjoy the splendor of the Lucerne Hammer and Elven Branched Spear as well!

Firearms:

  • Pistol***:  It’s not spectacular on its own, but it’s what you have to start with if you dip a level of Desperado Privateer Warlord.  Ask your GM if it’s okay to start with a Dragoon Pistol as your battered firearm instead, as they both have a price of 1000 gp.
  • Dragoon Pistol*****:  It has the same stats as a regular pistol, except it has 3x crit, 30 ft range increment, and capacity 3.  Much better!
  • All Two-handed Firearms*:  The longer reload time, increased misfire chance, and two-handed requirement outweigh the benefits.
  • Revolver*****:  If your GM allows advanced firearms, this is your best bet!
  • Tube Arrow Shooter****:  This isn’t a firearm, it’s a backup weapon!  Wear one on each arm to have a couple of backup shots in case you can’t get a chance to reload.

Shooting Star:  Only one choice, a starknife!

Crimson Totem:  This one should be obvious, too!

Q: The Scorpion Whip is confusing.  How does it work?

A: If you're only proficient with a scorpion whip, then it's just a light reach weapon. It threatens at the same range any other reach weapon, and can't attack inside your reach deadzone. You can't strike out to 15 feet with it. HOWEVER! If you're proficient with both a regular whip and scorpion whip, then you can also strike out to 15 feet, and also strike inside your reach deadzone. Being proficient with both gives you the best of three worlds: Reach + Shield fighting style, extra range for initiating strikes, and no worrying about your reach deadzone. You'll still need armor spikes (or Improved Whip Mastery) in order to use AoOs inside your deadzone, though.  If you’re not a maenad, you can get whip proficiency with a level of Rubato Bard, and use a COWPIS for scorpion whip proficiency.

Q: What do discipline weapons really do?  Do I need to have a discipline weapon to use a discipline’s maneuvers?

A: No.  Thanks to the errata, Piercing Thunder is currently the only discipline that has particular weapon requirements.  You can use any weapon you want for any discipline.  If you use a discipline weapon, you add +2 to the DC of your maneuvers that force saving throws.  That’s all!

Discipline Weapon Group Cheat Sheet

Axes:  Black Seraph, Iron Tortoise, Primal Fury, Unquiet Grave

Bows:  Radiant Dawn, Silver Crane, Solar Wind, Tempest Gale

Close:  Broken Blade, Iron Tortoise, Shattered Mirror, Steel Serpent, Thrashing Dragon

Crossbows:  Solar Wind, Tempest Gale

Double:  Thrashing Dragon, Veiled Moon

Firearms:  Solar Wind, Tempest Gale

Flails:  Black Seraph, Radiant Dawn, Riven Hourglass, Sleeping Goddess

Hammers:  Eternal Guardian, Golden Lion, Primal Fury, Radiant Dawn, Riven Hourglass, Silver Crane

Heavy Blades:  Cursed Razor, Eternal Guardian, Golden Lion, Iron Tortoise, Mithral Current, Primal Fury, Scarlet Throne, Shattered Mirror, Sleeping Goddess

Light Blades:  Cursed Razor, Elemental Flux, Mithral Current, Riven Hourglass, Scarlet Throne, Shattered Mirror, Steel Serpent, Thrashing Dragon, Veiled Moon

Monk:  Broken Blade, Elemental Flux, Sleeping Goddess, Steel Serpent

Natural:  Broken Blade, Chimera Soul, Unquiet Grave

Polearms:  Black Seraph, Eternal Guardian, Golden Lion, Mithral Current, Piercing Thunder, Radiant Dawn, Unquiet Grave

Spears:  Cursed Razor, Piercing Thunder, Scarlet Throne, Silver Crane, Sleeping Goddess, Veiled Moon

Thrown:  Elemental Flux, Solar Wind, Tempest Gale

Note, Fool’s Errand has all weapons as discipline weapons.

Weapon Modifications:

Adventurer’s Armory 2 provides new options in the form of weapon modifications.  They make the weapon’s category (simple, martial, or exotic) increase by one step.  The only one of interest to Zealots is Versatile Design (+500 gp), which allows the modified weapon to be considered a weapon of another weapon group.  Now you can have a longspear that’s also a heavy blade!  You can take the Weapon Adept feat to remove the drawback of its category increasing.

Magic Weapon Enhancements: 

Enhancement Bonus (+1 to +5)*****:  Boring, but practical.  Increasing your accuracy makes your strike maneuvers land more often, and strikes can’t impart their cool effects if they don’t hit!  Sufficiently high enhancement bonuses also let you bypass certain types of damage reduction.

Benevolent (+1)****:  Increase your Aid Another bonus to attack by the enhancement bonus of your weapon!

Corrosive/Flaming/Frost/Shock (+1)*:  If you attack only once per round, 1d6 extra damage isn’t worth the price.

Courageous (+1)*:  According to this FAQ, it only increases your saves vs fear.  It doesn’t increase all morale bonuses like people hoped.

Cruel (+1)*****:  Feared enemies you hit get sickened with no save!  And considering how ludicrously easy it is to inflict fear effects, this is kind of bonkers.

Dazzling Radiance (+1)***:  Dazzle and potentially blind creatures within 15 feet of you when you use Dazzling Display.  Spiffy extra debuffing, just make sure you don’t hit your allies!

Dueling (PFSG) (+1)*****:  (Credit to upho!)  Every +1 bonus on your weapon now gives you a total of +3 to several combat maneuvers, including both trip and dirty trick.  Dirty Tricking your enemies into submission just got that much easier!

Dueling (UE) (+14000 gp)*****:  Same name as the PFSG one, but totally different effect.  A +4 bonus to initiative, and it’s a flat cost!  Everyone should get this eventually, even if it’s just on a spiked gauntlet that you never attack with.

Fortuitous (+1)****:  Once per round, when you make an AoO, you get to make a second AoO with a -5 penalty for free!

Furious (+1)*****:  While you’re raging, your enhancement bonus is +2 better.  If you can replenish your rage rounds like a Primal Disciple Barbarian, you’ll pretty much always benefit from this!  And anything that increases your enhancement bonus makes Dueling (PFSG) and Leveraging that much more insane.

Leveraging (+1)****:  (Credit to upho!)  For trip-using builds.  Your weapon’s enhancement bonus is doubled when using trip, drag, reposition, and bull rush.  And it stacks with the bonus from Dueling (PFSG) to make for some crazy trip bonuses!

Lucky (+1)****:  For Firearm Zealots.  Once per day, you can reroll a natural 1 on your pistol’s attack roll.  Turn a miss into a potential hit, and prevent a misfire!

Menacing (+1)****:  Increase the attack bonus for flanking by +2 for all flanking allies.  Combine with Golden Commander’s Stance to make this bonus easier to take advantage of.

Reliable (+1)*****:  For Firearm Zealots.  Your dragoon pistol won’t misfire and break anymore!  If you have Amateur Gunslinger (Quick Clear), retrain it out once you get this.

Training (+1)*****:  (Credit to Mithral Leaf!)  Your weapon gives you one bonus combat feat.  Situational on a regular weapon, but if you combine it with the Greater Transformative arrow cheat trick “clever use of game mechanics,” you can have a ton of combat feats at your disposal to pick and choose from at a moment’s notice.  The weapon must be “drawn and in hand” to give you the feat, so it’s possible you could get two +1 Training spiked gauntlets for an easy couple feats at only 8302 gp each.  If your GM allows that, it’s a great choice.

Cyclonic (+2)***:  Your ranged attacks aren’t impaired by wind, water, or other enviornmental factors.  A handy feature to have if you’re up against enemies with wind wall or fickle winds and can’t spare a swift action to use a boost or stance that does the same thing.

Transformative, Greater (+15000 gp)*****:  (Credit to Mithral Leaf!)  Your weapon can turn into any other kind of weapon.  Put on a regular weapon, this could be useful if you like having a swiss army knife and using different weapon groups to get the most out of different disciplines.  But you could do something which probably isn’t intentional and make an arrow with this enhancement, dividing the cost of your weapon by 50.  A +5 Greater Transformative arrow costs a mere 1306.05 gp, total.  And every subsequent enhancement is likewise reduced in cost.

Armor

Your choice of armor will depend on your fighting style, just like your weapon will.  Changing materials and enhancements will also be a factor to keep in mind as you level up.

Strength-based:  At level 1, Four-Mirror Armor with an Armored Kilt.  If you don’t have enough money to buy Four-Mirror Armor, Scale Mail will be fine.  Replace your armor with masterwork Full Plate (1650 gp) as soon as you have enough money.  That’s usually good enough to see you through your entire career, but you could replace it with Adamantine Full Plate (16500 gp) for an easy DR 3/- if you find yourself taking a lot of minor hits.  Double-Plated Celestial Plate Armor (26000 gp) is the best of the best with 10 base armor bonus and +4 max dex bonus.  Is 1 more armor bonus worth the 19950 gp increase over regular full plate?  Might be at high levels.

Dexterity-based:  At level 1, a Chain Shirt or Parade Armor, depending on if you started with 18 or 20 dexterity, respectively.  Once you can, replace your armor with Celestial Armor or Celestial Plate Armor, depending on your preference.  With 26+ dexterity, Celestial Armor gives a total of +14 AC and is light armor, so it doesn’t slow your movement speed.  With 22+ dexterity, Celestial Plate Armor gives a total of +15 AC and is medium armor.  Add the Nimble modification to increase the max dex bonus by 2 and reduce the ACP by 1, but reduce the armor bonus by 1.

Charisma SAD:  If you’re not taking a Cha-to-AC option, wear the heaviest armor your encumbrance will allow.  Otherwise, get Celestial (Plate) Armor.

Unarmored:  This is generally a bad idea.  You’re giving up a useful equipment slot for no benefit.  You could do it by buying a wand of mage armor for 750 gp and either using UMD or asking your party’s wizard to poke you with it every hour.  But mage armor tops out at a +4 bonus to armor, while actual armor gives more AC and can have more enhancements.  The only way this is a good option is if you’re at least level 16, worship Arshea, have Celestial Obedience, and incredibly high charisma.  Even then, you’d need 38 charisma to match the armor bonus of +5 full plate.

Magic Armor Enhancements:

Enhancement Bonus (+1 to +5)*****:  Simply not getting hit is one of the most useful enhancements there is.  And it increases the Benevolent ability!

Benevolent (+1)*****:  Increase the amount of AC you grant with Aid Another!  This used to cost a flat 2000 gp, but it’s still splendid with its new errata’d price.

Fortification, Light/Moderate/Heavy (+1/+3/+5)****:  You have a 25%/50%/75% chance to ignore sneak attacks and crits.  Make Rogues and crit-fishers cry with your lack of dying!

Glamered (+2700 gp)***:  Make your armor look like regular clothing.  Now you can be more inconspicuous and still have protection!

Shadow, Improved/Greater (+3750/15000/33750 gp)***:  +5/10/15 competence bonus to stealth, lovely for those sneaky Zealots who foray into Veiled Moon.

Burdenless (+4000 gp)***:  This doesn’t reduce the weight of your armor, it increases your carrying capacity by 50%!  That makes it just as useful (maybe even more so) for strength-based characters as strength-dumping characters.

Restful (+4500 gp)****:  Add a comfy blanket and teddy bear to your armor, allowing you to sleep in it and only need 2 hours of sleep per day.  That’s 6 more hours per day to do what you want!  A Ring of Sustenance does the same thing at half the price, but it takes up a ring slot while this enhancement doesn’t, and your party’s crafter is more likely to have Craft Magic Arms and Armor than Craft Ring.

Hero’s Hauberk (16600 gp)*****:  For Zealots who dipped a level of Rubato Bard, and even more useful if you have rage, like from Bloodrager, Barbarian, Spiritualist, or Wilder.  DR 1/- that stacks with everything, light fortification while raging, and +1 luck bonus to all skills and reduce penalties to attacks, saves, and skills by 1 while using bardic performance.  Quite the collection of little bonuses!  The DR is useful all the time, the skill bonus makes your counters more likely to succeed, and the penalty reduction makes it easier to use things like Martial Power.

Righteous (+27000 gp)****:  Cast Righteous Might on yourself for 10 rounds once per day.  Amazing for strength-based Zealots!  This is the spell that battle clerics are so infamous for using and making fighters feel terrible about their life choices.  And it’s a flat GP cost, so it doesn’t drive up the price of your future armor enhancements!

Shields

Use a heavy shield by default.  All Zealot builds benefit from a shield except for Two Handed and Archery builds.  Yes, even Finesse Melee and Firearms Zealots will want a shield.  Privateers with Sea Combat can reload pistols with their hands full, after all!  If you don’t have Sea Combat, use a buckler.  The best materials are Living Steel to break metal weapons that roll a natural 1 against you, or Darkwood to reduce the shield’s weight by half and ACP to 0.

Magic Shield Enhancements:

Enhancement Bonus (+1 to +5)*****:  Moar AC!

Bashing (+1)****:  If you shield bash, a bashing spiked heavy shield deals 2d6 damage.

Fortification, Light/Moderate/Heavy (+1/+3/+5)****:  It’s better to put this on your shield than on your armor, because you likely have more interesting enhancements to put on your armor.

Maelstrom Shield (14710 gp)***:  Trip as a free action when you shield bash with no AoO.  Devastating against enemies who aren’t immune to trip, but that number quickly decreases as you go up in levels.  You can also create drinkable water at will which doesn’t fade after a day like the Create Water orison does!

Tempest Shield (15710 gp)***:  Bull rush as a free action when you shield bash with no AoO.  Now you don’t need to take the Shield Slam feat or its prerequisites!

Wondrous Items and Rings

Slotless:

Shard (10 to 1000 gp)*****:  Gain a +1 to +10 competence bonus to the next use of a certain skill check.  Don’t use these as-is.  Either get a Synaptic Mask (9000 gp) for a constant +10 competence bonus, or dip Aegis 3 and get the Harness Shard customization to use shards without disintegrating them.

Ioun Torch (75 gp)****:  A hands-free light source!  A must-have if you don’t have Darkvision.

Traveler’s Any-Tool (250 gp)****:  Counts as a masterwork tool for Craft and Profession, and creates whatever tool you want!

Cracked Dusty Rose Prism Ioun Stone (500 gp)*****:  Slotless +1 to initiative for super cheap.  Everyone should have one.

Wayfinder (500 gp)*****:  A COWPIS gives you Weapon Focus, a lovely +1 attack that no one would scoff at!  Alternatively, plop your Dusty Rose Prism into this, and you get +1 CMB.

Cognizance Crystals (1000 to 81000 gp)*:  These hold some power points to use on powers.  You can’t use them to replenish your own power point reserve or use them for Sleeping Goddess augments, Mission augments, or Martyrdom.

Warrior’s Scabbard (1000 gp)****:  Draw a weapon from this scabbard while maintaining psionic focus and gain +1 insight to attack with the weapon for 1 round.  Excellent for Mithral Current users who don’t already have an insight bonus to attack.

Cracked Opalescent White Pyramid Ioun Stone (1500)*****:  AKA the COWPIS.  Gain weapon familiarity with one weapon.  Now you can wield whatever exotic weapon you want!  Put it in your Wayfinder to make it truly purple.  Seriously, an exotic weapon and +1 attack for just 2000 gp can’t be beat.

Handy Haversack (2000 gp)****:  A timeless staple of the adventuring life.  Carry tons of stuff weightlessly, and access any of your items as a move action with no AoO.

Effortless Lace (2500 gp)**:  Unnecessary, even for Finesse Zealots.  A COWPIS will let you use an awesome estoc or elven branched spear for cheaper compared to this with a longsword.

Autoloader Magazine (3500, 7000, 14000 gp)****:  From Steelforge 1 by Dreamscarred Press.  Reduce the action required to reload your crossbow by 1 step, which stacks with Rapid Reload, hold 20 bolts in reserve, generate 1/2/3 new bolts per round, and sacrifice a special bolt to make the Autoloader Magazine create duplicates for 24 hours.  Since you’ll only be making one attack per round most of the time, the cheapest version is the best.  Sometimes you might use a counter that uses an attack roll, so the second version can come in handy, but you’re highly unlikely to run out of your reserve of 20 bolts in combat.  Put this on a light crossbow, and you won’t need to pick up Rapid Reload.  Best of all, if you can pick up a single +5 bolt for 1006.05 gp and have it be duplicated.  You don’t even need to have a masterwork or magical crossbow to benefit from it, saving you 45793.95 gp when comparing a Least Autoloader Magazine and +5 bolt to a +5 crossbow.  Oh, and that’s not all.  Make your wonderbolt fire, acid, or even drow poison.  Of course, since the wonderbolt only lasts for 24 hours, you’ll need several wonderbolts.  A regular crossbow and 45 wonderbolts will last you 45 solid days of adventuring before catching up to the cost of a +5 crossbow.

Four-Leaf Clover (3750 gp)****:  3 times per day, gain a +2 luck bonus to a save or skill check as a free action, even if it’s not your turn!  Increased by the Fate’s Favored trait.

Cracked Pale Green Prism Ioun Stone (4000 gp)*****:  +1 competence bonus to attack or saves!  You can get two of these, one for each bonus.  Some of the only things this doesn’t stack with are a Bard’s Inspire Courage, a Holy Tactician Paladin’s Weal’s Champion, and Bracers of Archery.  A competence bonus to attack is very rare.

Dusty Rose Prism Ioun Stone (NOT cracked!  5000 gp)*****:  +1 insight to AC!  Stacks with almost everything, just not Battle Mantra (Sleeping Goddess 1).

Steelbone Frame (6000 gp)***:  Reduce your ACP for medium/heavy armor by 2, and ignore your armor’s speed penalty for 1 round 3 times per day.  ACP reduction is useful if you regularly use maneuvers that use skills affected by it like much of Fool’s Errand.

Network Node Earrings (13500 gp)****:  From Steelforge 1 by Dreamscarred Press.  If you have a friend with a collective, this lets you use each other’s collectives to increase your effective range and coverage.  You can use clever strategies and be an extremely long range support character who doesn’t even need to be present at the battlefield in order to contribute.

Banner of Ancient Kings (18000 gp)*****:  Purple if you dip a level of Rubato Bard, blue if not.  You have to wield a longspear in two hands, but the benefits are enormous!  You get a +4 circumstance bonus to initiative, +2 resistance on saves vs mind-affecting effects for your whole party, the ability to reroll saves vs mind-affecting effects, and your Inspire Courage bonus increases by 1!  You can take the Flagbearer feat if you want to give your party a +2 morale bonus to damage and saves vs fear and charm, but remember that the morale bonus to attack won’t stack with your Zeal.

Banner of the Scarlet Rose (18000 gp)*****:  An alternative to the Banner of Ancient Kings.  You get a +2 shield bonus to AC, +4 luck to CMD, +2 resistance on saves vs mind-affecting effects for your whole party, and your Inspire Courage bonus increases by 1.  But you only need to use it in one hand!  Female users only.  It’s a tough choice between this and the other banner.  This is better if you need +2 AC and a weapon better than a longspear, and aren’t too bothered about having less initiative.  Don’t use this if you don’t have a level of Rubato Bard, though.

Tuned Bowstring (18000 gp)****:  For Archer Zealots who dipped a level of Rubato Bard.  This lets you maintain a bardic performance in combat without spending performance rounds as long as you shoot an arrow!  Your tempo and performance rounds are now that much easier to manage.

Karyukai Tea Set (38160 gp)*****:  [Link] It’s easy to reliably get a 26+ on a diplomacy check for a Zealot, and that means Greater Heroism for you and 5 other allies for 12 hours!  Or does it?  Depending on how you interpret the wording, it will last the full 12 hours, or it will only last as long as a CL 11 Greater Heroism, 11 minutes.  Even so, it could be useful if you have tea right at the entrance of a dungeon, then blitz through as far as you can go before the tea wears off.

Darkskull (60000 gp)*****:  Only use this if your party shares the same faith or alignment as you, and is fine with you carrying around an unambiguously evil skull.  It gives your party magic circle against good, and more importantly, a nice buff from a certain list.  The best buffs are freedom of movement or death ward.

Psychoactive Skins:

These don’t take up a slot, per se.  You can wear up to 3 at once, but only benefit from 1 of them at a time.

Skin of Proteus (84000 gp)*****:  (Credit to upho!)  You now have metamorphosis on at all times.  The better version of the phenomenally cosmically versatile power I told you to take Unlocked Talent for.  Now you can have fast healing, or increase or shrink by 2 sizes, or gain 2 natural attacks, or flight, or even 3 options from minor metamorphosis!

Belt (AKA Waist): 

Girdle of Protection (2000 to 50000 gp)**:  From Steelforge 1 by Dreamscarred Press.   An alternative to the Ring of Protection, one of the Big Six items, letting you free up your ring slot for something else.  But this slot is where you typically get your physical stats.

Belt of [Physical Stat] +2/+4/+6 (4000, 16000, 36000 gp)*****:  One of the Big Six items.  Improve either your strength or dexterity, depending on which you favor.

Belt of Physical Might +2/+4/+6 (10000, 40000, 90000 gp)****:  2.5 times more expensive as a single stat belt, but now you get a bonus to constitution too!

Belt of Physical Perfection +2/+4/+6 (16000, 64000, 144000 gp)**:  All 3 physical stats.  The extra cost is not worth it for what little you will gain.

Anaconda’s Coils Belt (18500 gp)****:  A +2 belt of strength, and you get +2 competence to grapple and 1d6 constrict.  If you like grappling or have the grab ability through Fiendbound Marauder Warder’s Fiend’s Grip or Aberrant Aegis’ tentacle customization, this is for you!

Body: 

Robe of Infinite Twine (1000 gp)****:  Create not only limitless twine, but also limitless rope!  In addition to being a fun bedroom enhancement, it has boundless adventuring applications!  The rope created is non-magical and lasts forever.

Robe of Needles (1000 gp)****:  This is a surprisingly highly useful item for Zealots!  6 times per day, you can make a ranged touch attack as a throwing weapon.  Ranged touch attack.  If you’re up against a big fat dragon or other beasty with massive natural armor but low touch AC, this is exactly what you need to land some strike maneuvers.  And it’s so cheap!  As gravy, it adds your strength to damage and does a little bit of bleed damage.

Bodywrap of Mighty Strikes (3000 to 147000 gp)*:  Made obsolete by Handwraps, which are cheaper.  They don’t stack.

Monk’s Robe (13000 gp)**:  Thanks to errata, this now stacks with Greater Unarmed Strike.  It will make your unarmed damage 1d10.  But Greater Unarmed Strike will raise your damage to that amount at character level 10, making this all but worthless.  The only reason to take this is if you dip Aegis for Hardened Strikes, don’t have Improved Unarmed Strike, and want to fight with unarmed strikes.

Robe of Arcane Heritage (16000 gp)****:  Excellent for those who picked up an Eldritch Heritage option that scales with level, like Abyssal or Orc.  Improves your level scaling by 4.

Charms: 

You need to attach these to a Necklace of Many Charms or a Bracelet of Charms.  Refinement Charms cost 500 gp, and Power Charms cost 2000 gp.  Refinement Charms of the same type stack with each other, but Power Charms don’t.  Also, Power Charms take up 3 charm slots.

Charm of Anger****:  +1 rage round per day.  Great for increasing the benefit you get for dipping Bloodrager, Barbarian, Spiritualist, or Wilder.

Charm of Armor***:  Sleep in your armor.  Much cheaper than the Restful armor enhancement.

Charm of Health***:  +2 max HP.  Every little bit helps.

Charm of Unity****:  Increase the size of your collective by 1.  Good if you have an extra large party, or if you’re a Void Prophet and want to debuff more enemies at once.

Power Charm of the Empowered****:  +1 point of animus at the start of every combat.  More resources means more effectiveness.

Power Charm of Intensity*****:  Your zeal lasts 2 rounds instead of 1.  A good alternative to taking the Community-Minded trait, especially if your GM doesn’t allow it.

Power Charm of the Unyielding****:  For Zealots who dip Aegis.  Increase your DR by 1.

Chest: 

Corset of Resistance (1000 to 25000 gp)*****:  From Steelforge 1 by Dreamscarred Press.   A fantastic alternative to the Cloak of Resistance, one of the Big Six items, letting you free up your shoulders slot for something else.

Carapace of Natural Armor (2000 to 50000 gp)*****:  From Steelforge 1 by Dreamscarred Press.  Same thing as the Corset of Resistance, but for the Amulet of Natural Armor.

Corset of Delicate Moves (2000 gp)****:  Once per day, you can exchange a move action for another swift action.  Sometimes using a boost or switching stances is more important than using Aid Another.  Plus, corsets are beautiful ♥

Blouse of the Boastful Bastard (8000 gp)***:  For Zealots who dipped a level of Swashbuckler.  Every time you get crit, you gain 1 panache.  More panache = more opportune parry and ripostes!  No matter how hard you try, it’s not always possible to avoid crits.  A dreaded 20/20 attack roll comes up 1 time out of every 400.

Eyes: 

Eyes of the Eagle (2500 gp)*****:  +5 competence to perception.  Wisdom is a dump stat for you, but you have perception as a class skill, and perception is the best skill in the game.

Third Eye, Aware (10000 gp)*****:  +10 competence to perception, a direct upgrade from Eyes of the Eagle.

Feet: 

Sandals of Quick Reaction (4000 gp)****:  You get both a standard AND a move action during surprise rounds!  It gets even better if you have the Ready Response feat or have dipped Warlord for the Warning presence or Monk (Master of Many Styles + Sohei) for Devoted Guardian, and means you effectively can’t be surprised.

Boots of Striding and Springing (5500 gp)****:  +10 move speed and +5 acrobatics!  Use this if you’re not going to take teleportation maneuvers.

Boots of Speed (6000 gp)***:  You’re one of the few martial classes who won’t be using this for the extra attack on a full attack.  You get 10 rounds of haste per day as a FREE action, and haste means bonus movespeed and +1 attack, reflex, and AC!  For the low price, that’s quite spiffy.  If you regularly use the Time Skitter boost, you won’t need this.

Hands: 

Gloves of Reconnaissance (2000 gp)***:  See and hear through walls for 1 minute per day.  That’s 10 rounds!  But if you have the ability to go incorporeal, like with Veiled Moon, this becomes less useful.  Also, your psicrystal is diminutive and starts with a minimum of a +18 stealth score, so it’s a magnificent scout.

Gloves of Larceny (2500 gp)****:  +5 competence bonus for Sleight of Hand, for the Tempest Gale users out there.

Healer’s Gloves (2500 gp)****:  +5 competence bonus for Heal, for the most zealous of Steel Serpent specialists.

Gauntlets of the Skilled Maneuver (4000 gp)****:  +2 untyped bonus to a specific combat maneuver.  Make your dirty trick specialist that much more overpowered!

Gloves of Arcane Striking (5000 gp)*****:  Now your Aid Another adds bonus damage or bonus AC to whoever you aid.  But you need to dip in an arcane caster class.  Being a race with spell-like abilities or taking a trait to gain a SLA will not work, because of this FAQ.  The most the gloves will give you is +1 to damage or AC.  It’s a lot of investment for a small bonus.  The exception is if you take the Mage Hunter prestige class, then the gloves are incredible!

Head: 

Plume of Panache (1000 gp)****:  For Zealots who dipped a level of Swashbuckler.  Once per day, cover the cost of 1 panache point for a deed.  You can grab half a dozen of these and put an unexpended one in your hat whenever you have a free moment, like between combat, giving you a lot more panache per day!

Hat of Disguise (1800 gp)****:  This is pretty awesome and fun, but you don’t need it because you took Unlocked Talent to get Minor Metamorphosis.  ...You DID take it, didn’t you?

Crystal Mask (2500 to 20250 gp)*****:  The ones that give competence bonuses are equivalent to Synaptic Masks.  But some give insight bonuses instead!  Grab Insightful Detection (20250 gp) for an incredibly cost-effective +9 insight to sense motive and perception if you have maneuvers that use sense motive like the Zenith strikes.  Otherwise, consider Mindarmor (10677 gp) for a hefty +4 insight bonus to will saves.

Maiden’s Helm (3500 gp)****:  +5 competence bonus to intimidate, and you can cast command 3/day.  The cheapest Paizo magic item for improving your intimidate score.

Circlet of Persuasion (4500 gp)****:  +3 to all charisma checks!  That’s a lot of skills, especially Eternal Guardian and Mithral Current counters, and if you have the Noble Scion (war) feat, it also includes initiative!  However, it’s a competence bonus, so make sure you don’t get a different item that overlaps it.

Jingasa of the Fortunate Soldier (5000 gp)*:  This got nerfed.  It used to provide a +1 luck bonus to AC, and now it’s a deflection bonus.  The critical hit negation only works ONCE per jingasa.  Not once per day.  Once, period.

Synaptic Mask (9000 gp)*****:  Combine with a +10 shard (1000 gp) to get a constant +10 competence bonus to a skill of your choice, for a total of 10000 gp.

Dervish Sikke (10000 gp)*****:  For Zealots who dipped a level of Rubato Bard.  +2 competence to a certain knowledge or perform skill, +2 to all knowledge skills, and your inspire courage bonus increases by 1!  Combined with the Banner of Ancient Kings, you can give a +3 inspire courage to your entire party with only 1 level of Bard.  It will NOT stack with the Banner of the Scarlet Rose, though.

Headband: 

Headband of [Mental Stat] +2/+4/+6 (4000, 16000, 36000 gp)*****:  One of the Big Six items.  Improve your charisma!

Headband of Mental Prowess +2/+4/+6 (10000, 40000, 90000 gp)**:  Spend magnitudes more gold to get a small boost to skills or your will save.

Headband of Mental Superiority +2/+4/+6 (16000, 64000, 144000 gp)*:  All 3 mental stats.  It’s too expensive to be worth it.

Neck: 

Amulet of Natural Armor (2000 to 50000 gp)*****:  One of the Big Six items.  Improves your natural AC.

Necklace of Many Charms (2000 gp)***:  See the Charms section.  This is rated lower than the Bracelet of Charms because it takes up a slot usually reserved for the Amulet of Natural Armor, and you can’t buy it in 1000 gp increments.

Golembane Scarab (2500 gp)***:  You ignore DR on golems.  The perfect item to slap on when going into an ancient forgotten pharaoh’s tomb or an abandoned wizard’s laboratory.  Destruction Mission Zealots don’t need this, of course.

True Love Locket (6000 gp)*****:  With one particular person, you have status, increase your aid another bonus by +1, and can cast borrow skill on each other once per day.

Amulet of the Blooded (Aberrant) (15000 gp)****:  (credit to TiaC!)  You gain 25% fortification and extend your reach by 5 feet when you make melee touch attacks.  Some maneuvers let your attacks count as melee touch attacks like Blazing Mirror Strike (Shattered Mirror 4) and Scarlet Eye’s Perception (Scarlet Throne 3), or you can use the Deep Impact feat.

Shoulders: 

Cloak of Resistance (1000 to 25000 gp)*****:  One of the Big Six items.  Improves your saving throws.

Poet’s Cloak (9750 gp)****:  For Zealots who dipped a level of Rubato Bard.  This lets you use bardic performance as a 4th level Skald’s raging song, granting a +2 morale bonus to strength, constitution, and will saves to your allies who accept it.  You also get a rage power which you share with your allies!  Lesser Spirit Totem gives you a negative energy slam attack for every ally you have, and it scales off of your charisma.  If you have ways of healing allies such as the Creation Mission or Radiant Dawn maneuvers, consider Lesser Celestial Totem to heal allies an additional 4 HP per effect.

Minor Cloak of Displacement (24000 gp)****:  20% concealment.  Marvelous if you don’t have another readily accessible source of concealment, like from a stance.  Definitely grab this if your GM allows Steelforge 1!

Wrists:

Sleeves of Many Garments (200 gp)***:  Your clothes now look however you want, whenever you want!  It’s the same cost as a royal outfit, and can give mechanical benefits like hot weather or cold weather clothing.

Bracelet of Charms (1000 or 2000 gp)****:  See the Charms section.  Each bracelet holds 5 charms, and you can wear 2 bracelets.  Start out with just one bracelet to save money, and get a second bracelet once you have more wealth.

Bracers of Archery, Lesser or Greater (5000 or 25000 gp)****:  A cracked pale green prism ioun stone is flat out better than the lesser bracers of archery.  The greater bracers give you another bonus to attack and damage.

Bracers of the Merciful Knight (15600 gp)***:  For Zealots dipping Holy Tactician Paladin.  You get 2 more Lay on Hands per day, they increase by 2d6, and you can use lesser restoration once per day!  Sadly, this doesn’t seem to work with the Knight Disciple’s Guardian Shield.

Rings:  

Ring of Protection (2000 to 50000 gp)*****:  One of the Big Six items.  Improves your deflection AC.

Ring of Sustenance (2500 gp)***:  You don’t need to eat or drink, and only need 2 hours of sleep per day.  Imagine what you can do with 6 more hours!  Compare with the Restful armor enhancement.  Most GMs won’t make you track food by the time you can afford this.

Ring of Ferocious Action (3000 gp)****:  5 rounds per day, you can ignore the staggered condition as a free action.  Spiffy for when you’re struggling to stay in the fight with your Defiance active, or just for when you get staggered by other means.

Ring of Foe Focus (10000 gp)****:  At will as a standard action, you can designate a foe and gain +2 untyped AC and saves vs them, and the duration lasts forever until you select a different foe!  If you can spot a boss enemy from afar before you engage it, this is the perfect opportunity to use the ring.  It’s not quite as great in battles with a lot of mooks or ones where time and action economy are crucial, though.

Ring of Tactical Precision (11000 gp)*****:  Increase your Aid Another by +1!  It also allows you to share a teamwork feat with one teammate, albeit in a really awkward, convoluted way.

Mundane and Alchemical Gear:

There are far too many especially useful things in these categories to list, so I will only list the ones that are of special interest to Zealots.  For more universal and thorough lists, take a look at other guides like this one and this one by Niel Carr for mundane items, and this one by Ascalaphus for alchemical items.

Masterwork Tool (50 gp)*****:  For next to nothing, you get a +2 circumstance bonus for any skill you can conceivably justify.  Circumstance bonus stack with other circumstance bonuses, too, just not from the same source.  It’s up to your GM what’s valid or not, and rightly so, because this is so cheap.

Masterwork Backpack (50 gp)*****:  Weighs 4 lbs (or 1 lbs if you’re small), and increases your effective strength for carrying capacity by +1.  The only characters who wouldn’t want this are medium-sized creatures with 9 strength or less.  Even if you’re a small creature with 5 strength, you gain more carrying capacity than the backpack takes up.

Gravelly Tonic (50 gp)****:  Guzzle this, and for 1 hour, you speak like Batman and gain a +5 alchemical bonus to Intimidate!  A magnificent boon for your Eternal Guardian counters!

Disciplines and Maneuvers

Maneuvers in this guide are rated based on how useful they are for the Zealot playstyle of protecting their party and using move actions for Aid Another.  Some maneuvers and stances that might be blue for Warlords might instead be red for Zealots, because they make use of full round actions, or don’t have powerful enough rider effects, for instance.  Maneuvers that hit multiple enemies are more useful, and maneuvers that allow an initiator to move as part of a standard action strike are especially great for Zealots.  Counters that can be used on allies are much more important than counters that only benefit the initiator.

Martial Traditions

You may join as many Martial Traditions as you want for free, because there are no rules saying you can’t.  You trade access of one discipline for the Martial Tradition’s discipline, and gain its associated skill as a class skill.  Each tradition has an optional allegiance benefit with the equivalent power of about 2 feats, which the GM can decide to not include in the game, so don’t look at traditions expecting to pick up a ton of free allegiance benefits.  Each tradition has an alignment requirement, an open-ended oath, and possibly a penalty for leaving.  Martial Traditions will be listed under their associated Disciplines.  Since the oaths are so open-ended and the allegiance benefits are subject to GM approval, I won’t include them in the descriptions.

Black Seraph

Skill:  Intimidate.  2 counters, 2 boosts.

Weapon Groups: Axes, Flails, Polearms.  This discipline has 13 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  Strikes from Black Seraph are either melee or non-weapon attacks, and none can be used with ranged weapons.

Martial Tradition:  Black Thorn Knights.  LN, LE, or NE.

Note:  You don’t have to be evil, but many Black Seraph maneuvers have the [evil] descriptor.

Note 2:  Profane damage deals full damage to incorporeal targets, counts as evil-aligned, and bypasses all damage reduction.  It doesn’t deal +50% damage to good creatures anymore.

1st Level

Stances:

Black Seraph’s Glare*****:  Demoralize as a free action whenever you damage a creature, and get a +4 profane bonus on these checks.  This saves you the trouble of getting Cornugon Smash or Enforcer, and works on any form of damage you inflict, not just melee attacks.  You could be a sorcerer flinging around fireballs and still use this stance to intimidate everything you damage.  There are a lot of area-effect strikes in Black Seraph, too.

Savage Stance*:  Your two-handed melee attacks have -2 attack and +1d8 damage.  Losing accuracy is awful, and the damage increase is negligible compared to other stances like Reaching Blade Stance (Mithral Current 1) and Phalanx Lancer (Piercing Thunder 1).

Strikes:

Gutstrike***:  +cha mod damage, and your target must make a save or be sickened for 1 round.  Sickened is quite nice, though of course not quite as nice as a disabling effect.

Ravaging Blow****:  [evil, fear].  +1d6 profane damage, and your target must make a will save or be shaken for 1 round.  Shaken isn’t quite as good as sickened, and it’s already incredibly easy to intimidate.  However, if you use this on a target that’s already shaken (or are using Black Seraph’s Glare/Cornugon Smash/Enforcer), the fear effects will stack and your target will be frightened!  Much better.

Voracious Drive*:  Full round charge attack with no AoOs, +1d6 damage, and no AC penalty.  Zealots don’t like spending full round actions, and especially not on strikes that have no riders.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Strength of Hell****:  For 1 round, you have a +2 profane bonus to attack and +1d6 damage.  Almost as good as Regal Blade (Scarlet Throne 2) which is a level higher, and applies to all attacks in a round, not just one.  Not a bad choice at low levels when killing a bunch of mindless mooks with AoOs is a better strategy than crowd controlling one at a time.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Inner Demon Strike*:  [evil].  +4d6 profane damage, and you take 1d6 damage.  Pure damage, no rider, and a drawback for using it.

Seraph's Wrath****:  +2d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone.  Prone is a good condition at low levels, the strike does good damage, and reflex is a good save to target.

Shadow Feather Strike***:  [evil].  30 foot ranged touch attack, 4d6+cha mod profane damage.  A big nuke in general, doing more damage than most other characters can do at level 3 with a ranged touch attack.  Sorcerers will burn with jealousy until they can shoot 2 scorching rays at level 7.  But it’s not as good as Chronal Aggression (Riven Hourglass 2) because it has no rider.

Counters:

Intimidating Force**:  Intimidate vs attack roll to negate it.  A bog standard skill vs attack negation counter with nothing else going for it.  Doesn’t work on allies, either.  Fear the Reaper (Eternal Guardian 2) is better in every single possible way.

Boosts:

Fear Eating Technique**:  [evil].  Use when you demoralize an enemy to heal 2d6+IL damage.  If you have a masochistic adrenaline junkie party member who will allow you to scare them repeatedly outside of combat (not to mention a lenient GM), you can use this to heal up to full!  In-combat, though, it’s better to use your swift actions to prevent damage rather than patch up damage you’ve already taken.

3rd Level

Stances:

Black Seraph Battle Stance**:  [evil].  Gain Protection from Good and the Unholy weapon property.  Though the deflection and resistance bonuses from Protection from Good won’t stack with items, it will still protect you from possession and mental control, and the natural attacks of summoned good creatures.  All Unholy does is add +2d6 damage to good creatures, so it’s not as impressive as something that increases accuracy or has a rider.  You can become immune to possession and mental control by buying a Clear Spindle Ioun Stone and putting it in a Wayfinder.

Strikes:

Savage Drive*:  Full round charge action with no AoOs, +4d6 damage, and no AC penalty.  It’s Voracious Drive with +3d6 more damage.  Yuck.

Tendon Rip*:  +2d6 damage and your target’s speed is halved for cha mod rounds with no save.  All this does is reduce an enemy’s speed, and doesn’t interfere with their actual actions.  Since it’s a melee strike, all your target needs to do in response is attack you back, or one of your friends in melee range.  Full-attacking enemies don’t do much movement other than 5 foot steps, anyway.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Taunting Laugh**:  Demoralize your target as a swift action, and they’re also flat-footed until the end of your next turn if successful.  Demoralizing as anything other than a free action is inefficient.  Flat-footed on its own isn’t a powerful enough debuff, unless your party’s Stalkers and Rogues can seriously capitalize on it, and even then, there are much better ways to make enemies lose their dexterity bonus to AC, such as by blinding them.
