Unfettered Progression**:  Use after you attack to move 10 feet with no AoO, and your next attack deals +2d6 damage and ignores DR.  Compared to other boosts, the damage increase is pretty small, and you have to wait for an entire round to use it.  Also, no rider or damage prevention included.  The 10 foot step is very small, but might be useful.

4th Level

Stances:

Walk in the Dark***:  Shed darkness in a 20 foot radius, gain darkvision 60, and use a move action to force a target to make a will save or be frightened for cha mod rounds, or shaken for 1 round if they save.  It’s not a bad idea to use your move actions for long-lasting hard crowd control instead of Aid Another.  The darkness aura will only be useful against creatures that lack darkvision, which is a pretty common ability in monsters, and can hinder your allies if they don’t have darkvision.

Strikes:

Bilious Strike*****:  [evil].  +6d6 profane damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be nauseated for cha mod rounds, or 1 round if they save.  Disgustingly high damage, all the benefits profane damage affords, and you ALWAYS inflict the disgustingly strong nauseated condition no matter what!  Utterly disgusting, making this strike live up to its name.

Circle of Razor Feathers*****:  [evil].  30 foot radius burst centered on you, targeting enemies only.  8d6 profane damage, and your targets must make a reflex save or be sickened for cha mod rounds, or half damage and 1 round on a successful save.  Just as disgusting as Bilious Strike, but in a different way.  Combine with Black Seraph’s Glare to demoralize everything you hit, heavily debuffing your opponents.  Echoes of Steel this to your psicrystal for double the fun!

Boosts:

None

Counters:

Vengeful Riposte****:  Attack when attacked and stagger your attacker for 1 round.  This can prevent your attacker from even hitting you in the first place, if they’d already used their move action to get to you, since becoming staggered reduces their actions, and your immediate action occurs immediately before their attack.  It can also reduce a full attack to a mere single attack.  And you can use this counter with both melee and ranged weapons, and against anything that is considered an attack, like an offensive spell!  If you could use it to protect allies, it’d be incredible.

5th Level

Strikes:

Abyssal Lance*****:  [evil].  Close ranged touch attack.  8d6 profane damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be stunned for 1 round.  Stunned is an amazing debuff, making this purple all on its own, and the fact that it’s on a ranged touch attack makes it even better.  Sure, Bilious Strike is an even BETTER all-purpose strike than this, but it’d be silly to knock this down to blue just because Bilious Strike is so disgustingly powerful.

Sensory Rip****:  Normal damage, 1d4 charisma damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be permanently blinded.  As a PC, blinding an enemy permanently is usually just as effective as blinding them for a few rounds, the duration of a normal combat.  It’s a good debuff, and the charisma damage has uses as well.

Sharing the Dark Soul*****:  [evil, mind-affecting].  +8d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1 round.  More damage than Abyssal Lance, but harder to hit, and with a slightly worse debuff.  But still, a debuff like that is still fantastic at this level.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Soul Consumption*:  [evil].  Use this when reducing a foe (minimum 1/2 HD) to 0 hp, and heal 3d8+IL HP.  Only slightly more healing than Fear Eating Technique from 2nd level, and has a much more difficult requirement.  Zealots don’t often land killing blows against non-mooks.

6th Level

Stances:

Razor Wings of the Black Seraph**:  [evil].  Gain a fly speed equal to your move speed (average maneuverability), +2 profane bonus to AC, and Whirlwind Attack.  Using Whirlwind Attack is a full round action, so it’s not great for Zealot even if you have massive reach.  The bonus to AC is pretty small compared to other stances, and there are many other ways to gain flight, especially by 11th level.  The humble Unbroken Stride (Sleeping Goddess 1) has you covered.

Strikes:

Abyssal Drive*:  Full round charge action with no AoOs, +8d6 damage, no AC penalty, and your target must make a fortitude save or be sickened for 1d4 rounds.  Wasn’t worth it with Voracious Drive, wasn’t worth it with Savage Drive, not worth it now.

Shadow Raptor Swarm*****:  [evil, mind-affecting].  30 foot cone, only targets enemies.  12d6 profane damage, and your targets must make a reflex save for half damage, and are shaken regardless for cha mod rounds!  Combine with Black Seraph’s Gaze to instantly frighten all of your enemies, no questions asked.  Without Black Seraph’s Gaze, it’s less impressive, but still great for ruining the days of mooks.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Black Seraph's Wrath***:  [evil].  Add your intimidate check result as profane damage to your next attack.  This is better for classes who can stack static damage modifiers.  But considering how most of the brunt comes from power attack, strength bonus, and your intimidate check which is easily increased by items, even a Zealot can do apocalyptic damage with this.

7th Level

Strikes:

Armageddon Lance***:  [evil, mind-affecting].  Close ranged touch attack.  14d6 profane damage, your target must make a will save or be panicked for 1 round, and you take 2d6 damage.  It’s Abyssal Lance with 6d6 more damage, deals damage to you, and inflicts a less useful debuff.  Not terrible, but the benefits are not worth the drawbacks compared to Abyssal Lance.

Charge of the Ravager*:  Full round charge action with no AoOs, +2d6 damage, and you can attack every enemy adjacent to your charge path.  You need some way to deal with difficult terrain, charge in a non-straight line, or move through enemies in order for this to not be even more awful than it already is.

Consumption Strike***:  [evil].  +10d6 profane damage, and you gain temporary HP equal to damage dealt for 1 minute.  Combine with Black Seraph’s Wrath to instantly gain 100+ temporary HP, depending on how high you can stack your intimidate and damage modifiers.  It doesn’t disable your enemies at all, but it does keep you in the fight.

Counters:

Devastating Riposte*:  Intimidate vs attack roll to attack your attacker with +8d6 damage.  It doesn’t negate the attack or inflict any debuffs, and you might fail the intimidate check.  Stick with Vengeful Riposte, which always works.

Boosts:

None

8th Level

Stances:

Vampiric Aura**:  [evil].  Enemies in a 20 foot aura take 2d6 profane damage, you gain the sum as temporary HP, and you can exclude cha mod allies from the aura.  The damage to any individual enemy is pitiful at this level, even against hordes of mooks, because the mooks need to be strong enough to actually hinder a 15th level character.  You gain an average of 7 hp per enemy, so you’d need to be around 10 enemies to get ~70 HP, which won’t last long in such a throng.  Against a small number of strong enemies, this stance is even worse, because you’ll deal less damage and gain less THP overall.  Cheese strategy:  Keep a portable hole filled with thousands of rats or bugs, open it up at the start of combat, and drink their delicious essence for thousands of THP.  Of course, you’ll have to repopulate your portable hole every combat.

Strikes:

Apocalyptic Strike****:  [evil].  40 foot burst centered on you.  16d6 profane damage, 1 round daze, and your targets must make a reflex save for half damage and to negate the daze.  This hits both friends and foes, so it’s not as party-friendly as other AoE Black Seraph strikes.  But daze is much better than sicken or shaken, if you don’t use Black Seraph’s Glare to demoralize everything you hit.

Soul Crusher**:  [evil].  3d4 charisma damage.  That’s all.  Sure, it could oneshot your typical barbarian, fighter, or other charisma-dumping class, but you’re unlikely to meet many high level monsters with low charisma.  Dragons and outsiders are known to be quite charming!

Void Seraph Strike**:  [evil].  30 foot ranged touch attack.  Your target takes 6d6 profane damage for 1d4 rounds and suffers 50% miss chance on attacks, no save.  It’s not as good as the blind condition, and damage-over-time effects aren’t very good in Pathfinder because combats are typically short.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Black Seraph Onslaught**:  Full round attack against a single creature.  You have a bonus attack, -2 AC, +4d6 profane damage, nauseate for 1 round per hit, and your target can’t be returned to life with raise dead.  While nauseating a target with no save is good, Zealots don’t like full attacks, and a multi-attack strike with bonus damage encourages you to get as many attacks as you possibly can like TWF or natural attacks, going against the focus of two-handed strikes Black Seraph usually supports.  The target can still be returned to life with resurrection, so it’s not like this ensures your enemy will never come back.  You need something that traps their soul like Septennial Seal (Shattered Mirror 9) to do that.

Final Ruling****:  This discipline deals some pretty incredible damage compared to others, and several strikes inflict no-save debuffs.  It’s one of the only disciplines that has powerful, useful, and party-friendly AoE maneuvers.  Aside from flight and some healing, it doesn’t have much utility, however.  Any Zealot would absolutely love to have Bilious Strike and some AoE strikes.

Broken Blade

Skill:  Acrobatics.  1 strike, 3 counters.

Weapon Groups:  Close, Monk, Natural.  Discipline weapon NOT required anymore.  This discipline has 8 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  All strikes in this discipline are melee-only.

Martial Tradition:  Sultanate of Beggars.  Non-lawful.

1st Level

Stances:

Iron Hand Stance*:  +2 shield bonus while you have a hand free.  It doesn’t stack with anything, and Zealots are usually always best off having both hands occupied, either with a shield or two-handing a weapon.  You can use unarmed strikes even with your hands full, after all.  You could combine it with Crane Style, but at that point you’re just shoring up a weakness rather than making yourself better at your job.

Pugilist Stance***:  You deal +1d6 damage.  Reaching Blade Stance (Mithral Current 1) is better in every way, but this stance does everything you really need to be ludicrously powerful in Broken Blade.

Strikes:

Flurry Strike*****:  2 attacks as a standard action.  An easy way to one-shot just about anything you meet at low levels.  Math time!  With 18 strength and lucerne hammer, you can deal up to 2d12+12 damage at level 1 with a standard action.  And that’s without power attack, or other damage increasing buffs or maneuvers like Pugilist Stance or Encouraging Roar.  I dislike giving a pure-damage strike such a high rating for Zealots, but there’s no denying that this simply annihilates anything you’ll face at low levels.  Broken Blade in general is overtuned and too strong, along with Primal Fury, and the designers have said they would make them less powerful with errata.  Someday.

Pommel Bash**:  Unarmed strike against your target’s flat-footed AC, and deal +1d6 damage.  Better for classes that can take advantage of the flat-footed status like Rogues and Stalkers, and it requires an unarmed strike instead of allowing the use of a discipline weapon.  Swift Current (Mithral Current 1) is the same thing, but better in that regard.

Shards of Iron Strike****:  Normal damage, and your target is staggered for 1 round with no save.  Given how staggered creatures can still do partial charges, it’s not very useful against enemies that only have a single attack per round, but great against full-attackers.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Brawler's Attitude*:  +4 competence bonus to CMB for a dirty trick, disarm, grapple, or trip.  It doesn’t give you protection from AoOs, so one of the safest uses for this boost is tripping with a reach weapon.  But spending your swift action for only a 20% extra chance of success on a minor debuff isn’t that great.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Cartwheel Axe Kick**:  Roll acrobatics vs DC 15 to move 10 feet without AoOs towards or away from your target and make an unarmed strike for +2d6 damage.  Strikes that move you are great for Zealots, but this only moves you 5 feet further than taking a non-action 5 foot step.  You also have to make the check, and can’t use whatever weapon you want.  Go with Relentless Warden’s Strike (Eternal Guardian 2), Fading Strike (Veiled Moon 2), or Hurricane Kick (Fool’s Errand 2) for mobility instead.

Knuckle to the Blade*:  Normal damage, make a disarm attempt with no AoO, and steal the weapon if you have a free hand.  Too situational, too weak, and 2nd level maneuvers are chock full of fierce competition.  A smart NPC will have a spiked gauntlet for backup, and won’t be at a severe disadvantage because you won’t run into any highly enhanced weapons at level 3.

Leg Sweeping Hilt***:  Trip with a +2 competence bonus and no AoO, and attack for normal damage if successful.  Prone is a nice condition at low levels, and the free attack will have a +4 bonus since your target will be prone.

Counters:

Counter Step*:  Acrobatics vs melee attack roll, and you need to 5 foot step out of the attack’s range to negate it.  THE worst 2nd level counter in the game, even worse than Stopwatch (Riven Hourglass 2) and Defensive Step (Silver Crane 2) because you can only use it against melee attacks.

Boosts:

Bronze Knuckle****:  Your Broken Blade strikes this turn deal +2d6 damage and ignore DR.  This seemingly humble little boost has the potential to make combinations that turn any monster you face into a gooey red paste.  As a Zealot, your job isn’t to deal damage, but hey, Broken Blade is overtuned, so I have to properly rate this highly for its damage-prevention potential via killing the baddies who want to damage you.

3rd Level

Stances:

Broken Blade Stance**:  Gain +IL to acrobatics for avoiding AoOs, and get one or two bonus attacks when using a full attack.  Remember, Zealots aren’t the best full attackers.  The damage potential from this stance is immense, but it’s best left to the Steelfist Commandos, Dervish Defenders, and other full attackers.

Strikes:

Steel Flurry Strike*****:  3 attacks with -2 attack and +3d6 damage as a standard action.  All by itself,  at an absolute minimum, that’s 3d3+9d6 damage, or 37.5 average damage.  With 18 strength, a tri-pointed double-edged sword, Pugilist Stance, and Bronze Knuckle, that’s a standard action strike that deals 3d10+18d6+18 damage, or 97.5 damage average, which ignores DR.  And that’s before other damage bonuses like buffs, Power Attack, or your weapon’s enhancement bonus.  And you can do this combo EVERY ROUND because you’re a Zealot.  Just imagine how high it can go if you stack size increases and strength.  See what I mean about Broken Blade being overtuned?

Counters:

Flat Iron Riposte***:  Acrobatics vs melee attack to negate it and throw your attacker 10 feet, and they must make a reflex save or fall prone.  Repositioning an attacker into a flanking position with your allies and making them prone (or just throwing em off a cliff) ensures they’re gonna have a bad time!  Just remember that it only works on melee attacks and only for you.

Boosts:

Iron Dust***:  When you use a strike, attempt a dirty trick with a +2 competence bonus and no AoO.  Dirty Tricks are always great, and if you combine this with a strike that hinders an enemy’s actions like staggered, they’ll be largely neutralized for a round.  But there are better counters and boosts.

4th Level

Strikes:

Iron-Breaking Palm*:  Sunder attack with no AoO and +3d6 damage, and you can entangle your target if you sunder their shield.  It’s generally not a great idea to destroy your treasure just to reduce your target’s AC by a little bit.

Iron Axe Kick*****:  Unarmed strike, +6d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1d4 rounds.  Huge damage and a long daze make this marvelous!

Counters:

Broken Blade Riposte*:  When hit in melee, attack with +3d6 damage and push your attacker 5 feet away.  It doesn’t negate the damage you take at all or inflict any debuffs.  It could potentially push a full-attacker out of range of their remaining iterative attacks, but they could take a 5 foot step to return to where they were and resume their full attack.

Boosts:

Iron Knuckle****:  For 1 round, your attacks with a discipline weapon deal +4d6 damage.  More damage than Bronze Knuckle, but it doesn’t ignore DR.  If you have a bajillionty natural attacks and want to pulpify everything you come across, it’s hard to do better than this.  Just remember, pure overwhelming damage is only good as long as your GM has you face enemies that can be taken down in a single round by such attacks.

5th Level

Stances:

Steel Grappler's Attitude***:  Count as 1 size larger and add cha mod to CMB and CMD for grapple, bull rush, and overrun.  Very little else in Broken Blade involves grappling, giving this little synergy.  But it will be a welcome addition to Zealots who dip Fiendbound Marauder Warder 1.

Strikes:

Iron Monger's Throw*:  Roll CMB with no AoO and a +4 competence bonus to throw your target 20 feet and deal 6d6 damage.  The damage is small since it doesn’t include you hitting with your weapon, the throwing distance is low, the description is unclear as to whether the target falls prone, and it’s a raw CMB check instead of an actual combat maneuver, so you can’t add bonuses to grapple that you get from equipment or feats.

Shards of Steel Strike*:  +8d6 damage, ignore DR, and 2d4 bleed damage for cha mod rounds.  Steel Flurry Strike does more damage even including the bleed.

Counters:

Throw the Blade Down*:  Acrobatics vs melee attack to negate it, 5 foot step, pull your attacker into your last square, and they must make a reflex save or fall prone.  Too limited in application and with a weak effect.

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Pit Fighter's Stance**:  You can make a dirty trick once per round as a swift action with no AoO, have +2 CMD vs dirty tricks and feints, and deal +2d6 damage against targets that are denied their dexterity bonus to AC.  Dirty tricks are nice, but Zealots can easily recover maneuvers and use swift actions for counters and better boosts.  This is for characters who can’t easily recover their maneuvers and still need to use their swift actions, especially Stalkers.

Strikes:

Singing Steel Strike*:  +8d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be deafened and silenced for 1d4 rounds.  The best you can possibly do is mildly inconvenience a spellcaster, assuming that they haven’t taken precautions against silence.

Steel Axe Kick*****:  Unarmed strike, +10d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1d3 rounds.  More damage than Iron Axe Kick, but less duration, for some reason.  Oh well, a multi-round daze is a multi-round daze.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Finishing Kick*:  Usable after you make a full attack.  Unarmed strike, +6d6 damage.  If you’re making a full attack and using a boost for pure damage, why the devil aren’t you using one of the Knuckle boosts instead?

7th Level

Strikes:

Shards of Adamantine Strike*****:  +12d6 damage, ignore DR and hardness, and your target must make a fortitude save or be nauseated for 1d4 rounds.  Nauseated isn’t quite as good as dazed, but it still makes an enemy almost totally incapable of harming your party.

Spinning Flurry Rush****:  2 attacks against all adjacent enemies for +4d6 damage.  Or is it enemies within reach?  The description and range text contradict each other.  If you have a boost or other natural rider effect on your attacks, this can be great for locking down a large group of enemies.  But if your GM rules that it only works against adjacent enemies, it’s terrible.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Adamantine Knuckle****:  For 1 round, your attacks of any kind deal +6d6 damage and ignore DR and hardness.  Better than both previous Knuckle boosts in damage, function, and applicability.  You could pull out a bow and instantly carve a tunnel through a cave with this.  If you’re a Ranged Zealot, you can use this instead of Aurora Break (Solar Wind 8) to get your ultra death arrow rain combo 2 levels earlier and not have to worry about energy resistance.

8th Level

Stances:

Unbreakable Stride Stance*:  Take no penalties moving through threatened areas, don’t provoke AoOs when moving, and have freedom of movement.  There are plenty of magic items that give you freedom of movement, and plenty of other ways of not having to deal with AoOs.

Strikes:

Meteoric Throw**:  Grapple attempt, throw your target 25 feet as a ranged touch attack, and deal 12d6 damage to your target and secondary targets if they fail a reflex save.  It can be a lot of fun to grab a dragon and squish a group of sycophantic kobolds beneath its big fat scaled rump, but all this maneuver does is a bit of damage and forced movement.  It doesn’t even knock anyone prone.

Spinning Adamantine Axe*:  One unarmed strike with +10d6 damage against all adjacent enemies, and enemies hit are knocked prone with no save.  Prone isn’t a good status effect at this point, and the fact this requires you to be adjacent heavily limits its usability.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Storm of Iron Fists Strike**:  Full attack against a single creature.  +4d6 damage, ignore DR, and your target must make a fortitude save or be reduced to -1 HP.  A good counter to your GM who has undoubtedly quadrupled the HP of every enemy you face to counter Broken Blade’s ludicrous full attack damage.  Unless your GM also made every enemy you face undead or constructs and thus immune to effects that require fortitude saves.

Final Ruling**:  This offers very easy, low effort, low investment ways to deal amounts of damage that far outstrip the CRs of your level.  There are even a few proper crowd controlling strikes mixed in.  But overall, the utility Broken Blade provides is nonexistent.  A pure brute force approach to kung fu which a savvy GM can make you feel bad for taking if you put all your eggs in this one basket.

Chimera Soul (Playtest)

Skill: Knowledge (Nature). 4 strikes, 1 counter.

Weapon Groups: Natural Weapons. This discipline has 9 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition: The Temple of the Formless Spirit. Any alignment.

Note 1: Some Chimera Soul maneuvers grant you a temporary primary natural attack if you don’t already have one of the same kind.

Note 2: You gain the shapechanger subtype if you know at least one Chimera Soul maneuver.

Note 3: Zealots can exchange a discipline with Chimera Soul for free.

1st Level

Stances:

Moon Hound Stance****: You gain a 1d6 bite attack and the benefits of Improved Trip when using it. Tripping as a free action with a +2 bonus whenever you hit is fantastic at low levels.  Low level enemies are squishy and it’s often better to simply oneshot them with raw damage, but they still might as well be dead if you manage to trip them.

Swift Panther Stance***: You gain 2 1d4 claw attacks and +10 speed.  The speed is useful both in and out of combat, and while the claws are nothing impressive by themselves, you never know when your GM will put you in a situation where you don’t have any other weapons.

Strikes:

Beast Swipe***: 2 claw attacks against one target with -2 attack, and you deal +1d6+(str*1.5) damage if both hit.  Slightly better than One-Two Punch (Fool’s Errand 1), not as good as Flurry Strike (Broken Blade 1).  It’s still likely enough to oneshot a level 1 enemy, but exchange it for a different maneuver as soon as possible, because it scales very poorly.

Bite of the Wererat*: Bite with +1d6 damage.  Why not just use a different strike maneuver with a greatsword for even more damage or more utility?

Wild Beast’s Roar**: [fear, mind-affecting] Demoralize creatures in a 30 foot cone, and you may use Knowledge (Nature) in place of Intimidate.  Better action economy than Dazzling Display, but a smaller area, and you risk hitting allies.  It also can’t make enemies panicked on its own.  Particularly useful for Void Prophets to add multiple enemies to their collective at once at low levels.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Primal Fang**: You gain +2 attack and damage with natural weapons for 1 round. Great if you have a ton of natural attacks and full attack with them like a ragebred skinwalker, but not terribly useful for Zealots aside from the increase in accuracy.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Bite of the Werewolf*: Bite with +1d6 damage and 1d6 bleed. A slightly better version of the highly underwhelming Bite of the Wererat.

Trample****: Standard action charge attack with 1d6 damage, and a free overrun attempt with no AoO and optional Knowledge (Nature) instead of CMB. It’s a standard action strike that moves you! That alone is worth a lot. It’s not as good as Fading Strike (Veiled Moon 2) or Hurricane Kick (Fool’s Errand 2), however, because you have to obey all of the rules of a charge.  Straight line, no difficult terrain, no intervening obstacles or creatures, etc.

Counters:

Blade Breaking Hide*: Sunder an attacking weapon with no AoO optionally using Knowledge (Nature), damage the weapon with your best natural attack if successful, and it does no damage if you destroy it. You need to deal 15 damage to a nonmagical longsword in order to destroy it, and that’s not always a sure thing at low levels unless your strength is particularly impressive. This counter also relies on destroying your loot. And you can’t use it to protect allies.

Boosts:

Envenomed Fangs****: Your next successful natural attack deals 1d4 strength damage with no save and ignores poison immunity.  Its duration is instantaneous, just like the Prana maneuvers from Steel Serpent, suggesting that you can apply it and have it remain for 24 hours before using it.  Dealing irresistible strength damage on the first attack of every encounter is fantastic for reducing incoming damage.

Primal Surge**: Your next natural attack deals bonus damage equal to cha.  Like Envenomed Fangs, it has an instantaneous duration, so you might be able to pre-buff yourself with this between combats as well.  But the effect is utterly piddly.  You only have so many maneuvers readied at one time, so this isn’t worth a slot, unless you really really want to kill a lone enemy before they can act.

3rd Level

Stances:

Furyhorn Stance**: You gain +5 reach, a 1d8 primary gore attack, and 2 1d4 secondary hoof attacks. The reach is lovely, but this stance is clearly for full attackers, not Zealots.

Strikes:

Bloody Horns***: Gore with +2d6 damage, your target is pushed 5 feet away, and they must make a reflex save or be knocked prone. No-save pushing makes for some interesting utility, and if you’re positioned well in relation to the enemies and your allies, you could help an ally escape a foe’s threatened area. Prone is still a decent condition at this level.

Mangling Claws**: 2 claw attacks with +2d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or have half movement speed for cha mod rounds. Potentially a big chunk of damage compared to other strikes of this level, since you’re making 2 attacks, but the rider barely does anything to help protect your team. Unless you and all of your allies can get away from your foe’s charge range before its turn comes up, it can still attack.

Return to Nature*: Natural attack with +3d6 damage, and you can make a sunder attempt with no AoO and optional Knowledge (Nature) instead of CMB against one item the target has. Not very good, for all the same reasons other sunder maneuvers aren’t very good. Destroying your loot is bad, you have to deal a lot of damage to get through the item’s hardness and HP, and your enemy proooobably has a backup plan to continue fighting.

Counters:

Bristle***: Your target within 30 feet must make a will save or be unable to move closer to you for 1 round. Very useful indeed if you’re protecting some squishy ranged allies from a big dumb melee monster, as it may prevent the monster from attacking at all on its turn. If your foe has any ranged attacks, spells, or another target it can get to in melee, this takes a nosedive in usefulness.

Boosts:

None

4th Level

Strikes:

Crushing Jaws*: Bite with +3d6 damage and ignore DR.  There are so, so many other maneuvers that do this better, and many also ignore hardness, making them useful out of combat. They’re also often lower level.

Tiger’s Leap*: Full round charge attack.  Make a full attack against a single target after charging.  An exact carbon copy of Raging Hunter Pounce (Primal Fury 2), coming 4 levels later. I guess this is what people are supposed to use until the errata for Path of War comes out if their GMs ban Primal Fury. Regardless, awful for Zealots.

Wide Swipe****: Claw with +2d6 damage against all enemies in melee range. It’s comparable to Silver Crane’s Spiral (Silver Crane 5) and even does extra damage! If you have a big reach, this is perfect for cleaning up hordes of mooks.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Bulette’s Charge*: Usable when you make a successful charge attack. Deal double damage.  Same problem as the Momentum line of maneuvers from Primal Fury. You have to devote every single action on your turn to do nothing but deal damage. That’s not what Zealots do best.

Heart of the Beast*****: For 1 minute, you gain +4 natural armor, scent, and increase your size by 1 category! Stacking size increases is one of the most powerful combat styles in the game, giving your more reach and damage, and this even gives you better AC and senses! Keep recovering this outside of combat so that it will always be on you.

5th Level

Stances:

Stance of the Sea King****: You gain the amphibious and aquatic subtypes, swim speed equal to your land speed, 1d8 primary bite attack, 2 1d4 secondary tentacle attacks with grab, and +4 CMB and CMD. The extra movement mode is lovely, but the grabby tentacles and extra CMB are the cream of this stance. Now you’re much better at controlling enemies and keeping them locked down! It’s just too bad that the tentacles are secondary attacks. You might have a hard time landing AoOs with them.

Strikes:

Fury Horn Smash*: Full round charge attack. You gain trample and a +4d6 slam attack while charging. Trample is much better than the overrun maneuver alone, and you could wind up making a lot of foes prone. But the stars need to align in order for this to actually be effective. You need to have a decent number of enemies in the proper position to trample, they need to be smaller than you, you need to be confident you won’t get too hurt by their AoOs, you can’t be on difficult terrain, and of course, your enemies need to not be immune to being tripped. Oh, I almost forgot, full round action and no other good rider.

Terrifying Roar***: [mind-affecting, fear] Panic enemies in a 30 foot cone for 1 round unless they make a will save, and they’re shaken for cha mod rounds regardless. This can be easily stacked with other methods of inducing mass fear, like Dazzling Display, Wild Beast’s Roar, or Black Seraph’s Glare (Black Seraph 1), letting you at least frighten enemies with no save.

Thrash*: Natural weapon attack with +4d6 damage against all adjacent foes, ignore DR, and push them 5 feet away. If you have a lot of enemies clumped up around you and you’re the party’s tank, that’s a good thing! You don’t want to push them away! And you don’t want a maneuver that only works against adjacent enemies when you could use one that targets enemies in your entire reach, like Wide Swipe!

Volley of the Manticore*: Shoot 1 + ⅕ IL spikes up to 180 feet that deal 3d6 + cha mod damage. At level 10, you’d shoot 3 spikes as a standard action, which sounds nice, until you remember that bog-standard Paizo archers can shoot 4 arrows per round at level 6 (5 with haste), and have a much easier time of stacking damage on their ranged attacks than you could on these spikes.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Chimeric Body Stance****: You gain a huge number of natural attacks that you don’t already possess, and two of: blindsight 30, burrow 30, darkvision 60, grab, fly 60 (good), scent, swim 60, or trample.  Most Zealots won’t be too interested in the extra natural attacks, but the new senses and movement modes grant amazing versatility. And hey, grab is on the list!

Strikes:

Dragon’s Breath***: 10d6 energy damage of your choice in a 30 foot cone or 60 foot line, and your targets must make a reflex save for half damage. The versatility of shape and energy type is nice, but it provides no other rider, and there are other strikes like Shadow Raptor Swarm (Black Seraph 6) and Ether Wave (Veiled Moon 6) that deal more damage or have better effects.

Kraken’s Grasp**: Knowledge (Nature) in place of CMB to deal 5d10 damage and grapple, immobilize, and entangle a foe, which can be extended each round as a swift action.  The damage is flat and doesn’t benefit from any modifiers like strength.  In fact, neither does the CMB check, since it’s purely a Knowledge (Nature) check, and Zealots aren’t very good at intelligence-based skills.  This isn’t very useful against melee bruiser enemies, but is great against casters.  To really jack up your knowledge checks, you’ll need a level of Rubato Bard and the Pageant of the Peacock masterpiece.

Lamia’s Sting*****: Sting attack with +4d6 damage and your target must make a fortitude save or be paralyzed for 1 round.  Paralyze is the best lockdown effect in the game, because it leaves your opponent helpless and vulnerable to coup de grace.

Titanic Claw**: Claw attack with +6d8 damage and your target is knocked 5/3 IL feet in any direction and knocked prone.  Reflex save reduces distance by half and negates prone.  It’s nice that you can force a target to move a little bit no matter what if you hit them, but the distance is nothing compare to what you can do with Fool’s Errand, and prone isn’t a very useful condition at this level due to the number of things that are immune to being prone.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

7th Level

Strikes:

Spellbreaking Roar****: 30 ft cone.  Area greater dispel magic with 5d6 damage.  A very useful piece of utility that almost no other initiators are capable of.  Characters with the Mage Hunter prestige class or a few Shattered Mirror maneuvers can dispel, but that’s about it.  This is an invaluable piece of utility, even if the damage is inconsequential.

Thousand Claws*: Full round action.  Attack with all your natural attacks and deal an increasing +1d6 damage per hit.  It’s nothing more than a plain old full attack with extra damage.

Counters:

Dragon Tortoise Shell**: Gain DR 20/- and energy resistance 20 acid/cold/electricity/fire until the start of your next turn.  You can’t use this to protect allies, and it’s almost certainly less likely to reduce as much damage as a counter that completely negates an attack.  The only time this would be useful is if you’re absolutely certain you have the full attention of multiple weak incoming damage sources.

Boosts:

None

8th Level

Stances:

Unleashed Dragon Stance***: Use Form of the Dragon II, and recover breath weapon uses with a swift action.  You become a large-sized dragon with some lovely stat bonuses, mobility improvements, natural attacks, and a breath weapon.  It’s a polymorph effect which has ups and downs.  You can’t use armor or any of your gear that doesn’t provide a constant bonus.  Fortunately, it will protect you from hostile polymorph effects.  The real nail in the coffin for this stance is that simply using a dorje of metamorphosis is better for combat.  This stance is still useful because of its versatility.

Strikes:

Fang Dragon Sting**: Sting attack with +6d6 damage and 4d4 constitution drain, fortitude half, and you heal 3 damage per point of constitution drained.  On average on a failed save, this will knock 10 constitution off of an enemy, or 5 HP per HD.  The heal is negligible.  This is simply a pure damage strike dressed up in some fancy paint.  But at least it can make landing subsequent fortitude save strikes easier.

Guillotine Jaws*: Bite attack with +7d10 damage, counts as adamantine, and has the vorpal quality.  You can chomp through walls, but any other strike that ignores hardness can do that too.  The vorpal quality on a bite means that you need to roll a natural 20 and confirm it for it to do anything special.  That likelihood is simply too miniscule.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Rampage*: Full round action.  Attack, move 10 feet with no AoO, attack a different creature, repeat until you miss.  If even one attack misses, the chain ends.  If there aren’t multiple foes in range to attack, you can’t attack the same creature twice in a row.  There are so many cases where this strike could even be flat out worse than a full attack.  How embarrassing.

Final Ruling**:  There are very few noteworthy maneuvers in this discipline for Zealots.  It’s low on crowd control, heavy on pure damage, and its utility is spread out far between different levels.  However, Envenomed Fangs and Heart of the Beast are things that any Zealot can benefit from every single combat.

Cursed Razor

Skill:  Spellcraft.  2 counters.

Weapon Groups:  Heavy Blades, Light Blades, Spears.  This discipline has 14 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  All strikes in this discipline are melee-only.

Martial Tradition:  The Quills.  Evil.

1st Level

Stances:

Aura of Misfortune****:  All enemies in close range have -2 saves.  The lower an enemy’s saves are, the more often your debuff and crowd control strikes work on them, and the more effective you are!  And it only gets better the more enemies you debuff at once, and the more party members you have who target saves.

Touch of the Witch**:  [curse].  Everything you hit becomes cursed for cha mod rounds.  With an AoE build, this makes it easier to curse multiple things in a single round, helping you get a better bonus with Luck Shifting.  But if you’re using a curse-centric AoO build, why not use Vigilant Keeper’s Stance (Eternal Guardian 1) instead?

Strikes:

Stutter Strike*:  [curse].  Normal damage, curse your target for cha mod rounds, and your target must make a will save or suffer -4 on language-based checks and 25% verbal spell failure for IL rounds.  How often do enemies try to use diplomacy, bluff, or linguistics in the middle of combat?  The spell failure chance is low, doesn’t work on psychic or psionic casters, and has a very short duration at early levels.

Woeful Burden*:  [curse].  Normal damage, curse your target for cha mod rounds, and their movement speed is reduced.  No-save effects are nice, except when the effect is largely useless.  Cursed Razor strikes are melee-only, so it’s not like you can use this with a ranged weapon and then kite your slowed target.  

Counters:

Spilled Salt*****:  Give a target within medium range -4 on an attack or skill check.  Huge range, incredible versatility, and can protect your allies!  Though -4 is only a 20% chance to succeed, this is the best 1st level counter in the game for protecting allies, because the only other level 1 counter capable of doing so (Body of Delusion, Sleeping Goddess 1) requires you to expend your psionic focus.  Great for Echoes of Steel with your psicrystal, because the psicrystal doesn’t need to make a check.

Boosts:

Luck Shifting**:  For 1 round, you get +1 luck to AC per cursed enemy within medium range, max +5.  At levels 1 and 2, you probably won’t be able to curse many enemies at once, so this is of limited use.  And once you get the ability to quickly curse multiple enemies, you’ll have better boosts and counters.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Mockery*:  +1d6 damage.  If target is cursed, +3d6 instead.  Yaaaawn, a riderless damage strike that even requires prior setup.

Torment the Weak*:  +1d6 damage.  If target is cursed, +1d6 damage per round for cha mod rounds.  More damage overall than Mockery, but what enemy is going to live for 4+ rounds at this level?  And why are you using a pure damage strike?

Counters:

Bad Karma****:  [curse].  Can counter any attack, including spells, and your attacker must make a will save or suffer -4 to all d20 rolls for 1d4 rounds.  It might sound like it could potentially be 4 times better than Spilled Salt, but you can’t use it if an enemy is attacking your allies instead of you.  And a -4 to d20 rolls won’t even do anything against most spells.  But it can make a full attacker miss several attacks over the course of its duration, and if it makes them miss at least 2, it’s better than most counters already.  Another major benefit is that it makes your target have -4 to saves, letting you lay on the punishment afterwards.

Word of Retribution**:  Usable when a cursed creature damages you.  Roll spellcraft vs DC 10 + ½ HD + cha, and your attacker takes the same amount of irresistible damage it dealt to you if successful.  If your GM throws a lot of fragile speedsters and glass cannons at you, like sorcerers, this isn’t too shabby.  But if you mostly go up against standard heavy hitters like large-sized enemies or Big Stupid Fighters, this won’t help much.

Boosts:

Murderous Spite***:  Your next attack against a cursed creature is a melee touch attack.  You get this one level earlier than Scarlet Eye’s Perception (Scarlet Throne 3), with a fairly easy requirement.  Remember that you can’t use Power Attack with touch attacks.

3rd Level

Stances:

Aura of Shared Misery*****:  When a creature within 20 feet of you gets cursed, another creature gets cursed for cha mod rounds, and cursed creatures within 20 feet of you take ¼*IL damage per die when damaged.  Now you can spread curses around willy nilly and effortlessly!  Get Cursed Razor Plague, and you curse EVERY enemy around you instead of just 1!  It’s a hefty damage increase for your allies as well, applying to every single attack they do.  Combines especially well with Elemental Flux which has damage dice galore, and full attackers.  If you’re a Finesse Zealot, I hope you’re using an estoc, because that deals 2d4 damage!

Strikes:

Dogpile Strike***:  +2d6 damage (+4d6 if target is flanked), and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone.  Tripping is still alright at this level, but there are better effects.  The damage is nothing to write home about.  If you trip something that has more than one of your allies around it, it’s probably dead anyway.

Huntsman's Curse****:  [curse].  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or be cursed, staggered, and suffer -1 attack, reflex, and AC, and half move speed for cha mod rounds.  Quite a lot of debuffs for quite a long time!  The staggered condition still allows the target to fight back with a standard action, however feebly.  Great for ruining a multi-attacking, durable, but low-willed opponent.

Counters:

Sorcerer's Sidestep***:  +2 luck bonus (+1 per cursed opponent in medium range, max 10) to saving throws for 1 round.  With Aura of Shared Misery and Cursed Plague Razor, you’ll be nigh-immune to effects that require saves.  Unless you roll a natural 1, of course.  Can’t protect your friends, though, and being the target of more than one effect that requires a save in a single round isn’t common.

Boosts:

None

4th Level

Strikes:

Hangman's Curse**:  [curse].  Normal damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be cursed and exhausted for cha mod rounds.  It gives more numerical penalties than Huntsman’s Curse, but fortitude saves are easier for frontliner enemies to resist, and staggered prevents full attacks.

Persecution***:  +4d6 damage, or +8d8 if your target is cursed.  Okay, it’s a humongous amount of damage that’s easy to enable by this point.  At IL 8, if you have Aura of Shared Misery and an estoc, you will deal 2d4+8d8+20 damage before other modifiers, for an average of 61.  A CR 8 enemy meant to be an average challenge for a party of 4 or 5 8th level characters has an average of 100 HP.  And it’s not difficult to add more damage.  Alright.  If you really want to have a massive damage strike for when there’s no need to debuff or crowd control enemies, then feel free to take this, simply because it’s just that powerful and can kill many things in one hit.  Of course, it will very quickly lose effectiveness as you level up.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Warlock's Stride**:  [curse].  For 1 round, your move speeds are doubled, and squares you move through have an aura that forces creatures who pass through to make a will save or suffer a curse with -15 speed, -4 to attacks, and -4 to skills for cha mod rounds.  Battlefield control is a rare thing to find in maneuvers, but you need to actually move in order to use it, and then you need your enemies to move into the squares you moved through.  If you have a high speed, you could use it to box low-mobility enemies into an area, or cover your party while you make a retreat.

Witchfinder's Brand***:  If your target in medium range uses a spell/power/SLA in the next round, it has to roll a concentration check (DC 15 + IL + cha mod) or be disrupted.  The DC is moderately difficult, making it a decent deterrent and effective crowd control against casters.

5th Level

Stances:

The Dragon Knows**:  Blindsight 60, and cursed enemies fail acrobatics checks to move through your threatened squares without AoOs.  Blindsight is nice, but if you can wait juuuust a bit longer, you can get Unavoidable Gaze of the Sleeping Goddess as a 6th level stance.  If you’re an AoO build, you probably already have an unassailable CMD to prevent acrobatics users from slipping by.  And the really slippery ones will use alternate movement moves, not acrobatics.

Strikes:

Festering Curse**:  [curse].  +4d6 damage, auto curse, and your target must make a fortitude save or take 2d6 damage per turn for cha mod rounds.  A negligibly more damaging version of Torment the Weak that requires a fortitude save?  Definitely not for melee enemies.  It might be useful on a caster enemy to force them to make concentration checks every round.

Witch's Revenge:**  [curse].  Normal damage, curse for cha mod rounds, and your target must make a fortitude save or suffer -4 to an ability score (if cursed, -6 to one score or -4 to a second score) for IL rounds.  Hangman’s Curse inflicts exhaustion which is the same as -6 to both strength and dexterity, and it’s worse than Huntsman’s Curse.  The only useful thing this can do is potentially remove a caster’s ability to cast their highest level spells, and that’s not a certainty.

Counters:

Shadow Pin*****:  [curse].  Immobilize your target no matter what for 1 round with no save.  There are loads of great uses for this.  You can stop big monsters from charging you or your allies, you can prevent an ally from being knocked away by a forced movement effect, and you can even force flyers to the ground.  Again, with no save or skill check!

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Oathbreaker's Aura**:  [curse].  Enemies within 30 feet lose their anarchic, axiomatic, profane, sacred, and insight bonuses, and anyone you hit becomes cursed for cha mod rounds.  Useful against only a small number of characters like psychic warriors, awakened blades, Sleeping Goddess users, Black Seraph users, Silver Crane users, and self-buffing melee clerics and warpriests.  Other types of bonuses are much more common, like enhancement or size.  As for the cursing aspect, Aura of Shared Misery is better.

Strikes:

Curse of Chains*****:  [curse].  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or be cursed and paralyzed for cha mod rounds, and enemies ending adjacent to the target can get paralyzed too!  Being paralyzed for 1 round usually means a coup de grace flavored death.  Being paralyzed for cha mod rounds means many more.  And it can even paralyze multiple targets with a battlefield control kind of effect!

Warlock's Blow****:  [teleportation].  Long range.  Your target must make a will save or be yoinked into your waiting embrace, and you attack for +8d6 damage.  This is hilarious for assassin type characters, who can kidnap and shank their target from several hundred feet away.  Or you could use it to nab and murderify that pesky wizard who’s been pelting your party with spells from some inaccessible spot.  Heck, you could even use it on an ally to pull their fat out of the frying pan and into your protective arms!

Counters:

Eye for an Eye***:  Your attacker suffers the same damage and effects they just hit you with, even spells, with no save.  If you got hit with something nasty from a glass cannon enemy despite your best efforts, this can erase that glass cannon from the board, because you probably have more hitpoints and Diehard.

Boosts:

Sorcerer's Gaze**:  For 1 round, your attacks ignore partial cover, deflection, and concealment, though you need to know what square your target is in.  Now those tricksy Improved Invisibility users don’t have such a huge advantage.  Deflection bonuses usually aren’t very high, unless your target is incorporeal and has a high charisma.  Really, it’s more cost-effective to use some method to reveal invisible creatures rather than keep this boost readied.

7th Level

Strikes:

Black Dog's Due**:  +8d6 damage (+12d6 if flanked), and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone.  Not many things are susceptible to being knocked prone at this level.  At least it ignores the problem that tripping has, of being more difficult against things with too many legs or a big size modifier.  But it still won’t work against things with no legs or that fly.

Traitor's Roar*:  [compulsion, curse, mind-affecting].  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or immediately take a standard action to harm its allies as much as possible.  Other than a curse for cha mod rounds, it doesn’t actually inflict a lasting debuff.  It’s only useful against enemies that can inflict tremendous damage or negative effects with a standard action, ones that will be better than you simply hitting an enemy with one of your debuffing strikes.  That’s not very common.  The enemy can even include you and your friends in its attack.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Woedrinker*****:  Standard action, not technically classified as a boost.  For 1 minute, gain 20% concealment and +2 luck to attack and damage (+2 per cursed enemy in medium range, max +10).  And for 1 hour, you gain 10 THP (+10 per cursed enemy in medium range, max +50).  An utterly ludicrous buff that you can have up at all times, effortlessly!  You have good social skills, so you should be able to convince your friends and psicrystal to let you curse them every so often.  Even if you’re a loner with no friends and just a psicrystal, the bonuses are still great.

8th Level

Stances:

Luckdrinker Aura*****:  You automatically know what magical effects are on visible creatures within 30 feet, and you can steal an effect from one creature for cha mod rounds and give it to another with a dispel check as no action.  You can use this to steal the buffs of a super buffed up cleric or druid, or save an ally from a harsh debuff by removing it from them and putting it on an enemy, or even transfer personal-only buffs from your party’s 9th level spellcasters onto your martial party members!  And even if you don’t do any of that, knowing what effects are on everyone around you is an incredible information tool.

Strikes:

Unending Nightmare Strike***:  Normal damage, 4 damage to all three mental ability scores, and your target must make a will save every round at the start of your turn or take 4 more mental ability score damage.  This one-shots creatures that have low mental ability scores, and can potentially one-shot many martial characters that dumped their mental scores like a barbarian with 7 charisma when your next turn comes up.  It reduces the DC of a spellcaster’s spells, and reduces the will save of everything.  It’s not a big effect immediately, so you have to be smart about picking your target.

Counters:

Warlock's Mirror***:  Roll spellcraft vs DC 10 + ½ HD + cha mod of your attacker, and if successful, the attack instead affects 3 creatures of your choice in medium range.  This can turn an enemy caster’s or initiator’s single target nuke into a triple target self-nuke!  Alas, it only works if you got targeted, not just your allies.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Festival of Shadows*:  Attack everything in close range for +10d6 damage (+12d8 if cursed), and all enemies in close range must make a reflex save or be immobilized for cha mod rounds.  Immobilization is good against flying enemies, but unlike Shadow Pin, it doesn’t stop people from teleporting.  Most enemies at this level will also be big and have reach, or have powerful ranged or supernatural abilities to use if they can’t hit you in melee.  And you need to be in close range of them.

Final Ruling****:  It has a little bit of everything dotted neatly through the levels, some of which have irreplaceable effects like Shadow Pin and Woedrinker.  It has the best 1st level ally-protecting counter in the game, making entry and qualification for higher level maneuvers easy.  Aura of Shared Misery with Cursed Razor Plague interacts beautifully with Eternal Guardian.  Great overall for AoO builds and Finesse Zealots, and even ranged Zealots will enjoy a few counters and boosts.

Elemental Flux

Skill:  Spellcraft.  2 counters, 1 boost.

Weapon Groups:  Light Blades, Monk, Thrown.  This discipline has 14 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Cagebreaker Brotherhood.  Chaotic.

1st Level

Stances:

Elemental Nimbus*****:  Various offensive bonuses, the best of which is water.  Any time you hit, your target has to make a fortitude save or be staggered for 1 round!  Stop enemies dead in their tracks as they approach with your AoOs, no longer able to use a standard action to attack!

Embrace the Elements**:  Various defensive bonuses.  You’ll need a way to switch your active element in combat as a free action for this to be very good, like with Elemental Flux Style.  Stroll around in Fire outside of combat for bonus initiative, and switch to Air in combat for bonus dodge to AC.

Strikes:

Spark Strike*:  +2d4 (augment +3d4) energy damage.  That’s it.  That’s all.  Unfortunately, we Zealots have higher standards than merely dealing paltry damage!  Adjust your top hat and monocle and leave this maneuver in the gutter where you found it.

Variable Flux*:  Normal damage, and your target must make a save or suffer a weak debuff for 1 round.  None of the effects are worth your precious standard action when other disciplines have better strikes.

Counters:

Eldritch Shield**:  Gain 10 (augment 20) energy resistance against a specific attack or effect.  It lets you easily completely ignore energy damage at low levels, but energy damage isn’t very common at low levels either.  You just might be able to convince your GM that you can use this to be immune to hot and cold weather!

Boosts:

Fluctuation Movement***:  You get weaker versions of several movement-based 1st level boosts in one!  The only one of particular interest is Air, letting you jump with +10 acrobatics as a free action.  It’s only half as good as Leaping Dragon (Thrashing Dragon), but it’s something.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Elemental Strike*****:  Normal damage, and your target must make a save or suffer a moderate to strong debuff for 1 round, including the likes of blinded and nauseated!  Augment to increase the damage and DC.

Counters:

Arcane Shield**:  Roll spellcraft vs attack roll to negate.  You can augment it to get a +2 shield bonus until the start of your next turn, but most Zealots will use shields anyway.  It’s better than some 2nd level counters, but still isn’t great because you can’t use it to protect allies, and is intelligence-based.

Boosts:

Degrade Resistance*:  Ignore 10 energy resist for 1 round.  Augment for +1d6 energy damage for your next attack.  If energy resistance is a serious problem for you, there are ways around it, like taking the Elemental Focus feat, or switching to a different active element.  Don’t waste your swift action forcing a square peg through a round hole.

Eldritch Fang****:  Your next attack deals +1d4 (augment +2d4) force damage, ignores DR, and your target must make a fortitude save or be staggered for 1 round.  Not a bad effect at all, and has multiple uses, letting you affect golems and ghosts alike.  But it won’t stack with Elemental Nimbus with the water element.

Energy Spark***:  Initiate when you make an attack to shoot one (augment for two at IL 7) 3d6 energy damage ray.  If no one on your team is in need of your protection via counters or crowd control, this can be useful for finishing off a low-health enemy.

3rd Level

Stances:

Elemental Flux Stance*****:  15 energy resist, +2d6 damage on your attacks, and you get an additional buff.  Every single effect this stance gives is excellent.  And you even get limitless fast healing to heal up to full HP after every encounter!  It might not scale, but it will easily last you until level 9, and you’ll always be able to find a use for it.

Strikes:

Energy Jolt***:  30 foot ranged touch attack.  3d6 (augment +1d6 and +1 DC per animus) energy damage, and your target must make a save or suffer a weak additional effect.  This might deal less damage than Elemental Strike, depending on what weapon you’re using, and its effects are worse.  The upside is that this is a touch attack, and the sickened and entangled debuffs last for cha mod rounds instead of 1 round.

Lance of Power***:  30 foot line.  5d6 damage, and creatures hit must make a reflex save to take half damage and negate a debuff.  You can augment up to 5 animus for +2d6 damage and +1 DC each.  The debuffs aren’t very powerful, but lines are great for dealing with swarms and enemies packed in narrow dungeon corridors.

Raging Flux**:  +4d6 energy damage.  For every 10 damage you deal, push the target 5 feet (+5 more per animus augment).  Useful if you’re fighting something with incredibly high saves near dangerous terrain, I suppose, since this offers no save.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

4th Level

Strikes:

Arcane Torrent*:  Target must make a reflex save or take 6d6 force damage.  Augment with 2 animus to make it a 15 foot radius attack.  The fact that it can be completely negated and doesn’t even have any riders of any kind is atrocious.

Energy Hammer*****:  +6d6 energy damage, and your target must make a save or suffer a serious debuff for 1d4 rounds, now including stunned!  Augment for +1d6 damage and +1 DC per animus.  The clear graduation up from Elemental Strike!  Three of the four debuffs are highly potent, the duration is amazing, and the versatility from a single maneuver is wonderful.  It even does higher damage than average for most strikes!

Counters:

Eldritch Consumption**:  Roll spellcraft vs DC 11 + attacker’s CL to negate a spell targeting you and heal some HP.  It only protects you, not your allies, and doesn’t work against area spells.  Also, you’re not highly likely to make the DC.  If you have 10 intelligence and maxed spellcraft ranks, you will have a 60% to make the DC against an equal level attacker.  You could get an Armillary Amulet for +5 more spellcraft, but that takes up your neck slot, and your Amulet of Natural Armor lives there!

Boosts:

Assay Resistance*:  Your next attack ignores 25 energy resistance, ignores DR, and deals +2d6 (augment +3d6) damage.  Like Degrade Resistance, it’s not worth the swift action.

5th Level

Stances:

Enter the Vortex*****:  You can throw energy blasts that count as thrown weapons, do 4d6 energy damage with a range increment of 30, and are ranged touch attacks.  You also get a movement ability, including tremorsense!  This stance fixes just about every problem that throwing weapon builds have.  You don’t need to draw your blasts or return them to your hand.  No weapon in the game can match a 4d6 ranged touch attack, either.  You can use these blasts with any other strike that uses ranged attacks.  You could grab Psionic Throw for a bit more oomph if you’re dexterity-based, or Powerful Throw (prereq: Power Attack, Str 15, BAB +1) from Akashic Mysteries to use strength instead of dexterity for throwing weapon attack rolls.

Strikes:

Elemental Drive*:  30 foot ray.  9d6 energy damage, and you bull rush (augment for +5 bonus) your target with IL + cha instead of BAB + str.  Bull rushing isn’t as useful as other effects at this level.

Elemental Vortex***:  +8d6 energy damage, and you might apply a moderate debuff.  Air’s effect gives your whole party a +4 bonus to hit for 1 round regardless of whether you hit with Elemental Vortex, which could be handy if you’re up against an ultra armored AC lover.  Other effects are just upgrades of Energy Jolt.  Energy Hammer is still the winner.

Counters:

Elemental Absorption***:  For 1 round, become immune to your active element’s damage and heal when you get hit by it.  You need to know ahead of time when this will be worth readying, because it only works for your active element.  It can completely negate certain attacks without a roll, but it can’t help teammates.

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Nexus of Elemental Retribution*:  Energy resist 30 vs fire, cold, acid, and lightning, and you store energy damage dealt to you, up to 2*IL, which you can release as a swift action in a 20 foot radius burst centered on you.  It’s too situational to use all the time, too dangerous to use near allies, and just not a good idea to use swift actions on plain old damage as a Zealot.

Strikes:

Eldritch Energy Hammer**:  Normal damage, and you use greater dispel magic to dispel one spell from your target and deal bonus damage equal to the spell’s level.  Carnival Swap (Shattered Mirror 4) has an even better effect and doesn’t require you to make a dispel check, but even its effect is too situational, making this a tough sell as well.  If your target has multiple buffs, you can’t even specify which one you want to dispel.

Elemental Destruction Ring****:  20 foot burst centered on you.  12d6 energy damage, and all creatures inside must make a reflex save for half damage and to negate a debuff.  Area-effect disabling debuffs!  The only downside this has is that you have to be careful with positioning so that you don’t hit an ally, and you have to put yourself right in the middle of all of your enemies to use it.  Big risk, but big reward!

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Eldritch Fang Flurry*****:  For 1 round, your attacks deal +3d6 force damage, ignore DR, and your targets must make a fortitude save or be blinded for 1 round.  Combine this with strikes that hit multiple targets for some devastating damage and debuffing!

Shatter Resistance*:  For 1 round, your attacks ignore energy resistance, deal half damage to creatures with energy immunity instead of none, and deal +4d6 energy damage.  Eldritch Fang Flurry is better in every way, because it ignores DR, inflicts force damage which affects incorporeal targets and is resisted by almost nothing, and includes a debuff rider.

7th Level

Strikes:

Cascade of Elemental Wrath*:  Full attack with +1d6 + cha mod damage, and all of your damage is purely elemental energy.  Augment with 2 animus for an extra attack.  Zealots don’t like using full round actions or strikes that don’t offer mobility, utility, or debuff riders.

Force Majeure*:  +14d6 damage, and all damage is pure energy damage.  Augment with 3 animus to make it force damage.  A standard action strike version of Cascade of Elemental Wrath.  Other than being a standard action instead of a full action, it has the same problems that Cascade of Elemental Wrath does.

Counters:

Redirecting Flux**:  Roll spellcraft vs DC 15 + effect’s CL to redirect a spell.  Like Eldritch Consumption, it’s a difficult skill check to make, and it only works if a non-area-effect spell targets you specifically.  Scary wizards, witches, and psions (who are known for having high intelligence) will probably be smart enough to not target you with anything that can trigger this counter.  If the stars align and you do manage to succeed at using it, it’s a nice way to turn your enemy’s strength against them.

Boosts:

None

8th Level

Stances:

Master of the Elements****:  Your type changes to outsider (native) with your element as a subtype, and you get to use Elemental Body III without losing your equipment.  Being immune to critical hits and sneak attacks is pretty amazing, as is increasing your size, reach, and stats with size bonuses.  Now you don’t have to save up for that Skin of Proteus anymore!

Strikes:

Zephyr Flux****:  [teleportation].  Full round action.  Hit one target for 14d6 energy damage and secondary targets within 30 feet of the primary target for 7d6 energy damage, and they must make a reflex save for half damage and to negate a debuff.  Then you can move to a space within 10 feet of a secondary target.  Though it’s a full round action, it’s effectively a 30 foot radius fireball combined with crowd control and movement!  One of the few instances where using a full round maneuver is worth it for a Zealot.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Elemental Breach*:  For 1 round, your attacks ignore energy resistance, immunity, and DR, and your energy damage is increased by 50%.  A pure damage boost.  Maybe, just maybe, you could combine this with Cascade of Elemental Wrath and a Two Weapon Fighting build to deal ludicrous damage round after round.  But there are ten bajillion ways to make builds that deal excessive damage and kill anything in the monster manual in a single round.  This combo isn’t bad by any means, but it’s just not something a Zealot should specifically be interested in.

9th Level

Strikes:

Strike of Elemental Devastation***:  Full round action.  Shoot 5 ranged touch attacks with a static amount of damage and 4 strong debuffs, 3 of which allow no save.  Another arguably good use of a full round action.  But remember that if you can’t use a move action to recover your maneuvers, you can’t spam this strike round after round.

Final Ruling***:  To make the most of this discipline, you really need to be able to switch your active element quickly.  Either have Elemental Flux Style to switch active elements as a free action,  a 1 level dip of mystic so that you can switch them as part of entering a new stance, or a way to quickly regain your psionic focus, like Overpowering Optimism or Psicrystal Reservoir.  You can change your active element when you regain psionic focus, because you also change your psionic active energy type at the same time!  If you’re careful and plan ahead, you could get by with a single element in combat, and only switch elements outside of combat for utility.  But once you get caught with your pants down, you might be in trouble and unable to switch to your most useful element without spending a standard action.  You also need a way to deal with energy immunity, eventually, preferably without relying on boosts.  It’s ironic that such a versatile, flexible, thematically chaotic discipline requires so much forethought to use it well.

Eternal Guardian

Skill:  Intimidate.  2 counters and 1 strike.

Weapon Groups:  Hammer, Heavy Blade, Polearm.  This discipline has 13 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Loyal Order of the Branded Waerloch.  Any non-evil.

1st Level

Stances:

Valiant Keeper’s Stance**:  Your allies don’t provoke AoOs while moving through squares you threaten.  It’s like Escape Route around you!  But low level enemies are already fairly easy to get around, so this stance’s benefit is most noticed at high levels when fighting bigger enemies with higher CMD.

Vigilant Keeper’s Stance****:  [curse].  All squares you threaten are difficult terrain for your enemies, and when you hit an enemy with an AoO, they become cursed until the end of your next turn!  The first effect alone makes this stance amazing, and the second makes it extremely easy to get the bonus effects of other strikes.  Enemies can’t even 5 foot step while within your threatened area!  Of the two 1st level stances, this one is much better at low levels.

Strikes:

Guard’s Oath***:  [curse].  Melee-only.  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or be cursed for 24 hours and provokes AoOs from you even when using 5 foot steps or withdraw actions.  Very handy dandy to prevent flighty enemies from escaping or slipping around to get at your squishier teammates, but many low level enemies don’t use movement-based tactics like this.  You’re more likely to fight a lot more mindless undead, orc warriors, wild animals, and thugs than scouts or cutpurses, and such things are likely to die quickly before you have the chance to actually use an AoO that this strike could grant you.  The 24 hour duration is what keeps this maneuver from being completely awful.

Strike of the Infinite Protector*:  Normal damage, give an ally in your collective (or 30 feet) +2 AC for 1 round.  Nice and simple, but also underwhelming.

Terrifying Blow****:  [fear].  Normal damage, or +1d6 if target is cursed, and your target must make a will save or be frightened for 1 round.  Crowd control that prevents your enemy from attacking you, especially at level 1, is very nice to have.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Warden’s Bearing**:  Get a +2 bonus to your next combat maneuver, be able to affect 1 size larger, and don’t provoke AoOs.  It can be nice to use on round 1 in preparation for an enemy’s charge, but you’ll get little chance to use it to good effect after that since using a strike is generally better than using this boost + a combat maneuver.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Relentless Warden’s Strike*****:  [teleportation].  Teleport 60 feet to a feared or cursed enemy and smack them for +2d6 damage!  Strikes that let you both move and attack, and only cost a standard action, are exactly what Zealots love most.  Fearing and cursing are very easy to do, especially with Vigilant Keeper’s Stance and Fear the Reaper.

Strike of the Royal Guardian*:  [curse].  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or be cursed with no time limit and suffer -2 damage on weapon attacks.  The effect is pitiful for a 2nd level strike that adds no damage and allows a save.  The only good thing you can say about this strike is that the curse lasts until it’s removed.

Counters:

Fear the Reaper*****:  [fear].  One of the best 2nd level counters in the entire game, especially for Zealots.  Roll Intimidate to negate an enemy’s attack against you OR an ally in your collective (or 60 feet), and you make the enemy shaken for 1 round if you succeed!  Most 2nd level counters only protect you and you alone, and do nothing else extra!  Combo this with Relentless Warden’s Strike to surprise the enemy archer you just terrified!

Oath of the Intercessor*:  Switch places with an ally within melee reach to take an attack for them.  It doesn’t attempt to negate or mitigate the attack at all, and it competes with one of the best counters in the game.

Boosts:

Debilitating Fear***:  Pick a feared creature, and it has to make a will save or be dazed for 1 round.  Dazed is a good condition to inflict, but if the creature is already feared, it’s the least of your worries.  But at least a dazed creature has a 0% chance to get an attack through, so if you don’t have more pressing matters to attend to, this can help you solidify your victory in a fight.

3rd Level

Stances:

Stance of the Eternal Guardian**:  Shield Other that slowly scales up with levels.  Not recommended for melee Zealots who will be in the thick of the fight, but could be useful for ranged Zealots.  Or you could simply take 1 rank of Use Magic Device and use a wand of Shield Other.  Other disciplines have superior 3rd level stances that aren’t so easily replicable.

Strikes:

None

Counters:

Intruder’s End****:  [teleportation].  For 1 round, your threatened area increases to a minimum of 20 feet, you gain +2 to attacks on AoOs, and you gain a bonus number of AoOs that explicitly stacks with other things like Impulsive Reactions!  Since this is an immediate action and not a swift action with a duration of 1 round, you have to remember what initiative count you used it on.  This is perfect for dealing with hordes of enemies, especially if you have Vigilant Keeper’s Stance to make your threatened area difficult terrain.

Swallow your Fear****:  Give yourself or an ally a reroll against a mind-affecting effect with a +4 morale bonus, with a sizeable chunk of temporary HP if they succeed!  Though this counter only works against a specific category of attacks, mind-affecting effects are things you definitely don’t want to land, and aren’t all that uncommon.  It’s even one level lower than Silver Crane Resurgence which has a similar effect.

Boosts:

Binding Fetters****:  [curse, teleportation].  Melee-only.  Activate when you hit to curse your target for 1 round, and they have to make a will save or be teleported next to you at the start of your next turn.  It’s like tying a bungee cord to your enemy.  A bungee cord made out of merciless black glowing chains!  You can even use this on allies, and thanks to your Collective, you can use it at range on them!  Shove your kleptomaniac rogue friend off a cliff to “go scouting,” and pull em back up before they splatter!

4th Level

Strikes:

Grim Guard’s Laughter*****:  [fear].  Melee-only.  +4d6 damage, and do a Dazzling Display for free!  If someone was already cursed, they’re frightened instead of shaken.  Good damage, great multi-target debuffing, great combo potential, and potential crowd control.  If you have ways to curse multiple enemies at once like Aura of the Shared Master and Cursed Razor Plague, this will let you frighten multiple targets at once!

Strike of the Steadfast Legion***:  Bonus damage equal to ½ your IL, and your friends gain DR/- equal to your cha mod for 1 round.  Allies can also sacrifice their own HP to grant temporary HP to others.  Now your psicrystal or a backline party member can give you oodles of temp HP to keep you strong on the frontline!

Counters:

Watchman’s Rebuke***:  Force an enemy to reroll a saving throw, and with a -2 penalty if cursed.  Can be good for ensuring a powerful crowd control effect lands on a particularly dangerous enemy, but you need to judge whether or not it wouldn’t be better to use a more widely applicable, protective counter.

Boosts:

Oath of Torpor**:  Every creature you hit after activating this boost before your next turn gets cursed, and has to make a will save when they move or be slowed for 1 round.  Since it’s a boost that relies on hitting multiple times in a round, it’s not the best for Zealots, unless you get lucky rolling initiative and use it in the 1st round of combat.  Then, if your enemies aren’t the sharpest tools in the shed, you’ll hopefully land a lot of AoOs as your foes come barreling into your reach deathtrap.  But even if you successfully slow an enemy for 1 round, they can still use a partial charge to move and attack.  And to trigger the slow in the first place, they have to move, which is something they might not care much about if they’re doing a full attack.  To make matters worse, spellcasters and initiators are still plenty dangerous with only a standard action.

5th Level

Stances:

Jailer of the Damned****:  You ignore immunity to mind-affecting and fear effects, and have a +2 bonus and don’t take AoOs when doing combat maneuvers on feared enemies!  This is very similar to Inarguable Presence of the Sleeping Goddess, also a 5th level stance.  If you want to be tankier, use IPotSG, but if you want to be better at crowd control, use JotD.

Strikes:

Shackles of the Condemned****:  [curse].  Melee-only.  Clip a spiked collar and chain leash onto your victim, dealing +5d6 damage, and your target is cursed and entangled for IL rounds with no save, and can’t move further than 30 feet away from you, even with teleports!  Pesky outsiders giving you grief with their hit-and-run tactics and at-will Greater Teleport?  Want to make even the slipperiest skirmisher your prisoner?  This is the strike for you!  Buuut it might be better to just inflict a more potent condition and then knock the poor sod out.

Counters:

Stand Your Ground***:  You and one ally only take half damage for an entire round.  On one hand, it’s nice because it’s a completely guaranteed effect that saves hitpoints, but on the other hand, it’s often better to negate an attack completely because of nasty rider effects.  Use your judgment based on what you’re fighting to determine whether this or another counter will keep your party in the fight the longest.  It’s much better against full-attackers.

Unbearable Gaze*:  Use when a foe targets you to make them roll a reflex save or be blinded for 1 round.  It only works when you’re targeted, and even if they fail their save, there’s still a 50% chance for the attack to hit you.  Not reliable enough, and can’t protect allies.

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Inescapable Grasp****:  Cursed creatures you threaten can’t 5 foot step or withdraw, and provoke an AoO if they move by any means.  A more aggressive version of Vigilant Keeper’s Stance that works against enemies that use special movement modes like teleportation and flying.  Remember that you still need to curse them, though.

Strikes:

Charge of Dismay*:  [fear].  Full round action.  Charge without provoking AoOs, deal +6d6 extra damage, and enemies within 30 feet must make a will save or be frightened for 1d4 rounds and then shaken for a minute.  Long-lasting crowd control is good, but this maneuver is brought down by the fact that it’s a full round action (you can’t use Aid Another), and it can’t frighten enemies with a higher HD than you, making it poor against significant threats.  You’re already perfectly fine at dealing with large hordes of weak enemies.

Strike of Sacrifice****:  +6d6 damage, and you can grant up to ½ your IL in AC to your friends for cha mod rounds.  Decent for melee Zealots for encouraging enemies to attack you instead of your friends, but much better for ranged Zealots.

Counters:

Infinite Focus****:  Allies within 60 feet don’t provoke AoOs for 1 round.  Any kind of AoO!  Even spellcasting, drinking potions, or standing from prone!  This can be useful if you’re up against an enemy AoO specialist or a humongous monster and need to reposition without fear.

Boosts:

Inescapable Fetters****:  [curse, teleportation].  Every creature you hit after activating this boost before your next turn gets cursed for ¼ IL rounds, and has to make a will save or be teleported next to you at the start of its turns and take an AoO from you.  It’s like a juicy combination of Binding Fetters and Oath of Torpor!  You can use it on friends too, yoinking them back to your heels round after round for free.  Amazing to use on allies who have charge builds.

7th Level

Strikes:
