Curse of Impending Doom*****:  [curse, fear].  +6d6 damage, and target is cursed for 24 hours with no save!  The curse imposes a -2 penalty to attacks, saves, and skills, and increases by -2 every time the victim succeeds on a roll.  Not only that, but if they fail, they have to make a will save or be panicked for 1 round!  And there is no way for the victim to remove this curse before 24 hours without magic or a suppression ability like Temporal Body Adjustment (Riven Hourglass 4).  Such a huge irresistible debuff and crowd control is amazing!

Counters:

Unbreakable Promise***:  [curse].  When another ally is attacked, you can make all enemies within 60 feet roll a will save or be cursed for 3 rounds and be unable to reduce other creatures below 0 HP by any means!  Of course, it’s best to not have your friends’ HP dip that low to begin with, but this one counter could give your entire party multiple more rounds of survivability to finish the fight.  Smart full-attacker enemies can easily end the curse by attacking themselves once, however.  You also can’t use this if you’re all alone.

Boosts:

Grim Satisfaction**:  [fear].  Initiate this, hit an enemy, and it must make a will save or cower for 1 round, and you heal IL HP, +10 if the enemy was cursed.  The healing isn’t super impressive, and cowering a single enemy as a level 8 boost isn’t the best action economy for its level.

8th Level

Stances:

Stance of the Infinite Warrior****:  [teleportation].  Squares you threaten during your turn remain threatened until the end of your next turn.  In conjunction with strikes that move or teleport you, now you can defend multiple areas of the battlefield at the same time!

Strikes:

Hammer of the Immortal*****:  Great Scott.  Attack every enemy you threaten for +8d6 damage AND give them a -4 AC and CMB penalty AND perform a free combat maneuver on them.  Combine this with ways to increase your threatened area like Oath of Eternity and Stance of the Infinite Warrior, and you can heavily damage and debuff virtually everything!

Counters:

Crushing Rebuke*****:  [fear].  The big brother of Fear the Reaper.  Make an Intimidate check to negate an attack roll against you or an ally, and all attacks it makes during its turn are considered natural 1s!  This destroys full-attackers.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Counters:

Oath of Eternity*****:  [curse, teleportation].  What Intruder’s End hopes to become when it grows up.  Increases your reach to a minimum of 40 ft, you gain bonus AoOs equal to ½ your IL, and your AoOs deal +3d6 damage and curse enemies for 1 round.  It does everything an Eternal Guardian specialist could ever dream of.  No one can do anything on the battlefield now without your permission!

Final Ruling*****:  Become the best of the best at battlefield control, the best of the best ways to protect your party!  And Eternal Guardian doesn’t just stop there, it has plenty of multi-purpose maneuvers that have additional utility.  1st level options aren’t spectacular, so don’t be afraid to wait until you’re IL 3 to pick up the really good stuff like Fear the Reaper and Relentless Warden’s Strike.  Then you’ll be in prime condition to grab whatever higher level maneuvers you want down the line.

Fool’s Errand

Skill:  Climb.  2 stances, 3 strikes, 2 counters, 3 boosts.

Weapon Groups:  All weapons.  This discipline has 9 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save, and all of them are locks.

Martial Tradition:  The Fellowship of Fools.  Any alignment.

Note 1:  Lock is complicated.  See Library of Metzofitz for info on how it works.

Note 2:  Unarmed strikes made as part of Fool’s Errand strikes act as though you have Improved Unarmed Strike.  You can’t substitute other weapons for unarmed strikes, like via Ascetic Style, with additional attacks in Fool’s Errand maneuvers.

Note 3:  Any class can exchange an available discipline for Fool’s Errand.

1st Level

Stances:

Lesson I: Balance***:  Gain Improved (or Greater) Unarmed Strike, make climb checks in place of acrobatics, and stand from prone as a free action with no AoOs.  Remember, unarmed strikes made as part of Fool’s Errand strikes already act as though you have IUS.  Using climb in place of acrobatics is very helpful to strength-based characters, and while prone isn’t a common condition, saving yourself a move action and AoO is crucial.

Lesson II: Control***:  [lock].  Make a free lock attempt against adjacent creatures you hit with unarmed strikes, and your locked foes have -2 + IL/4 attack against anyone other than you.  A great all-purpose stance for being a better tank, hindering the movement options of your enemies and encouraging them to attack you instead of your allies.  The downsides are that it only works against adjacent enemies, and only with unarmed strikes, so its usefulness decreases as your reach increases.

Strikes:

Iron Grip***:  [lock].  Melee-only.  Normal damage and make a lock attempt.  Simple as can be!  But remember that the ONLY thing that lock directly does to your target is make it unable to move.  It can still attack any of your friends within reach, and has no penalties of any kind.  To get the most out of locking, you need to move around and drag your target, and Zealots prefer to save their move actions for Aid Another.  Still, preventing enemies from running past you to get at your squishy teammates, or fleeing, is useful.  Use this instead of One-Two punch if you have a two handed weapon and don’t use Lesson II: Control.

One-Two Punch***:  Melee-only.  Two unarmed strikes with -2 attack and normal damage.  A much more balanced version of Flurry Strike (Broken Blade 1).  If you don’t have a decent static damage modifier or unarmed strike dice at level 1, however, it’s probably better to stick with a two handed weapon or more damaging strike maneuver in most low level circumstances.  A good use of this strike is with Lesson II: Control, since it gives you two chances per round to land unarmed strikes and locks rather than just one.

Whirlwind Sweep****:  Melee-only.  Climb check vs target’s CMD to throw a creature 10 feet and knock them prone.  Since you can even throw them 10 feet up, and move them one square diagonally without losing movement, this offers a very nice repositioning + debuff + 1d6 damage combo that’s perfect to use against most of the enemy types you’ll face at low levels.  And of course if there’s dangerous terrain around, things get even more fun.

Counters:

Lock Step*****:  Climb check vs attack roll to negate, but can only be used against a foe you have locked.  The setup isn’t too difficult if you’re using Lesson II: Control, and you can even negate attacks aimed at your allies rather than just yourself!  And it’s a 1st level counter!

Boosts:

None

2nd Level

Strikes:

Hurricane Kick****:  Melee-only.  Fly your land speed and make a melee attack for normal damage.  A standard action move + attack!  It’s not as good as Fading Strike (Veiled Moon 2), because it’s not a teleport, and you have to attack at the end of your movement and not before.  Even so, it makes you vastly more mobile.

Steel-Shattering Fists**:  Make a weapon attack and unarmed attack against the same target with -2 attack and normal damage, and ignore DR and hardness.  This even works with ranged weapons!  You aren’t likely to meet many enemies with high DR at level 3, but an option to bypass DR and hardness is good to keep in your back pocket for your whole career.  Hardness ignoring attacks let you tunnel through rock, too, so have fun destroying your GM’s dungeon maps!  Situational, but not bad.

Counters:

Lead and Follow****:  [lock].  Useable when you hit a creature with an AoO.  Make a lock attempt, and their movement is halted if successful.  Great for Zealots with a big reach who don’t rely on Lesson II: Control.  It can completely prevent smaller enemies from getting in melee range to hurt your team.

Boosts:

Bob and Weave***:  Move to another space adjacent to an already adjacent foe with no AoOs, and it becomes flat-footed against your next attack this turn.  It’s situational, but it’s a form of no-AoO movement that doesn’t use a move action, which is great for interacting with lock.  If you already have another enemy locked, use this to drag them around easily!  That could wind up pulling them away from a squishier ally.

Death at Ten Paces***:  Your next melee attack has a range of 30 feet but only affects a single target.  This combines nicely with many melee-only disciplines and strikes.  You can even lock and drag someone from 30 feet away!  A nice option for melee Zealots who lack other forms of mobility or reach.

3rd Level

Stances:

Lesson III: Suppression**:  [lock].  The target of your first attack every round is flat-footed, you can make a lock attempt against an adjacent creature once per round as a free action, and your AoOs lock adjacent creatures.  Now that you’re level 5, you’re likely to have access to bigger reach, and some enemies will too.  It’s not easy to actually get an enemy to provoke an AoO while adjacent to you.  Making an enemy flat-footed actually doesn’t reduce their reflex save at all, so they won’t become easier to lock, so only Stalkers and Rogues will be interested in that.  Locking once per round for free is great for action economy, and the only truly useful portion of this stance for a Zealot.

Strikes:

Adamantine Grip***:  [lock].  Melee-only.  Normal damage, make a lock attempt regardless of whether or not you hit, and your target is entangled while locked if successful.  Entangled is a useful debuff both for your team’s defense and offense against the target, and makes your target’s reflex save worse by lowering their dexterity, so it’s even harder for them to escape your locks.  Unless they use strength instead of dexterity to do so.

Windmill Waltz Flurry*:  Full round action.  1 weapon attack and 2 unarmed strikes with -2 attack and normal damage, you move 5 feet with no AoOs between each attack, and you move up to your speed either before or after the attacks.  It’s a full round action with no riders.  The anathema of Zealots everywhere.

Counters:

The Best Weapon is Theirs*:  Climb check vs attack roll to negate it and disarm a melee weapon, then catch it in a free hand.  A generic skill-vs-attack negation counter that only protects yourself and only has particular usefulness against enemies that use melee weapons.  There are much better counters for Zealots.

Boosts:

None

4th Level

Strikes:

Night Falls**:  Melee-only.  Lock an already locked creature to pin and silence them.  If you have the ability to make another lock in the same round, like with Lesson III: Suppression, you can silently oneshot an enemy in a surprise round, and if you have the ability to use a move action in a surprise round as well, like with Sandals of Quick Reaction, you can quickly drag them away!  Sadly, the target suffers no penalties at all to try and escape you, unlike a regular pinned target, so it’s not completely reliable.  It requires a lot of setup and is situational, but it’s a very fun way to play Batman!  It’s not worth using in combat, because if your victim manages to escape, then all you have done is used a standard action to deny them their move action, and they still have a standard action to attack you with.

Counters:

Make them Humble**:  Dispel or suppress your target’s freedom of movement or similar ability.  Now a simple 4th level spell won’t completely ruin your efforts to control the battlefield!  Such effects will only come up rarely, unless your GM has decided to only attack you with medium level spellcasters who have specifically heard of you and your penchant for locking.  But even if you can’t lock enemies, there are still plenty of other debuffs you can inflict on them.  They’re in other disciplines, though, not Fool’s Errand.

The Sincerest Form of Flattery***:  Gain a maneuver you see being initiated until you recover this maneuver.  Depending on what maneuvers your party members have, you could potentially copy some amazing high level maneuvers that you otherwise couldn’t, like Woedrinker (Cursed Razor 7) once you get high enough.  It’s usually best to use this counter before combat rather than during for the sake of action economy.  However, if your opponents are initiators and at least 2 levels higher than you, you can potentially copy a maneuver of a higher level than you’d normally be able to use!

Boosts:

Tornado Slam*****:  [lock].  Melee-only.  Climb check vs CMD to throw a target 30 feet, knock them prone, move to a space adjacent to them with no AoO, and lock them with no save.  An incredible combination of movement, debuffing, and control, and possibly even some damage, all as a swift action!  Slam dunk suplex your foes like an NBA jammin’ pro wrestler!

5th Level

Stances:

Lesson IV: The Ladder*:  You’re immune to falling damage, and you can jump in mid air for the rest of your turn by spending a move action or using a maneuver that would let you move further than your land speed.  As awesome as it is to be able to double (triple, quadruple, etc) jump just like in action and fighting video games, its action economy demand is absolutely terrible.  Simply get a fly speed instead.

Strikes:

Blade-Dance Ballet*:  Full round action.  1 weapon attack and 3 unarmed strikes with -2 attack and normal damage, you move 5 feet with no AoOs between each attack, and you move up to your speed either before or after the attacks.  The exact same thing as Windmill Waltz Flurry, with one more unarmed attack.  And just as terrible.

Surround from Within***:  [lock].  Melee-only.  Attack adjacent enemies for normal damage and make a lock attempt against them.  At last, you can lock multiple enemies with one standard action!  But alas, you have to be adjacent to them.  A tragic restriction now that you’re getting to be higher level.  Combine with To the Skies for hilarity!

Counters:

Moment of Mastery***:  Roll attack rolls to negate one creature’s attacks against you for an entire round.  Similar to Calm the Storm (Mithral Current 2), which is absolutely terrible.  However, with the typical playstyle of Fool’s Errand to lock enemies and limit their choices in who to attack, you can get decent mileage out of this if you’re the only viable target for your opponent.  You won’t want to use a counter that makes you move out of full attack range, since that will end your lock.  It’s still a risky proposition that requires setup and a bit of luck.

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Lesson V: Expression**:  Your unarmed strikes are usable at range with a range increment of 10 (max 5) and affect 15-foot cones with your target as the originating square.  You are now Vi!  This is a handy way to sock your way through a crowd of mooks, but not a good way to debuff them, as your strike and boosts effects don’t apply to the cone targets.  For that reason, a Destruction Mission Zealot’s augment is strictly better.

Strikes:

Flowing Dance of the Fool*:  Full round action.  Melee-only.  Move up to your speed, lock one creature along your path, drag them with no movement penalty, and make a standard action strike against them.  This is the equivalent of using your move action to move and lock, sacrificing your ability to use Aid Another, as well as taking up one of your maneuvers known and readied.  Interesting ability, but the costs do not outweigh the benefits.  It’s worse than Tornado Slam in almost every way.  Just use that instead.

Tempest Tango Blitz*:  Full round action.  2 weapon attacks and 2 unarmed strikes with -2 attack and normal damage, you move 10 feet with no AoOs between each attack, and you move up to your speed either before or after the attacks.  Windmill Waltz Flurry and Blade-Dance Ballet’s very slightly bigger brother who still just can’t impress the Zealots at the school dance.

Counters:

No Escape****:  Negate your locked victim’s successful escape attempt, or allow them to escape before moving adjacent to them and locking them again.  You can even use this to foil teleporters!  A must-have for locking enthusiasts.

Boosts:

To the Skies***:  Throw your locked foes upwards 5 feet per climb rank, have them land prone unless they can fly, and you can follow one target up to attack it with other actions and make it fall no matter what.  At level 11, you’ll toss your opponents 55 feet up and deal 5d6 damage, and this is one of the rare ways that you can actually knock flying creatures prone!  It still won’t be of much use against legless creatures, though.  And it’s less useful indoors.

7th Level

Strikes:

Utter Commitment**:  Melee-only.  Unarmed strike + 7*IL damage, and your attack also creates a 30 foot cone (half damage) regardless of whether you hit.  Dealing a flat +91 damage at level 13 is nothing to sneeze at, as the average CR 13 monster has 180 hp.  It’s always handy to have an area effect strike as well for mooks and swarms.  But since it doesn’t have any riders, its usage is limited for Zealots.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Finger of God*****:  [lock].  Melee-only.  Climb check vs CMD to throw your target 5 feet per IL, knock them prone, move to a space adjacent to them with no AoO, disarm and grab an opponent’s weapon along your path with a climb check instead of CMB, and make a free melee attack against your thrown target.  WOW.  That’s a lot of stuff for one simple little swift action!  It’s great for all the reasons Tornado Slam is, and it does even more!  The only thing it doesn’t do is give you a free lock attempt, but combined with Lesson VI: Supremacy, your free attack will give you the lock attempt.

Lightning Strikes Twice****:  Use when you hit with an attack.  Your attack will automatically hit again at the start of your turn for half damage.  But all of the rider effects will work at full power!  This gives you two chances to crowd control an enemy with a debuffing strike that allows a save, and makes it much more difficult for enemies to get away from you.  Even if they manage to teleport away, they will still be hit again, no matter where they are, when your turn comes up!

8th Level

Stances:

Lesson VI: Supremacy*****:  [lock].  You can make a lock attempt against an adjacent creature once per round as a free action, your AoOs lock adjacent creatures, you take no movement penalty when dragging your locked enemies, and you can use this stance in tandem with any other 7th level or lower stance.  Now you can use almost any stance you want, and get tons of free locking and control!  If there isn’t another 8th level stance that you desperately want, take this with no questions asked.

Strikes:

Endless Dance of Death*:  Full round action.  3 weapon attacks and 3 unarmed strikes with -2 attack and normal damage, you move 10 feet with no AoOs between each attack, and you move up to your speed either before or after the attacks.  You guys will never believe this.  Listen close.  You ready?  You prepared?  You sure?  This is Tempest Tango Blitz…  With ONE.  WHOLE.  EXTRA.  WEAPON.  AND.  UNARMED.  ATTACK.  Mind blown.

Sky-Shattering Throw*:  Full round action.  Melee-only.  Climb check vs CMD to throw a locked creature 100 feet per climb rank, make them take impact/falling damage, and knock them prone.  Throwing some poor fool 1500 feet can be hysterical amounts of fun, but how useful is it, really?  It’s a full round action, too.  And your target needs to already be locked.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Special:

Proof of Victory*****:  Duplicate any 8th level maneuver of a discipline you already know a maneuver of, or a 7th level maneuver of any other discipline, and its DC is treated as a 9th level maneuver.  There’s nothing else in the entire universe that gives so much versatility!  You now know every 1st-7th level maneuver in the entire game, including the really amazing ones like Woedrinker (Cursed Razor 7).

Final Ruling****:  This is an astonishingly well balanced discipline.  Nothing too overpowered or underpowered, and everything has a use.  Well, except for those full round action maneuvers, but that’s because we’re Zealots.  It requires a lot of setup to get the most effect out of it, but it succeeds at doing everything you need it to do as a supporty, controllery tank.  Sure, you won’t be flat out stunning, dazing, or nauseating anyone, but locking and using superior positioning can be just as helpful for your party.  The main downside to Fool’s Errand is its high reliance on climb, a largely useless skill once you get a fly speed.  Or reach level 5 and have Unbroken Stride (Sleeping Goddess 1).

Golden Lion

Skill:  Diplomacy.  1 counter.

Weapon Groups:  Heavy blades, Hammers, Polearms.  This discipline has only 3 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Descendants of the Golden Council.  Any alignment.

1st Level

Stances:

Pride Leader's Stance**:  Allies within 20 feet gain +4 morale to saves vs fear effects.  Pretty underwhelming, since you’re not likely to meet many monsters at low levels that will try to spook you.  And despite the description, it doesn’t actually help against being demoralized with intimidate, because demoralizing is a skill check vs a DC.  The defender doesn’t roll a save.

Strikes:

Hunting Party****:  Melee-only.  Normal damage, and an ally in your Collective range (or adjacent) can make an AoO against it too!  You might not be the star hitter of your team, but the big stompy barbarian will love you for allowing them to murder more things every round!  Since Zealots can use this maneuver through their collective, you can even give an AoO to your archer friends.

Tactical Strike****:  Melee-only.  Normal damage, and an ally in your Collective (or within 10 feet) gets to take a 10 foot step without AoOs for free.  Useful for putting your fellow melee buddies into flanking positions or pulling squishy friends out of harm’s way.  Sadly, it does nothing if you miss.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Demoralizing Roar*:  For 1 round, enemies you hit must make a will save or be shaken for 1 round.  This is worse in every way than things like Enforcer, Cornugon Smash, and Black Seraph’s Glare.  You need to spend a swift action, and it doesn’t benefit from your intimidate bonus at all.

Encouraging Roar*****:  For 1 round, allies in your Collective (or within 30 feet) get a +2 morale bonus to attack and damage.  And if you have the Community-Minded trait, it lasts for 3 rounds!  Not too shabby!  The only downside is that since it’s a morale bonus, it won’t stack with your Zeal, but at least it will always be useful for the damage bonus, and from levels 1 to 4.

Pride Movement****:  Grant a move action to an ally who’s in your Collective range (or adjacent) to take a free move action to move.  Very handy indeed if you have a friend who uses natural attacks or other means to get multiple attacks at low levels.  The movement is still subject to AoOs, so sadly you can’t use this to scoot a squishy mage buddy away from something nasty.  Fantastic for using with Echoes of Steel with your psicrystal.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Call to Action*****:  Melee-only.  +2d6 damage, and you grant a move action to an ally in your Collective, regardless of whether or not you hit.  Any move action, not just one specifically for movement!  That’s great for fellow psionic characters who have Psionic Meditation to regain their psionic focus.  If you’re teamed up with a fellow Zealot, then…  Heh heh heh.  Let the Aid Anothers and maneuver recovery flow!

Distracting Strike****:  +2d6 damage, and your target is flat-footed until its next turn with no save.  Very handy if you have friends that benefit from that status, like Rogues or Steel Serpent users, and generally results in a reduction in AC against a lot of enemies.  Make sure you don’t use this strike on an enemy who’s about to have its turn, because then it will immediate lose the debuff.  Delay your turn until right after your intended target so that your party can squish it better.

Pyrite Strike*****:  Melee-only.  +1d6 damage, and your target moves 5 feet and provokes AoOs from everyone threatening it except you!  Sure, this has the potential to mess up a good flanking position, but the fact that you can use this both offensively and defensively to help teammates is excellent.  And if there’s nasty terrain around, like a cliff or fire, shove your foe into it!

Counters:

Warning Roar****:  Roll diplomacy to negate an attack against an ally in your Collective, or 60 feet.  It’s definitely nothing to shake a stick at, and Zealots can be great at diplomacy, but Fear the Reaper (Eternal Guardian 2) simply blows it out of the water.

Boosts:

Defending the Pride*****:  All allies in your Collective (or 60 feet) gain a +4 morale bonus to AC for 1 round.  The Community-Minded trait makes it 3 rounds!  And morale bonuses to AC are almost non-existent!  This could potentially cause a lot more misses for your enemies over the course of 3 rounds than a single counter could.  But be careful of using this 24/7, because your GM might simply increase the enemies’ attack bonuses to compensate.  At that point, you’re just wasting your swift action, a trait, and a maneuver readied.

3rd Level

Stances:

Golden Commander Stance***:  As long as two of your chummies are in melee with the same enemy, they’re both considered flanking!  I hope you were able to convince someone else to take the Outflank feat on your journey to Harrying Partners!  At its worst, this stance will do nothing at all if you have no fellow melee allies, but at its best, it’ll give a huge number of people +2, +4, or even +6 to attack if you have the Menacing weapon enhancement.

Strikes:

Kill the Wounded****:  Melee-only.  Hit an enemy, and they will take +2d6 damage from allies for 1 round.  This is an average of +7 damage to your entire party.  The TWFers, natural attackers, and archer machine-gunners on your team will sing your praises!

Pack Pounce*:  Melee-only.  You need to target an enemy that’s adjacent to one of your allies, and you deal +5 damage per adjacent ally, up to +15.  Just +15 damage for a highly situational and difficult-to-use maneuver?  No additional effects?  No buffs or debuffs?  That’s barely better than the average of +4d6 damage!

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Circling the Prey****:  Grant yourself and your allies a 5 foot step.  It may not seem like much on its own, but moving a squishy teammate out of a stompy monster’s reach and moving frontliners into flanking positions can have a greater effect than a simple counter.

4th Level

Stances:

Golden Lion Charger*:  You can charge without AoOs and have +2 attack on charge attacks.  A pitifully low bonus, a pitifully weak utility, far too high of a level, and Zealots shouldn’t spend full round actions charging anyway.  I wouldn’t even take this if it were a 1st level stance.

Strikes:

Charge of the Battle Cat*:  Full-round charge attack, +4d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone.  Scroll down to Piercing Thunder for just a minute and look at all of those disgusting red ratings.  Feast your eyes on Iron Lancet Charge.  Charge of the Battle Cat is a carbon copy of that, but WORSE.  How?  How is this possible!?  I don’t have a rating worse than red!

Golden Swipe****:  Melee-only.  +6d6 damage, and your target moves 10 feet and provokes AoOs from everyone threatening it except you.  An upgrade version of the lovely Pyrite Strike from 2nd level.  But at this point in your career, you want to look for more impactful rider effects instead of a bit of movement and extra damage.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Direct the Pride***:  Make a teammate in your Collective go immediately after your turn.  It’s not White Raven Tactics from 3.5e, it doesn’t actually give your ally any additional actions they wouldn’t otherwise have.  It just potentially improves their initiative order for 1 turn.  It can be nice to prevent an ally from being flat-footed on round 1 if you manage to roll a high initiative check.  You can also cause an ally to act in a surprise round if you were able to but they couldn’t.  If you really, really, really need one particular teammate to take a turn before the enemies do in a certain round, this could be worth it, but that’s not always going to be the case.

5th Level

Strikes:

Roar of Battle*****:  +6d6 damage, and your target takes +3d6 damage from your allies for 1 round.  A better version of Kill the Wounded, and can be used with ranged attacks as well!  Oh, and you don’t even need to hit!

Strategic Blow****:  Melee-only.  +8d6 damage, and an ally in your Collective (or within 10 feet) can take a move action for free.  It’s just Call to Action with 6d6 more damage.  It’s good, but there are probably better things you can do with 5th level maneuvers by now.

Counters:

Guard the Pride*:  Grant 1 Collective member a bonus to AC equal to ½ IL for 1 round.  When you get this at level 9, the bonus will be +4.  Sure, the 1 round duration is nice since it can apply to multiple incoming attacks, but it’s not good enough, especially compared to the incredible Defending the Pride from 2nd level.  And if you use this at the start of an enemy’s full attack, guess what?  They can simply switch targets with their remaining attacks and murder someone else.  Absolutely dreadful, even considering you’re a Zealot and don’t have to abide by the adjacent restriction.

Boosts:

Discipline of the Pride*****:  For 3 rounds, give your allies one of your combat feats.  Now you don’t need to dip another class to share Harrying Partners with your whole party!  And depending on your party, your other combat feats could be nice to share as well.  Since it’s 3 rounds long and you can recover maneuvers so easily, that can add up to quite a few bonuses, like other Teamwork feats such as the one you took to qualify for Harrying Partners.  You could use this out of combat to give your whole party Lookout to make party able to act in surprise rounds, for example.

6th Level

Stances:

Golden General's Attitude**:  All allies within 60 feet get +1 morale to attack, damage, and saves vs fear per 4 ILs.  That’s +2 at level 11, +3 at level 12, at which point it finally is better than the humble level 1 Encouraging Roar.  Also, the bonus to attack doesn’t stack with your Zeal.  Maybe if you’re a much higher level and have an absolutely massive party, this would be more worth it.  The effects of this stance can be duplicated with spells like Heroism and Good Hope, and you need your stance to do something unique and directly beneficial to your role.

Strikes:

Harry the Prey*****:  Attack, and regardless of whether you hit, all allies in your Collective (or 30 feet) get to make an attack against anyone else they want!  Even ranged attacks!

Counters:

Endurance of the Strong**:  When an ally in your Collective (or within 30 feet) takes damage, heal them for IL*2.  At level 11 and above, enemies are prooooooobably going to be doing more than 22 damage per hit, in which case an attack-negating counter is better.  But if you’re up against some piddly weak mooks, this is useful for coming out ahead rather than just coming out unharmed.

Boosts:

Lion's Feast*:  For 1 round, if an enemy gets reduced to 0 HP within 20 feet of you, all allies in your Collective (or adjacent) gain temporary hitpoints equal to 2*HD of the victim.  Temp HP doesn’t stack, and things that die easily usually have low HD, meaning this won’t actually amount to much damage negation.

7th Level

Strikes:

Orichalcum Swipe****:  +12d6 damage, PUNT your foe twice their base speed in a straight line, and they provoke AoOs from everyone threatening it except you!  If design intent follows Fool’s Errand, the direction you choose could possibly even be directly up, making your hapless target take extra falling damage and fall prone!  If you hit an enemy with an especially high speed, you can make em go bang, zoom, straight to da moon quite easily, and they might need to spend an entire turn (or charge action) to get back into the fight.  If they’re not dead from all the AoOs.  In typical small bare dungeon rooms with no dangerous terrain, this is less impressive.

War Lion's Charge**:  Charge with no AoOs.  +14d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be stunned for 1 round.  Well, it’s ironically better than almost all of the charge maneuvers in Piercing Thunder, doing tons of damage and applying a deadly debuff that takes an enemy out of the fight.  But it’s still a full round action.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Golden General's Victory***:  You have to reduce something to 0 HP use this boost.  When you do, your Collective members (or allies within 60 feet) heal IL hitpoints.  It’s not much at this level, but hey, it turns weak mooks into delicious little water balloons of health for your party.  It has no HD restriction, so you can even get away with carrying a bag full of rats and murdering one per round outside of combat to heal up!  And with none of the moral hang-ups that Silver Crane users have to worry about!  Just the wrath of your GM!

8th Level

Stances:

Triumphant Lion's Leadership***:  You and allies in your Collective (or within 10 feet) gain +1d6 damage per foe you’ve slain (max +5d6) while in the stance.  Wake up bright and early, start your day with a balanced breakfast and 5 counts of murder from your bag-full-of-rats, and you’re ready to go adventuring!  Sure, it’ll make your army of NPC archers oneshot anything they fire a volley at, but literally the only thing that this stance does is add damage.  If the favored style of gameplay at your table is rocket tag, then go for it.  But a better stance is one that offers utility.

Strikes:

Lion Lord's Agony*:  Melee-only.  You deal damage equal to your HP deficit.  You don’t add your weapon’s damage, or your strength, or enhancement bonus, or buffs, or anything else.  And you become shaken for 1 round afterwards.  The reason the Lion Lord is in agony isn’t because he’s fueling this strike with his pain, he’s agonized about the mere fact that this terrible strike exists and is 8th level!  You have to 1) have tons of HP, 2) be at low current HP, showing that you’ve been failing at your job negating damage, and 3) not even deal a fraction of the damage you could with things like size-stacking, power attack, full attack, and buffs.  A+ theme, F- execution.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Alpha's Roar*****:  Grant allies in your Collective (or within 30 feet) a +4 morale bonus to saves and the DCs of their effects for 1 round.  The bonus to saves is lovely, but the bonus to DCs is incredible!  Casters save up every scrap of gold and feats they can just to squeeze another +1 DC into their spells!  And this even benefits your own maneuver DCs!  AND the Community-Minded trait extends this to 3 rounds!  Honestly, I wouldn’t blame any Zealots at this level if they just spend their swift actions using Defending the Pride, Discipline of the Pride, and Alpha’s Roar to keep them up all the time.

9th Level

Untyped:

Lord of the Pridelands*****:  Standard action, but it’s more like a boost than a strike.  You and allies in your Collective (or within 60 feet) gain a +2 morale bonus to hit, damage, AC, and saves for each ally in the range, up to +10.  Community-Minded trait extends this to 3 rounds.  It might be a standard action, but that is a huge amount of both offensive and defensive bonuses!

Final Ruling*****:  Golden Lion is chock full of absolutely amazing maneuvers that help your whole party in huge ways, and Zealots are uniquely the best at using it because of their Collective!  It gets better the more melee allies you have in your party, but worse if you have few.  It’s also very low on crowd controlling and debuffing strikes, so you will want to supplement your arsenal with another discipline.  Despite those problems, the purple maneuvers that apply long-lasting buffs (thanks to Community-Minded and the extended range of your Collective) and give free actions to allies are so deep dark rich royal purple that you will definitely want something from here.

Iron Tortoise

Skill:  Bluff.  0 maneuvers.

Weapon Groups:  Axes, Heavy Blades, Close.  This discipline has 9 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  All strikes in this discipline are melee-only, except for some that use a shield as a throwing weapon.

Martial Tradition:  Defenders of the Realm.  Lawful.

Note:  Iron Tortoise maneuvers require use of a shield in one hand.

1st Level

Stances:

Snapping Turtle Stance***:  +1d6 damage to shield bashes, and you don’t lose your shield bonus to AC when shield bashing.  Useful at low levels for helping to oneshot weak enemies, and it gives you time to pick up other crucial feats before you eventually get Improved Shield Bash.  But a different stance that gives +1d6 damage is otherwise simply superior, like Reaching Blade Stance (Mithral Current 1) or Phalanx Lancer (Piercing Thunder 1).

Stance of the Defending Shell**:  +1 stacking shield bonus to AC, +1 per 4 additional ILs.  It only does one single thing, it does it with a pitifully low bonus, and it doesn’t do it very well with a shield bonus rather than a dodge or insight bonus.  At least it improves Iron Shell.

Strikes:

Angering Smash***:  Shield bash for normal damage, and your target has -4 attack against anyone other than you for 1 round.  It’s like +4 AC to your whole team against a single enemy, which isn’t too shabby at all, especially at low levels where attacks that don’t target AC are less common.

Snapping Strike*:  +1d6 damage.  That’s it.  Sure, you could easily oneshot enemies at level 1 if you combine this with a stance that gives you an additional +1d6 damage, like Snapping Turtle Stance, but inflicting debuffs and crowd control is a better use of your standard action than adding an average of +3.5 damage.

Throwing Shell**:  Ranged shield bash with 20 foot range increment and +1d6 damage, and you catch your shield at the start of your next turn if your target was within 2 range increments.  Firstly, if you’re a strength-based Zealot, your attack roll with this will be bad, unless you get Powerful Throw.  Secondly, you lose your shield for the entire remainder of your turn and are much more vulnerable.  It’s a useful tool at low levels to deal with ranged enemies lurking on terrain you can’t get to, like a high wall.

Counters:

Iron Shell****:  Shield bash + your shield bonus to AC to negate an attack.  With a good attack bonus, this is exceedingly likely to succeed, even when compared to skill-based counters at early levels.  Sadly, it doesn’t help your allies.

Boosts:

None

2nd Level

Strikes:

Enraging Strike**:  +10 damage, and your target must make a will save or be forced to attack you with -2  with its next action, and if it has anything in hand, it must make a melee attack.  Great for ensuring that your allies won’t be attacked, but your own bacon is still on the line!  It’s much better against archers and spellcasters who are silly enough to hold a staff, but melee enemies and spellcasters with empty hands will laugh at you for using this.

Tactical Snap***:  Normal damage with a trip attempt with no AoO and a +2 competence bonus.  Trip is still spiffy at low levels, so this is a great form of lockdown.

Counters:

Defensive Shell***:  Shield bash to negate an attack against an ally in your collective (or adjacent).  Zealots can use this much better than other classes, but it’s an attack roll with your shield instead of your regular weapon or a skill check, so it might not be as likely to succeed as Fear the Reaper (Eternal Guardian 2).  It also can’t protect yourself, just allies.

Enduring Shell*:  Add your shield bonus to a fortitude or reflex save.  Early on, this will only give you a +2 or +3 bonus, and later on, you’ll have better counters.  It only works for you, and doesn’t help against will saves which are typically more dangerous.

Boosts:

Taunting Turtle***:  A target within 30 feet must make a will save or be forced to attack you on its next turn.  Not so tactically useful against an enemy that’s already in your face, but if there’s an enemy menacing your squishy allies 30 feet away from you, you can use this to pull them away, possibly make them eat some AoOs from your allies, and not get a full attack against you.

3rd Level

Stances:

Iron Tortoise Stance***:  You’re considered 1 size larger for CMD, have +5 reach for AoOs, and have +1 AoO per round.  The bigger your reach for AoOs, the better you are at controlling the battlefield and protecting your allies!  The extra AoO can also be used for Bodyguard.

Strikes:

Greater Snapping Strike*:  +3d6 damage and ignore DR.  No rider, no deal.

Counters:

Burnished Shell****:  Roll BAB + shield bonus vs caster level to negate a targeted spell.  A relatively low level way to deal with nasty spells, and with a moderately good chance of success.  A caster’s CL is usually just equal to their level, unless they’re optimized with magic gear.  You, on the other hand, will have a decent shield bonus with little investment.

Tortoise Defense**:  Suffer -10 speed for 1 round and get DR 20/- against one attack.  It’s better to negate an attack altogether rather than just reduce the damage you take.  However, this has no chance to fail, and things aren’t likely to hit you for more than 20 damage at level 5.

Boosts:

None

4th Level

Strikes:

Ricochet Shell****:  Ranged shield bash with 20 foot range increment hitting 4 enemies for +3d6/2d6/1d6/+0 damage.  It doesn’t suffer the same awful drawbacks as Throwing Shell, and it combos well with boosts and other things that inflict a rider when you hit, like Aggravated Wounds and Shield Slam.  The only downside is that strength-based Zealots will have a bad attack roll unless they take Powerful Throw.

Smashing Shell****:  +4d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for ??? rounds.  Dazing is always great, but how long does it last?  Even if it’s 1 round, it’s good.

Counters:

Snapping Riposte*:  Shield bash vs attack roll, and attack with a +2 competence bonus if successful.  It doesn’t negate the incoming attack, so you’ll need to actually kill your attacker in order for this to be worthwhile.  Vengeful Riposte (Black Seraph 4) scoffs at this.

Boosts:

Aggravated Wounds***:  For 1 round, your melee attacks make your targets have a cumulative -4 attack penalty against everyone except you.  This includes AoOs!  And if you attack the same target multiple times in the same round, the effect stacks!  For your party, this has the same effect or less as Defending the Pride (Golden Lion 2).  You need to use multi-attack strikes to get the most out of this.

5th Level

Stances:

Turtle Knight's Stance*:  You can’t voluntarily move more than 5 foot steps, but gain +IL to CMD, improved uncanny dodge, and a stacking +4 shield bonus to AC.  Sadly, you can’t even use teleportation strikes or voluntarily allow allies to move you if you want to keep this stance.  A shield bonus to AC is worse than a dodge bonus, which many 3rd level stances give, and improved uncanny dodge is something you want to have before a fight begins rather than during.  Other stances are better at helping you control the battlefield rather than just giving you a bonus to CMD, like Stance of the Thunderbrand (Piercing Thunder 5).

Strikes:

Shell Shock**:  Shield bash for +6d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked 20 feet away and fall prone.  This works well against big enemies with a high CMD, as they probably have a low reflex save.  But there are still a lot of enemies that are flat out immune to being prone, like flying or legless enemies.

Vicious Snapping Strike*:  +5d6 damage, and your target’s movement speed is halved for 1 round.  Both the effect and the duration are pretty weak, regardless of the fact there’s no save.

Counters:

Quick Snap*:  When hit, counter attack for x2 damage.  It’s even worse than Snapping Riposte, because it requires you to be hit!  Astounding!

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Mithral Tortoise Stance*:  Treat your armor as 1 category lighter, increase max dexterity by +2, halve total armor check penalty, and +2 dodge to AC and CMD.  This are some hysterically abysmal bonuses for this level.  Iron Pikeman’s Attitude, a 1st level stance from Piercing Thunder, does everything of note that this stance does.

Strikes:

Snapping Turtle Rush**:  Standard action charge attack.  +8d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or fall prone.  How nice, a charge that’s a standard action rather than a full round action!  And how sad, its rider inflicts prone.  And how unfortunate, it doesn’t do anything to assist you in completing the charge, like not provoking AoOs or moving through difficult terrain.

Throwing Shell Cyclone*:  20 foot radius burst centered on you.  Full round action.  12d6 damage, reflex save for half.  Awful action economy, small radius, yawn-worthy damage, and no rider.  Circle of Razor Feathers (Black Seraph 4) is better in almost every way.

Counters:

Steel Shell*:  BAB + shield bonus vs attack roll to negate it, and DR 20/- if you fail.  And considering how your BAB + shield bonus is going to be pitiful against an attack roll because you can’t add other attack bonuses like strength, you’re going to fail.  DR 20/- against a single attack is nothing at this stage in the game.

Boosts:

None

7th Level

Strikes:

Cyclonic Shell Crush*****:  Shield bash with +7d6 damage against all adjacent foes, and your targets must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1d4 rounds.  It targets adjacent enemies, not enemies in reach, so you need to get in close to use this, but it has the potential to hit and lockdown more than one enemy with a single standard action.

Counters:

Iron Defender's Riposte**:  Zip over to an ally in your collective (or within 20 feet) and roll BAB + shield bonus vs attack to negate it, and counter attack with +4d6 and a fortitude save to resist being dazed if successful.  But the duration of the daze is unlisted.  Like with Steel Shell, a BAB + shield bonus is atrocious because you can’t add your other attack bonuses, so you’re almost always going to fail.  As such, the only useful thing this counter does is let you dash over to a friend a long distance away, because you’re a Zealot with a collective.

Boosts:

Unlimited Aggression****:  [mind-affecting].  All enemies within 60 feet must make a will save or be forced to attack you on their next turn.  This is a great way to coerce melee enemies that are far away to come for you, possibly provoking AoOs from your allies they’re disengaging from, and you when they approach you!  Just be careful that your defenses are good enough that you don’t get absolutely obliterated by the focus fire, especially from ranged enemies.

8th Level

Stances:

Turtle General's Stance**:  +2 additional shield bonus to AC, and when targeted with a cone or line effect, attack roll with shield vs attack or caster level to block it in a line behind you.  Like lining up the planets for an auspicious event, you need to line up yourself, your allies, and your AoE-using enemy in order to adequately protect your party.  Having massive size increases helps, of course.  But this only protects against lines and cones, and does nothing against other AoE shapes like fireballs.  The shield bonus is also way too low.  Useful if you size-stack and go up against a lot of dragons, maybe.

Strikes:

Glorious Shell Shock*:  Shield bash against 3 adjacent enemies with +8d6 damage, and hit targets are thrown 20 feet.  Adjacent requirement is bad, weak effect is bad.  If you have Shield Slam or a Tempest Shield, you’re already pushing enemies away with every attack.

Counters:

Adamantine Shell*:  BAB + shield bonus vs attack roll to negate it, and DR 40/- if you fail.  Same problem as Steel Shell.  You WILL fail the attack roll, 40 DR won’t save you from the nasty secondary effects (or energy damage) of whatever’s hitting you, and counters at this level should be helping against more than just a single attack.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Counters:

Invulnerable Shell of the Iron Tortoise*****:  You and your allies in your collective (or adjacent) are immune to everything for one instant.  Sweet muffin of mercy!  It’s been a long and difficult slog, but the capstone maneuver of Iron Tortoise comes through!  This can negate full attacks, huge AoE nukes, buildings falling on top of your party, and maybe even exploding supernovas, provided they happen within the same instant.  A Warder with a single level dip in Zealot could use this and Extended Defenses to make their party immune to everything for several entire rounds per day.  But a Zealot can recover it every round!

Final Ruling*:  This discipline has very little going for it.  Despite being considered the tank discipline, it does little in the way of improving your own defenses that other disciplines don’t do better, and it doesn’t have much effective crowd control that makes enemies unable to attack your party.  Even the counters are of low quality, as they’re limited in which targets they can protect, or suffer from fundamental math problems that make them never succeed.

Mithral Current

Skill:  Perform (Dance).  4 counters and 1 boost.

Weapon Groups: Light Blades, Heavy Blades, Polearms.  This discipline has 8 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  All strikes in this discipline are melee-only.

Martial Tradition:  Lens Maker Society.  Any alignment.

1st Level

Stances:

Reaching Blade Stance****:  +1d6 damage on melee attacks, and your first attack per round has +5 reach.  Better than Pugilist Stance (Broken Blade), but not quite as good as Phalanx Lancer (Piercing Thunder).  The extra reach will help you make strikes on enemies that are a bit further away than you’d like, and +1d6 damage per hit can easily make the difference when fighting low level HPs to take them out of the fight.

Ready the Draw**:  You threaten with sheathed weapons, can draw when making AoOs, and gain Combat Reflexes usable with your cha mod instead of dexterity.  This combines the effects of Improved Quick Draw and Impulsive Reactions, minus the ability to sheathe after making an AoO.  These are important features to have if you want to use AoOs as a Mithral Current user, and you should, because your AoOs protect your party.  If you don’t take the two above options, you’ll be stance-locked into this stance.  Use it as a stop gap during low levels.

Strikes:

Swift Current***:  +1d6 damage, and IYDYW (if you drew your weapon), your target is flat-footed.  Combined with Reaching Blade Stance and a lucerne hammer, this lets you swing for 1d12+2d6+strength damage, which is easily enough to kill just about anything you’ll meet at low levels.  Drawing makes you more likely to hit, but is mostly of interest to Stalkers, Rogues, and Steel Serpent users.

Tidal Blade****:  Attack 2 creatures in reach, and IYDYW, you have +2 attack.  Vastly, immensely better than Piercing Strike (Piercing Thunder 1) because it doesn’t require your targets to be adjacent, and comes with an extra bonus.

Counters:

Flowing Creek*****:  The best 1st level counter in the game for self-defense.  Roll perform (dance) vs an attack to negate it, and take a 5 foot step.  Unlike the inferior 2nd level counters from Broken Blade, Riven Hourglass, and Silver Crane, you don’t need to move out of range of the attack in order to negate it.  And it’s a 1st level counter, not a 2nd level!  And it uses a charisma-based skill!  The only negative is that it only protects you, not your teammates.

Boosts:

Following Wake*:  Use when you charge, and make a trip attempt with perform (dance) instead of CMB.  While tripping is nice at level 1, Zealots aren’t the best chargers, because they want to keep their move actions for Aid Another.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Dual Crash*:  Plain ol’ regular attack.  IYDYW, you make a second attack with -2.  This only gives a slight leg up against single targets compared to this discipline’s 1st level strikes, and 2nd level maneuvers are filled to the brim with too many good choices from multiple disciplines to spend on a strike that has no riders.

Iron Wave**:  +2d6 damage.  IYDYW, your attack has close range instead of melee, and your target must make a will save or be vulnerable until the end of your next turn.  See if you can convince your party members to buy silversheen weapons (+750 gp) to take advantage of this, and it could be a good setup for helping your heavy hitters magnify their damage against a tough foe.  But it’s a costly investment at level 3, and isn’t certain to work.

Riptide Strike*****:  +2d6 damage.  IYDYW, you make a trip attempt with no AoO and a +2 bonus.  Strong status effects are difficult to inflict at low levels, so this is excellent.  It’s better than Two-Fold Assault (Sleeping Goddess) when you get it, because it’s an actual CMB check with a bonus, not a wisdom-based skill check, and even does more damage.

Counters:

Calm the Storm*:  Attack roll vs attack roll to negate, and your target must make a reflex save or be unable to make further attacks against you.  Several problems with this.  1) Charisma-based skill check counters are often easier to boost than your attack bonus, and will have a higher chance of succeeding.  2) This only protects against melee attacks.  3) This only protects you, not your friends.  An enemy can continue using its iteratives on someone else nearby.  4) If you have a counter that moves you out of range of the attack, like Flowing Creek from 1st level, you can already negate full attacks against yourself.

Boosts:

Ride the Wake*:  IYDYW this round, move up to your speed with no AoOs.  Unlike other 1st or 2nd level movement boosts, you have to trigger your ability to use this by drawing and striking, and it gives no real advantage over those other boosts.

3rd Level

Stances:

Flowing Water Stance****:  +4 dodge to AC, +4 initiative, and you may sheathe your weapon once per round with no AoO.  Being able to sheathe for free means you don’t need to take Mixed Combat or Lightning Swap.  Sheathing as a free action is an important ability to have since your strikes have better effects when you draw as part of them.  Thankfully, every stance in Mithral Current (minus the 1st level stances) include this ability.  The dodge and initiative bonuses are very high and will never go amiss.

Strikes:

Rippling Current*:  +3d6 damage.  IYDYW, your target is considered flat-footed.  A teeny tiny piddly itsy bitsy teensy weensy upgrade to Swift Current from 1st level.  You’re a big kid now, it’s time to move on to strikes that have good debuff and crowd control riders.

Salt Breeze Strike***:  +3d6 damage.  IYDYW, your target suffers -4 attack for 1 round with no save!  Not bad at all against full attacker enemies, as it’s twice as good as shaken and comparable to sickened.  Stagger or slow would be better, though, and nauseate would be even better.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Rushing Wake*:  Use this when making a charge, and you can make a trip attempt against enemies adjacent to you along your path.  If you don’t have a way of moving through enemies while charging, it’s going to be difficult to use this to any meaningful degree.  It also doesn’t prevent you from taking AoOs from movement.  Oh, and using it eats up your swift and full round actions.

4th Level

Strikes:

Blinding Reflection****:  +6d6 damage.  IYDYW, your target must make a fortitude save or be blinded for 1 minute, or dazzled for 1 round if they save.  Blinded for a whole entire minute!  If you think a fight is going to last for a while, then this strike will do loads of work for you.  And it deals an incredible amount of damage for a 4th level strike.

Silver Wave**:  +6d6 damage.  IYDYW, your attack has close range instead of melee, your target must make a will save or be vulnerable until the end of your next turn, and you can make a free bull rush attempt with cha mod bonus.  Bull rushes aren’t useful unless the terrain is in your favor, and enemies are beginning to get big and/or have alternate movement modes.

Counters:

Disruptive Wave***:  Usable against spells, powers, and SLAs.  Make a charge attack on your attacker and possibly disrupt their concentration with the damage.  Immediately getting in melee with, damaging, and negating the action of a spellcaster is quite impressive!  But you need to hope that the terrain is in your favor.  There has to be an unobstructed straight line between you and your target, with no difficult terrain.  Shifting Waters Stance (5th level) and other abilities like flight will help mitigate this problem.

Ride the Current***:  Draw a sheathed weapon, attack your attacker, and move 10 feet with no AoOs.  This can negate an attack with no skill check required and place you somewhere more advantageous, and even punishes your attacker to boot!  Sadly, it can’t help your allies.

Boosts:

None

5th Level

Stances:

Shifting Waters Stance*:  You don’t need to move in a straight line while charging, can charge through difficult terrain, can move +5 feet when using maneuvers that move you, and and can sheathe your weapon once per round with no AoO.  Zealots don’t charge very much because it’s usually a full round action, but Mithral Current has 1 counter, Disruptive Wave, that lets you charge as an immediate action.  But that’s the only one.  Not something you want to devote your active stance to.

Strikes:

Rapid Current**:  2 attacks for +3d6 damage.  IYDYW, make another attack with no bonus damage.  3 attacks with no iterative penalty for +6d6 total damage as a standard action sounds pretty neato mosquito, and exceeds the number of attacks a full attacker with +9 BAB can do at the moment, but Zealots have better things to do with their constantly recovering maneuvers, like applying crowd control.  For levels 9 and 10, it’s not a terrible idea to keep in your back pocket if crowd control isn’t required and you use a two handed weapon.

Whirlpool Strike***:  Attack all enemies in reach for +3d6 damage.  IYDYW, attack enemies adjacent to you as well.  A multi-attack strike is a good thing to have to clear out mooks, and can be combined with Intruder’s End (Eternal Guardian 3) to increase your reach if you’re not size-stacking.  The IYDYW bonus is useful if you don’t have Haft Strike or a Zweihander Sentinel Warder dip.

Counters:

Flowing Stream***:  Perform (dance) vs attack or reflex DC to negate an attack or area spell.  If you succeed, you move up to your speed without AoOs towards the attacker and attack with a drawn weapon for +3d6 damage.  It’s similar to Disruptive Wave, but it doesn’t require Shifting Waters Stance to be functional, and does more damage.  However, it requires a skill check, and doesn’t work against any spell, only area spells with reflex saves.

Mithral Flash**:  Attack vs attack to negate.  If successful, you attack your attacker, deal +5d6 damage, and your weapon is considered silver.  Depending on how well you can stack your attack bonus, it may be better than your perform (dance) bonus by now.  However, this counter does nothing to protect your allies, move you around the battlefield, or apply riders.

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Mithral Current Stance**:  Everything you hit must make a will save or become vulnerable to silver until the end of your next turn, you threaten with sheathed weapons, you can draw when making AoOs or using maneuvers even while flat-footed, and you can sheathe your weapon once per round with no AoO.  If you can land a lot of hits on multiple enemies with AoOs or multi-target strikes, and convince your party to use silversheen weapons, this could be a nice setup for increasing your party’s damage, but it’s nothing that Golden Lion can’t do more easily.

Strikes:

Crashing Wake****:  Move 30 feet as a free action, and attack every enemy adjacent to you during your movement for +4d6 damage.  Moving during a standard action strike is wonderful, and dealing several high damage attacks isn’t bad at all.  It’s forgivable that this strike has no riders.  Just make sure you have a way to deal with the AoOs you may take.

Quicksilver Wave***:  +8d6 damage.  IYDYW, your attack has close range instead of melee, your target must make a will save or be vulnerable until the end of your next turn, and you can make a free trip attempt with cha mod bonus.  Trip is much better than the bull rush of Silver Wave, but it’s a little late in the game to be relying on tripping instead of applying more powerful debuffs.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Endless Current****:  For 1 round, move 10 feet with no AoO every time you make an attack.  This includes AoOs, letting you position yourself exactly where you want while your boost is up, and no move action needed.  It might look tempting to use a full attack, but there are a few decent multi-attack standard action strikes to use instead, like Rapid Strike, Whirlpool Strike, and Crashing Wake.

7th Level

Strikes:

Blade of the Silver Sea***:  +8d6 damage.  IYDYW, your attack is silver, ignores DR, and suppresses fast healing and regeneration for cha mod rounds.  This can be exactly what you need when there’s a tough monster that refuses to be killed by anything other than the most specific of weaknesses.  Going up against a cairn linnorm but don’t have any cold iron weapons?  This strike has you covered!

Raging Whirlpool Strike*:  Attack all adjacent foes for +5d6 damage.  IYDYW, you get a second attack for +3d6 damage.  Absolutely dreadful because it only hits adjacent enemies, not enemies within you reach, and does nothing but a bit of damage.  Sands of Time Hurricane (Riven Hourglass) is infinitely better.

Counters:

Flowing River****:  Perform (dance) in place of a saving throw, and if successful, you zip over adjacent to your attacker with no AoOs no matter how far away it is and attack with a sheathed weapon for +5d6 damage.  It’s like a teleport in that it doesn’t matter where your attacker is, but with no actual teleporting involved.  They could be up in the sky on a chariot made of clouds, or safe behind an adamantite portcullis lobbing fireballs at you, but you’d still hunt them down in the blink of an eye!

Boosts:

None

8th Level

Stances:

Mithral Lightning Stance***:  +10 enhancement bonus to your movement speeds, +6 dodge to AC vs AoOs, your weapons are silver, you can sheathe a weapon once per round as a free action with no AoO, and make a free attack with +3d6 damage against anyone who makes an AoO against you.  This is best combined with strikes that move you without providing you protection from AoOs, like Crashing Wake.  It’s risky and does nothing to debuff your enemies, but it makes for fantastic mobility and multi-target damage.  Against enemies without Combat Reflexes, you can bait out their AoO so that allies will be able to move through their threat range without fear of retribution.

Strikes:

Mithral Wave****:  +14d6 damage.  IYDYW, your attack has close range instead of melee, your target must make a will save or be vulnerable until the end of your next turn, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1d4 rounds, a reflex save or be knocked prone, AND a will save or be made vulnerable to silver until the end of your next turn.  The huge number of status effects, one of them being dazed, and at range with massive damage, makes this strike a killer!  But…  It’s just not quiiiite as good as other 8th level strikes like Hammer of the Immortal (Eternal Guardian) or Self Beyond Self (Sleeping Goddess).

Riptide Slice*:  +12d6 damage.  IYDYW, target touch AC.  Nice and simple.  And utterly underwhelming.  Try to debuff your target’s AC to enable your teammates to hit them, rather than just landing a single moderate damage hit.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Counters:

Dance of the Silver Hurricane**:  For 1 round after using this counter, you use a perform (dance) check result instead of AC and CMD, and move 10 feet whenever an attack misses you.  You can choose whether your movement provokes AoOs or not.  Then at the start of your next turn, attack every enemy that attacked you regardless of distance, and your attack is silver and ignores DR.  IYDYW, they take +1d6 damage every time they missed you, max +6d6.  A counter version of Mithral Lightning Stance!  You can stack your perform (dance) quite high and become a prickly little porcupine, but counters that protect allies are much more valuable.  You can combine Mithral Lightning Stance, Crashing Wake, and Dance of the Silver Hurricane all at once, and maybe ask your party to leave the room while you handle everything.  As long as there are no spellcasters or ranged attackers.

Final Ruling***:  The first level stance and strikes will allow you to utterly decimate your way through low level challenges.  But as you go deeper into the discipline, you will need to rely on three things to make the most of it:  Quick Draw, Improved Quick Draw, and Mixed Combat (or Lightning Switch).  Bushi dips get Quick Draw at level 1, 3rd level stances and up give the effect of Mixed Combat, and Ready the Draw and Mithral Current Stance give the effect of Improved Quick Draw.  To use this discipline to its fullest, you will either need those feats, or be stance-locked to a certain stance for combat.  Even with all of them, the effects aren’t the greatest for Zealots.  The best counters are amazing for ruining a caster’s day, which can mean saving your allies from a nasty crowd control spell, and some counters don’t even require a perform (dance) check.  Pick and choose carefully if you’re dabbling in Mithral Current.

Piercing Thunder

Skill:  Acrobatics. 3 strikes, 2 counters, 1 boost.

Weapon Groups:  Polearms and Spears.  Discipline weapon or piercing weapon required.  This discipline has 12 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save. All strikes in this discipline are melee-only, aside from one that throws your discipline weapon.

Martial Tradition:  Reverents of the Lance.  Any alignment.

Notes:  While you maintain a Piercing Thunder stance, you can retrieve unattended weapons as a free action, provided you are adjacent to the weapon at some point during turn (including as part of a move action).

1st Level

Stances:

Iron Pikeman’s Attitude**:  You gain the Endurance feat, treat armor as 1 category lighter, have less ACP, and more max dex bonus.  If you’re a strength Zealot, you’ll be using heavy armor at the minimum (Four-Mirror Armor + Armored Kilt, for example), and if you’re a dexterity Zealot, you’ll be using light armor.  The weight category reduction will only benefit your speed in combat if you wear medium armor.   A level 1 dexterity Zealot (20 dexterity) could start with a Chain Shirt + Armored Kilt and have an AC of 2 higher than other dexterity Zealots with the same speed, though.  The most useful thing this stance does in the long term is allow you to sleep in heavy armor, because it gets lowered to medium, and the Endurance feat lets you sleep in medium armor.

Phalanx Lancer*****:  Wield two-handed discipline weapons in one hand, deal +1d6 damage with discipline weapons and shield bashes, and lock shields with adjacent allies.  This lets you use the purple Reach & Shield fighting style without needing a feat and deal a hefty amount of bonus damage on each strike, amazing for early levels when feats are in short supply.

Strikes:

Bronze Lancet Charge*:  Make a charge with no AoO and deal +1d6 damage.  The lack of AoO is nice, but charging at early levels is usually to close the distance with an enemy, making the benefit moot, unless you’re charging something with 15 foot reach, which is pretty unheard.  You also need an unobstructed straight line, and are subject to difficult terrain.  Know what gets around all of these problems?  Teleport maneuvers!  This is a full-round maneuver to boot.

Piercing Strike***:  Extend your reach by 5 and hit 2 creatures adjacent to each other.  Twice the hits means twice the goblins, kobolds, skeletons, or wolves being taken out of the fight, but its effectiveness is largely nullified if enemies don’t stay adjacent to each other.

Counters:

Oaken Shield**:  “All from an ancient oaken-tree, A mighty branch he tore, And lammed those lads so lustily, That some rose up no more.”  Gain a +4 shield bonus to AC against 1 attack.  This only has a 20% chance to help you, and can’t help allies.  But it’s only a level 1 counter.  Not everyone can be Iron Tortoise or Mithral Current.

Boosts:

Bronze Lancer’s Edge*:  Your next charge does +1d6 damage.  A piddly amount of damage, specifically in tandem with a full-round action that Zealots don’t typically do.  A two-handed swing with a lucerne hammer from a strength-based character typically kills low level enemies in one hit already.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Armor-Piercing Thrust*:  A melee touch attack.  No rider debuffs, you’re certainly still too low level to have a weapon with on-hit effects, and you can’t add Power Attack damage.

Throwing Thunder**:  Throw your discipline weapon with +2d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone.  Knocking an enemy prone at range is a decent effect, but you have to move up to the enemy you just knocked prone to retrieve your weapon, at which point they will be inside your reach deadzone.  It’s a good thing that you can pick up weapons from the ground as a free action while in a Piercing Thunder stance.

Thunderous Fall****:  +2d6 damage.  If your target’s riding a mount, they must make a reflex save or be dismounted and knocked prone.  If they’re not mounted, you make a free trip attempt with a +2 bonus.  See, now this maneuver has multiple applications that actually synergize with the reach-based fighting style of the discipline.  Unlike with Throwing Thunder, you and your weapon will be exactly where you want in relation to your prone enemy.

Counters:

Brace for Impact*:  Make an acrobatics check to negate a charge attack and damage your enemy for IL or IL*2 damage.  It only works on yourself, which is already a black mark for a counter that a Zealot is shopping for.  It only works on charges specifically, making it highly situational.  And it requires acrobatics which is difficult to make if you’re a strength-based Zealot.  Acrobatics uses dexterity and suffers from armor check penalty.

Boosts:

Hastened Leap***:  Move 20 feet or make a jump check with a running start and a +10 competence bonus.  Dreamscarred Press realized that they made Thrashing Dragon too powerful (along with Broken Blade and Primal Fury), and I suspect this is more in line with what they were hoping Leaping Dragon (Thrashing Dragon 1) would be.  Being 1 level higher than Leaping Dragon, the only additional thing this boost does is let you move 20 feet, which is the equivalent of rolling a 10 on an acrobatics check and making the jump instead.  It could be useful for strength-based, heavy armor wearing Zealots, but the 2nd level maneuver slots are filled with fierce competition from other disciplines.

3rd Level

Stances:

Twin Thunder Stance**:  Use two-handed weapons in one hand and gain Two Weapon Fighting without prerequisites.  If you have TWF already, your two-handers are treated as light weapons and you get Improved Two Weapon Fighting.  Being a barbarian from Diablo is fun, and the effects are powerful, but the Two Weapon Fighting fighting style does not agree with Zealots.

Strikes:

Goring Strike***:  Increase your reach by 5 and make a line attack equal to your reach.  Deal +2d6 damage, and your targets must make a fortitude save or suffer 1d4 bleed damage.  With size and reach increases, and favorable terrain like a cramped dungeon hallway, you can potentially hit several targets at once.  It can even be used in a pinch to hit enemies inside your reach deadzone.

Piercing Thunder Hammer**:  +2d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone.  Uhhh…  This is just a worse version of Thunderous Fall from 2nd level.  What the deuce?

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Iron Lancer’s Edge**:  Use with a charge attack to deal +3d6 damage and stagger your target with no save.  Crowd control effects that prevents enemies from making a full attack with no save are wonderful, but you have to use up your precious swift action and make a full round charge.  A tough sell for a Zealot.  You could use it in round 1 of combat if you win initiative.

4th Level

Strikes:

Iron Lancet Charge*:  +6d6 damage on a full round charge with no AoO, and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone.  Lots of damage, but knocking a single target prone as a full round action at this level just doesn’t cut it.  It’s clear that strikes like this are intended for Hussar Warlords and the like, not for Zealots.

Leaping Strike*:  Make an attack that effectively uses your acrobatics bonus in place of your BAB and deal +6d6 damage.  A nice hefty smack that’s nearly impossible to miss, but all it does is damage a single target.  As a 4th level maneuver.  That’s it.

Twisting Lance**:  Make a trip attempt with a +4 competence bonus, and if you succeed, make a free attack with +5d6 damage.  A slight upgrade to Thunderous Fall, since the trip bonus is higher, and your damaging attack comes after the target is prone rather than before.  For Piercing Thunder, it’s okay.  Compared to other disciplines, well...

Counters:

Repositioning Leap*:  Roll acrobatics to negate an attack, and make a standing jump to move elsewhere without AoOs.  Much better for dexterity Zealots than strength Zealots, but Mithral Current, Silver Crane, and Broken Blade have been doing similar things since maneuver levels 1 and 2.  A standing jump moves you a number of feet equal to half your acrobatics check, so you need to get a result of at least a 20 to move more than one square.  And, of course, this only protects you, not your friends.

Boosts:

None

5th Level

Stances:

Stance of the Thunderbrand*****:  +4 dodge to AC, +5 reach, and enemies you threaten can’t use the Withdraw action and always provoke an AoO when they move by any means!  This is almost completely better than Inescapable Grasp (Eternal Guardian), a 6th level stance!  The only thing Inescapable Grasp does that Stance of the Thunderbrand doesn’t is prevent cursed enemies from taking 5 foot steps at all!

Strikes:

Meteor Spiral Thrust*****:  ‘Eyyyyyy!  Well, well, well!  Finally something impressive!  +8d6 damage, overcome damage reduction, and your target must make a fortitude save or be nauseated for 1d3 rounds!  It’s an undeniably hefty chunk of damage that not even a Zealot would sneeze at, and 1d3 rounds of an enemy being unable to use a standard action to attack you is spectacular!

Throwing Comet***:  Throw your weapon in a 30 foot line for +8d6 damage and knock them prone, but they can roll a reflex save for half damage and not fall prone.  Then you have to go pick up your weapon, or waste money on the Returning enhancement.  This does a bit more damage total than a 9th level wizard’s lightning bolt, and knocking multiple enemies prone is useful, but the fact you just threw your weapon away is tough to deal with.

Counters:

Twisting Parry**:  Make an attack roll and use it or your AC to redirect an attack against another enemy within reach or range of the attacker.  Even though it can’t protect your teammates, it has interesting applications because of its reliability.  You could use this against a high-damage incoming attack even if it will miss due to your AC, and risk nothing in countering it, but potentially cause your enemy to take out one of their glass cannon buddies.  Of course, it’s situational based on what you’re fighting.

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Diving Thunderbolt Stance*:  You’re immune to falling damage, gain a bonus to jumping equal to 2*IL, your vertical jump isn’t limited, and you’re considered charging when you jump or attack from higher elevation.  In short, you’re a Final Fantasy Dragoon.  But dragoons don’t make for good Zealots, who need their move actions for Aid Another!  Leave this to the Hussars and other mounted classes who already get an elevation bonus against smaller targets simply for being mounted.

Strikes:

Glorious Thunder Charge*:  Charge with no AoO, +8d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be nauseated for 3 rounds.  It’s Meteor Spiral Thrust, but without bypassing damage reduction, requiring a full round action, and coming 1 level later.  What the deuce.

Impaling Comet Strike*:  Make a melee line attack with +10 reach and +6d6 damage, and ignore damage reduction.  The only useful functionality this has is that it lets you hit enemies inside your reach deadzone, and by now, you really should have a way to deal with that, like a Warder dip or Haft Strike.

Steel Lancer’s Edge*:  Charge with no AoO, +8d6 damage, ignore damage reduction, and you can make an acrobatics check to jump as a free action.  Listen, Piercing Thunder, free movement is only useful for Zealots if it doesn’t take up their move action, and that’s exactly what full round action maneuvers do!

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Lightning Rush**:  Get a +30 enhancement bonus to base land speed for 1 round and move up to your speed with no AoO.  It’s a lot of movement, but it does exactly the same thing that Leaping Dragon (Thrashing Dragon) has been doing since level 1: Swift action movement.

7th Level

Strikes:

Leaping Thunder Crash*:  Like Leaping Strike, make an attack that effectively uses your acrobatics bonus in place of your BAB and deal +35 damage, and your target has to make a fortitude save or be disarmed.  Oh, and it’s a full round action.  And only affects a single target.  Show me an enemy at level 13 that relies on a single manufactured weapon.

Rush into the Fray**:  Charge with no AoO, ignore difficult terrain, and attack or make a combat maneuver against all enemies in reach at the end of the charge with +5d6 damage or +5 CMB.  Charge rules state that you need to end your charge at the closest available square within reach of your target, so it could be hard to hit multiple enemies with this.  If fortune smiles upon you, you could inflict some hefty crowd control with combat maneuvers, but it requires a full round action.  Also, the combat maneuvers from this maneuver are subject to AoOs.

Counters:

Breaking the Charge*:  Use against an enemy charging within 10 feet of you, +5d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone.  Most charging enemies will be huge or bigger with 15+ foot reach by this level, or not bother with the charge action at all, making this nigh impossible to use.

Boosts:

None

8th Level

Stances:

Deadly Thunder Lancer’s Stance**:  Add your cha mod to attack, damage, and acrobatics to jump or tumble, gain Spring Attack, and use standard action strikes instead of regular attacks when using Spring Attack.  Ironically, the static bonuses to attack and damage make this stance better for full attacking rather than attacking once per round, but it still does nothing of particular utility for a Zealot.

Strikes:

Thundering Lancer’s Blow*:  +12d6 damage, bull rush as a free action with a ½ IL bonus, and knock your target prone if successful.  Hit-and-run style initiators would love this, but that’s not the role that Zealots excel in.  By 15th level, too many enemies are nigh immune to being prone, or don’t care about being prone because they have SLAs to obliterate you with regardless of whether or not they’re on their back.
