Boosts:

Adamantine Lancer’s Edge**:  Use with a charge action to deal +8d6 damage and ignore damage reduction, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1 round.  Against a single target, this is abysmal even with the fact that it dazes, because of the inefficient action economy.  But against an ideally set up group, using Rush into the Fray, you could potentially daze and debuff a huge number of enemies.

9th Level

Strikes:

Piercing Charge of the Dread Lancer*:  Charge with no AoO in a straight line, ignoring difficult terrain and intervening creatures, and you don’t require a target.  Automatically hit all enemies in the line you move through, and they must make a reflex save or take +15d6 damage, save for half.  Super cool visual, but you have better things to do than spend a full-round action to deal damage with no crowd control and move to a position that leaves your party undefended.

Final Ruling**:  Almost everything in this discipline relies on full round actions and doesn’t inflict any meaningful debuffs.  Great if you’re a Hussar Warlord, not great if you’re a Zealot.  For one of the disciplines native to Zealots, it doesn’t fit their playstyle at all.  You could take Phalanx Lancer at an early level to use the best fighting style in the game for Zealots, and take one more maneuver you can stomach to see on your character sheet (perhaps Hastened Leap) to qualify for the glorious Stance of the Thunderbrand and maybe Meteor Spiral Thrust, but go no further.

Primal Fury

Skill:  Survival.  2 counters.

Weapon Groups: Axes, Heavy Blades, Hammers.  This discipline has 6 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  All strikes in this discipline are melee-only.

Martial Tradition:  Bloody Fangs.  Non-good.

1st Level

Stances:

Running Hunter's Stance**:  You have scent and +10 enhancement to base land speed.  Good for encounters that begin with a large distance between you and your enemies, and overland travel.  Also handy for tracking via scent and finding stealthy sneaks!

Stance of Aggression*:  You have -2 AC and +1d6 damage.  Simply worse than every other stance that gives you bonus damage, aside from Outer Sphere Stance.

Strikes:

Crushing Blow***:  +1d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be flat-footed until its next turn.  A lower level version of Distracting Strike (Golden Lion 2) that allows a save.  Very handy if you have friends that benefit from that status, like Rogues or Steel Serpent users, and generally results in a reduction in AC against a lot of enemies.  Make sure you don’t use this strike on an enemy who’s about to have its turn, because then it will immediately lose the debuff.  Delay your turn until right after your intended target so that your party can squish it better.

Panthera on the Hunt**:  Full round charge attack.  +2 attack and damage, and you ignore AoOs.  It could be useful at levels 1 and 2 during round 1 to get into position on the battlefield, but don’t expect to rely on it in many other situations.

Primal Wrath**:  +4 damage, or +6 with a two-handed weapon.  Slightly more damage than other 1d6 damage strikes, but with no rider.  Use it to oneshot mooks at low levels, then forget it.

Shoulder Rush*:  Bull rush or overrun with no AoO and a +4 bonus.  You’re probably not going to have any of the feats that make bull rushes or overruns worthwhile at low levels, and you have better options at high levels.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

2nd Level

Strikes:

Crippling Strike*:  +2d6 damage and 1d3 bleed damage per round.  Bleed is a particularly weak rider that doesn’t do meaningful amounts of damage or hinder the enemy’s combat effectiveness in any way.

Devastating Rush**:  +2d6 damage, and ignores DR and hardness.  On it’s own, it’s not particularly useful in combat, especially at low levels where DR is rare.  But it can be fun to use outside of combat since it lets you smash through walls effortlessly, if your GM doesn’t mind you completely ruining their dungeons and maps.  You can even use this to punch through adamantite locks on chests and doors.

Raging Hunter Pounce**:  Full round charge attack.  Make a full attack against a single target after charging.  Pounce, the holy grail that Paizo martials aspire to, available as a mere 2nd level strike!  But we Zealots know that there’s more to life than simply spamming full attacks round after round, don’t we?

Counters:

Bloody Riposte*:  When hit, counter attack for +2d6 damage.  You still have to take the hit, completely counter-intuitive to the Zealot’s goal, unless your counter attack does enough damage to kill your attacker.

Boosts:

Momentum Crash*:  Usable when you make a successful charge attack.  Deal +10 damage.  First, you have to charge, which is no bueno for Zealots, and second, it merely adds some damage rather than a useful rider.

3rd Level

Stances:

Primal Warrior Stance**:  You ignore difficult terrain while charging, count as 1 category larger for CMB, CMD, and special attacks based on size, and your attacks increase by 2 sizes.  The last thing alone can let you stack your weapon die size to truly obscene amounts.  A half-giant with a greatsword manifesting minor metamorphosis and using Primal Warrior stance has a weapon die size of 8d6.  Combine that with Vital Strike and Seize the Opportunity, and you can oneshot most things that draw an AoO from you without much trouble.  This is one of the maneuvers that causes people to say that Primal Fury is overtuned.  But is it specifically good for Zealots?  No, because Zealots like stances that add to their utility and party protection, and other classes can use this stance more effectively.

Strikes:

Disparity Blow***:  +2d6 damage, and you make a trip attempt with no AoO and a +4 bonus.  This would have been good at 2nd level, and it’s still okay now, but its usefulness will quickly fade as enemies become bigger and start flying more.

Frenzy Strike*****:  Make 1 attack with each weapon you have as a standard action with +2d6 damage.  Not only is this a standard action, but it’s abusable beyond belief by stacking as many natural attacks and weapons as you possibly can.  There are a lot of manufactured weapons that don’t need to be wielded in a hand, like armor spikes, a sea-knife or two, a barbazu beard, and a dwarven boulder helm.  You can even get magic items that give you more attacks like a Cloak of the Manta Ray or Helm of the Mammoth Lord.  Dip Aberrant Aegis to get 4 tentacles and a sting natural attack.  Surprisingly, Zealots can use strikes like this better than any other class if combining it with a strong boost like Bronze Knuckle, as Zealots are the only class in the game that can recover multiple maneuvers every round without a swift or full round action.

Counters:

Blade-Breaking Counter*:  When you get hit, sunder your attacker’s weapon with no AoO and a +2 bonus, and take half damage if you break the weapon, or no damage if you destroy it.  It doesn’t work at all against unarmed strikes, natural attacks, or ranged weapons, can’t be used to help allies, and destroys your loot.  You also need to do a significant amount of damage with your sunder in order for it to have a chance to help you.

Boosts:

None

4th Level

Strikes:

Furious Primal Wrath**:  -4 attack, +20 damage, or +35 damage if wielding a two-handed weapon.  35 damage is the average of 10d6, and Zealots can be quite accurate with full BAB and Aid Another.  But CR 7 monsters have an average of 85 HP, so this strike won’t oneshot them.  It’s better to use a debuffing strike, unless you know your attack will kill the target.

Impaling Strike*:  +4d6 damage, ignore DR, and your target must make a fortitude save or take 1d4 constitution damage.  Constitution damage is nothing more than a little extra damage and fort save reduction.  Furious Primal Wrath is more effective overall at killing enemies.

Counters:

Shrug It Off*:  Survival vs attack to negate it.  It can also negate spells and supernatural effects, but only if they used an attack roll.  Most other counters that use a skill to do nothing more than negate an attack came at 2nd level.  This is late to the party.  And it’s wisdom-based.

Boosts:

Momentum Crush*:  Usable when you make a successful charge attack.  Deal +20 damage and ignore DR.  Same problem as Momentum Crash for Zealots.

5th Level

Strikes:

Cornered Frenzy Strike****:  Full round action.  Attack every enemy within reach once with each weapon for +4d6 damage, and suffer -2 AC until your next turn.  Unlike Frenzy Strike, it’s a full round action, but also unlike Frenzy Strike, it attacks everything in reach, making it perfectly acceptable to use instead of Aid Another when you’re well surrounded by enemies, provided you can deal enough damage and knock out enough enemies to justify doing so.

Dizzying Blow***:  Full round charge attack.  +10d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be nauseated for 1d4 rounds.  One of the few full round charge maneuvers that has a good debuff!  And quite a huge chunk of damage, as well!  This is alright to use on the first round of combat to get into the fray, as you won’t have any maneuvers you need to recover, and you’ll still be disabling a foe and moving.

Meteoric Collision*:  Full round charge attack.  Bull rush with a +4 bonus with no AoO and deal 7d6 damage.  Bull rushing isn’t very useful without heavy feat investment, and the damage is negligible.  It doesn’t even add any modifiers.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Lightning Step*:  Mid-charge, make one 90-degree turn and ignore difficult terrain.  This solves some of the more annoying problems for chargers, but it doesn’t change the fact that charges are still full round actions and undesirable for Zealots.  Even if you have a decent charge like Dizzying Blow, there are much better boosts.

6th Level

Stances:

Skirmisher's Stance*:  If you move 10+ feet, you have +2 AC and deal +2d6 damage.  Zealots don’t like moving 10+ feet every round, and even if you had a way to do so without interfering with your move action, the bonuses are spectacularly low for a 6th level stance.

Strikes:

Charge of the Battle Panthera*:  Full round charge attack.  +12d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone.  Sure, you can use it to knock down big fat enemies with high CMDs but low reflex saves, but there’s a good chance they also have the ability to fly, like outsiders and dragons.  Prone just isn’t a reliable debuff anymore.

Shield-Breaking Strike*:  Normal damage, and you break your target’s non-magical armor or shield for up to a -4 bonus, or make a regular sunder attack with a +2 bonus against magical equipment.  Destroying your loot is bad, the lack of a damage bonus on a sundering strike is bad, and the teeny tiny reduction in AC is especially bad for a strike of this level.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Blade of Fury*:  Usable when making a charge attack.  Deal +IL*2 damage.  I don’t think that even charge-centric characters would want to spend a swift action for a piddly 22 damage.

7th Level

Strikes:

Blood-Spray Strike*:  +8d6 damage and 2d4 constitution damage with no save.  Constitution damage is nothing more than extra HP damage and a penalty to fort saves.  Dealing 6 constitution damage to a target with 13 HD is the equivalent of 39 damage, or the average of 11d6, so it’s not exactly small.  But you very likely can do more damage overall by simply full attacking with haste and power attack.

Primal Frenzy*****:  Attack every enemy within reach once with each weapon for +6d6 damage, and suffer -2 AC until your next turn.  And it’s a standard action!  The holy grail of being a visceral zealous blender, combining the action economy of Frenzy Strike with the multi-target effect of Cornered Frenzy Strike, and the damage of both as well!  With this and a powerful boost that adds damage to each strike, Zealots become one of the best “full attackers” in the game, since they can Aid Another themselves for more attack bonus and recover both Primal Frenzy and the boost in the process!  If you want to keep up the good work of protecting your team instead of dealing pure damage, get Golden Lion Command and give your allies a huge amount of temporary HP every round!

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Devastating Momentum*:  Usable when you make a successful charge attack.  Deal +40 damage, ignore DR, and your target must make a fortitude save or be stunned for 1 round.  Stunning is great!  Now if only it didn’t have to be used with a charge attack.  You specifically can’t stack this with another stun or daze maneuver like Dizzying Blow.

8th Level

Stances:

Iron Hide Stance**:  You have DR 5/-, your strength bonus to damage is doubled (or tripled with two-handers), and you count as one size larger for CMB and CMD.  The DR is quite nice and will keep you in the fight longer.  If your strength is high enough, you can get a huge increase to your damage.  If you have 30 strength, your two-handed damage bonus from strength will go from +15 to +30.  This can be quite handy for size-stacking AoO builds, but you need to compare the damage you will gain with the damage from weapon size increases from Primal Warrior Stance.

Strikes:

Meteoric Crash*:  Full round charge attack.  Bull rush with a +4 bonus, deal 10d6 damage, your target must make a reflex save or be knocked prone, and you can take an AoO against them if you knock them prone.  Good luck finding anything at this level that can’t fly.

Counters:

Unbreakable Panthera Guard*:  Survival vs attack roll to negate it and gain 2*IL temporary HP for 1 minute.  It does the same thing as any typical skill-to-negate counter regularly dotting 2nd level of many disciplines, and all it has to show for itself at 8th level is that it gives you a few THP.  It needs to do a lot more to compete with other party-protecting and enemy-punishing counters.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Wrath of the Primal Hunter**:  Full round charge attack.  Make a full attack against a single target after charging with +4d6 damage and ignore DR.  Well, I guess this would be impressive to any typical Paizo martial who loves full attacking and pouncing.

Final Ruling*****:  For most Zealots, this is an absolutely terrible discipline with no redeeming qualities or dippable maneuvers in the slightest.  But if you make a very specific build focusing on getting as many attacks per round as you possibly can, and using multi-attack standard action strikes, you can become a truly horrific force of destruction.  Use a damage increasing boost to kill everything easily, or get Golden Lion Command to grant your party a huge number of temporary hitpoints, and effortlessly recover both your strike and your boost every round.  Because you’re a Zealot, and you can do that.

Radiant Dawn

Skill:  Diplomacy.  0 maneuvers.

Weapon Groups:  Bows, Flails, Hammers, Polearms, Sun’s Gleam.  This discipline has only 6 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Bank of the Sun.  Any non-chaotic.

Note:  You can use a close ranged touch attack called Sun’s Gleam in place of a ranged weapon attack with strikes that can have essence invested in them.  It uses strength or dexterity for the attack roll, deals 1d6+cha force damage, and can be nonlethal at no penalty.

Note 2:  You gain Essence equal to your number of maneuvers and stances known, to a maximum of the highest level Radiant Dawn maneuver or stance you know.  You invest Essence into a maneuver when you ready it, and can’t reassign the Essence while that maneuver is expended.

Note 3:  Any class can exchange an available discipline for Radiant Dawn.

1st Level

Stances:

Spoils of War****:  Allies in your collective (or close range) heal 3 + 1 per essence damage when they hit with an attack, once per round.  This is sure to keep your allies nigh immortal at level 1, and greatly help keep them in combat.  Boosting your allies’ accuracy with things like Zeal and Dismiss to trip enemies means they will hit more often and heal more often.

The Caged Sun*****:  Increase your healing received by 50%, be unable to heal other creatures, excess healing on you turns into temporary HP, and gain +1 attack, AC, and saves, and +2 healing received per essence.  Can be entered as a free action if you’re below 50% HP!  An incredible stance whether you’re fighting solo or are in an emergency situation where you really need to heal yourself.  The only reason you wouldn’t want to take this as a Radiant Dawn user is if you’re a backliner who’s completely guaranteed to never be heavily targeted or separated from your allies.

Strikes:

Dismiss****:  Normal damage, and you attempt to trip and push (like a bull rush) the target, using either strength or dexterity and your IL instead of BAB, with +2 to the check per essence.  Tripping at level 1 is excellent, and the fact that it uses your best stats helps ensure success.  Your allies probably won’t make multiple attacks with full attacks at low levels unless they’re TWFers or natural attackers, so pushing an enemy out of melee range of your frontliners isn’t the worst thing.  It can help save a squishy teammate and get them out of harm’s way.

Staunching Strike****:  Normal damage, and you divide healing among your allies in your collective (or close range) equal to your cha mod + 3 per essence.  Without essence, it heals for less than Enduring Crane Strike (Silver Crane 1), but can be used with ranged attacks.  Being able to distribute the healing amongst your allies as needed is amazing as it lets you not waste any.  If you’re up against enemies whose damage capability outpaces your healing, however, you may want to use strikes that disable the enemies instead.

Counters:

Bolster*****:  Grant an ally in your collective (or close range) DR/- equal to your cha mod + 1 per essence for 1 round.  Absolutely incredible due to it’s round-long duration, especially so for a level 1 counter.  With 20 charisma and 1 essence, you’ll make an ally almost invincible during low level combat.

Decree of Mercy*****:  Make an enemy within close range deal nonlethal damage with their next attack or spell, plus one more instance of damage per essence.  Excellent for ensuring that even the heaviest hitters don’t kill when they hit, and with an incredible bonus.  Whenever you heal hitpoint damage, you also heal an equal amount of nonlethal damage.  And since Radiant Dawn has so many healing maneuvers, it’s very easy to do this.  In effect, this counter makes an opponent’s attacks deal no damage at all.  Since it works on spells, you can use it when an enemy sorcerer nukes your team with a fireball!  This scales much better than Bolster.  Great for giving to your psicrystal with Echoes of Steel.

Boosts:

None

2nd Level

Strikes:

Curate’s Strike****:  Normal damage, and you divide healing among your allies in your collective (or close range) equal to 2x cha mod + 4 per essence, OR grant an ally a saving throw.  The next step up from Staunching Strike, providing almost double the healing, and now with a fantastic additional effect of removing nasty debuffs from your allies.

Decree of Torment*****:  Normal damage, lower the target’s CMD by 1 per essence for cha mod rounds, and your target gains cha mod number of brands for 1 minute that allow attackers to make a free combat maneuver by expending a brand, using your IL and cha mod in place of their BAB and strength if desired.  Absolutely astounding for helping your team inflict long-term crowd control and debuffs to an enemy, with amazing versatility and likelihood to succeed!  Even a wizard ally shooting with a crossbow will be able to trip or blind an enemy with dirty trick, thanks to this.

Counters:

Healer’s Bane**:  Usable when a target in close range heals HP.  The healer must make a will save with +2 DC per essence or the heal-ees take half the damage they would’ve healed +cha mod per essence, while you distribute the healing +cha mod per essence amongst your allies.  This utterly demolishes healers, needless to say.  But how useful is it for you as a player to take, really?  The most common combat healers are Paladins, Vitalists, Medics, Silver Crane and Radiant Dawn users, and Life Oracles, but it’s much more common for players to use combat healing than enemies or monsters.  This maneuver seems like something the GM would occasionally use against players rather than a situational tool that players would consider getting.

Witness to Glory*****:  Usable when initiative is rolled, even flat-footed.  One ally in your collective (or close range) gains your cha mod +1 per essence as a bonus to initiative and your IL +2 per essence in temporary HP.  If you don’t have Uncanny Dodge, Defensive Strategist, or another way of using counters while flat-footed, you want this.  It’ll help a frontliner get into the fray quickly and stay there, or let a controller ally lock down the encounter more quickly.

Boosts:

Expose Weakness***:  Attack roll that deals no damage, but if you hit, your target becomes flat-footed and has -2 AC per essence for 1 round.  Since you can use Sun’s Gleam with this, it’s almost certain to hit.  It will make the Stalkers and Rogues on your team very happy.

3rd Level

Stances:

Armaments of the Empire****:  Up to cha mod weapons in close range gain a +1 weapon special ability from the Soulknife’s list, and creatures wielding those weapons get +1 CMD per essence.  Sadly, this stance doesn’t benefit from the increased range of your collective, because it affects weapons, not creatures.  But giving your allies whatever tool they need to fight whatever foe you face at a moment’s notice is phenomenal for versatility.

Strikes:

Lifeburst Strike****:  +1d6 damage, and you divide healing among your allies in your collective (or close range) equal to 3x cha mod + 5 per essence, OR grant an ally a saving throw with a +2 bonus.  A simple upgrade from Curate’s Strike, but well worth it.

Disrupt Essence****:  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save +1 DC per essence or have an ability, sense, or movement mode disabled for cha mod + 1 per essence rounds, with an additional ability disabled for every 2 essence.  Though it doesn’t completely lock down an enemy like a strike that nauseates, stuns, or paralyzes, it can cripple the ability of many things to harm you, especially if they’re one-trick ponies with a single potent ability.  It can even help you pin down certain enemies by removing their ability to fly or burrow, and force them to fight your melee party members.  Longbows are discipline weapons for Radiant Dawn, and perfect to use for this purpose.  Of course, this strike is fairly useless against regular full-attacking brute characters and monsters.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Decree of Death**:  Attack roll that deals no damage, but if you hit, the next attack on the target within 1 round deals +50% damage +2 more damage per essence.  Almost guaranteed to hit thanks to Sun’s Gleam, and will turn your party’s heavy hitters into even heavier hitters, enough to pulpify anything.  But a simple raw damage increase isn’t what you should be using your swift actions for, as optimized damage characters will already be able to kill most important enemies they get a full attack on.  Since this only works on one attack, the heavy heavy hitter in question needs to be a particular build like a mounted lancer, a vital strike hippopotamus druid, or a user of the Zenith Strikes from Scarlet Throne, and you need to delay your initiative before their turn to ensure the setup works.

4th Level

Strikes:

Shatter Spell****:  +2d6 damage and the target is affected by dispel magic that can also remove curses with IL +2 per essence in place of CL.  You can even use it on willing allies!  Great for stripping strong buffs off of gish enemies, and removing nasty debuffs from your allies.

Counters:

Decree of Silence****:  Usable when someone in close range casts a spell/power/SLA on your allies in your collective (or close range).  The caster must make a concentration check as if you automatically dealt weapon damage to them and add +1 to the check DC per essence, or lose their spell.  Concentration checks upon being damaged are incredibly difficult to make, as it’s hard to boost your concentration check to keep pace with the damage that attacks deal at higher levels.  With Sun’s Glare, you always have a decently damaging attack.  Beware of spellcasters that are far away, because you can’t use this counter unless they’re in close range.

Boosts:

Lifeburst Imbuement****:  Make the next attack of an ally in your collective (or close range) deal +2d6 damage and divide healing among your allies in your collective (or close range) equal to 4x cha mod + 6 per essence.  It doesn’t offer free saves like Curate’s Strike or Lifeburst Strike, but it’s a swift action rather than a standard, letting you heal your team while using your standard actions for disabling strikes.  Locking down enemies will often result in more damage prevented against your team.

Sunstroke*****:  Make the next attack of an ally in your collective (or close range) have a long range, and increase the area radius by 5 feet per essence, but if the attack targets multiple creatures, it only deals half damage and allows the targets to roll saves twice and take the better one.  WELL.  Now you can turn your party’s one-hit-wonder damage character into a piece of artillery!  Or better yet, you can make your potent disabling strikes hit multiple targets rather than just one!  At level 7, investing 2 essence into this, you’re looking at a 680 foot range, 10 foot radius strike.  Even with the reduced effect against multiple targets, Sunstroke is superior to the amazing Reflected Blade Style (Shattered Mirror 3) if you attack at least 4 targets, and that’s not even taking into account the long range.

5th Level

Stances:

Stance of the Sunlight Shield*****:  Create 1 + 1 per essence 10x10 sunlight shields (walls of force) within close range when you enter this stance, and 1 as a free action every round you maintain it, that have 1 HP and IL + cha mod + 3 per essence hardness, can be angled in any way and used as platforms, and don’t impede your allies’ attacks.  At level 9 with 20 charisma and 2 essence invested, your sunlight shields would need to take at least 21 damage from a single attack to break.  Every single round, that is at least 21 free damage reduction to an ally.  A wall of force inhibits the tactical movement of enemies and completely blocks spells other than teleports and gaze attacks, making your allies nigh invulnerable to low-damage archers, weak minions, and spellcasters.  You can layer shields atop one another, so even if a big 60 damage attack hits 3 of your shields, only 2 would break, while the hardness of the third shield would negate the rest of the damage.  The utility provided by creating platforms at whatever angle you please is phenomenal, and allows you to carry your party merrily through the air if they don’t mind squeezing together on a 10x10 square.  It’s even totally worth using a swift action to enter this stance in the middle of combat since it lets you create multiple shields at once.

Strikes:

Divide and Conquer****:  +3d6 damage, and your target must make a will save +1 DC per essence or have 1 + 1 per essence effigy of them created within close range of you until the end of your next turn that transfers any damage and effects it suffers to the target.  You are now Illaoi!  If you or your allies have ways to attack multiple targets like Sunstroke, Reflected Blade Style, Destruction Mission, or AoE spells or strikes, you can compound the punishment on your target by the number of effigies you create.  And since the damage and effects get redirected to your target regardless of distance, you can snipe a victim from afar with a longbow (or Sunstroke), plop their effigies into the middle of your party, and insta-gib them!  This isn’t purple because it doesn’t immediately hinder or take an enemy out of the fight.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Decree of Purity*****:  Grant an ally in your collective (or close range) a save with your cha mod as a bonus, completely ending the effect if successful, and divide healing among your allies in your collective (or close range) equal to 5x cha mod + 7 per essence.  It just works.  No attack needed, no questions asked.  Holy guacamole.  It combines the effects of all the previous healing maneuvers and makes them all better!

Untyped:

Noblesse Oblige*****:  Free action.  Usable when an ally would die or be destroyed, once per day per creature.  You set their HP to 1, make a free attack against any enemy, deal +3d6 damage, and heal your saved ally for your attack’s total damage +7 per essence.  Deciding to learn this maneuver depends completely upon how lethal your games are.  If people never die, you obviously won’t need this, but saving your allies once per day as a free action is the best thing you can possibly do!

6th Level

Stances:

Battle Against the Sun*:  Shed daylight out to close range, and create a 20 foot line once per round as a free action, originating from anywhere within the daylight, that heals allies and damages enemies equal to your IL (reflex save half), and you can affect one additional target adjacent to the line and increase the save DC by 1 per essence.  Sadly, the numbers just aren’t impressive enough to be worth a stance.  You’ll heal a few allies and damage a few enemies for 11 HP at best when you get this, and that’s pocket change.  It doesn’t buff allies, hinder enemies, or improve your utility in any way.

Strikes:

Path of the Sun*****:  Create a line that’s close range feet long that lasts for cha mod + 1 per essence rounds, deal IL + cha mod damage (reflex half) and blind enemies in the line for ½ cha mod + 1 per essence rounds unless they make a reflex save with +1 DC per essence, and your allies can enter the line’s squares as a free action and don’t provoke AoOs when doing so.  It’s a multi-target debuff, area denial, and party buff all in one!  Entering squares for free effectively lets allies teleport around the line, being wherever they want to be at any point during their turns.  It helps melee teammates get into position, squishy teammates escape sticky situations, and skirmishing teammates dart in, attack, and dart away again!  Enemies will need to be careful not to blind themselves by walking into the line.  This strike is absolutely perfect for using with the Strike of Unity conviction or using Echoes of Steel to give it to your psicrystal.

Karmic Strike****:  +4d6 damage, you divide healing among your allies in your collective (or close range) equal to 6x cha mod + 8 per essence, and your target must make a will save or gain 1 + 1 per essence brands for 1 minute that other creatures can expend when the target deals damage to them, taking only half damage and reflecting half damage back to the target.  In addition to being an excellent upgrade to other healing strikes (minus the ability to grant a free save,) it further protects your party by reducing the damage of your target.  It’s better against creatures with a single big hit rather than full attackers.  The reflected damage is just gravy.

Counters:

King’s Castle****:  [teleportation]  An ally in your collective (or close range) teleports adjacent to you or an ally that just got attacked, gains your IL + 6 per essence in temporary HP and your cha mod + 1 per essence in DR/- for 1 round, is targeted by the triggering attack instead of the original victim, and makes a free attack against the attacker with +1d6 damage per essence.  This is marvelous for repositioning your tough frontline allies to protect squishy allies.  It’s reliable because you don’t need to make an opposed roll.  The only problem is that the attack will always go through, so your ally might be subjected to whatever riders were on the attack.

Boosts:

Decree of Freedom***:  For 1 + 1 per essence rounds, you or target ally can move or attack freely no matter what, without penalty.  Conjuration specialist wizards enjoy throwing down annoying solid clouds and webs, but this is sure to give your allies a leg up on getting to their targets and cutting them down.  Free your two-handed weapon using martial allies from grabs and grapples, letting them rip off the jaws and tentacles that dared seize them!  It’s also handy for bursting out of shackles when your enemies capture you!

7th Level

Strikes:

Harsh Light of Day****:  +5d6, ignore miss chance and redirection attempts, and your target must make a will save +1 DC per essence or have all illusions and polymorph effects you choose dispelled and be unable to benefit from miss chance for cha mod + 1 per essence rounds.  This is an interesting companion strike to Tyrant’s End in that it enables your party to take down a highly buffed foe.  Since it removes polymorph effects, it can even devastate the target’s offensive capabilities, making things safer for your party.

Counters:

Push the Advantage****:  Usable when you or an ally defeats an enemy.  Give one ally in your collective (or close range) a standard action and 5 feet of movement per essence, and divide healing among your allies in your collective (or close range) equal to 7x cha mod + 9 per essence.  Sacrificing your immediate action for a standard action is an incredible trade, especially a standard action from a more offensively oriented ally, and adding in movement and healing heaps the frosting on top!  The only downside is the trigger requirement.  You have to already be winning to a degree in order to use this.

Boosts:

Awaken the Sleeper****:  For 1 round, an ally other than yourself in your collective (or close range) gains one of your known maneuvers of 6th level or lower, can use your IL and init mod in place of their own, can roll twice for any attack, damage roll, saving throw, or skill check as part of a maneuver that round, gains half their max HP in temporary HP, and gains +15 speed per essence.  So many buffs!  The most notable one is that the rerolls apply to any maneuver you make, not just the one that was granted.  Use Echoes of Steel to give Awaken the Sleeper to your psicrystal so that it can use it on you!  Sure, your psicrystal doesn’t have any maneuvers known to grant you, but you still get the massive THP and rerolls!

8th Level

Stances:

Sun’s Zenith*:  You can’t invest essence in maneuvers, but your unexpended maneuvers and stances are treated as though they have essence equal to your number of expended maneuvers from your Zealot class, not including other classes or feats.  This stance is incredible for initiator classes that have a difficult time efficaciously recovering their maneuvers like Rajahs and Stalkers, but not nearly as good for Zealots who can recovery maneuvers easily and powerfully.  The point of this stance is to enter it when you have a lot of maneuvers expended so that your remaining maneuvers will be extra powerful, and you can invest your essence into other receptacles like akashic feats and veils.  Zealots probably won’t have those.

Strikes:

Tyrant’s End****:  +6d6 damage, and your target must make a will save or have their SR, DR, resistances, and immunities suppressed, take +50% damage, and suffer -4 AC per essence for 1 round.  Though it might seem at first glance like another cynical pure damage strike, it actually enables your party to use tactics and effects that otherwise wouldn’t have worked on the target.  This even removes immunities from types like a dragon’s immunity to paralysis or a lich’s immunity to stun!

Counters:

Decree of Vengeance*****:  Usable when you or an ally in your collective (or close range) is attacked AND the attack is resolved.  One ally + one additional per essence can make an attack or standard action strike against the attacker, use your Sun’s Gleam if desired, and you divide healing among your allies in your collective (or close range) equal to 8x cha mod + 10 per essence.  With some essence invested, this turns your immediate action into several standard actions for your party!  Tragically, this counter occurs after the triggering attack is resolved rather than interrupting it, so someone is going to get hurt.  Fortunately, this counter comes with lots of healing to patch them up!  The sheer boon to action economy, letting your team annihilate an enemy for a mere immediate action on your part, is well worth it.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Judgement Day****:  Full round action.  Close-range radius burst centered on you that deals 50 + 15 per essence (reflex half, DC +1 per essence) untyped damage, heals allies for 50 + 15 per essence damage, acts like breath of life once per creature per day that works on creatures that had died since the last sunrise, and can revive creatures slain by death effects.  Even though this is a full round action, the ability to resurrect and heal multiple creatures at once in such an enormous area is great utility.  And it’s not like this maneuver even uses an attack roll, so you don’t have to worry too terribly much about using Aid Another.

Final Ruling*****:  Radiant Dawn is bursting with incredible utility and support, the best healing out of all the disciplines, and some unique ways to break the action economy and ensure your team wins with everyone alive by the end.  Sun’s Gleam is an absolutely incredible tool for any Zealot, giving anyone a ranged touch attack.  Even strength-based characters!  And it deals force damage, a rarely resisted kind of damage!  Zealots are even better than Rajahs at using most of this discipline because of their superior maneuver recovery, though Rajahs have greater essence capacity and high level stances like Sun’s Zenith to help them.  Grabbing this discipline is highly recommended for any Zealot, and you don’t even have to beg your GM or use a martial tradition or Unorthodox Method to get it!

Riven Hourglass

Skill:  Autohypnosis. 1 counter and 1 strike.

Weapon Groups:  Flails, Hammers, Light Blades.  This discipline has 12 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Lords of the Wheel.  Any neutral alignment.

1st Level

Stances:

Distorted Clock**:  Double the duration of a spell on yourself, and get +2 to saves against non-instantaneous effects.  Zealots aren’t known for their spellcasting or self-buffing ability.  Even if you take Unlocked Talent to get minor metamorphosis, it will increase the duration from 1 minute to 2 minutes, and that doesn’t mean much in a single encounter.  You can use it between combats to double the effectiveness of your wand of infernal healing, though.

Sands of Time Stance**:  +2 initiative and reflex.  A good stance to walk around in outside of combat, but you’ll want to enter a better stance when combat begins.  And that takes a swift action.  Its usefulness plummets once you get another stance that adds to initiative.

Strikes:

Sands of Time Approach*:  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or be fatigued for 1d4 rounds.  Fatigued is a very weak effect no matter what level you are.  The best this can do is to use it as a ranged attack and prevent an orc barbarian from charging.

Strike of the Hourglass****:  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or only be able to take a standard or move action next round.  There are two ways you could read this.  One is like the staggered condition, which is pretty good.  The other is that your target can ONLY take a standard or move action, so swift, immediate, and free actions are not allowed!

Counters:

Clockwatcher*****:  You can act in a surprise round!  This gives you a whole entire standard action in every surprise combat over Zealots who don’t have this ability, and a move action as well with Sandals of Quick Reaction.  You won’t use it every combat, obviously, but it’s incredibly powerful when you do use it.

Boosts:

Minute Hand*****:  An attack as a swift action with -2.  Even for a Zealot, not too shabby!  If you do a lot of damage per regular attack at low levels, such as by using a two handed weapon with high strength while in a stance that increases your damage, this can be used to finish off an enemy and prevent it from harming your friends, making it better than a counter in that case.  Since there aren’t many 1st level counters that can reliably be used on allies, you won’t always have the chance to use a counter at levels 1 and 2 of your career, and so having an excellent boost like this is a tremendous boon at low levels.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Chronal Aggression****:  Close ranged touch attack for 2d6+cha damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be sickened for 1 minute, or 1 round even if they succeed!  Sickened is a much nicer debuff than fatigued, and ranged touch attacks are easy to land.  Use Echoes of Steel with your psicrystal to let it shoot a laser every round too!

Rapid Strike*:  Melee-only.  2 normal attacks against the same creature.  A different strike that deals +1d6 or +2d6 damage and has a good secondary effect is much better.

Temporal Burn***:  +2d6 damage, bypass DR and hardness.  You won’t meet many things at level 3 that have DR, but this is fun because it lets you punch through brick walls.  And there is many a tale of clever adventurer groups carrying around an adamantine weapon to dig through dungeon walls and locked chests and doors.

Counters:

Stopwatch*:  Autohypnosis vs attack roll, and you need to 5 foot step out of the attack’s range to negate it.  Flat out worse than almost every other 2nd level counter in the game.

Boosts:

Unhindered Step**:  +30 enhancement bonus to land speed for 1 round.  You can start moving around with teleports at this level, so why waste swift actions on paltry movespeed buffs?  The only use I can see is for overland travel outside of combat.

3rd Level

Stances:

Riven Hourglass Stance*****:  +4 dodge to AC, +4 initiative, immunity to slow, and spells targeting only you have a 20% miss chance!  So many benefits, and they’re all good!  Throw Sands of Time Stance in the dumpster if you haven’t already.  The miss chance vs spells is practically unheard of!  A great stance both in and out of combat.

Strikes:

Temporal Fury***:  +2d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be slowed for 2 rounds.  It’s harder to make full-attacker enemies fail fortitude saves, and they’re the ones who suffer the most from being slowed.  Slow is a decent condition for 2 rounds, but why not nauseate instead?  Take a peek at Chains of Doubt (Sleeping Goddess 3).

Counters:

Flickering Defense****:  Attacker takes -4 on the attack roll and must roll twice and take the lower result.  And you can use this on allies!  Let’s do some quick math!  If you use this on an enemy who has a 50% chance to hit your ally, this reduces it to about 9%.  If the enemy has a 25% chance to hit originally, it gets reduced to 0.25%  And if they have a 95% chance to hit originally, it gets reduced to 56.25%.  It’s a hefty reduction in the likelihood the attack will succeed, and doesn’t require a skill check.  But there’s one problem.  Skill check counters can reduce the success chance of the attack to 0.  This never can.  And skills are very easy to increase.  That makes this inferior to Fear the Reaper (Eternal Guardian), a 2nd level counter, which also inflicts a debuff and sets up combos.  However, it’s great for using Echoes of Steel with your psicrystal, because the psicrystal doesn’t need to make a check.

Probability Twist**:  Reroll a d20 or damage roll on your turn.  It specifically says “in combat,” so you can’t use this to make easy skill checks out of combat.  The best you can do with it is give one of your powerful strikes another chance to hit.

Boosts:

Time Skitter*****:  Gain haste for cha mod rounds!  Even if you don’t use the extra attack on full attacks, the other benefits are definitely welcome, and you can keep it active outside of combat.  Depending on how low your charisma is, it might not last all combat, but still worth it!

4th Level

Strikes:

Chronal Draw***:  +3d6 damage, and your target must make a will save or be exhausted for cha mod rounds.  This equates to a sizeable -3 attack, -3 (maybe 4 or 5) damage, -3 AC, and -6 CMD.  Not a bad effect, by any means, but it’s just not as good as action-denying debuffs like nauseated or stunned.

Tip the Hourglass***:  Melee-only?  The range says “Melee or ranged attack,” but the description says “Make a melee attack.”  +4d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be slowed for cha mod rounds.  Better than Chronal Draw against full attacks, but worse against everything else.

Counters:

Temporal Body Adjustment*****:  Negate any negative condition affecting you or about to affect you, no skill check required!  It’s almost Iron Heart Surge from 3.5e!  Now you’re effectively immune to everything that isn’t hitpoint damage!

Boosts:

Gift of Time*****:  Grant an ally in your Collective (or adjacent) an action they can use immediately, and lose that action for yourself.  If you have an excessively powerful teammate whose full round action is better than your Aid Another + Strike + Counter combo suite, this could be worth it.  You can’t transfer a swift action since you need to use it to activate the boost, so weigh your options carefully.  Use Echoes of Steel to give this to your psicrystal, however, and you can effectively give someone on your team a free turn.

5th Level

Stances:

Chronal Fission*****:  You can use a counter once per round for free!  With your amazing Zealot maneuver recovery, you’re certainly in no danger of running out of counters to use.  You can use 2 counters in the same round, or use a boost and still be able to use a counter prior in the round!  The more maneuvers you can expend in a single round, the brighter the Zealot shines.  As long as you’re not totally inefficient with them, of course.

Strikes:

Sands of Time Tornado**:  Melee attack against all adjacent enemies, and those hit take 2*cha mod and must make a fortitude save or be sickened for 1d4 rounds.  Sickened alone and allowing a save isn’t great at this level.  The fact that you need to be adjacent is especially not great.  It’s nice that it’s multi-target, but other disciplines do multi-target debuffing better.

Time-Thief's Talons**:  +2*IL damage, and you heal 2*IL damage.  It has no rider effects and it’s such a small amount that I can’t ever recommend doing it in combat, unless you’re fighting some very weak enemies.  If you carry around a bag full of rats or other squeaky helpless little creatures, you can gobble them up between combat to heal.  Ew.

Counters:

Relativity Burst*****:  Turn an immediate action into a move action!  If you have Psionic Meditation, this lets you regain your psionic focus as an immediate action.  Sounds amazing, right?  Just hold out for 2 more levels, and you’ll be able to get the much more amazing Overpowering Optimism (Sleeping Goddess 6) for that purpose and not need Psionic Meditation.  You could also use this to use Aid Another twice in one round, and if you can increase your Aid Another bonus high enough and share Harrying Partners with your teammates, the amount of AC or attack bonus you grant someone could definitely be worth it.  Since it’s immediate and not on your turn, you can use it effectively as a counter by increasing a friend’s AC when they’re attacked.  Oh, and you can also use it in the conventional way of moving out of range of attacks to negate them with no skill check.

Boosts:

Hour Hand*:  When you attack, use this to make another attack with -4 attack and +4d6 damage.  Unlike with Minute Hand, you don’t simply attack with this boost alone.  You have to make another attack on your turn to do it.  Regardless, a bit of damage isn’t worth a swift action.

6th Level

Stances:

Sand-bearer's Swiftness*:  Permanent haste, immunity to slow, and all attacks and spells targeting only you have a 20% miss chance.  Lovely effects, but they can all be replicated by maintaining Time Skitter out of combat and using a different stance like Riven Hourglass Stance or Inarguable Presence of the Sleeping Goddess.

Strikes:

Shatter the Hourglass*****:  Normal damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be paralyzed for 1d4 rounds, and if they succeed, they’re slowed for 1d4 rounds instead!  It doesn’t matter that this strike does no additional damage, because once you paralyze something, a friend can simply waltz up and coup de grace it!  A genuine save or die with a powerful debuff if they don’t die!

Temporal Wave****:  30 foot cone.  Creatures inside must make a will save or be nauseated and slowed for cha mod rounds, or slowed for 1 round if they succeed.  Excellent multi-target crowd control no matter what!  Just try not to hit your allies.

Counters:

Temporal Distortion*:  Move up to twice your speed without AoOs.  A very specialized, very narrow version of just one of the many many things Relativity Burst can do.

Boosts:

None

7th Level

Strikes:

Sands of Time Hurricane*****:  Melee-only.  Attack every enemy within reach 2 times with a +4 bonus, and they must make a fortitude save or be nauseated for 1 round.  A fantastic crowd control strike, especially considering that you’re practically guaranteed to hit since you attack twice with a bonus.  It’s even worth considering using on single targets.  If you size-stack and have a huge reach, it gets better and better.

Temporal Dilation*:  Poof someone 1d4 rounds forward in time with a melee touch attack, or 1 round if they make a will save.  Though they won’t be attacking you while they don’t exist, you won’t be able to do anything else to them either.  With the great nauseating and paralyzing strikes you have access to now, this just doesn’t have a purpose.

Counters:

Beat the Clock*****:  Trade an immediate action for a standard action!  This can do literally everything that Relativity Burst can do, and more!  Now you can get another strike off every turn, and protect friends by disabling their attackers just before their attack goes through!

Boosts:

None

8th Level

Stances:

God of the Hourglass Stance*****:  Immunity to slow, fatigue, exhaustion, can always act during a surprise round, can take a single standard action if someone uses time stop nearby, and gain an extra standard or move action per round.  Even the last benefit alone would make this stance amazing, but it comes with several cherries and gallons of gravy on top!  Just think of what you can do with an extra standard action every round!  With Beat the Clock, you can make 3 standard actions in a single round!

Strikes:

Wrath of Time*:  60 foot cone.  Everything inside take damage equal to twice your autohypnosis check, fortitude save half, and gets completely disintegrated if it reduced to 0 HP.  The damage is pitiful, there’s no secondary effect, and destroying loot is bad.

Counters:

Heart of the Time Lord***:  Cast heal on yourself when you’d be reduced to 0 HP.  That heals 150 HP and removes a huge number of nasty effects.  You’ll have to carefully judge whether this will be better than using another counter that could potentially negate more than 150 damage and any accompanying effects, like being full attacked by a high CR dragon with grab.  Many good counters negate full attacks by moving you out of range of iterative attacks, but this does not.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Counters:

Break the Hourglass****:  Trade an immediate action for a standard AND a move action (or a full round action)!  But you can only use this when you’re being targeted or affected by an attack, so you can’t use it to save your friends like you could with Relativity Burst and Beat the Clock.  Also, you can only take the bonus actions to attack or affect your attacker.  No Aid Another allowed.  Maybe you could save your friends from a breath weapon by killing the dragon with a full attack, but that’s the extent of this counter’s protective properties.

Final Ruling*****:  Riven Hourglass flat out gives you more actions per round to do more stuff.  The more stuff you can do, the greater an impact you have on the outcome of a battle, and the better you protect your friends.  One reason God Wizards (a popular term for wizards who specialize in battlefield control and summoning) are so powerful is because they optimize their action economy by hindering the enemies’ abilities to act and summoning more allies to give themselves more effective actions per round.

Scarlet Throne

Skill:  Sense Motive.  4 strikes, 3 counters.

Weapon Groups:  Heavy Blades, Light Blades, Spears.  This discipline has 8 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  All strikes in this discipline are melee-only.

Martial Tradition:  Scarlet Sentinels.  Any alignment.

1st Level

Stances:

Circular Stance*:  You can’t be flanked.  It’s not the same as improved uncanny dodge, because it doesn’t prevent you from being flat-footed.  It also doesn’t add any other functionality or bonuses whatsoever.  The only reason to use this is if you’re in an urban campaign and your GM really, really likes throwing level 1 rogues at you.

Scarlet Einhander**:  When using a weapon in 1 hand, +2 shield bonus to AC and +1d6 damage.  The shield bonus doesn’t seem to stack with a buckler, and a two-handed weapon will usually deal comparable or better damage.  The main point of this stance is to make the one-handed + empty offhand fighting style not completely terrible for people who want to engage in that aesthetic.  For optimization, you want to pick a stance with better functionality or bonuses.

Strikes:

Blade of Breaking**:  Disarm or sunder with no AoO and a +4 competence bonus.  Excellent in the early game for campaigns that mostly feature NPCs rather than the typical beasts or mindless undead.  If your GM is savvy (or just spiteful), expect to see a lot of NPC enemies bringing backup weapons.

Red Zephyr's Strike*:  Attack with normal damage, and move 10 feet with no AoO if successful.  The movement comes after the attack, limiting its usefulness to people who want to be out of melee, IE, non-tanks, IE, non-Zealots.

Scything Strike***:  Attack 2 adjacent enemies for normal damage.  For a discipline that likes to tout its martial superiority in such a haughty way, it’s rather pathetic with maneuvers like this compared to Tidal Blade (Mithral Current 1), which doesn’t require your targets to be adjacent, and even gives you an attack bonus.  Still, at low levels, this can help you oneshot two enemies at once with enough damage.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Prince's Attitude**:  For 1 round, you have +4 dodge to AC while moving through threatened squares, and +2 competence to reflex and will.  Zealots use their move actions for Aid Another, typically not movement.  And even if you do have a penchant for moving through threatened squares without using teleportation maneuvers, hopefully you’d have a decent acrobatics check.  The bonuses to saves can help in some situations, but not many.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Garnet Lance*:  +2d6 damage and ignore DR.  You really shouldn’t need to worry about DR at low levels outside of skeletons and zombies, and you want to inflict status effects, not raw damage.

Rising Zenith Strike****:  Make an attack that effectively uses your sense motive bonus in place of your BAB and deal double damage.  Math time!  With 18 strength, a greatsword, and Power Attack at level 3, you will deal 4d6+18 damage, plus more with things like a damage stance, a boost, and other buffs.  That’s an average of 32 damage.  An average CR 3 monster has 30 HP.  Imagine how disgusting this can be on a class that can stack a higher damage bonus and sense motive bonus, like a Primal Disciple Barbarian, Brutal Slayer Stalker, or Ordained Defender Warder.  This gets a high rating simply because it’s overtuned.  I think this was designed with the idea that people would be using it with a rapier.

Counters:

Sanguine Barrier**:  Sense motive +2 vs attack to negate it.  The +2 bonus gives it a leg up compared to other counters, but it still can’t hold a candle to the awe-inspiring might of Fear the Reaper (Eternal Guardian 2) because it can’t be used on allies and is wisdom-based.

Boosts:

Regal Blade***:  Gain +2 insight to attack and +1d8 damage to a single attack this turn.  Handy for ensuring you finish off a low health enemy, but using a counter to negate an attack could be more reliable.

3rd Level

Stances:

Unfettered Movement*:  +10 base speed, +4 AC against AoOs.  Know what doesn’t provoke AoOs?  Teleportation maneuvers!  Know what doesn’t have anything useful for a Zealot?  This stance!  Other 3rd level stances give you +4 AC in all situations, and more.

Strikes:

Dazing Attack*****:  +3d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1 round.  Simple and effective lockdown!

Strike of Defeat**:  Deal +4d6/+8d6 damage if your target has >75%/25% HP remaining.  You won’t be able to tell how much HP unless you have another ability that lets you, or if the GM tells you.  It doesn’t hurt to ask the GM how injured an opponent looks.  If you do manage to use this against an enemy with less than 25% hp, it’s almost certainly a guaranteed kill at this level, but it will fade in usefulness very quickly.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Scarlet Eye's Perception***:  Your next melee attack is a touch attack.  You can’t use Power Attack with this, and Murderous Spite (Cursed Razor 2) comes 2 levels earlier.  Enemies with an exceptionally high armor or natural armor AC aren’t all that common at low levels, either.  But when you need it, it’s good to have.

4th Level

Strikes:

Red Zephyr's Dance*:  Full round action.  Make a full attack, moving 10 feet between each attack.  No bonus damage, no rider.  Oh, and it doesn’t prevent AoOs.  It’s like one big ball of awfulness wrapped up in a graceful red package.

Weeping Scarlet Razor*:  +4d6 damage and 4 bleed damage per round.  Bleeds are usually poor in general, and strikes that do nothing but damage are extremely poor for Zealots.

Counters:

Sanguine Perseverance***:  Roll sense motive in place of a saving throw.  A skill check, even if it’s not charisma-based, will almost always be higher than your actual saves.  Since you can use it every round for free outside of combat, this makes you great at waltzing through trap-infested labyrinths with relative safety.

Boosts:

Noble Blade***:  Gain +5 insight to attack and +2d8 damage to a single attack this turn.  Likely to be better than Scarlet Eye’s Perception in many situations, unless you’re going up against something with truly ludicrous armor or natural AC like a dragon or a Fighter using AMG options.

5th Level

Strikes:

Riddle of Iron*****:  +5d6 damage, and your target must make a will save or be dazed for 1 round.  The duration is no improvement over Dazing Attack, but targeting will saves is much better than targeting fortitude saves!

Ruby Zenith Strike****:  Make an attack that effectively uses your sense motive bonus in place of your BAB and deal triple damage.  You thought Rising Zenith Strike was too strong?  Well then, have I got a strike for you!  In an actual game I was GMing, a level 11 Zweihander Sentinel Warder with 20 PB and NPC wealth used this to oneshot a level 13 Oracle NPC from full health.  #AnecdotalEvidence.  I could splat down more math, but I think you get the picture.

Counters:

Sanguine Perfection*****:  You ignore or negate a huge number of conditions for cha mod rounds, including especially things that would usually take you out of the fight like unconsciousness.  You can use this against incoming conditions, or conditions you’re already suffering, making it a lot more versatile than many other counters.  The only things it doesn’t protect you against are grappled, entangled, pinned, or dead.

Scarlet Riposte*:  Roll sense motive with a +4 competence bonus vs a melee attack to negate it and counter attack for +3d6 damage.  The competence bonus won’t stack with most magic items, this only works against melee attacks against you, and the counter attack is too underwhelming to be of note.

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Scarlet Duelist Attitude***:  +5 insight to AC, CMD, and initiative.  The bonuses are the best of any stance, but only slightly better than many 3rd level stances that give +4 to AC and initiative.  If you already have a stance with good combat functionality and need one for pure defense that you haven’t yet been able to get, this is a decent choice.

Strikes:

Blade of Perfection**:  Automatically hits, ignores DR, and can’t be countered.  It’s a nice sentiment, and you can wallop someone with no chance of failure to finish them off, especially with a two-handed power attack.  But you already have tons of accuracy with the Blade boosts and Zenith strikes, which turn your attack rolls into skill checks and prevent a natural 1 from auto missing.

Final Blow***:  Make a coup de grace with no AoO if your target has <25% HP.  You can also roll sense motive DC 20 to sense if they’re eligible.  If you use this, you’ll undoubtedly score a kill!  But unless you fight enemies with a lot of HP, it’s usually easiest to simply hit them with other strikes, because it’s easy to leapfrog from >25% to dead.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Red Zephyr's Fleetness**:  For 1 round, you have +30 speed and 50% miss chance.  The miss chance is certainly nice for self defense, but you probably won’t get much use out of the speed bonus.  You can also replicate the miss chance with equipment or buffs, or take half damage with a maneuver that makes you incorporeal from Veiled Moon.

7th Level

Strikes:

Ruby Battle Lord's Strike*:  Full round action.  Make a full attack with no iterative penalty and a +2 insight bonus.  Let’s just do some quick and cheap math, shall we?  With 24 strength, Power Attack, and a +3 greatsword, a medium level 13 Zealot will normally attack for 2d6+25 damage at +19/+14/+9, resulting in 35.28 damage per round (DPR) against an enemy with 28 AC.  But with Ruby Battle Lord’s Strike, the Zealot will have 70.56, double the amount.  At level 16, when you get another iterative, the difference in DPR will be even greater.  But since this is a full round action, it’s way better for other classes.  So why the red rating?  Simply, the Zenith strikes and the upcoming Descending Sunset Strike are so overtuned that they do comparable damage with a standard action.

Sanguine Proclamation*:  [mind-affecting].  +10d6 damage and your target must make a will save or be knocked prone.  Overwhelming your opponent with your regal dominance is deliciously thematic and awesome!  But knocking someone prone as a 7th level strike, especially mind-affecting, is pathetic.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Royal Blade****:  Gain +5 insight to attack and +5d8 damage to a single attack this turn, and a hit target must make a will save or cower for 1 round.  Huge accuracy, huge damage, and a hard lockdown effect!  For best efficacy, use this on an AoO and use your standard action to lockdown a different foe so that you can lockdown two foes in the same round.

8th Level

Stances:

Scarlet Majesty Stance***:  [mind-affecting].  Enemies must make a will save to be able to attack you.  At first glance, this might seem like an anti-tanking stance by encouraging enemies to attack your allies, but it’s ironically quite effective for the Zealot’s method of indirect party damage prevention.  After all, you can’t use Martyrdom on yourself, only on your allies!

Strikes:

Descending Sunset Strike****:  Make an attack that effectively uses your sense motive bonus in place of your BAB and deal quadruple damage.  The final entry in the Zenith strikes.  Every point of damage or size increase you manage to get will increase your damage exponentially.  It’s not difficult to be able to oneshot standard enemies of your CR even as a Zealot with no class features that give you a damage bonus.  If you can knock out an enemy every round with this strike, then take it, but if your GM makes enemies tougher and gives them more HP, stick with debuff and crowd control strikes.

Riddle of Steel*****:  “That is strength, boy. That is power: the strength and power of flesh. What is steel compared to the hand that wields it? Look at the strength of your body, the desire in your heart.”  +10d6 damage, and your target must make a will save or be stunned for 1d4 damage.  Long duration, one of the best lockdown debuffs, targets will, and oodles of damage!  Doesn’t get much better than that.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Heavenly Blade of the Scarlet Throne*****:  +100 damage, and your target must make a will save or be paralyzed for 1d4 rounds.  Okay, so maybe I spoke too soon.  This is clearly way better than Riddle of Steel.  Being paralyzed opens you up to coup de grace, while being merely stunned does not!

Final Ruling***:  The mobility-enhancing maneuvers of this discipline are nothing for a Zealot to get excited about, but the boosts make it very easy to land strikes, and the Zenith strikes give you a massive easy oomph of damage when you need it.  Counter-intuitively, the secret to using Scarlet Throne effectively isn’t to use a one-hander, it’s to use a two-hander.  You’ll need the Unhindering Shield feat to use a buckler and a greatsword at the same time.

Shattered Mirror

Skill:  Craft (glassmaking, painting, sculpture, or sketching).  3 strikes, 2 counters, 1 boost.

Weapon Groups:  Heavy Blades, Light Blades, Close.  This discipline has 8 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  All strikes in this discipline are melee-only.

Martial Tradition:  Stained Glass Champions.  Any non-evil.

1st Level

Stances:

Dopplehanger Dance*:  A slightly better version of Step Up that doesn’t require an immediate action or prevent you from taking a 5 foot step on your next turn.  Stances need to do way more to be worthwhile.  All you can do with this is harass archers and spellcasters, and if you have a reach weapon, you can already do that.

Obsidian Reflection Stance****:  All creatures within 20 feet of you, including you, have either a bonus or penalty to attack and damage rolls.  If you’re very clever with your positioning, this can be even better than Golden General’s Attitude (Golden Lion 6) since it’s untyped and gives a bigger bonus.  You can hang back as a ranged character to give yourself and a few other ranged teammates the benefit of your buff aura, and possibly your melee friends too if they’re very careful about not allowing enemies to slip past the front line.  If you’re the only melee character in your party, you can leap into the fray to make enemies hit like kittens trapped in fluffy stockings.

Strikes:

Breaking Glass Strike*****:  Normal damage, dazzle for cha mod rounds, and your target must make a will save or be dazed for 1 round!  A crowd control effect that makes your enemy completely unable to fight back, AND applies another small debuff regardless, as a 1st level strike!  Quite possibly one of the best 1st level strikes for Zealots in the game if you meet something you can’t simply paste with one single swing of a two-hander.

Copycat Cut**:  +1d6 damage, and you can copy an attack roll your target makes next turn to use for your own attack next turn, and deal +2d4 damage if you do.  It’s unlikely that anything will survive long enough at low levels for you to hit the same target a second time after creaming it with a damage-adding strike, but you might get to keep the target’s attack roll if it lives long enough to make one.  Of course, you don’t necessarily want it to roll high, because that means someone in your party probably gets hit.  Decent for boss fights with high saves and multiple attacks.  Outside of that, not so good.

Left-Hand Strike*:  Craft check vs target’s AC to ignore target’s shield bonus to AC and deal +1d6 damage.  You need to succeed on 2 different rolls against AC in the same action for a pitiful bonus to hit in rare circumstances.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Funhouse Waltz*:  For 1 round, you gain +10 enhancement to speed and don’t need to move in a straight line to charge.  Nice for Hussars and other chargers, but not for Zealots.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Broken Mirror Strike**:  Normal damage, and your target must make a reflex save or get the broken condition on its armor or shield for cha mod rounds.  This can knock a solid 5 AC off of someone wearing plate armor, but your GM probably won’t be throwing many NPCs in plate your way at level 3, because that will give you 1500 gp a pop for treasure from the armor alone.  You’re more likely to encounter enemies in breastplates, at best, which means -3 AC from this strike.  A decent chunk for a decent duration, but disabling the target entirely would be better.

Mimic's Gambit**:  Normal damage, and you gain one spell affecting the target for up to cha mod rounds.  It all depends on whether or not you’re fighting something that has powerful buffs, and if you’d be able to hit the enemy in order to copy them.  It works great against self-buffing melee divine casters, and you could nab something like Righteous Might, but arcane casters are often too evasive to hit.  All in all, it only buffs you, not your team, and doesn’t hinder the enemy.

Counters:

Equivocate**:  For 1 round, when your target is targeted by a spell/power/SLA, you get its effect as well for 1 round, and vice versa.  It offers no save, so it’s lovely for using against self-buffing enemies like divine casters or a BBEG that has a ton of minions dedicating to supporting him with healing or buff spells.  But alas, it suddenly turns terrible if you have any offensive casters on your team, as they no longer can hurt your target without also hurting you.  You’d think that you could use Equivocate on an ally and double up on healing and buffing, but it can only be used on enemies.

Obsidian Sidestep***:  Make a craft check in place of a saving throw.  Unless you dipped 2 levels of Paladin, your craft check is likely to be better than your saves.  At level 3 with a mere 10 intelligence, your bonus will be +6 at minimum, and can easily be increased with equipment.  With a dip in Rubato Bard and Pageant of the Peacock, you use bluff in place of craft and become nigh untouchable as far as saves go, especially outside of combat since you can continually recover this.

Boosts:

Obsidian Razor Style**:  Gain an insight bonus to melee damage equal to your ranks in Craft for 1 round.  This is for full-attackers and crit fishers.  Zealots are neither.  If you regularly use standard action strikes that give you multiple attacks, this could get more mileage.

3rd Level

Stances:

Infinity Mirror Stance**:  Gain 1 mirror image per 4 ILs when you enter this stance.  Mirror image is one of the most common and powerful defenses for wizards, and for good reason.  But this stance isn’t as good as the spell it’s based on.  Every extra mirror image you have increases your chance to be missed by an amount that exceeds and stacks with conventional miss chance.  1 image = 50% chance, 2 = 67%, 3 = 75%, 4 = 80%, 5 = 83%.  Casters can get 8 for a 89% miss chance.  But every time one of your images gets hit, it disappears, leaving you a bit more vulnerable than before.  If a lot of attacks are coming your way, such as from full attacking enemies or lots of mooks, your images will drop quickly, leaving you with absolutely nothing until you change to a different stance, and you’re much more likely to be in harm’s way than a wizard.  A stance that gives a bonus to AC and some other benefits, like Flowing Water Stance (Mithral Current 3), Stance of the Thunderbrand (Piercing Thunder 5), or Riven Hourglass Stance (Riven Hourglass 3), would be much better if you want a defensive stance.

Strikes:

Curse of the Twisted Reflection****:  [curse, mind-affecting].  Normal damage, your target must make a will save or become confused for cha mod rounds, and your target is cursed for cha mod rounds regardless of the save.  Confused is potentially a very powerful and deadly effect, especially if used on more than one target at a time.  If one confused creature attacks another, they both will be forced to attack each other every turn until one of them is no longer confused.  But on a single creature, it’s much less potent, and has a chance to do nothing at all.  If you land this on an enemy and then ensure its friends are closer to it than you are, the confusion has a 75% chance of working in your favor for a much longer duration than Breaking Glass Strike.  It’s a risk, but statistically, it is worth the gamble.

Shattered Glass Smite***:  +3d6 damage, and you make a 30 foot cone with your target as the originating square, 3d6 damage with no save.  The cone doesn’t deal much damage and is hard to aim since it depends on where your target is.  It is rare as a relatively low level form of area effect damage, however, and could be boosted with Reflected Blade Style.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Reflected Blade Style*****:  For 1 round, your next standard action strike that only targets 1 creature also affects another in close range.  This is like trading a swift action for a standard action and extending your range to boot!  Inflicting a disabling debuff on an enemy can undoubtedly be better than negating an attack with a counter!  Try this with Curse of the Twisted Reflection to hopefully lock two enemies into attacking each other for several rounds!

4th Level

Strikes:

Blazing Mirror Strike****:  Melee touch attack, normal damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be blinded for cha mod rounds.  Quite a lengthy duration for one of the better debuffs, and it’s a touch attack rather than a regular one!  The only downside is that it’s a fort save, making it harder to land on melee-loving enemies.

Fetch's Wrath*****:  [teleportation].  Teleport to medium range and attack for +4d6, or attack and then teleport.  HUGE range, and Zealots always love standard action strikes that move you!

Counters:

Doppleganger Waltz*:  Move whenever your target moves, up to 3 times.  This lets you chase after slippery targets like Veiled Moon and Mithral Current users and keep them in melee range.  You should have other ways of consistently landing attacks and affecting slippery targets without having to waste immediate actions chasing after them, such as AoOs, ranged strikes, and the almighty Reflected Blade Style.

Boosts:

Carnival Swap**:  Next time you hit this round, you transfer one magic effect from your target to yourself and vice versa for cha mod rounds.  It’s like an improved Mimic’s Gambit that also requires a swift action.  It’s almost impossible to find a perfect scenario where you will simultaneously steal a good buff from your target and also transfer a dangerous debuff from yourself to them.  High potential for effectiveness, but very low chance to ever realize it.  You could go out of your way to set up scenarios where this will be useful, such as asking a friendly Wizard to cast silence on you before you attack an enemy caster, but that’s a lot of effort.

5th Level

Stances:

Silvered Mirror Stance***:  Share one spell effect on you that has a range greater than personal with your friends within 30 feet.  Sadly, you can’t steal self-buff spells from casters and share them with your friends like Metamorphosis and Righteous Might.  The best you can do is save your party’s casters spell slots by sharing important buff spells they provide you.  It requires specific party composition and organization, and might not even be needed if your caster friends are well prepared.  Not everybody wants a Polymorph, and there are stances that are better than giving your party Displacement in many circumstances.

Strikes:

Curse of the Smoking Mirror****:  [curse].  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or be cursed and suffer whatever damage it deals for cha mod rounds!  That’s a huge deterrent for any self-aware attackers.  Use on enemies that specialize in damage and have little utility (like any Paizo non-caster class), and it’s almost as good as a pure disabling debuff.

Gleaming Imprisonment***:  +4d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be put into stasis for cha mod rounds.  It’s a surefire way to completely remove an enemy from combat for a while, but they will eventually come back, and they will have been able to buff and heal themselves while in stasis.

Counters:

Empty Frame****:  You and your stuff becomes incorporeal for 1 round.  An immediate action version of Ghostwalk (Veiled Moon 3) that comes 2 levels later.  Its utility is useful for the same reasons, but of questionable value as a counter.  Unless your enemies have force damage or ghost touch, that’s a 50% reduction in damage for an entire round, and 50% miss chance against non damaging spells.  But it’s only for you, not your friends.  Otherwise, it’s similar to Stand Your Ground (Eternal Guardian 5), which is probably better for overall team protection.

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Cursed Mirror Stance*:  You gain bonus AoOs equal to cha mod, stacking with everything, and anyone who hits you with a melee attack provokes an AoO from you.  It offers no utility, it doesn’t do anything about ranged attackers and spellcasters, and it requires you to be hit.  Leave this to the Barbarians who have the high HP, DR, low AC, and high two-handed damage to make the best use of it.  Using this as a low damage Zealot just tells the enemies to attack someone else.

Strikes:

Murderous Reflection*:  +7d6 damage, and add your target’s strength modifier to your attack roll.  Though it’s highly likely to hit, it doesn’t matter if you’re only making a single attack with no rider effects at level 11.

Warped Glass Strike*****:  +4d6 damage, and your target must make a will save or attack the closest creature for cha mod rounds.  A more focused, specialized version of confusion from Curse of the Twisted Reflection.  If you’re facing more than one enemy in melee, it’s very easy to use this with long reach and perhaps take a 5 foot step away to effectively turn your victim to your side for a several rounds.  And with Reflected Blade Style, it gets even easier, letting you lock two enemies into mortal combat.  It’s not mind-affecting, either.  HOWEVER, the target could alternatively attack the last creature who damaged it.  You.  In that case, it’ll require a lot more finagling to make this effective, likely involving teleportation or invisibility.  But still, forcing an opponent to focus on you counts as protecting your allies!

Counters:

Plagiarism****:  When targeted by a spell/power/su/SLA, you gain the ability to use it for cha mod rounds and your target loses it for cha mod rounds, but the attack still affects you.  There are all sorts of crazy supernatural abilities that are wonderful for spamming for several rounds, like the breath weapons of great wyrm dragons!  Provided you can survive being hit by them, of course.  If your enemy has a seriously dangerous ability, it’s definitely worth using this to shut it down with no skill check or chance for the enemy to make a save, as that will help out your team over the course of the combat.

Boosts:
