Copycat's Cunning***:  You use the enhancement bonus and gain the special enhancements of someone else’s weapon, armor, or shield for cha mod rounds.  Now you have a good excuse to stick with a +1 weapon with a bunch of other special enhancements if someone in your party has a +5 weapon!  Remember, don’t use this in the middle of combat, use it outside.

7th Level

Strikes:

Double Team*:  + 2*(craft check) bonus damage, and knock your target prone.  Potentially lots of damage, but prone isn’t a good enough effect at this level, even though it offers no save.

Infinite Reflections*:  Make a full attack against a single target, but your iteratives have -4 instead of the usual -5, and keep attacking forever until you miss.  Full attacks are generally bad for Zealots, as is losing the flexibility of a full attack by being forced to only attack a single target.  And if you’re unlucky and miss one of your early attacks, you’ll be unable to make any more iteratives, so a regular full attack could have greater damage potential.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Mirror Demon's Waltz*****:  Teleport long range, and enemies you started and ended your teleport adjacent to are cursed and flat-footed for 1 round with no save.  Exceptional mobility that doesn’t interfere with your move actions, though it does take up your swift.  Flat-footing your target to ensure you land a disabling strike could definitely be better than using Fetch’s Wrath and a counter, so it’s worth it.  Your Rogue and Stalker friends will love the flat-footing as well.

8th Level

Stances:

Unholy Mirror Stance***:  When a spell/power/SLA targets an enemy within 30 feet, make it affect a number of extra enemies equal to your cha mod.  This lets you turn the single-target save-or-die or nuke spells into multi target ones!  Naturally, that can have a ginormous effect.  But it also raises the question, if you have a powerful nuker or save-or-die full caster in your party, wouldn’t they already be using battlefield control and area-effect spells at this level?

Strikes:

Shattered Mirror Strike*:  [mind-affecting].  +6d6 damage, and make a craft check vs your target’s CMD to give them a 50% miss chance and 50% spell failure chance on spells with verbal or somatic components for cha mod rounds.  Against physical attackers, it’s not as good as the blinded condition, because blind has additional useful effects.  Against casters, it’s handy on arcane and divine casters (who haven’t cast Mind Blank on themselves), but not useful against psychic or psionic casters.  Better to disable a caster completely rather than just give them a 50% chance to fail their spell.

Counters:

Obsidian Negation****:  Make a craft check vs your target’s CL + wis mod to negate their spell/power/maneuver and make them unable to use it for cha mod rounds.  The perfect counter to one-trick-ponies who use the same attack over and over!  But wait, we’re level 15 now.  Most casters, even spontaneous ones, and initiators are going to have some versatility.  Convert Intrusion (Sleeping Goddess 6) has a similar effect 4 levels earlier, doesn’t add the target’s wis mod to the DC of your skill check, and gives your allies a buff.  At least Obsidian Negation works on maneuvers as well, and doesn’t require you to be the target.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Septennial Seal*****:  +13d6, and your target must make a will save or die and have their soul trapped for 7 years.  Well, save-or-dies are technically crowd control, which Zealots love doing as standard actions.  And this will ensure that the sneaky lich or the complex multi-faceted nemesis that your GM has been building up for the entirety of your campaign won’t come back after defeat.  It could be fun to go on a murdering spree and hang up the dozens of mirrors you collect all around your house, with the agonized visages of your imprisoned victims’ souls screaming in the reflection.

Final Ruling****:  A lot of the maneuvers in this discipline become more effective the more powerful your enemies are, but they are also very situational depending on your party composition and opposition.  Maneuvers that steal an enemy’s abilities will only be powerful if the enemy itself is powerful.  Ignoring those, there are maneuvers that every Zealot will enjoy like Breaking Glass Strike for a level 1 daze, and Fetch’s Wrath for a mid-level teleport strike.  If nothing else, consider Reflected Blade Style, as it can completely change your playstyle from being conservative and using counters to being a risk-taker and using double strikes.

Silver Crane

Skill:  Perception.  1 counter.

Weapon Groups: Bows, Hammers, Spears.  This discipline has 7 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Empyreal Guardians.  Any Good.

Note:  You don’t have to be good, but all Silver Crane maneuvers have the [good] descriptor.

Note 2:  Sacred damage deals full damage to incorporeal targets, counts as good-aligned, and bypasses all damage reduction.  It doesn’t deal +50% damage to evil creatures anymore.

Note 3:  All Silver Crane strikes can be used to hit incorporeal or possessing creatures without harming the possessed host.

1st Level

Stances:

Eyes of the Crane***:  Roll twice on perception checks and piercing concealment, and use detect evil at will.  A good out-of-combat stance for both social and exploration situations, and can help in combat against particularly sneaky lurkers.

Silver Crane Waltz****:  +4 insight to initiative, +2 insight to reflex and AC.  Very good bonuses for a 1st level stance.  Other stances with an initiative bonus are a mere +2, or +4 at 3rd level.  Just remember that Dusty Rose (cracked or non) Ioun Stones won’t stack with this.

Strikes:

Enduring Crane Strike***:  Melee-only.  Normal damage, and you heal yourself or an ally in your Collective (or within 30 feet) for 1d6+cha mod HP.  Wonderful at low levels, but scales very poorly.  The damage output of enemies will quickly outstrip the amount of healing you can do per round, and you will prevent more damage to your party by debuffing your enemies with strikes that make them unable to attack.  Your GM may or may not allow you to get away with using this maneuver to punch a friendly creature and fully heal your party between combats.  If they don’t, show them Boots of the Earth, a Paizo item, and tell them that HP attrition in Pathfinder is a ridiculous notion.

Flashing Wings*:  Melee-only.  +1d4 damage, and your target is dazzled for one round.  Yes, dazzled.  Pathetic damage, pathetic debuff, and not the least bit redeemed by the fact that it gives no save.

Silver Strike*:  Normal damage, use the better of two attack rolls to hit.  Simply being more likely to hit with a plain old regular attack isn’t useful for a Zealot.  Mathematically, it’s worse to use it against high AC enemies than low AC enemies, too.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Crane Step**:  Take a 5 foot step.  Useless for Zealots with a good acrobatics check, whether that’s through being dexterity-based or having the Agile Dancer trait, as other boosts like Leaping Dragon (Thrashing Dragon 1) will move you further, and you can use acrobatics to avoid AoOs.  For other Zealots, it will be useful for moving into a flanking position, or hopping out of melee range to deny an enemy with multiple attacks from making a full attack.  At levels 1 and 2, that’s not very common.  You could also use this to get more AoOs on medium enemies with a reach weapon, if they keep brainlessly approaching you.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Blessed Pinions**:  +2d6 sacred damage, bypasses DR/good, and hit incorporeal or possessing creatures.  Incorporeal foes this low level are uncommon, but this is a good tool to have to deal with them, as is the unique ability to deal with possessions.

Emerald Displacement Strike***:  Normal damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or suffer -4 perception and 20% miss chance for cha mod rounds.  It’s unreliable and there are much better debuffs to inflict, but the high duration at this level and potential to make at least 2 attacks miss over its duration make it somewhat useful.

Counters:

Defensive Step*:  Perception vs attack roll, and you need to 5 foot step out of the attack’s range to negate it.  Exactly the same thing as Stopwatch (Riven Hourglass 2), and it also uses a wisdom-based skill.

Boosts:

Blazing Crane's Wing*:  For 1 round, your attacks deal +2d6 damage against undead and evil outsiders.  Far too situational, and at level 3, you’ve graduated beyond the generic low level crypts full of zombies and skeletons that so many GMs are fond of.

3rd Level

Stances:

Stance of the Silver Crane**:  Gain Protection from Evil and the Holy weapon property.  Though the deflection and resistance bonuses from Protection from Evil won’t stack with items, it will still protect you from possession and mental control, and the natural attacks of summoned evil creatures.  All Holy does is add +2d6 damage to evil creatures, so it’s not as impressive as something that increases accuracy or has a rider.  You can become immune to possession and mental control by buying a Clear Spindle Ioun Stone and putting it in a Wayfinder.

Strikes:

Exorcism Strike*****:  +6d6 sacred damage to undead and evil outsiders, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1 round.  Otherwise, +2d6 damage and no daze.  Amazing against undead and evil outsiders, but terrible otherwise.  Note that undead have “Immunity to any effect that requires a Fortitude save (unless the effect also works on objects or is harmless),” so this might not even be able to daze undead.  Your GM might let it slide, though.

Silver Knight's Blade****:  Melee-only.  +4d6 sacred damage, and you heal yourself or an ally in your Collective (or 30 feet) for the same amount of damage.  A perfectly respectable strike to use if crowd-control isn’t crucial.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Silver Crane's Blessing***:  Use when you successfully attack to heal yourself or an ally in your Collective (or 30 feet) for 2d6+cha mod HP.  A nice chunk of healing that’s strong enough to undo an attack from some enemies you meet around this level, but you’ll very quickly meet enemies that are more deadly and want to use damage-preventing counters instead.

4th Level

Strikes:

Sacred Pinions*****:  +5d6 damage (not sacred for some reason), and hits incorporeal and possessing creatures.  Its short description says that it stuns for 1d4 rounds, but its long description does not, though it does mention a fortitude partial save.  Errata is needed.  If it can stun any creature, then it’s purple, but if it only stuns incorporeal and possessing fiends, it’s far more situational.

Sapphire Displacement Strike***:  Normal damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or fail all perception checks and suffer a 50% miss chance for cha mod rounds.  Strangely, failing all perception checks means you’re unable to perceive anything, so you can’t see or hear anything, but it doesn’t impose any of the other penalties of being blinded or deafened.  Still, long-duration miss chance is good.

Counters:

Silver Crane Resurgence*****:  You or an ally in your Collective (or 30 feet) reroll a failed saving throw with a +4 sacred bonus.  Protecting allies from nasty things is what Zealots do best, and save-or-die effects are the nastiest!  This is one level higher than Swallow your Fear (Eternal Guardian 3), but can be used on any save, and gives a sacred bonus instead of morale.

Boosts:

Silver Crane's Leap**:  Move up to your speed with no AoO.  Useless for Zealots with a good acrobatics score, as they can leap all over the place and avoid AoOs with Leaping Dragon (Thrashing Dragon 1) and a good acrobatics check.  If you’re in heavy armor, you’re only going to move 20 feet, unless you have speed increasers like Boots of Striding and Springing, Speed of Thought, and Unhindered Way.  And you know what else is good at moving you around with no AoOs?  Teleportation strikes!  This is only of real tactical use if you lack any sort of ranged weapon (easily obtainable with a Robe of Needles), and you’re just a short distance away from moving up to melee to use a crowd control melee strike maneuver.

5th Level

Stances:

Stance of the Crane Knight***:  Fly speed = base speed * 2, radiate light, and DR 10/evil.  You gain flight 1 level earlier than Unbroken Stride (Sleeping Goddess 1) at IL 10, and the DR is a nice big chunk of protection against almost anything that isn’t a good outsider.

Strikes:

Argent Knight's Banner****:  Melee-only.  +8d6 damage, and you and all allies in your Collective (or 30 feet) are healed for 4d6 HP.  Huge damage, and lots of healing for your party!  But it doesn’t amount to much healing for a particular individual ally, so beware of enemies focusing fire.  It may even be worth NOT using your Martyrdom or counters on allies who have full HP, so that you will get more bang for your buck when using this.

Silver Crane's Spiral****:  Attack all adjacent enemies, all enemies in melee reach, or all enemies in your 1st range increment for ranged weapons, with a +2 insight bonus.  A strange distinction for melee, but if you don’t have a way to attack inside your reach deadzone, at least this gives you the option to.  An Archery Zealot with a longbow and a nice huge range increment can potentially get a ludicrous number of attacks off, though of course, they’re just regular plain old shots that won’t deal much damage.

Counters:

Emerald-Tipped Feathers*:  You gain DR 20/evil against 1 attack.  Enemies that deal pure damage at this level are likely to deal far more than just 1 attack for 20 or less, and part of the point of using counters is to completely negate attacks so that you don’t suffer riders like grab or ability damage.

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Silver Crane Endurance*:  You gain fast healing 5.  This has negligible use in combat, as 5 HP per round is unlikely to be the difference between staying in the fight and dying.  Other stances that offer actual functionality are better in that they’ll help you do your job of defending your team, resulting in less HP lost overall.  Outside of combat, just use a wand of cure light wounds or put on some Boots of Earth.  Or punch your psicrystal with a healing strike repeatedly.  It has hardness 8, it won’t mind.  Unless it’s a Bully.

Strikes:

Argent King's Scepter****:  Melee-only.  +12d6 damage, and you heal 60 HP.  Huuuuuuge damage for a 6th level strike, and a big heaping spoonful of healing, but you can’t use it on allies.  60 healing is like rolling the average of 17d6.  That’s better than using Argent Knight’s Banner in a party of 4.

Holy Pinions**:  +10d6 damage, hits incorporeal and possessing creatures, and such creatures must make a will save or be forced corporeal and stunned for cha mod rounds.  Annihilates those types of creatures, but simply acts as a high damage hit to anything else.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Silver Crane's Mercy**:  Use this when you make a successful attack and heal yourself an ally in your Collective (or 30 feet) for 9d6 HP.  This is an average of 31.5 damage, and it’s very easy to suffer more than that much damage from a single attack at this level.  Consider a damage-prevention counter instead.  An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

7th Level

Strikes:

Diamond Displacement Strike****:  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or be permanently blinded and deafened, or staggered for 1 round if they succeed.  Stagger might not be a perfect form of crowd control, but it still does a good job of shutting down full-attackers.  And keep in mind, that’s if your target saves!  This is good against almost anything you use it on, except things with blindsight.

Counters:

Diamond-Tipped Feathers***:  DR 30/evil against one attack, or negate an incoming effect, or remove one condition, with no check required!  But wait.  Temporal Body Adjustment (Riven Hourglass 4) was doing this several levels ago.  The DR against a single attack is pathetic compared to a counter that fully negates an attack.  If you don’t have access to Riven Hourglass and don’t want to take Advanced Study to get it, you could take Diamond-Tipped Feathers.

Boosts:

Holy Rush**:  [teleportation].  Poofaport 50 feet away adjacent to an ally.  The range doesn’t interact with your Collective, because the target is You, not an ally.  You could cleverly use your Psicrystal to skitter around the battlefield and act as a point you’ll teleport to, but that’s dangerous for your little crystal buddy.  As a result, Reunion in Dreams (Sleeping Goddess 4) has a longer range, comes at a lower level, and has additional functionality.

8th Level

Stances:

Diamond Wings of the Imperial Crane****:  You gain SR 15+IL, +4 sacred bonus to saves, and effects that fail to beat your SR heal you for 2*level of the effect.  The SR is quite high indeed, and it will take a lot of luck and CL stacking for a caster to harm you!

Strikes:

Celestial Pinions**:  +15d6 damage, hits incorporeal and possessing creatures, and such creatures must make a will save or die.  The penultimate form of murdering ghosties and people who abuse Magic Jar!  It remains just as situational as ever, though.  The humongous damage bonus is nice, at least.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Benediction of the Silver Crane****:  Use when you make a successful attack and heal yourself and all allies in your Collective (or 30 feet) for 12d6 HP.  Because of the multi-target healing, this has the potential to undo more damage to your party overall than some counters could prevent in a given round.

9th Level

Strikes:

Strike of Silver Exorcism**:  +80 sacred damage and dazzles for 1 round.  +120 damage if your target is undead or an evil outsider, which really means +180, and must make a will save or die.  And even if they save, they’re slowed for cha mod rounds.  The true ultimate form of demolishing the most evil creatures around!  Pointless against other creatures, however.  Naturally, this and the Pinion strikes will have higher ratings if these enemies are more common in your campaign.

Final Ruling***:  This discipline provides oodles of healing, but healing isn’t always as good as simply preventing damage in the first place.  If your GM favors enemies that deal a lot of damage, the healing maneuvers are worse than maneuvers that disable enemies or negate attacks, but if you play in a low PB game with comparatively weak enemies, the healing maneuvers are better.  Grab one of the Pinion strikes to have a useful tool against incorporeal and possessing enemies.

Sleeping Goddess

Skill:  Autohypnosis. 2 counters, 1 strike.

Weapon Groups:  Flail, Heavy Blade, Monk, Spear, Mind Blade equivalent.  This discipline has 16 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Servants of the Secret Hymn.  Any non-evil.

Notes:  You can augment Sleeping Goddess maneuvers with 1 power point + 1 per 4 initiator levels you have, to a maximum of 6.  You gain bonus power points equal to the highest level Sleeping Goddess maneuver you know, plus 1 PP per extra Sleeping Goddess maneuver (including stances).

1st Level

Stances:

Battle Mantra***:  Choose from having an insight bonus to attack, AC, or CMB/CMD, and change which bonus you have as a free action once per round.  It makes for a flexible and early source for an insight bonus, but items like the Dusty Rose Ioun Stone will step on its toes.  Many 3rd level stances will be flat out superior in both function and raw numbers.  The main advantage Battle Matra has is its flexible and action-economy friendly bonus.

Unbroken Stride****:  You can walk on water, useful for those low-level wilderness or spelunking sessions where your GM challenges you with rivers and streams.  Then you get to walk on walls which is always useful, and finally fly!

Strikes:

Ego-Wounding Strike*:  [mind-affecting].  Your target has to make a will save or suffer -2 to attacks and skills.  It’s not very useful at low levels, where individual enemies don’t have the chance to make many attacks over the course of the combat, and at high levels when the strike scales better, you have better strikes to use.  And it’s mind-affecting.

Harmony-Shattering Strike****:  Your target has to make a will save, or your allies deal +1d6 damage to it for 1 round!  This is much more likely to result in a significant impact in low level combat than its cousin Ego-Wounding Strike.  It also scales better the more attacks your party members have.  And it’s NOT mind-affecting!

Counters:

Body of Delusion**:  Make an Autohypnosis check and reduce the damage from an attack by half.  On one hand, this counter is one the only two level 1 counters in the game that can be used on allies, the other being Spilled Salt (Cursed Razor 1).  On the other hand, its effect isn’t impressive unless you augment it (with a sufficiently high initiator level) and possibly expend your psionic focus.  To make matters worse, since Autohypnosis is wisdom-based, you’re not very likely to succeed on the skill check.  Still, it’s better than nothing during levels 1 and 2.

Boosts:

Call the Soul’s Blade**:  Summon a masterwork melee weapon for 1 round/level.  Pretty useless at level 1, when you can simply wear armor spikes for disarm-insurance!  But it may come in handy if you start the campaign naked in a dungeon.

Flash of Insight***:  When you successfully hit with an attack or combat maneuver, you can initiate this boost and allow a teammate to roll another saving throw against something affecting them.  It’s situational, it requires a swift action instead of an immediate action, and the ally isn’t guaranteed to succeed at the save, so it’s fairly iffy.  But if you really need to cleanse them of a devastating debuff that you failed to protect them from before, this is how to do it.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Mind-Revealing Strike***:  [mind-affecting].  +1d6 damage, and your target has to make a will save or you read its surface thoughts for cha mod rounds!  It’s of questionable use in combat, because your target’s surface thoughts will probably be “Grrr, I’m gonna wreck this Zealot for that!”  Or possibly reveal some tactical info about what actions they’re going to take next.  You can get creative and use it out of combat, and even as a no-damage touch attack.

Two-Fold Assault***:  Melee-only.  +1d6 damage, and you make an Autohypnosis check to make a free combat maneuver with no AoO, or two if you expend your psionic focus.  This would be great if not for the fact it’s an Autohypnosis check instead of a CMB check.  That means you can’t combine this with the bonus from Battle Mantra, feats, or items that improve your CMB.

Counters:

Adamant Will***:  Gain +4 insight to AC against one attack, and give an ally the same bonus against the next attack targeting them.  Careful, you can only use this when YOU get attacked, not when an ally gets attacked, so it’s worse for non-frontliner Zealots.  With 3 power points, this can be a marvelous boost to a teammate’s AC for 2 whole rounds.

Fearless Faith**:  Reduce your fear by 1 step when you get feared, or an ally’s if you expend your psionic focus.  It’s highly situational and has to compete with your other counters.

Boosts:

Reactive Reversion****:  [teleportation].  You are now Tracer!  Or Ekko!  Or Weaver!  But without the automatic healing.  Mark your space when you use this boost, and you can reactivate it again as a free action any time during the next round, almost making this like a counter for you to negate an attack if you’re in a different square from where you activated it.  You can even use it to do Xtreme Cordless Bungee Jumping!

3rd Level

Stances:

Internal Dominion of the Sleeping Goddess*:  [mind-affecting].  Once per round as a free action, reroll a saving throw or force an enemy to reroll an attack roll against you.  While this is technically a free counter per round, it doesn’t do anything to protect your party, just you, and only from one attack.  It has to compete with all of the other 3rd level stances, many of which are very good.  A +4 bonus to AC will work for you against every attack you take in a round, not just one.

Strikes:

Chains of Doubt*****:  [mind-affecting].  +3d6 damage, and target has to make a will save or be nauseated for 1 round!  Expend your psionic focus, and a second enemy is nauseated as well with no save!  Nauseated enemies can’t take standard actions, so they probably can’t hurt your party!

Inexorable Embrace of Sleep***:  [mind-affecting].  +2d6 damage, and the target has to make a will save or be unable to use maneuvers, [Su]’s, SLAs, spells, or powers for 3 rounds.  However, they can still use such abilities that are free actions, so an enemy Zealot will still be able to use Martyrdom on his friends!  Very handy against enemy spellcasters if you can manage to attack them without leaving your party undefended, so this is great for disruption-loving Ranged Zealots.  Utterly useless against full-attackers.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Grasp of the Goddess*****:  Increase your reach by 5 feet and gain an additional AoO for 1 round, and you can use an immediate action and expend your psionic focus to teleport anywhere within your reach.  Not augmented, this is worse than Intruder’s End (Eternal Guardian 3) in every way.  But if you’re a size-stacking AoO build, it’s superior to Intruder’s End when you augment it with 3 PP, making it last an additional round.

4th Level

Strikes:

Puppet of the Goddess**:  [mind-affecting].  +4d6 damage, and your target must make a will save or be affected by false sensory input for 1 round.  It won’t make it any more difficult for your target to hit you back, since you can’t simply make yourself appear invisible with it.  This will take cooperation from the GM and some creativity to find a good use for.

Counters:

Traumatic Reversal**:  [mind-affecting].  Body of Delusion’s older brother, but theirs seems to be a family of late bloomers.  Reduce the damage you take from an attack by half with no check needed, and your attacker must make a will save or take half the damage they would’ve dealt.  You can use this on an ally if you expend your psionic focus.  At the lofty Initiator Level 20, you can finally augment it for 6 points to take no damage and deal full damage in return, but by then you have better counters.  Still, it’s not bad against glass cannon enemies.

Boosts:

Armory of the Sleeping Goddess*****:  Summon a +3 melee weapon that lasts for 1 round/level.  Vastly better than its baby cousin Call the Soul’s Blade, and effectively saves you about 18300 gp, which is a lot at level 7; about 78% of a level 7 PC’s total wealth.  Since your maneuvers recover every round for free outside of combat, you can keep this boost active effectively at all times, as most combats aren’t going to last longer than 7 rounds.

Reunion in Dreams****:  [teleportation].  Teleport a friend to a square adjacent to you.  Too bad it’s close range -- oh wait.  You’re a Zealot!  You can use this on your Collective members from a much greater distance than normal!  Expend your psionic focus, and you can poofaport over to a friend.  If you leave your psicrystal 170 feet behind you, safely out of danger, then you can use this maneuver to teleport both yourself and several Collective members out of the fight if it gets too hot to handle.  At IL 9, your psicrystal gains a flight speed of 50, making you much more mobile by extension.  Once you reach level 15, start making friends in all corners of the world and add them to your Collective so that you can easily teleport around the entire plane!

5th Level

Stances:

Inarguable Presence of the Sleeping Goddess****:  You can affect enemies who are immune to mind-affecting effects, and all attacks against you have a 20% miss chance!  Now you can bamboozle undead and golems with your [mind-affecting] strikes, and it also combos wonderfully with intimidation, Eternal Guardian, and Black Seraph.

Strikes:

Reshape the Sculpted Mind***:  [mind-affecting].  Deal 1d4 damage to a mental ability score, and your target must make a will save or suffer a debuff depending on which ability score was damaged.  They become unable to communicate with a 50% failure chance on verbal spells, confused, or frightened.  Steel Serpent is better at dealing ability score damage, and other strikes are better at inflicting crowd control debuffs, but its flexibility gives it a leg up.

The Ties that Bind*****:  Melee-only.  +5d6 damage, and your target must make a will save, or it and one of its buddies will be entangled for cha mod rounds.  Even though this affects 2 enemies instead of 1, it’s worse than Chains of Doubt from 3rd level.  Unless you expend your psionic focus.  Then it’s flat out better because it has +2d6 damage and +2 DC, nauseates for 1 round, still entangles, and isn’t mind-affecting!

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Reverberation of Defeat**:  When you splat an enemy to 0 HP, enemies within 30 feet must make a will save or be shaken AND sickened for cha mod rounds.  Giving multiple enemies -4 attack, -4 saves, and -2 damage as a swift action for multiple rounds is great!  It might be worth using instead of a counter to negate an attack.  The trick is that you need to land a killing blow to use this, and you have to have not used a counter before your current turn or a boost before making your attack, so it’s a gamble.  Strangely, this is NOT marked as [mind-affecting].

6th Level

Stances:

Unavoidable Gaze of the Sleeping Goddess****:  You gain a bonus to initiative equal to your cha mod, automatically know where all creatures within 60 feet are, ignore miss chances, and can read surface thoughts.  Mindbogglingly good for information gathering, and it’s not bad at all for a combat stance either!

Strikes:

Dreaming Nomad Strike*:  [teleportation].  Teleport and attack multiple enemies!  Sounds awesome, right?  But there are some severe downsides for Zealots.  First, it’s a full-round action, so you won’t be using Aid Another.  Second, if you miss an attack, your attack chain stops, and you might end your turn in a space you didn’t want to.  Third, you can’t attack the same target twice.  And finally, it doesn’t even deal any additional damage or inflict any debuffs.  This is for full-attacker classes.

Strike of Transfixed Awe*****:  +6d6 damage, and your target must make a will save or be stunned for 1 round.  As if that wasn’t enough already, you also learn the target’s caster level, and they lose a spell or some PP!  This strike finally dethrones Chains of Doubt from its lofty perch.  And it’s not even mind-affecting!

Counters:

Convert Intrusion****:  Make an Autohypnosis check vs an enemy’s caster level to negate a spell or power that’s about to murder you, including area effect spells like fireball or solid fog, and grant your friends a bonus to saves for 1 round if you negate it!  While the effect is lovely, the Autohypnosis check could be difficult to pull off.

Boosts:

Overpowering Optimism*****:  One of the purplest maneuvers in the game for Zealots.  Regain your psionic focus, and you can augment a maneuver within 3 rounds with maximum PP for free!  Now you can assail your foes round after round with high damage, possibly no-save debuff strikes, or touch attacks with Deep Impact, or use your Mission abilities, or Improved Path of Dedication, and have plenty of PP to use Martyrdom!  Is it worth using using every round instead of counters?  It just might be, if your extra damage and successful debuffs accomplish the same goal of disabling enemies so that they can’t hurt your party.

7th Level

Strikes:

Pierce the Soul*:  +7d6 damage, and your target must make a will save or have the damage transferred to an ally they have a bond to.  This is of little practical use in combat, even if you’re fighting an enemy adventuring party with a Zealot or Telepath in it, because the damage is redirected to a random bonded creature.  It’s especially bad for Void Prophet Zealots who pull enemies into their collective because of the risk.  I suppose you could kidnap a wizard’s familiar and use it as a voodoo doll.  “Spill the beans, Polly, or your master gets it!”

Counters:

Soul-Crushing Mien**:  [mind-affecting].  When something wants you to make a will save, get a +4 bonus on the save and stun whoever tried to overpower you for their impudence!  Show your enemies who the true dominatrix goddess is!  For a counter this high level, it’s too situational, and can only be used on yourself.

Boosts:

Perfect Distillation of the Soul*****:  An upgrade of Armory of the Sleeping Goddess, nuff said.  Summon a +5 melee weapon.  You save 50000 gp, or 35.7% of a level 13 PC’s total wealth on your weapon.

8th Level

Stances:

Unimpeachable Authority of the Sleeping Goddess***:  [fear, mind-affecting].  Enemies within 60 feet of you are automatically shaken, no save!  And you can use a move action to make an enemy roll a will save or be panicked for one round.  Sometimes inflicting a powerful debuff on a strong but weak-willed enemy is more important than using Aid Another and recovering your maneuvers.

Strikes:

Self Beyond the Self*****:  [compulsion, mind-affecting].  Your target must make a will save or be affected by mind control for 1 round regardless of creature type.  Though it doesn’t deal additional damage, the fact that your enemy will be fighting on your side makes this the best crowd control debuff possible, even better than the stun from Strike of Transfixed Awe.

Counters:

Indomitable Idealism****:  Congratulations!  You are now nigh-immune to death!  If you get killed or knocked unconscious by any means, you teleport to someone who has seen or knows you and are unaffected.  This can be a friend or enemy!  Park your psicrystal safely 100 feet away from you, and you can poof away to fight another day.  Or, if you’re feeling bold, poof over to a squishy enemy and show them the error of their ways!  You’re still at risk of being killed if enemies decide to quickly chase down and gang up on you before you can recover your maneuvers, of course.  This would be purple, but it doesn’t really do anything to further your victory in combat or protect your allies.  It simply saves your own life.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Immortal Truths of the Sleeping Goddess**:  [mind-affecting].  +10d6 damage, and if this would reduce your target’s HP to 0, make an opposed charisma check with them.  If you win, you diplomance them and turn them helpful!  TV Tropes link warning!  Regardless, you also learn the target’s beliefs and ideals.  If you have this maneuver readied, you also know the HP of every creature in your melee reach.  The thought behind this strike is wonderful, adorable, beautiful, and could facilitate some great stories.  But alas, it’s 9th level, and it requires you to land the killing blow on the enemy and beat them at a check, so you will almost never get to actually use it.  Might as well keep it readied for the passive effect and extra PP, though.

Final Ruling****:  There are enough great things in Sleeping Goddess to focus almost exclusively on it, and that’s not a bad thing, because you gain 1 additional PP for every extra Sleeping Goddess maneuver you know.  It has mobility, unique utility both in and out of combat, decent damage with augmenting, excellent debuffing and crowd control, and party support.  If nothing else, make sure you get Overpowering Optimism.  Unbroken Stride and Reunion in Dreams are great for qualifying for it.

Solar Wind

Skill:  Perception.  1 strike.

Weapon Groups:  Bows, Crossbows, Thrown, Firearms.  Discipline weapon NOT required anymore.  This discipline has 6 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Acolytes of the Arrow.  Any alignment.

Note:  When you learn Solar Wind, you can use a variant energy type instead of fire.  There is Glacial Frost (cold), Virulent Spray (acid), and Oncoming Storm (electricity).  You can learn a different variant when you gain a level in a new class that has Solar Wind.

1st Level

Stances:

Phantom Sun Stance**:  Create free basic ammo or throwing weapons!  It could be useful if your GM is a stickler for carrying capacity and tracking the minutiae of ammo count.  An Efficient Quiver for 1800 GP makes that a non-issue, though, or simply a Durable arrow for 1 GP.  Throwing weapon users could use this stance so they won’t have to worry about Quick Draw or Returni *snickersnicker* I almost got through that with a straight face.  One nice use for this stance is traceless assassination, since the ammo fades immediately after use.

Stance of Piercing Rays**:  +1d6 fire damage per shot, +2d6 at level 8, +3d6 at level 16.  Very quickly loses effectiveness, better for full attackers, and possesses no utility.

Strikes:

Curving Ray Shot*:  Roll perception vs your target’s AC to negate cover on an attack roll.  There are more impressive things to do with a standard action than give yourself a non-guaranteed +4 bonus to hit on a single attack.  Look at the Deadeye’s Bowman trait instead.

Solar Sting**:  Create a 10x10 square of vicious caltrops for 1 round per 2 ILs.  It sounds like decent battlefield control, but it doesn’t actually create difficult terrain.  The caltrops need to hit their attack roll to slow an enemy.  From levels 1 to 3, this will only last 1 round, and at higher levels, enemies with high natural armor will squish the poor little caltrops into solar powder.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Horizon Wind Lancet*:  +1d6 fire damage on one ranged attack you make this round.  An average of 3.5 energy damage.  For one attack.  For you alone.  Shimmy on over to Golden Lion and grab Encouraging Roar instead to give your whole party +2 damage for 3 rounds.

Steady Hand***:  Increase the range of your 1st range increment by 30 feet for 1 round.  Not useful at all for Archery Zealots, but potentially quite good for Firearms Zealots.  The 1st range increment for firearms targets touch AC!  That equates this boost to a mid-range attack bonus buff that could help you land an important strike on a big sturdy enemy.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Solar Flare*:  +2d6 fire damage and ignore cover.  Look at the Deadeye’s Bowman trait instead, and find something better to do with your standard actions, like Tempest Gale does.

Solar Lance**:  +2d6 damage with a free bull rush attempt with +2 using charisma instead of strength.  It could be used to help yourself or a squishy ally escape some of the wrath of a full attacker enemy, but its uses are otherwise limited.

Counters:

Intercepting Shade***:  Make an attack roll to negate an attack roll.  Let’s compare it to other 2nd level counters and do some quick math!  Which ones you pick will depend on a few factors.  Let’s say you’re a medium-sized level 1 Archer Zealot with 18 dexterity and 14 charisma.  You’d have a +5 bonus to attack, and a +6 bonus to Intimidate or Diplomacy.  Archer Zealots can spare to spend fewer points on strength and constitution to have a higher charisma, so realistically the skills would be higher.  Skill checks are much easier to boost through items than attack rolls, as well.  In this case, going with Fear the Reaper (Eternal Guardian 2) is much better.  But you could potentially stack your attack bonus higher by being a small-sized, getting a masterwork weapon ASAP, and taking Point Blank Shot and Weapon Focus.

Boosts:

Feel The Wind**:  Ignore ranged attack penalties from weather effects, even magical, for 1 round.  Wind Wall and Fickle Winds are often considered unassailable hard-counter obstacles for archers in conventional Pathfinder, but this nice little boost blasts right through em.  A highly situational tool to keep in your back pocket, but crucial when you do need it.  Wait until a higher level to take it.  Or just take Galebreaker’s Stance or Eye of the Storm from Tempest Gale.

3rd Level

Stances:

Sunwalker Stance*:  You get Shot on the Run and +2 AC if you move 10+ feet on your turn.  Shot on the Run is a full round action.  And you can’t even use a strike maneuver.  I just don’t even know what to say.

Strikes:

Blinding Ray Shot*****:  Shoot an enemy for normal damage and blind them for 1d4 rounds with no save!  Finally, something that isn’t terrible in Solar Wind!  Blind is an excellent debuff, it has the potential to last several rounds, and it always works.

Solar Reflection*:  Shoot one target for +2d6 damage, shoot a second target for normal damage if successful.  And it’s a full round action.  Know what a bog standard Paizo archer can do?  Rapid Shot.  And at level 6, they can get Manyshot and an iterative attack for 4 arrows in a full round action.  But we shouldn’t talk about full round actions as Zealots lest I asplode.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Phantom Wind Ray*:  Your target makes a perception roll vs your attack roll, and is flat-footed if they fail.  Dimensional Strike (Veiled Moon) was doing this at 1st level without an opposed roll.  Heck, Distracting Strike (Golden Lion) was doing this at 2nd level with +2d6 damage and making the target flat-footed against EVERYONE for an entire round.  Tell you what.  If you really want to stay within Solar Wind, just use Blinding Ray Shot.  Blinding has the same effect as being flat-footed, and much more.

4th Level

Strikes:

Dazzling Solar Flare*****:  +4d6 fire damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1d4 rounds!  And as a small consolation prize if they succeed, they’re dazzled for 1 round.  In an barren desert of red, maneuvers like this are like a refreshing oasis for Zealots.  Daze is a great debuff, 1d4 rounds is a long time, and the damage isn’t unwelcome.

Disarming Gust*:  Make a disarm check with charisma instead of strength/dexterity to CMB, with a +2 bonus, and disarm and deal 3d6 fire damage to your target if successful.  No additional damage from your actual weapon itself, though.  Just 3d6 fire.  Guess what Tempest Gale was doing better as early as 1st level with Disarming Shot.  Or 3rd level with Disarming Blast.

Solar Storm**:  Shoot a creature for normal damage OR a 5 ft square.  The creature in the square has a Wind Wall effect for 1d6 rounds and can’t move out of it unless it makes a reflex save.  For defensive purposes, it’s not as good as Fickle Winds, because it hinders whoever you use them on just as much as it protects them from missiles.  If you find yourself in a situation like this with a bajillion archers all aiming at one motionless friend, it might be useful.  As a debuff, it’s not great, since enemy archers likely have high reflex from dexterity.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Searing Break**:  +3d6 fire damage to your ranged attacks for 1 round.  Great for full attacker archers, not so great for defending your party.

5th Level

Strikes:

Double Solar Reflection*:  Solar Reflection with another attack that does +4d6 damage.  Still a full round action.  Still inferior to a plain old Paizo archer using Rapid Shot and Manyshot.

Focused Solar Lance****:  +4d6 damage, and make a CMB check with a +2 bonus and charisma instead of strength to pin an enemy.  Pinned is a very potent condition, and it lasts until the target breaks free, which could be quite a while if they don’t have a good CMB or escape artist check!

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Blinding The Bull*:  Automatically confirm a critical threat.  At first glance, very spiffy indeed since bows have x3 and pistols have x4 crit, but does the math back it up?  A mighty composite longbow would deal an additional (1d8+str+enhancement+PBS)*2 damage, and a pistol would deal (1d8+enhancement+PBS)*3 damage.  You might be using a Dragoon Pistol, which has only x3 crit, because of its bigger capacity and longer range increment.  And you can only use this boost when you threaten a crit, not whenever you want.  You won’t use it often enough to warrant a readied maneuver slot, and it won’t even do worthwhile extra damage.  Not even crit-fishers would want this, because they like weapons with high threat ranges and as many attacks as possible such as with Two Weapon Fighting.

Solar Wind Lancet*:  Your next ranged attack does +4d6 damage and your target must make a fortitude save or be knocked prone.  Prone is too weak of a debuff at this point.

6th Level

Stances:

True Shot Stance**:  Ignore cover and partial concealment, and your weapon becomes keen.  Regarding cover, you probably have Deadeye’s Bowman and can even pick up Improved Precise Shot now.  Regarding concealment, use Solar Wind Style, a Tracer Bullet, a Tar and Feathers Feather Token, a Salt Lamp, a Smog Smoke Pellet, a Dye Arrow, or simply a wand or scroll of faerie fire or glitterdust.

Strikes:

Twisting Wind Shot*:  Your attack is an automatic crit.  You have to spend feats on Critical Feats to make this worthwhile, and ranged weapons aren’t the best weapons to specialize critting with.  Leave it to the Stalkers.  If you really want to use this, you can take Staggering Critical at level 15 and Stunning Critical at level 17, stunning and staggering everything you hit with no save, but then be prepared for your GM to bring out crit-immune enemies.

Solar Meteor Blow**:  Shoot a creature for +6d6 damage, or a 5 ft square.  All enemies in a 15 ft radius must make a fortitude save or be knocked prone.  It took this long to get an area-of-effect maneuver in a discipline about supernatural archery, and it’s pretty underwhelming.  Knocking things prone alone just doesn’t cut it anymore.  It might be useful to keep hordes of weak mooks at bay for another turn, if they don’t have a ranged or magic ability to use while standing up.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Burning Break**:  All your ranged attacks deal +5d6 fire damage for 1 round.  Exactly the same thing as Searing Break, and not great for Zealots for the same reasons.

7th Level

Strikes:

Stunning Solar Flare*****:  +8d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be stunned for 1d3 rounds.  At long last, we get a good debuffing strike again!  A magnificent upgrade to Dazzling Solar Flare.

Triple Solar Reflection*:  Double Solar Reflection with another attack that does +6d6 damage.  Still a full round action.  Still inferior to a plain old Paizo archer using Rapid Shot and Manyshot.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Phantom Sunstorm*:  Your next ranged attack deals maximum damage.  Using Stunning Solar Flare with a longbow, that increases your average damage from 31.5 to 54.  A 22.5 damage increase for a swift action as a 7th level maneuver.  Wowie zowie, goodness gracious, great balls of fire.  I can hardly contain my zzzzzz...

8th Level

Stances:

Solar Hailstorm Stance****:  When making a full attack, gain 2 extra attacks and add cha mod to damage.  (Sarcasm blue) Yes, my children, embrace the Paizo-style machine-gunner archery.  Abandon these petty hopes of being a methodical sharpshooter protecting your friends with cunning debuffs and calculating interventions.  Initiators, using standard actions to attack?  Hah!  Use full attacks and further increase your damage with boosts, it is the one true way!  But really, this stance adds an utterly ludicrous amount of damage if you want to full attack.  And if you can kill an enemy with overwhelming damage, there’s no need to disable them with debuffs or counter their attacks.  Just know that I will be disappointed in you, and I hope your GM quadruples the HP of everything you fight until you start defending your party properly again.

Strikes:

Solar Wind Tsunami***:  A 60 ft cone that deals 15d6+IL damage, reflex save for half.  At least it’s not energy damage.  It’s a nice tool to use to clear out a big bundle of mooks, if your caster friend doesn’t want to use one of their fireballs or cones of cold.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Aurora Break**:  Your ranged attacks deal +8d6 fire damage for 1 round.  Combine with Solar Hailstorm Stance to make me despise the very ground you walk on and absolutely annihilate anything that would dare to harm your party.

9th Level

Strikes:

Solar Wind Nova***:  Grenade-like attack.  The central target takes 10d6 damage and 10d6 fire damage, and creatures in a 20 ft radius can make a reflex save for half.  Ones who fail get knocked prone.  It’s nice that it’s a no-save ranged touch attack for the central target, and it’s a little bit better than a regular CL 20 delayed blast fireball since it knocks enemies prone.  Decide which you want between this and Solar Wind Tsunami, because you really only need 1 area-of-effect damage tool.

Final Ruling*:  Utility is next to non-existent, and the good maneuvers are buried sparsely in higher levels, so you’ll need to figure out what mediocre low level maneuvers you’ll need to pick in order to qualify for them.  You can get good ranged crowd controlling and debuffing strikes in other, better disciplines like Sleeping Goddess.  The only low level maneuvers of note are Steady Hand for Firearms Zealots and Feel the Wind.  How tragic that this is one of the 5 default disciplines for Zealots.

Steel Serpent

Skill:  Heal.  1 strike, 1 counter, 2 boosts.

Weapon Groups: Light Blades, Close, Monk.  This discipline has 17 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Ordre de Repas Exotiques.  Any alignment.

Note:  Pranas remain on your weapon for 24 hours if you don’t use them.  Link for proof!

1st Level

Stances:

Body of the Night****:  Add heal ranks to stealth as competence bonus, and have +4 competence to attack and +1d6 damage against opponents denied dexterity to AC.  The bonus to stealth won’t stack with items like a Cloak of Elvenkind, but it’s a huge scaling bonus nonetheless.  If you can reliably feint, blind, stealth, or turn invisible in combat without interfering with your action economy, this is one of the best stances for accuracy.  For a Zealot, that will usually come in the form of strikes that inflict blindness.

Poisoner's Stance**:  Gain poison use, and increase the DC of your poisons, pranas, and stings by IL/2.  Almost worthless at low levels, as the DC increase isn’t very high, and mundane poisons are expensive.  It may be worth using at higher levels to better ensure your debuffs stick.

Strikes:

Hunting Serpent Blow**:  Melee-only.  Roll heal vs target’s AC.  If successful your target is considered flat-footed and you deal +1d6 damage, but if unsuccessful, you have -2 to attack instead.  It’s a higher risk, higher reward version of Dimensional Strike (Veiled Moon 1), but the risk isn’t worth the small +1d6 damage reward.

Sting of the Rattler*:  +1d4 damage, and 1d4 damage one round later.  Damage-over-time abilities aren’t very good in Pathfinder because combats are typically very short, and individual enemies don’t live very long.  In any case, this damage is piddly, and it doesn’t have a rider.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Dizzying Venom Prana*****:  Your target is staggered for 1 round with no save, and must make a fortitude save or take 2 wisdom damage.  Since you can apply and keep a prana on your weapon well before combat begins, this is a guaranteed form of crowd control to the first thing you hit!  And potentially lowering the will save of an enemy is certainly welcome.  No other prana in the game has an effect other than ability damage.  It scales fantastically into high levels by ruining the first round a full attacker gets.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Iron Fang**:  +2d6 damage, ignore DR, and a prana used with this strike has +2 DC.  Identical to Garnet Lance (Scarlet Throne 2), except it makes your pranas better and can be used with ranged weapons.  If you really need a prana effect to land on an enemy with high DR, this is a good tool for your toolbox.

Sting of the Asp**:  +1d6 damage, 2 strength damage (fortitude save half), and next round, your target takes 1d6 damage and 2 strength damage with no save if they failed.  Combined with Weakening Venom Prana, even if your target makes both saves, they will take a minimum of 2 strength damage, which will make it harder for most enemies to hurt your party.  In the best case scenario, this can combo up to 8 strength damage.  In all honesty, the debuff is too minor compared to other strikes to be worthwhile in most cases.

Counters:

Fading Dodge****:  Heal vs attack to negate it and make a free dirty trick on your attacker with no AoO.  Most low level counters merely negate an attack, but this goes above and beyond the call of duty by letting you perform the best combat maneuver in the game as well!  Since your opponent just acted by trying to attack you, they’ll have to contend with the debuff for a full round, letting your friends smack them silly while they’re blinded or entangled!

Boosts:

Weakening Venom Prana**:  1d4 strength damage (fort save half).  Dealing at least 1 strength damage on the first round of combat for free no matter what has some value, but the debuff is still fairly weak.  Using a counter to negate an attack will almost always be better.

3rd Level

Stances:

Steel Coils****:  You can grapple with no AoOs, you gain constrict 4d6+str, and +4 natural armor to AC.  Phenomenal for Zealots with the grab monster ability, which can be gained from taking a dip in Fiendbound Marauder Warder or Aberrant Aegis.  You deal 4d6+1d8+str*2 damage to everything you hit, and grapple them for free!  A huge increase to damage, crowd control, and durability!

Strikes:

Sickening Venom Strike**:  2 constitution damage with no save, and your target must make a fortitude save or be sickened for 1d4 rounds.  The constitution damage is effectively the same as dealing extra damage equal to your target’s HD, and at level 5, that means ~5 HP.  That’s less than the average damage of a strike that deals +2d6 damage.  Sickened is a respectable debuff, but it’s not a disabler.

Sight Piercing Fang*****:  Melee-only.  +2d6 damage, and your target must make a reflex save or be blinded for 1 minute.  Very good debuff, incredibly long duration, a decent chunk of damage, and it targets reflex saves!

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Night's Knife*:  For 1 round, add your heal ranks to your damage rolls.  Incredible for full-attackers, not so incredible for Zealots.

4th Level

Strikes:

Sting of the Adder**:  +5d6 damage, 1d4 wisdom damage (fortitude save half), and for 2 rounds, your target takes 1d6 damage and 2 wisdom damage with no save if they failed.  On its own, even over the full duration and combined with another wisdom damaging prana, it’s not likely to take down anything but enemies with exceptionally low wisdom.  Strikes like this are best used in situations where you can attack, disengage from combat safely, and let the ability damage work its magic.  That becomes much more difficult if your opponents have good methods of spotting or catching up to you.

Counters:

Poison Blood*:  Use when hit by a slashing or piercing weapon, your attacker takes 2*IL acid damage.  You still have to take the full effect and damage of the attack, and the return damage isn’t very high except against the squishiest of mooks.  It’s also useless against many attacks, and you could run into enemies with acid resistance.  Humorously, it doesn’t list a range or specify melee, so you could use this to squirt a gout of acid hundreds of feet away at a sniper!

Boosts:

Rattler's Feint*:  Feint with no AoO and a +4 competence bonus, and add +2 to your attack’s critical confirmation roll.  This is for Stalkers and Rogues.  Zealots use their swift actions for more important things.

Tearing Fang*:  For your turn, your attacks deal +2d6 damage, and 2 bleed damage for 1d4 rounds which can stack.  This is an average of 7 damage per hit, the same as Night’s Knife at IL 7, and the bleed is negligible.  It might be fun to full attack someone and then zip away to cover to stealth, perhaps with Reactive Reversion (Sleeping Goddess 2), then watch them bleed out.  But removing bleed effects is as easy as drinking a potion of cure light wounds.

5th Level

Stances:

Hooded Killer's Stance*:  You gain +3d6 sneak attack, and + 2/IL competence to intimidate and stealth.  The intimidate bonus might be tempting, but at this level, you almost surely have items that increase your skills like a Maiden’s Helm, and they won’t stack with this.  Body of the Night gives a better bonus for stealth, only does slightly less damage than Hooded Killer’s Stance, and gives a big attack bonus.

Strikes:

Steel Fang*****:  +8d6 damage, ignore DR, your target must make a will save or be dazed for 1 round, and +3 DC if you’re using a poison or prana.  A strong form of crowd control that will almost always take effect and do a nice big clump of damage!

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Burning Venom Prana*:  1d4 wisdom damage (fortitude save half).  Honestly, Dizzying Venom Prana from 1st level  is superior.  Staggering an enemy with no save is much better than potentially dealing a bit more wisdom damage.

Pressure Point Break*:  For 1 round, add your sneak attack or deadly strike damage to attacks made while grappling, +2d6.  Since Zealots don’t have sneak attack, this obviously doesn’t live up to the potential that it could with a Stalker or Rogue!  The best it can do is give you a little extra damage when you grab people with Steel Coils, and Night’s Knife does more damage.

6th Level

Stances:

Spitting Cobra Stance*:  You deal +2d6 damage with throwing weapons, provoke no AoOs with throwing weapons, and add +1 damage or ability damage per die you deal.  Throwing in general is an awful fighting style, this stance adds barely any damage, and it’s too hard to stack up enough dice when dealing ability damage to make this worthwhile.

Strikes:

Sting of the Viper*:  +8d6 damage, 1d6 charisma damage (fortitude save half), and for 2 (or 3, description doesn’t match with listed duration) rounds, your target takes 2d6 damage and 2 charisma damage with no save if they failed.  Unless you’re fighting a barbarian with 5 charisma, there aren’t very many enemies that this will be useful against.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Blend With The Night**:  For 1 round, you have greater invisibility and +2d6 sneak attack.  The +2 attack bonus you get for being an unseen attacker, and the fact that your target is denied its dexterity bonus to AC against you will help you land a good debuffing strike, but this is clearly intended for chopping something up with a full attack.  At least you can use this every round while out of combat to be nigh permanently invisible.

Virulence*****:  One poison, sting, or prana gets +5 DC until used.  Great to stack on top of your prana of choice before a battle.  That’s two whole entire swift action maneuvers that you don’t need to spend in combat itself, improving your effectiveness!

7th Level

Strikes:

Silencing Strike**:  Melee-only.  +5d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save and be silenced for 1 round if successful, or 1d6 rounds if unsuccessful.  The fact that this always works is great, and will interfere with casters using verbal spell components.  If you try to use it to silently take out guards in your favorite stealth video game, remember that simply engaging in combat lets other people make a perception check DC -10 to hear the noise, and your GM might say that the enemy you hit can still make noise by stomping their feet.  As such, it’s actually pretty awful at helping you be stealthy, and its mechanical use is too situational.

Counters:

Bite The Mongoose*:  When hit, counter attack for +6d6 damage and 1d6 constitution damage (fortitude save half).  Unless you kill your attacker with the counter, you’ll take full damage and have almost nothing to show for it.

Desert Serpent Mirage*:  Attack vs attack to negate it, and you gain total concealment against your attacker for 1d4 rounds.  Perfect for Stalkers and Rogues to defend themselves and set up for a few rounds of sneak attacking, but awful for a Zealot.  Use Fading Dodge instead to blind your attacker and effectively give everyone full concealment against them.

Boosts:

Numbing Venom Prana***:  2d4 dexterity damage (fortitude save half).  Finally, another decent prana!  Because it governs so many different bonuses, dexterity is one of the best stats to damage, especially against particularly large foes like dragons who might not even have double digit dexterity.  However, not even this prana can compare to the no-save stagger of the humble 1st level Dizzying Venom Prana.

8th Level

Stances:

Hooded Cobra Attitude*:  [compulsion, mind-affecting].  You gain a 30 foot gaze attack, make enemies shaken unless they make a will save, and can use an attack action to paralyze one target with a will save for 1d4 rounds.  Though 1d4 rounds to paralyze as a standard action may seem spectacular, remember that you can do that with strikes just as well, and this is a stance.  Stances need to give more functionality to be useful.  Also, many enemies at this level will be immune to gaze, compulsions, or mind-affecting abilities.  Unimpeachable Authority of the Sleeping Goddess (Sleeping Goddess 8) is much better.

Strikes:

Adamantine Fang*****:  +12d6 damage, ignores DR, your target must make a will save or be paralyzed for 1 round, and +4 DC  if you’re using a poison or prana.  Absolutely monstrous damage, nigh irresistible, and one of the best debuffs you can inflict.  Paralysis = coup de grace!

Sting of the Cobra*:  +8d6 damage, 2d4 constitution damage (fortitude save half), and for 2 (or 3, description doesn’t match with listed duration) rounds, your target takes 2d6 damage and 2 charisma damage with no save if they failed.  For all intents and purposes, it’s simply a flat damage-over-time strike with no other effect.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Five-Fold Hydra Sting*****:  [death].  +50 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or die and require wish or miracle in order to be resurrected.  Like any other standard action strike that has the ability to remove an enemy from combat, this can’t be anything other than purple.  Not quite as purple as Septennial Seal (Shattered Mirror 9), but purple nonetheless.

Final Ruling**:  This discipline was clearly made with Stalkers (and later Hidden Blade Rogues) in mind, catering to sneak attack users and evasive hit-and-run playstyles.  In a stand-up fight, Steel Serpent is worse than most other disciplines, because its debuffs are minor and increase over time.  You could very well use guerilla warfare and these maneuvers to great effect if you’re able to keep avoiding direct combat, but that is not the strength of a Zealot.  Fortunately, any initiator at all would benefit from grabbing Dizzying Venom Prana, and you can get it with the Combat Training trait.

Tempest Gale

Skill:  Sleight of Hand.  8 strikes, 1 counter, 3 boosts.

Weapon Groups:  Bows, Crossbows, Firearms, Thrown.  Discipline weapon required.  This discipline has 8 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  Cirque de la Fumée.  Any alignment.

Notes:  Ranged combat maneuvers with Tempest Gale maneuvers don’t provoke AoOs.  Also, while you maintain a Tempest Gale stance, you can retrieve unattended weapons as a free action, provided you are adjacent to the weapon at some point during turn (including as part of a move action).

1st Level

Stances:

Galebreaker's Stance***:  You ignore wind penalties and wind wall.  In regular Paizo Pathfinder, it’s nearly impossible for most archers to deal with wind wall, but now you can do it all ding dong day long!  A good utility stance when you need it.

Sniper's Eye Stance****:  You reduce your penalty for long ranged attacks and have a bonus to ranged combat maneuvers, and the bonus scales with levels!  The stance of choice for wreaking havoc on your foes’ ability to do anything against you.  It doesn’t actually increase your first range increment, so it won’t let Firearms Zealots do touch attacks from further away.  You don’t actually have any ranged combat maneuvers at 1st level other than Disarming Shot, so consider a different stance at level 1 like Elemental Nimbus (Elemental Flux) or Battle Mantra (Sleeping Goddess).

Strikes:

Disarming Shot***:  Shoot a hapless buffoon for regular damage and make a disarm attempt with sleight of hand instead of CMB.  Not too shabby at all at level 1, when many of your enemies will be level 1 humanoid warriors and the like.  It’s better in urban campaigns, and worse in wilderness campaigns where animals are more common.

Distant Gale*:  +1 damage per 20 feet of distance, max +5.  You need to be at least 80 feet away to do more average damage than a +1d6 damage strike.  And Zealots have better things to do than add mere damage!

Slipstream Strike***:  Normal damage shot that ignores cover.  Archer Zealots can take the Deadeye Bowman trait to not worry about this, but Firearms Zealots will appreciate the effective +4 attack bonus in areas with chest-high walls like a typical Gears of War level.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Eye of the Needle***:  Your next ranged attack has +4 to hit a target in melee.  Stacks with Precise Shot!  For someone who only attacks once per round and needs them to have a significant effect, every shot counts.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Dustcatching Breeze*****:  +2d6 damage and make a dirty trick maneuver as a sleight of hand check.  Dirty tricks can inflict all sorts of amazing debuffs, including blind!

Piercing Shot**:  30 foot line, 3d6 damage, reflex save for half.  Hitting multiple targets at once is always fun in those cramped dungeon corridors, and it’s not often you have a free, low-level option for dealing with swarms.  But the damage is low and it lacks a rider.

Sudden Gust****:  +2d6 damage and make a trip maneuver as a sleight of hand check.  At low levels, making an enemy fall prone at the feet of your frontliners is superior to hitting them with a dirty trick and easier to pull off than at high levels.  But dirty trick gets much better later.  You could take this at level 3 and retrain it to Dustcatching Breeze once you start running into enemies that it doesn’t work as well on.

Counters:

Deflecting Shot*****:  Roll sleight of hand to disarm a foe and negate an attack regardless of whether the foe can be disarmed.  Much better than a lot of 2nd level counters because you can use it on allies and it provides an extra benefit beyond an attack negation!

Boosts:

Distracting Draft**:  Feint at range with sleight of hand instead of bluff, and if successful, your next ranged attack deals +1d6 damage.  You need to use this against a target with at least 20 dexterity AND succeed on the check in order for this to be better than Eye of the Needle from 1st level, making it pretty situational.

3rd Level

Stances:

Tempest Gale Stance****:  Add your cha mod to ranged weapon damage and ¼ IL to ranged combat maneuvers and Tempest Gale DCs.  Sniper’s Eye Stance is more than twice as good at improving your combat maneuver bonus.  Tempest Gale Stance at level 5 gives +1 while Sniper’s Eye Stance gives +4.  And at level 20, the difference is +5 vs +12.  The bonus to DCs is useful for only a small number of maneuvers, as many of them are simply reflex saves to reduce damage.  You won’t find a good maneuver to use this with until you get Iron Wind at 4th level or Blinding Shot at 5th level.

Strikes:

Battering Gale*:  +3d6 damage and make a bull rush maneuver as a sleight of hand check.  Size restrictions still apply, and you might want to be small-sized, making this unusable much of the time.  It’s also not as good as dirty trick or trip.

Disarming Blast*:  +3d6 damage and make a disarm maneuver as a sleight of hand check.  Disarm will get less and less useful as you go up in levels, unless your GM almost exclusively sticks with humanoid NPC enemies who use weapons and not, say, spells or other special abilities.  And in all of those cases, dirty trick and trip are still better.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Cascading Draft*:  Your next ranged attack deals +2 damage per 20 feet, max +20.  A boost version of Distant Gale, and just as terrible!

4th Level

Strikes:

Cutting Gale*:  +5d6 damage, ignore damage reduction, and your target must make a fortitude save or bleed for cha mod damage every round.  Does bleeding hinder the enemy from vengefully murdering your party in any way?  For damage, this is worse than a regular Rapid Shot + Manyshot archer firing away without a care.

Exploding Gale*:  +4d6 damage, and creatures adjacent to your target must make a reflex save to avoid cha mod damage.  It does nothing but damage, and the damage it does is more piddly than a pug puppy that isn’t housebroken.

Iron Wind****:  +4d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be staggered for cha mod rounds!  That’s quite a nice duration for a nice debuff, especially against enemies with a high number of attacks.  It’s not quite as useful against enemies who don’t rely on full round actions to get the full effect of their offensive capabilities, of course.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Wind Tunnel**:  For 1 round, you ignore cover bonuses and ranged increment penalties.  It could be fun to bullseye someone sitting behind a fortress’ arrow slit from 1100 feet away with your longbow, but in a close quarters fight where you need to be in range to protect your Collective, that benefit won’t come into play very often.

5th Level

Stances:

Dancing Winds Stance*:  If you move 10+ feet, you gain improved evasion and have a 20% chance to be missed by attacks.  Zealots might love using their move actions, but they certainly don’t use them to move!  This stance is best when fleeing.  And if you’re running away, use Reunion in Dreams (Sleeping Goddess 4th level) to do it in proper psionic style!

Strikes:

Blinding Shot****:  +5d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be blinded for cha mod rounds!  Finally something that has the potential to rival the mighty Dustcatching Breeze.  Dirty tricks can be removed with a move action, but this can’t!  Of course, it’s a fort save rather than a sleight of hand check, so it could be difficult to land on a big stompy frontliner enemy that you really need to blind.  Now you have a good reason to use Tempest Gale Stance.

Grounding Shot**:  +5d6 damage, and if your target is flying, roll sleight of hand vs their fly check to make them unable to fly for cha mod rounds.  Very situational, but can result in hilarity as a strafing dragon or self-styled God Wizard tumbles out of the sky where they’ve been raining down bad breath and spells and land with a splat at the feet of your melee friends.

Piercing Gale***:  50 foot line, 10d6 damage and knock targets prone, reflex save for half and avoid being knocked prone.  Not too shabby when you get it, since it outclasses a 9th level sorcerer’s lightning bolt!  The value of knocking things prone is starting to decline in these mid and upper levels, and you have to make sure not to hit your melee allies.

Counters:

False Wind*****:  Shoot an enemy for regular damage, and the friend it was attacking gets to move up to their speed without AoOs, potentially negating the attack!  It could even protect your ally from spells if they’re able to move out of line of sight or the area of effect, or simply disrupt the spellcast if the caster fails the concentration check against your damage.  It’s repositioning, damage, and attack negation all in one!

Boosts:

None

6th Level

Stances:

Winds of Vengeance Stance*:  Gain cha mod additional AoOs that stack with others, make an AoO on enemies that successfully hit your allies.  It’s better to prevent enemies from hitting your allies in the first place, not simply inflict a bit of damage when you fail to do your job.  Delightfully thematic for a vengeful Zealot, but mechanically not great.

Strikes:

Razor Tempest*:  +8d6 damage, and your target bleeds for cha mod damage with no save.  Just a bigger version of the awful Cutting Gale.

Wind Lance*:  A ranged attack that deals double damage.  Mister Zen Archer Monk over there is trying not to double over in mocking laughter.  It’s likely that another strike that isn’t terrible, like Blinding Shot, will do more damage.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Trick of the Wind***:  Make an attack that effectively uses your sleight of hand bonus in place of your BAB.  Similar to to Leaping Strike from Piercing Thunder, but this is a boost, not a strike.  With a high enough bonus with sleight of hand, this could make your next crucial debuffing strike nearly impossible to miss, giving it worthy competition to use instead of a counter.

7th Level

Strikes:

Black Wind****:  50 foot line, 15d6 damage, reflex half.  If they fail the reflex save, they must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1 round.  It has two layers of potential failure, making it more difficult to successfully inflict the daze condition, which is what we care about most.  However, if you can catch 3+ enemies in the line, the raw damage and potential to daze at least one of them could be better than using a lower level strike that only targets one enemy.

Hunting Zephyr**:  An attack that auto hits, threatens a crit, and can’t be countered!  Excellent for shooting apples off of your friends’ heads so that you don’t have to worry about rolling a natural 1 while impressing a crowd, but hitting without rider effects isn’t for Zealots.  If you have a powerful debuffing boost or weapon enhancement to use in tandem with it, it gets better.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Punishing Tempest*:  Make a bull rush attempt with sleight of hand instead of CMB against every target you hit this round.  Even if you full attack and unleash a volley of arrows after using this, there’s only so much you can do with bull rushes at level 13.

8th Level

Stances:

Eye of the Storm***:  Add cha mod to ranged weapon damage, ignore weather penalties and wind wall, suffer no long range penalties, ignore partial cover, and ignore partial concealment.  Everything you could possibly want to ensure that your arrows don’t miss due to external circumstances!

Strikes:

Breath Stealing Wind**:  +10d6 damage, and the target must make a fortitude save or be silenced for cha mod rounds.  If you’re fighting a level 15 spellcaster that allows herself to get shot and doesn’t have a backup plan for what to do when she’s silenced, just full attack and put her out of her misery.  Maybe you could shoot your non-stealthy friends to make them quieter with this, if they don’t mind the damage.

Steel Tornado*:  +10d6 damage, and make a trip AND a disarm maneuver against everything your target’s holding as sleight of hand checks.  A good way to humiliate a level 15 fighter NPC who doesn’t have a locked gauntlet or flight, I guess.  Like those exist.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Vicious Tempest Volley*****:  Full attack with +2d6 damage and a free combat maneuver using sleight of hand on every hit.  Now this is a full attack I can actually get behind!  You can inflict a number of devastating dirty tricks and other debuffs equal to your number of attacks, and do a huge amount of extra damage!  Combine with Solar Wind Stance for 2 more attacks and even more damage.  You now have my permission to retrain to Rapid Shot and Manyshot.  Just don’t forget about your trusty Aid Another that has served you so well for the past 16 levels.

Final Ruling**:  I don’t recommend investing heavily into this at all.  If you really want these maneuvers, then start level 1 as a Privateer Warlord, take 1 level of another class, and start your Zealot career at level 3 with Practiced Initiator to get the best 2nd level maneuvers right off the bat.  Getting Sniper’s Eye Stance, Dustcatching Breeze, and Deflecting shot will serve you well.  At IL 9, you’ll be qualified to pick up False Wind, and finally Vicious Tempest Volley at IL 17.  Remember that many disciplines have ranged weapon attacks, not just Tempest Gale and Solar Wind, so decide whether or not it would be worth missing out on good Sleeping Goddess strikes.

Thrashing Dragon

Skill:  Acrobatics.  2 strikes, 4 counters, 1 boost.

Weapon Groups: Close, Light Blades, Double Weapons.  Two weapons, double weapon, natural weapons, or unarmed strike required.  This discipline has 2 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  All strikes in this discipline are melee-only, except for some that use a a throwing weapon.

Martial Tradition:  Crashing Tempest Academy.  Any alignment.

1st Level

Stances:

Inner Sphere Stance***:  While wielding 2 weapons, +2 dodge to AC and +2 morale to will saves.  The bonuses are pretty small, but they’re important for keeping you on your feet.

Outer Sphere Stance*:  While wielding 2 weapons, -2 AC and +1d6 damage.  There are several other 1st level stances that give you +1d6 damage but have no weapon restriction and don’t give you a defensive penalty.

Strikes:

Offensive Roll*:  Full round action.  Move 10+ feet alongside an enemy, provoking AoOs, roll acrobatics vs AC, and attack with +1d6 damage vs flat-footed AC if successful.  Full round action, bad for Zealots.  No rider, bad for Zealots.  This even has a stringent movement requirement on how to use it, leaves you open to AoOs, and you need to make another skill check to get any benefit.  That means you need to get a good result on two acrobatics checks and one attack roll all in the same turn for this to work.

Swift Claws****:  Attack with 2 different weapons.  It’s not as good as Flurry Strike (Broken Blade 1) because you specifically need 2 different weapons, so you can’t use a two-handed weapon and gain 1.5x strength to damage.  Still, attacking twice at level 1 as a standard action is a good way to oneshot many of the low level enemies you’ll meet.

Wyrmling's Fang*:  Throwing weapon attack with +1d6 damage.  It doesn’t have a rider, and doesn’t do anything to improve your action economy related to using throwing weapons, like drawing the weapon or returning it to your hand.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Leaping Dragon*****:  Make a running jump with a +10 competence bonus.  This is incredible for mobility, letting you get into a good position without a move action.  Since it’s a running jump, the number of feet you move is equal to your acrobatics check result.  It’s better for dexterity-based Zealots, because for some reason being agile makes you a better long distance jumper than having strong leg muscles in Pathfinder.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Flick of the Wrist**:  Full round action.  2 attacks with +2 attack, and automatically disarm your target if both attacks hit.  As has been said ad-nauseum, full round action strikes aren’t good for Zealots, but the attack bonus and automatic disarm are very useful indeed in a campaign where you regularly fight enemies that use weapons.  And don’t use locked gauntlets.

Sweeping Tail****:  Trip with no AoO and a +4 bonus, and your target takes 2d6+cha mod damage if successful.  Tripping is great at low levels, and the huge bonus makes it almost guaranteed to succeed.  The damage is gravy.

Counters:

Reflexive Twist**:  Roll acrobatics in place of a reflex save.  Zealots have a poor reflex save, and strength-based Zealots especially will have low reflex, but failing a reflex save usually just means you take some hitpoint damage.  This is useful for tripping traps while exploring a dungeon, but you want to use more widely applicable and useful counters during combat.  Consider Obsidian Sidestep (Shattered Mirror 2) instead.
