Sun Dips Low**:  Acrobatics vs melee attack to negate it.  It can’t protect your allies, it only works against melee attacks, and it doesn’t have any secondary effects.  At least it’s not as actively counter-productive as Counter Step (Broken Blade 2).

Boosts:

Flash Kick*:  Usable only while full attacking.  Unarmed strike with no AoO, -2 attack, and +2d6 damage.  Swift action strikes are useful at low levels, potentially letting you take out another enemy, but you can only use this while full attacking, which Zealots don’t like doing.  If you’re full attacking with unarmed strikes, you might as well use Broken Blade maneuvers for the +2 damage bonus, and Bronze Knuckle as a stronger boost.  For everyone else, get Minute Hand (Riven Hourglass 1) instead.

3rd Level

Stances:

Battle Dragon's Stance**:  +4 initiative, +1d6+cha mod damage, and reduce your two weapon fighting penalties by 2.  It provides a tremendous amount of damage, possibly doubling it depending on your weapons and stats, but relies on full attacks to work its magic.

Strikes:

Ancient's Fang*:  Throwing weapon attack with +4d6 damage.  Just as pointless, underwhelming, and lacking in usefulness as Wyrmling’s Fang.

Fangs Strike Low*:  Normal damage, reduce your target’s speed by half, and deal 1d6 bleed damage for 3 rounds.  Know what a lot of other 3rd level strikes do?  +3d6 damage straight off the bat with no wait time.  And they often have a decent rider, too.  The speed reduction only helps if you can ensure that nobody in your party is within attack range of the target afterwards.  But this is a melee-only attack, so you almost certainly will be!

Vicious Swipe*****:  +3d6 damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1d4 rounds.  See, this is what I was talking about in Fang Strikes Low.  Lots of immediate damage, and a devastatingly effective and long lockdown debuff!

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

4th Level

Strikes:

Devastation Roll*:  Move 10+ feet alongside an enemy and roll acrobatics vs CMD to avoid an AoO, and attack with +6d6 damage vs flat-footed AC if successful.  At least unlike Offensive Roll, this is a standard action instead of a full round action, but you still need to move alongside an enemy somehow to make it work.  You could do that with Leaping Dragon, but then you eat up your swift action for little benefit.  This still provides the same pitiful effect as Offensive Roll.

Dragon Assault*:  Full attack.  Every attack increases by +1d6 damage on the next attack, max +5d6.  If you have a build that gives you a huge number of attacks like a Ragebred Skinwalker natural attack build, you can easily deal enough damage to completely eviscerate whatever you want.  But you could do that better with a class other than Zealot, couldn’t you?

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Dragon Rush***:  Usable after successfully hitting with an attack.  Unarmed strike with +3d6 damage.  Since this is a swift action that only inflicts raw damage, it’s only useful if it ensures that your target dies, as that will prevent it from attacking in return.  Against squishy enemies, this could be better than a counter.

Sharpened Talons*:  For 1 round, when two weapon fighting, your attacks deal +2d6 damage.  Bronze Knuckle (Broken Blade 2) was doing the same damage much earlier, let you ignore DR, and didn’t restrict you to TWFing.  And Iron Knuckle (Broken Blade 4) is just better.

5th Level

Stances:

Bend with the Wind*:  When an attack misses you, you gain +2 dodge until your next turn OR can make a 5 foot step to another square your attacker threatens.  This has a very strange rich-get-richer syndrome, where it makes you better at something that you’re already good at, but doesn’t help with something you might be bad at:  AC.  It also provides no utility that helps your party.  Almost any other stance that gives +4 AC is better.

Strikes:

Thrashing Dragon Twist****:  Attack all foes within reach (or adjacent, description conflicts with range listing) with 2 weapons.  It doesn’t provide any sort of rider or even any damage bonus, but it’s a standard action, so it could be good against a huge horde of fragile mooks if you have long reach.  It gets better with two reach weapons like using Twin Thunder Stance (Piercing Thunder 3) or two Fiend’s Grips from a dip of Fiendbound Marauder Warder.  If your GM decides that it only works against adjacent foes, it’s much worse, but not completely useless.

Counters:

Reversing Thrust*:  Acrobatics vs attack to negate it and make a counter attack.  At least this lets you negate the incoming attack, unlike many of the other counter attack counters.  Still, it has limited use for a Zealot who focuses on debuffs and team protection rather than damage.

Boosts:

Hurricane of Fangs*:  For 1 round, increase the range increment of throwing weapons by +30 and deal IL bonus damage with them.  The scaling damage bonus can be quite high, but you need to be able to attack several times in one round with throwing weapons in order to take advantage of it, which isn’t easy or efficient.  Especially as a Zealot.

6th Level

Strikes:

Great Wyrm's Fang*:  Throwing weapon attack with +9d6 damage.  It seems that whatever family of dragons invented this line of maneuvers did not believe in innovation as it grew older.

Tail Slap*****:  Regular attack, and if successful, bonus unarmed attack with no AoO and +6d6 damage and your target must make a fortitude save or be stunned for 1d4 rounds, or dazed for 1 round if they made the save.  Two attacks as one standard action means more damage, and a long duration stun is amazing.  A daze even on a successful save is even more amazing!  You just have to hope that you hit with both attacks, because if even one attack misses, you won’t lockdown your target at all.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Rending Claws*:  Usable after successfully hitting with 2 different slashing or piercingweapons.  Deal 8d6 damage.  This is a paltry average of 28 damage and has an activation requirement not easily met by Zealots.

Unbreakable Talons*:  For 1 round, when two weapon fighting with slashing weapons, you deal +4d6 damage and ignore DR/adamantine.  A much better option for full attackers, but there’s one little problem.  Broken Blade’s boosts are leaps and bounds ahead.

7th Level

Stances:

Brutal Dragon's Stance*:  While wielding 2 weapons, you have -2 AC and deal +2d6+cha mod damage.  Compared to Battle Dragon’s Stance, the only thing this does better is give you an extra 1d6 damage.  And you don’t get a TWF attack penalty reduction or an initiative bonus.  Absolutely dreadful, even for full attacker enthusiasts!

Strikes:

Thrashing Dragon Frenzy***:  Attack each adjacent enemy 4 times with 2 different weapons, and add 2 unarmed strikes or natural attacks against each enemy.  Attacking 6 times as a standard action is something that even a Zealot can get behind!  It requires adjacency, so reach doesn’t work.  But the sheer damage potential is kind of bonkers for clearing up crowds of mooks.  Make sure you have a natural attack or IUS if you consider using this.

Counters:

Alacrity on Wing*:  Acrobatics vs attack to negate it, and counter attack with two weapons for +2d6 damage.  It’s Reversing Thrust with more damage.  Still not useful for Zealots.

Boosts:

None

8th Level

Stances:

Dragon Warrior's Talons*:  You ignore DR and deal 2d4 bleed damage.  If you want to ignore DR, use a boost, have a weapon with a sufficiently high enhancement bonus, or be a Destruction Mission Zealot.  And 2d4 bleed at level 15 is beyond pitiful.

Strikes:

Thrashing Blades**:  Full attack as a standard action with +2d6 damage, and you have -4 AC and reflex until your next turn.  This is almost worse than Frenzy Strike (Primal Fury 3) and definitely worse than Primal Frenzy (Primal Fury 7).  Still, if you can load up on attacks and explode an enemy, it might be worth taking as a Zealot since it’s a standard action.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Doom Talon*:  Usable when you score a crit threat.  Automatically confirm the crit and deal +4d6 damage.  Confirming crits is already easy for people who build to be crit fishers, and this only provides a piddly amount of extra damage.

9th Level

Strikes:

Deadly Dragon Strike*****:  Attack 1 or 2 foes with 2 weapons with +12d6 damage, and targets must make a fortitude save or die.  You can even use both attacks on the same target for 2 saves!  Unlike just about every other 9th level strike in the game, this is a save or die against TWO targets!  And against a single target, it’s doubly difficult to resist.

Final Ruling*:  This discipline is clearly marketed towards full attackers, but ironically is outclassed in almost every way by Broken Blade and Primal Fury.  Good maneuvers for Zealots are far too sparse and spread out for Thrashing Dragon to be worth learning.  But many Zealots might want to consider grabbing Leaping Dragon with the Combat Training trait for low level mobility.  Once you have better mobility with teleportation strikes, you can retrain the trait.

Unquiet Grave

Skill:  Knowledge (Religion).  0 maneuvers.

Weapon Groups:  Axes, Natural, Polearms, Scythes.  This discipline has only 6 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.  All strikes in this discipline are melee-only.

Martial Tradition:  The Scales of Mourning.  Any alignment.

Note 1:  You can expend an Unquiet Grave strike to touch and heal a target healed by negative energy damage for 1d8 hp per maneuver level.

Note 2:  If you’re undead, you get the Grave Call (GC) effects of Unquiet Grave maneuvers you initiate.  If you’re undead healed by positive energy, non-undead healed by negative energy, or have the graveblood subtype, you can decide whether or not to use the Grave Call effects.

Note 3:  Temporary HP gained from Unquiet Grave maneuvers stack with themselves up to ½ your max HP and last 1 hour.

1st Level

Stances:

Bean Nighe Attitude*:  1 + ¼ ILs insight bonus to saving throws.  Piiiiiitiful.  No utility, and the bonus is teeny tiny.  The only neat thing about this stance is that it makes you look like you’ve been horribly, bloodily murdered!

Starving Vampire Stance**:  Gain 2x target’s HD in THP when you reduce a creature’s HP to 0.  Very useful indeed in the rocket-taggy low levels when one-shottable enemies are plentiful.  Its usefulness quickly dwindles as you become less able to land killing blows compared to your more damaging allies, though.

Strikes:

Hungry Stillness Strike*:  +1d8 negative energy damage.  Just some plain old extra damage with no additional effect.  For a Zealot, that’s as boring as a night in a non-haunted crypt.

Thirsting Axe Strike***:  Normal damage, and you gain THP equal to the damage dealt.  If you’re a big strong beefy size-stacking Zealot like a half-giant, and use a two hander, this will give you a HUGE amount of temporary HP every round, making you nigh immortal at low levels.  Note that this requires that you attack a creature, not an object, so you can’t use this to build up your THP pool out of combat unless you have an ally with fast healing or regeneration.

Counters:

Whisper of Undeath**:  For 1 round, you gain negative energy resistance 5 and +1 to saves vs energy drain and death effects.  GC, you gain positive energy resistance 5 and +1 to saves vs effects with the good and/or light descriptor.  These types of damage come up very rarely in regular campaigns.  Only take this if you’re playing in a campaign that heavily emphasizes undead and enemies that use Channel Energy.

Boosts:

Gravekeeper’s Hood***:  You become immune to the blinded condition for 1 round.  GC, you boost your channel resistance by 6 for 1 round.  Blindness generally isn’t a condition that you need to worry about very much at low levels, but this is a decent boost to have in your back pocket at higher levels.  It also lets you function in complete darkness, because darkness imposes the blinded condition.  As a fun bonus, you can use this to roleplay a blind swordsman!

2nd Level

Strikes:

Headstone Breaking Strike*:  1d4 damage to a physical ability score, and can affect undead creatures.  Though it offers no save, the effect honestly is not strong enough to warrant using over something that inflicts a bigger debuff or crowd control effect.  Sting of the Asp (Steel Serpent 2) is better, and even it is underwhelming.

Raging Specter Strike**:  Touch attack, and you can use Power Attack.  This will help you deal with pesky full plate + tower shield NPCs or big beefy natural armor monsters.  Exceeeept that those things generally don’t come along all that often at level 3.  Also, Power Attack isn’t a crucial feat for Zealots like it is for other martials.

Counters:

Chilling Grave Defense****:  Your attacker in close range suffers -4 strength and dexterity for 1 round.  This amounts to -2 attack and -2 or -3 damage, usually, and the debuff lasts all round, applying to their iterative attacks and AC.  And it gives no save!  Exceedingly useful for the fact that it will help your party both offensively and defensively for several rolls.

Rattling Skeleton Parry**:  For 1 round, you gain DR 5/bludgeoning and magic, and cold resistance 10.  GC, you also gain +1 natural armor to AC.  This is alright at low levels, but will quickly become useless when you meet monsters that bypass magical DR.  Bites and claws deal bludgeoning damage, believe it or not.  It’s more useful against weapon users, as many NPCs tend to use swords and bows instead of maces.

Boosts:

Stalking Ghoul***:  For 1 round, you gain +4 competence to stealth and can hide in plain sight.  Since maneuvers automatically recover every round out of combat, it’s almost like being invisible!  Marvelous for scouting or escaping a hairy situation.

3rd Level

Stances:

Avenging Revenant’s Advance*:  You’re healed by negative energy, harmed by positive energy, and can’t have your move speeds reduced below half.  GC, you’re healed by cold damage.  If you’re a living creature and don’t have any other way to activate the Grave Call effects of your maneuvers, this is one way, but most GC effects aren’t that incredible.  Also, most move speed reduction debuffs only reduce your speed to half in the first place, and ones that reduce it further are very rare.  Even if you do get immobilized, there are teleport maneuvers to fall back on.

Strikes:

Life Sealing Strike**:  +2d8 negative energy damage, and your target must make a will save or be cursed and unable to heal HP for cha mod rounds.  Wonderful for beating up Paladins, Vitalists, Medics, Silver Crane and Radiant Dawn users, and Life Oracles!  But honestly, how often are you going to fight those things in a typical campaign?  

Wight’s Blow*:  +1d8 negative energy damage and 1 negative level until the end of the encounter.  A negative level inflicts 5 damage and a -1 penalty to almost every roll, but -1 just is too tiny to be worth spending a standard action on.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Darkened Axe Style**:  Your melee attacks deal +2d8 negative energy damage for 1 round.  Great for full attackers, but not for Zealots.

4th Level

Strikes:

Hunting Mohrg Strike*****:  +2d8 negative energy damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be paralyzed for 1 round.  Paralyze is the deadliest debuff, because it makes your target vulnerable to coup de grace, which is usually instant death.  And even if they somehow don’t die, they’re still totally unable to attack your party!

Shrieking Shadow Axe**:  1d8 strength damage, and you gain THP equal to twice the strength damage dealt.  The THP is miniscule compared to what you can get from Thirsting Axe Strike, but the strength damage is sizeable enough to actually put a significant hamper on an enemy’s offensive capabilities.  It’s still risky and highly variable, though.

Counters:

Wretched Ghast Riposte****:  Your attacker in close range becomes sickened for 1 round, and must make a fortitude save or become nauseated for 1 round.  If your attacker fails this save, this is incredible, and completely shuts them down.  Even if they succeed, the counter still debuffs them!  Being sickened is slightly less effective than the -4 penalty to strength and dexterity from Chilling Grave Defense, though.

Boosts:

Rotting Axe Style*:  For 1 round, your melee attacks ignore hardness and IL DR.  GC, you ignore all DR.  Sorry, but Bronze Knuckle (Broken Blade 2) was doing this a long time ago and even has a damage bonus.

5th Level

Stances:

Mourning Ghost Attitude**:  Your armor becomes ghost touch, and you and your gear can move through solid objects but not end your movement in them.  It takes some creativity and favorable terrain to make this worthwhile, but it can help you become a true terror of a skirmisher.  For home defense, you can hop through a wall, attack an enemy, and use a movement-granting boost like Leaping Dragon (Thrashing Dragon 1) to jump back through a wall to safety.  It also lets you scout dungeon layouts like a pro.  But there’s one little problem.  Ghostwalk (Veiled Moon 3) lets you do all of this even better by making you genuinely incorporeal.  So, sadly, a 5th level stance just can’t compare with a 3rd level boost.

Strikes:

Flowing Gore Blow*:  +4d8 bleed damage which is much more difficult to heal than other bleeds.  For once, it’s quite a lot of damage for a bleed, and it almost certainly will apply multiple rounds.  If you allow your target to stay in the fight for multiple rounds, that is.  Due to the rocket-taggy nature of Pathfinder combat, damage-over-time effects just aren’t that useful.  If your GM has the tendency to give enemies increased HP and healing abilities, this will be more useful.  But as the game normally is, not at all.

Howling Banshee Strike*:  +4d8 negative energy damage, and your target is deafened for cha mod rounds.  No save, yay!  Nearly useless rider effect, boo!

Counters:

Ancient Lich Parry****:  Until the beginning of your next turn, you gain SR 15+IL.  GC, you also gain an equal amount of positive energy resistance.  Against an equal level caster with no CL increases, you have a 75% chance to ignore their spells.  And since its duration is longer than instantaneous, it could save you from multiple spells before it expires!

Boosts:

6th Level

Strikes:

Feasting Wraith Strike*:  2d4 constitution damage (will save half), and your target must make a will save or be shaken for cha mod rounds.  Constitution damage is nothing more than straight damage that scales with your target’s HD and also inflicts a slight fortitude save debuff.  Shaken on its own isn’t a good enough effect for a 6th level strike.  Too underwhelming all around.

Headsman’s Descending Axe***:  +6d8 negative energy damage, but if your target is below 1/4th their max HP, they die with no save and you gain 2x HD THP!  This is very comparable to Final Blow (Scarlet Throne 6), but its effect is much better if you can fulfil its conditions.  The downside is that unlike with Final Blow, you don’t have any ability to know your target’s HP.

Counters:

Ascending Necromancer Style****:  Until the start of your next turn, you become immune to energy drain and constitution damage.  GC, you instead become immune to channeling and positive energy damage.  These forms of damage aren’t particularly common in regular campaigns, but this will be a staple in undead-heavy campaigns.

Looming Nightwalker Parry***:  Until the start of your next turn, you gain negative energy resistance 20 and DR 15/silver and good.  GC, you gain positive energy resistance instead of negative.  The DR is very high and difficult to bypass, and it lasts against multiple incoming attacks, so it’s a good choice against multi-attackers and multiple opponents.

Boosts:

None

7th Level

Stances:

Charging Dullahan’s Advance*:  You don’t provoke AoOs for moving through threatened squares, and allies within 30 feet deal +IL negative energy damage to creatures you’re flanking.  GC, your mount doesn’t provoke AoOs for moving through threatened squares.  Now you can be a headless horseman!  If you want to not have to worry about enemies with big reaches, then use a boost or teleportation strike instead of this stance, or get a bigger reach yourself.  The utility of this stance is next to non-existent for a Zealot, and the damage bonus is quite low considering how much setup it requires.

Strikes:

Poltergeist’s Wrath**:  Melee attack in medium range.  +6d8 damage, and your target is knocked prone with no save.  Unfortunately, the usefulness of the prone condition has waned at these high levels because so many enemies are immune to it.  All you need to become immune is have a fly speed!

Counters:

Scything Reaper Riposte****:  Your attacker in close range suffers 2d4 negative levels, will save half, for the rest of the encounter.  The raw penalty to attack can be potentially much greater than the ones from Chilling Grave Defense and Wretched Ghast Riposte, and last multiple rounds instead of just one.  On an average roll of a failed save, that’s 5 negative levels.  It might not debuff your attacker’s AC, but it definitely debuffs their saves!

Boosts:

None

8th Level

Stances:

Laughing Demilich Attitude*****:  You gain 100 fly speed (or +50), the immunities of the undead creature type, and can use death knell once per round as a free action.  GC, you become immune to positive energy and gain DR/20 bludgeoning and good.  Flight and immunities are incredible, especially mind-affecting, death, paralysis, stunning, drain, and nonlethal damage.  Really, you get A LOT of immunities.  It’s rare for creatures to lay around in the dying threshold of HP at this level, but when you do manage to use death knell, it’s a nice few extra THP, and a caster level increase for Zealots who went with the Awakened Blade prestige class.  The immunities alone make this spectacular.  Try to activate the GC effect for a huge amount of DR that’s exceedingly hard to bypass.

Strikes:

Soul Drinking Strike**:  +3d4 intelligence, wisdom, and charisma damage, will save half.  That’s 7.5 damage to each mental ability score on average and a failed save, enough to oneshot the typical int-dumping and cha-dumping martial characters you might run into.  If they haven’t bought magic items to bolster their defenses, I mean, since they’re presumably around level 15 like you are.  Spellcasters will have such high scores that this strike alone won’t be able to shut down their spellcasting.

Counters:

Chilling Mist Sidestep****:  7d8 negative energy damage to a melee attacker, and until the start of your next turn, you’re immune to weapon damage, and spells targeting you have a 50% chance to miss.  You’re not almost totally untouchable, certainly against physical attackers, but spellcasters can still get lucky against you.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Pitiless Axe of the Executioner*:  3d6 constitution damage and 9d8 bleed damage that ignores immunity to bleed and is difficult to stop.  GC, you gain 2x your targets HD in THP.  Like so many other Unquiet Grave strikes, this merely does a bunch of raw HP damage with no other meaningful rider and needs to work over multiple rounds to be meaningful.  The 9th level strikes of most other disciplines are straight up save-or-dies.

Final Ruling**:  Unquiet Grave offers almost no crowd control or utility at all.  Most of its strikes require multiple applications for their debuffs to be meaningful, and it’s better to simply knock an enemy out of the fight with a single strike.  The discipline’s saving grace is that its personal defenses are quite respectable, and its counters inflict useful round-long debuffs on attackers.  Sadly, those counters can only be used when you’re attacked, not your allies.  If you have an ally with fast healing, pick up Thirsting Axe Strike to cheese yourself to a full pool of temporary HP between combat and make yourself more resilient.

Veiled Moon

Skill:  Stealth.  4 counters, 1 untyped maneuver.

Weapon Groups:  Light Blades, Double Weapons, Spears.  This discipline has only 6 maneuvers that force an opponent to make a save.

Martial Tradition:  The Wayward Path.  Any alignment.

Note:  Your gear and up to 25 lbs of carried items become incorporeal when you do via this discipline.

1st Level

Stances:

Leaping Spirit Dance*:  +2 dodge to AC and reflex when you move 10+ feet in a round.  Zealots don’t move around very much other than 5 foot steps because of how important it is to use Aid Another.  You could use this with Fading Strike at levels 3 and 4, but once you reach level 5, there are plenty of stances that increase AC at all times.

Spirit Sensing Stance**:  You gain scent, and can use it on ethereal creatures.  Ghost-smelling stance!  Scent is a nice extra little sense to have, but you’re not likely to use it on ghosts before they’re in range to float up and caress you with their cold clammy appendages.  Running Hunter’s Stance (Primal Fury 1) gives scent as well, and a better secondary bonus.

Strikes:

Dimensional Strike**:  Normal damage, and your target is flat-footed against your attack.  No ifs, ands, or buts.  Lovely if you’re a Rogue, Stalker, or Steel Serpent user.  Not so lovely if you’re a Zealot with an already high BAB and a preference for debuff strikes.

Disturbing Blow****:  [mind-affecting].  Melee-only.  Your target suffers a -4 penalty to its next d20 roll.  Great for comboing with an ally who uses debuffs like a witch, as it can make a target’s saves harder just like it can make their next attack harder.  And this strike doesn’t allow a save!  Won’t work on vermin or undead, though.

Counters:

Inner Sense*:  +2 insight bonus to a saving throw.  Only a 10% chance to work, and only protects you.  And it’s not like you’re going to be hit with Hold Person or Paralyze at levels 1 and 2, unless your GM is a complete scumbucket and throws you into a pack of ghouls.

Boosts:

Ghost Hunting Blow**:  For 1 round, your attacks have Ghost Touch.  You’re not likely to meet any incorporeal foes at low levels, but the nice thing about this being a 1st level maneuver is that you can take it at level 1, tuck it away un-readied for a while, and have it as an option once you do meet some ghosts and shadows.

2nd Level

Strikes:

Fading Strike*****:  [teleportation].  Poofaport and attack, or attack and poofaport as far as your move speed!  This is the premiere gold standard teleportation strike.  The higher your speed is, the further you can poofaport, but that doesn’t mean it’s bad for heavy armor users by any stretch of the imagination.  It’s versatile in that you can use it to hit an enemy and then disengage from melee without AoOs or worry about difficult terrain.  Heck, you can use it to poofaport anywhere, you don’t need to attack someone when you do!  If your GM grumbles, say that you’re attacking the 5 foot square which has 5 AC, using your foot.  Oh, and this works with ranged weapons, too.  Now you’re completely un-pin-downable as a ranged Zealot.

Cursed Fate****:  +2d6 damage, and your target must make a will save or suffer -4 to all d20 rolls until your next turn.  Wreaks havoc on full-attackers, and helps out your friends who target saving throws.

Resonance Strike**:  Melee or ranged touch attack, 3d6+IL force damage.  A respectable laser beam (that requires a weapon for range purposes) that works on just about anything.  But it doesn’t have any riders.

Counters:

Half-Gone*:  [teleportation].  Stealth vs attacker’s perception to become incorporeal against the attack.  Being incorporeal makes you take 50% damage or have 50% miss chance from non damaging spells.  But isn’t it better to succeed at the skill check and take 0% damage?

Boosts:

None

3rd Level

Stances:

Formless Dance**:  You have see invisibility and blur.  There are a lot of ways to deal with invisibility via items, and many better stances.  Blur’s miss chance is alright, but mathematically, if you’re not already only being hit on natural 17s-20s, then a stance with +4 AC is better.

Strikes:

Brilliant Moon*:  +4d4 force damage and ignore your target’s armor bonus to AC.  There are quite a lot of enemies that don’t wear armor, like magical beasts, aberrations, dragons, and many outsiders.  It could be useful against spooky ghosts of fighters who wear armor.  If it had any sort of rider to be worthwhile.

Counters:

Altered Penumbra**:  [teleportation, figment].  Roll stealth vs perception to poofaport 10 feet away and have the attack hit a minor image you leave behind instead.  A little mobility is nice for escaping a melee full attack’s range or a small area of effect, but a minor image that immediately gets attacked isn’t likely to trick anybody for long.  You can’t use this on allies, either.

Boosts:

Ghostwalk*****:  [teleportation].  Become incorporeal until the start of your next turn.  If you’re dexterity-based, you’ll probably have a big bonus to hit since you’ll ignore a target’s armor, shield, and natural armor bonuses, but you’ll also only deal half damage unless you have a ghost touch weapon.  If you’re strength-based, your attack rolls will switch to using dexterity.  You’ll lose your natural armor bonus and gain a deflection bonus equal to cha mod.  But the juiciest bit of utility comes with the fact that you can walk through walls as far as your speed can take you.  If your GM wasn’t already fuming about you teleporting at will with Fading Strike, this might make them rip up their carefully made dungeon maps in frustration!  Also, you make no sound and can’t be sensed with auditory-based perception checks.  You can swim at full speed, float through the air, and become immune to falling damage by using this right before you hit the ground.

4th Level

Strikes:

Breath of the Moon**:  [mind-affecting].  Melee-only?  The range label says melee or ranged attack, but the description says melee attack.  Normal damage, and your target must make a will save or be confused and unable to target you for 1d4 rounds.  Curse of the Twisted Reflection (Shattered Mirror 3) comes one level earlier and lasts longer, but leaves you as a viable target.  This is better for sowing discord and trickery than using in pure combat.

Flicker Strike*****:  Melee-only.  Poof, attack vs flat-footed, and poof again with no AoO!  Fading Strike with twice the poofing!  You can even use a combat maneuver instead of an attack, giving this strike wonderful versatility.  And just like Fading Strike, you can use it outside of combat.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

None

Untyped:

Ethereal Reminiscence*:  [teleportation].  Full round action.  Become incorporeal for 1 round, heal 2*ranks in stealth, and make a progressively harder will save or take 2d6 damage, disappear for 2d4 rounds, and be fatigued for an hour.  A wand of cure light wounds is cheap, doesn’t take up a maneuver known or readied, and doesn’t potentially hurt you when you use it.

Fading Leap*:  [teleportation].  Poofaport twice your speed as a move action.  Other classes might gleefully drool over this, but Zealots prefer to move using their standard actions!  Flicker Strike is just as good out of combat.  Or you could grab Fetch’s Wrath (Shattered Mirror 4) for another 4th level teleport strike, and with medium range to boot.

5th Level

Stances:

Stance of the Ether Gate*:  [teleportation].  You can poofaport up to your move speed as a move action.  If you take three whole entire feats (Dimensional Agility, Assault, and Dervish), you can make full attacks with this.  Not worth it for a Zealot, of course.

Strikes:

Essence Shattering Strike*****:  +6d6 force damage, and your target must make a fortitude save or be dazed for 1d4 rounds.  A great status effect for a good duration, and a heaping dose of the best damage type in the game.  The only bad thing is that it’s a fort save, but it’s still great.

Warp Worm*:  [teleportation].  Full round action.  Teleport around and make a melee touch attack against up to 3 targets for 10d6 force damage, but stop if you miss.  It’s much like Dreaming Nomad Strike (Sleeping Goddess 6), but terrible for all the same reasons.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Twisting Ether**:  [teleportation].  Switch places with an ally in your Collective, or within 30 feet.  If you’re using this to help a squishy ally out of a jam, then you have to make sure that you’re not putting your ally right back into a jam you left behind.  Tanks are usually on the front lines, after all!  This is just a limited version of Reunion in Dreams (Sleeping Goddess 3) that comes 2 levels later.

6th Level

Stances:

Spiritual Weapon Stance*:  Your gear has ghost touch, you deal +2d6 force damage, and you have spell resistance 5+IL.  If you really need to deal with incorporeal foes, then use a maneuver that turns you incorporeal, or just smack the ghosty with your magic weapon and be satisfied with dealing half damage.  The spell resistance is too low to help you very often.

Strikes:

Ether Wave**:  40 foot cone.  12d6 force damage, reflex save for half.  As attractive as force damage is, this has no use beyond dealing with a bunch of fragile mooks, and that’s what AoOs and battlefield control are for.

Vaporform Crash**:  Melee-only.  Only targets incorporeal foes.  +12d6 force damage, your target loses its incorporeality with no save, and you become incorporeal with a +4 bonus to charisma for 1d4 rounds.  It completely ruins incorporeal enemies and gives you a lovely buff, but since it only works against one type of enemy, it’s hard to justify learning.

Counters:

Phantom Penumbra***:  [teleportation, figment].  Roll stealth vs perception to poofaport 20 feet away, become incorporeal until your next turn, and have the attack hit 1d6 major images you leave behind instead.  That’s much more likely to confuzzle your foes than Altered Penumbra is, moves you further, and gives you another lasting defense in the form of incorporeality!  Enemies with special senses might not be fooled, and this can’t protect allies, unless your GM decides to have the enemies waste turns attacking the major images.

Boosts:

None

7th Level

Strikes:

Dispersal Strike***:  +12d6 force damage, your target becomes incorporeal for 1d4 rounds, and must make a will save to prevent its held items from remaining corporeal.  Making your target incorporeal could potentially be a bad thing for you, since now they gain all the defensive benefits and can easily flee.  It works well against enemies with high natural armor, high strength, low dexterity, and low charisma.

Flashing Ether Touch*:  [teleportation].  Melee touch attack.  Your target must make a will save to negate being teleported 60 feet for 10d6 damage and falling prone.  This strike can be completely negated, and prone is not a very useful condition at this level.  If you just want the utility of tossing enemies around, get the Veiled Moon Shunt feat, which works with any attack you make.

Counters:

None

Boosts:

Fade Through*:  [teleportation].  Not technically a boost, but still a swift action.  Poofaport twice your move speed.  Marvelous for full attackers, not marvelous for Zealots.

8th Level

Stances:

Anchoring Spirit****:  You become incorporeal, and can prevent enemies within 30 feet from teleporting with opposed IL checks.  This is handy when fighting outsiders that like to abuse their at-will greater teleport and other zippy foes.  Being incorporeal at all times is nothing to sneeze at, either!

Strikes:

Eclipsing Moon*:  [teleportation].  Full attack, melee-only.  Poofaport your speed between each attack with +2 competence to attack and +4d4 damage against flat-footed AC.  A full-attacker’s gooey ectoplasm-coated dream!  Just imagine how much havoc you could wreak if you were a TWF Stalker!  But alas, you’re a Zealot.  Fate smiles cruelly upon you.

Counters:

Lunar Penumbra*:  Roll stealth vs perception to switch places with your attacker and make make them hit themselves.  Against a full attacker, all this will do is inflict a bit of damage on them and not protect you from any further attacks.  It might even put you in a disadvantageous position, into enemy flanking, or take your attacker out of your allies’ flanking.  The best it can do is pull an evoker into his own empowered maximized dazing fireball.

Boosts:

None

9th Level

Strikes:

Banish to the Beyond***:  Melee touch attack.  Your target must make a will save or be tossed to the Astral Plane and unable to go to the Material Plane by any means for 1 hour.  Even if they save, they disappear for 1 minute.  It gets any enemy out of your hair no matter what, even ones with plane shift, but you don’t get their loot, and they could come back to bite you in the bum later, so it doesn’t really count as a save-or-die.

Final Ruling***:  The early teleportation maneuvers are incredible for mobility both in and out of combat, and incorporeality has a ton of benefits, especially for a charisma-based class like the Zealot.  Other than that, it’s not a very useful discipline for Zealots.  Choose between Fading Strike and Relentless Warden’s Strike (Eternal Guardian) when you get 2nd level maneuvers, and choose between Flicker Strike and Fetch’s Wrath (Shattered Mirror) when you get 4th level maneuvers.  Once you get your 4th level teleport strike, you can retrain out your 2nd level one for a different 2nd level maneuver.

Third Party Material (under construction)

This section will cover material that wasn’t published by Paizo or Dreamscarred Press.  Unlike the days of 3.5e, Pathfinder third party publisher (3pp) developers are actually pretty high quality!  But you knew that already, looking at a guide for a third party class like Zealot.  Note that mixing material from different 3pps is not going to be balanced.  But Pathfinder is nothing if not a glorious box of tinker toys where a lot of the fun comes from mixing and matching pieces.  Use at your own risk, but have fun!

Spheres of Power and Might

Spheres of Power is the magic system made by Drop Dead Studios (DDS) with the aim to reduce the ludicrous quadratic power curve of Vancian casters and make theme-based casters much more possible and viable.  Though this is a guide for Zealots, who are non-casters, there are still some great choices for dipping that benefit a Zealot’s playstyle.  Spheres of Might is DDS’s martial combat system.  Instead of building something new from the ground up like Path of War did, it builds on Paizo’s already-existing combat rules and shifts the focus away from doing full attacks and towards using your standard, move, and swift actions for fighting.  As a Zealot enthusiast, this has my full approval!

Getting into Spheres, The Basics

The best way to get into Spheres of Power is to dip into a class that uses spherecasting rather than just spending feats.  Doing so will give you 2 free talents and several spell points.  However, Spheres of Might in particular has two additional ways you can use it without a class dip.

Firstly, since Zealots are proficients with all martial weapons, they can trade out their proficiencies for a Martial Tradition (not to be confused with the Path of War traditions that trade out your disciplines), which changes your proficiencies to simple weapons, light armor, and bucklers, and gives you 4 combat talents.  This is almost always worth it, because at worst, you can use Equipment Sphere talents to regain armor and weapon proficiencies while still having talents left over, and at best, you can simply decide to make do with those starting proficiencies and have 4 talents to do whatever you want with.

The second way to gain more combat talents without a class dip is to use Feat to Talent Progression Conversion.  This lets you trade out 5 feats you get from leveling up for 10 combat talents, or 8 feats for 15 talents.  It’s more efficient than simply using your feats to buy Extra Combat Talent multiple times.

In both Spheres of Power and Spheres of Might, there are talents that eat into your action economy and talents that give passive benefits.  Obviously, Zealots will be most interested in the more passively beneficial talents, because PoW strikes and boosts/counters tend to be more powerful than any Spheres talents that use standard or swift actions with low investment.  Also, Spheres of Might uses “attack actions” which are not compatible with PoW strikes.  Since there are so incredibly many talents, I’m not going to rate each and every single one of them, because there would be a vast sea of red that not even Moses could cross.  I’m only going to mention the ones that are worthy of consideration for Zealots, or traps to avoid.

Magic Talents

When you spend a talent to pick a sphere, you first gain the base abilities of that sphere, and then you use more talents to gain any other talent in the sphere.  You also can pick sphere-specific drawbacks that give you bonus talents at the cost of limiting your ability to use the sphere in some ways.  Remember that this is a Zealot guide, and ratings are based upon how good these talents are for Zealots with a low caster level (CL), few spell points, and a demanding action economy.

Alteration

Base abilities:

Shapeshift***:  Standard action, touch range, 1 SP, 1 minute/CL, gain 1 trait (or 2 at CL 5) and either Blank Transformation or a (transformation) form.  The rating depends upon how often you're able to pre-buff before you enter combat so that you don't have to use actions during combat to buff, and that depends upon your GM and what kind of campaign you're in.

Sphere-Specific Drawbacks:

Beast Soul***:  Get this if you want to use a (transformation) form instead of Blank Transformation.  (Transformation) forms make your equipment meld into you, and Blank Transformation doesn't.

Lycanthropy*****:  You can only shapeshift yourself.  Definitely something you should take with the aim of pre-buffing.  A very easy free talent.

Unnatural Transformation****:  Touching silver can end your shapeshift.  A little risky, but enemies with silver weapons are very rare, with the exception of Mithril Current users.  Silver is rare, but free talents are forever.

Talents:

Additional Limbs**:  An Extra Arm is handy if you use both a shield and a two-handed weapon but lack Pikeman's Training or Shield Brace.  A Pair of Legs is mostly useful out of combat for overland travel.  An Extra Head offers a small amount of utility with +1 to all skills, as long as whoever you're using diplomacy on doesn't mind your freakish body horror.  A fun and flavorful talent with some use both in and out of combat, but nothing incredible.

Agile***:  +2 dodge to AC is great during combat, +4 initiative is lovely when you're about to enter it, and uncanny dodge is something that initiators crave because it allows them to use counters during the first round of combat if they haven't gone yet.  A good, versatile talent if you don't have the Defensive Strategist (religion) trait.

Greater Change****:  A great candidate to spend one of your free talents on that you got from drawbacks.  Now you can use 2 traits (or 3 if you have CL 5).

Lingering Transformation***:  The usefulness of increasing the duration of your shapeshift from 1 minute/CL to 10 minutes/CL depends on your GM and what kind of campaign you're in.  If you often have reliable forewarning, this talent isn't worth taking, but if you do a lot of long explorations, it might be.

Size Change****:  You know how much I gush about the minor metamorphosis power?  Well, here it is, in sphere form!  The downside is that you can't enlarge beyond Large with Size Change, but you can with minor metamorphosis if you're already a large sized race, like a Gamla-heritage Aasimar, or a Tiger Catfolk.  Depending on what other traits you have access to, and if you can gain more than just one trait when using shapeshift, this can potentially be better than minor metamorphosis.

Tentacles****:  Grab is a fantastic ability for crowd control because it's a free action grapple whenever you attack, but the downside is that you need to apply it to a natural weapon.  It's best if you already have a natural weapon from your race so that you don't have to spend a trait gaining one, or use Beast Soul and a (transformation) form instead of Blank Transformation.

Dragon Transformation (transformation)***:  Gain +2 natural armor to AC, darkvision 60, 40 speed, a gentle sneeze, and still have the ability to use speech and hands, meaning you can use manufactured weapons and shields.  Speech isn’t such a big deal since Zealots have telepathy.  If you also take Tentacles, this is a good form to apply it to because it has a bite attack.

Elemental Transformation, Dedicated (transformation)****:  Gain +2 natural armor to AC, darkvision 60, 25% fortification, and depending on which element you pick, +2 to a stat and a new movement mode and mastery!  Strength-based Zealots could pick earth, and dexterity, constitution, and charisma-based Zealots should pick fire.  Why not water for +2 constitution, you ask?  Because water mastery gives you a -4 penalty to attack and damage if you or your target is touching the ground, which will be the vast majority of the time.  Be careful, because earth mastery has the same problem if you or your target are flying or swimming.  Fire is the safest choice, and dexterity is useful for everyone.

Serpentine Transformation (transformation)*****:  Gain +2 natural armor to AC, low light vision, 40 speed, 20 climb speed, no legs so you can't be tripped, and a bite with grab and constrict already included!  Now you don't even need to spend a talent on Tentacles!  At CL 1 with the single talent used to get Alteration Sphere, you can take the sphere-specific drawbacks listed above and wind up with Size Change and Lingering Transformation, letting you become a large serpent with bite, grab, and constrict for 10 minutes.  Not too shabby!

Final Ruling***:  With a low CL and few talents, Alteration Sphere is only worth taking if you're sure you can frequently pre-buff, or if you really like being a snake or a ball of fire.  Things improve greatly if you can get CL 5 for an extra trait.  As an alternative to taking Alteration Sphere, check out the Transformation, Hybrid Transformation, and Improved Transformation feats which let you get great buffs from Alteration that scale with your character level, not your CL!  More details in the Feats section.

Bear

Note:  Bear Sphere was released on April Fools Day 2019 for the sake of unbearable puns and probably isn’t very well balanced, intentionally.

Base Abilities:

Bear Spirit**:  Swift action, 0 SP, 1 minute/CL, you gain the animal creature type and Endurance feat and can use (bearacteristic) talents.  It’s the same mechanic that Fallen Fey Sphere uses.  It’s a pre-buff, so it can’t be that bad, right?  That depends on how good the rest of the talents in Bear Sphere are.

Bear Strength (bearacteristic)**:  Free action as part of melee attack, 1 SP, gain ½ per CL to attack and damage and don’t provoke an unarmed AoO.  It’s not atrocious, it’s just incredibly inefficient at low levels.  If you’ve already spent all the spell points you’re going to on other buffs and don’t have anything else to use spell points on, you might as well dump the remainder by using this.  The worst part is that you can’t trade it out with a drawback.

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

None.  This is a pain, because it means you absolutely must spend another talent in order to get anything else out of this sphere.

Talents:

A Step Too Fur (bearacteristic)****:  Free action, 1 SP, make the area around you in a 5 ft radius difficult terrain for 1 round that only affects enemies.  This is quite handy for controlling enemies and keeping them glued to you, you big beefy beary Zealot tank!  It’ll become less useful at higher levels when enemies stop caring about terrain.

Smarter than the Average Bear (bearacteristic)***:  1 SP, gain +1d6 to a skill check.  This combines nicely with skill-based counters!

Ursine Blow (bearacteristic)**:  +1 SP when using Bear Strength, potentially move an enemy 10 feet and knock them prone.  A nice rider effect, but very costly in terms of spell points.  Each attempt takes 2 SP total, and you won’t have many.

Final Ruling**:  I don’t even mind the jokes, but the fact of the matter is that this isn’t a very good dipping sphere for Zealots.  Its talents require a high CL or a lot more talents to make good use of.  The fact you have to spend more than one talent just to access the sphere beyond the base abilities is the nail in the coffin.  At least it actually has some potential uses thanks to its good action economy, unlike some other spheres.

Blood

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Conjuration

Base Abilities:

Summon*****:  Gain a companion with 1 HD and a free (form) or (type) talent, summon it as a standard action for 1 SP, concentration or 1 additional SP for 1 minute/CL, and have it act on the turn after it’s summoned.  Behold, the premiere minionmancy sphere!  Everyone knows how powerful summoning is in regular Pathfinder because it improves your action economy and makes enemies effectively waste actions attacking your expendable minions.  Zealots especially love psicrystals, familiars, and mounts for their utility and action economy assistance.  But can a low level dip of Conjuration Sphere stand up in higher level play?

Base Forms:

Biped*****:  It has arms to use weapons and manipulate items with, and its mighty 16 strength gives it enough carrying capacity to serve as a mount.  There is nothing in the rules that says bipedal creatures can’t be mounts.  I’m sure everyone has heard silly stories of Gnome Sorcerers riding Half-Orc Barbarians.  Many GMs disallow this, though.  The only relevant rule is “If you attempt to ride a creature that is ill suited as a mount, you take a –5 penalty on your Ride checks.”  If your GM allows you to use your bipedal companion as a mount, it’s the best choice, but if not, go with a quadruped.  Funnily enough, they also make the best backline support companions because they can take the Warrior archetype.

Quadruped****:  It doesn’t have arms, but its 14 dexterity makes its reflex a bit better than bipeds, and its 1.5x bonus to carrying capacity and 40 base speed help it serve as a mount.  They also are good with the Familiar and Mage archetypes if you want a higher base speed than an orb but aren’t concerned about difficult terrain.

Orb***:  A good form for Familiar Mage companions because of a 30 ft hover speed and 16 dexterity.

Other forms*:  They just don’t excel in any way over bipeds and quadrupeds.

Companion Archetypes:

Beast***:  Your companion gains a free (form) talent, but its intelligence becomes 2 and it gains the animal type.  It makes your companion’s actions less versatile, as you can only make it do whatever you can convince your GM it could do.  Druids and other classes that get animal companions can use handle animal with them as a free action, but you don’t get that benefit.  A somewhat risky choice, but the bonus talent could be well worth it.

Familiar****:  Your companion costs -2 SP to summon, but divides its HD in half, or HP in half if its HD is 1.  This means you can summon and have your companion remain without concentration for 0 SP!  It’s definitely not durable to be in the thick of combat, but if it also has the Mage archetype, it gives you a decent amount of utility.   Avoid the Limited Range drawback if you have a companion with this archetype.  If you have the Gift for Magic (magic) trait, it’s inefficient to use Familiar companions because your CL 3 will get rounded down to CL 1 for them.  Give them the Mage archetype as well, and also Warrior if they’re bipeds!

Mage****:  Your companion gains spherecasting with a casting tradition, but its HD becomes d6 and BAB becomes ½.  Not for melee Zealots using their companion as a mount, of course, but a great choice for mounted ranged Zealots who stay out of harm’s way, and for Familiar companions who support from the backlines.

Martial Companion**:  Your companion loses evasion, devotion, multiattack, and improved evasion, but gains a SoM combat talent at every even HD, and optionally can lose natural attacks to gain Battle Creature (form).  This is actually a risky proposition because evasion is your companion’s greatest form of defense.  Being able to avoid damage from AoEs means enemies have to directly attack your companion to kill it, using up actions and relieving pressure from your less expendable party members.  Since you have to get your companion’s HD up to 4 in order to get its second combat talent, it’s generally not worth the loss in protection.

Mindless*:  Your companion has no intelligence score, skills, or feats, but it gains +1 HD if your CL is 4+.  Feats are more important than an extra HD for a utility companion.  The increase in HD is to enable it to have enough raw stats to be a beatstick for a high-caster.

Warrior*****:  Bipeds only.  Your companion loses its natural attacks and gains Battle Creature (form) twice.  That means it gains a martial tradition (4 free talents) and 2 magical weapons it’s proficient with!  Just another reason to hope your GM allows bipedal mounts!  Backline support companions also make great Warriors, because there are many supporty combat talents in Alchemy, Gladiator, and Warleader.  Fun fact, this stacks with Mage!

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Elongated Summoning****:  If you have Greater Summoning and/or Lingering Companion, definitely grab this, because your companion will be out all day!  Heck, the mere act of taking this drawback already pays for one of those talents!

Figment Companion*****:  Enemies can make a will save to negate your companion’s offensive effects.  Since a low level companion will be better used for utility rather than attacking, this is a free talent.

Limited Range***:  Your companion is dismissed if it moves more than 5 feet away from you.  If you’re using the companion as a mount, this is a free talent, but you lose the option of using the companion as a wall to control a distant area, or as a backline supporter.

Material Weakness****:  Your companion needs to make a will save when damaged by a certain material or be dismissed.  Tell me, when was the last time you saw an enemy wielding a cold iron weapon?

Object Bound*****:  You have to drop an object to summon your companion, and it can be attacked.  In all honesty, the object is likely going to be more durable than your low CL companion is.  The only possible downside is if you use a weapon and heavy shield because the hand with the heavy shield can’t be used for anything else.  Use a buckler instead, or find some way to hold all your gear but also be able to carry and drop your pokéball.  Or, just summon your companion outside of combat so you won’t have to do it during.

Talents:

Extra Companion*****:  You get another companion!  Now you can have a mount AND a backline support buddy, or two, or three!  Remember, if you have the Gift for Magic (magic) trait, you get +2 CL which applies to ALL of your companions.  Since your CL is going to be so low, it’s often better to spend talents on Extra Companion rather than (form) talents.  Your companions are squishy and will probably die a lot, but that’s okay, because they can be summoned the next day with no penalty, unlike a mount or familiar you’d get from a class feature.  They’re expendable, so don’t worry about coddling them.

Greater Summoning****:  Summon lasts 10 minutes/CL.  On its own, that’s already good for out-of-combat utility and pre-buffing, but if you also get Lingering Companion, it lasts all day!

Spell Conduit****:  It’s no good by itself.  Zealots dipping into spherecasting won’t be using touch spells during combat either on enemies or allies.  What makes it potentially blue is when you get it for free with the Spell Stand-In general drawback.  That gives you the Spell Channel feat as well, and all of your spells originate from your companions, which is just fine for pre-buffing.

Altered Size (form)***:  Taken once makes your companion large or tiny, taken twice makes them huge or diminutive.  Nice both for mounts who want to be big and supporty Familiar Mages who want to be little!  Note that if you’re a small sized Zealot, you can already ride a medium companion and don’t have to spend a talent on this.

Avian Creature (form)****:  30 ft fly speed (average), which can be wingless, supernatural, and with perfect maneuverability if you want!  Every adventurer wants flight at some point!  Even if you stay at ground level, a hovercraft mount lets you ignore difficult terrain and get a juicy +1 attack bonus against lower elevation creatures.

Battle Creature (form)*****:  Get 2 free simple magic weapons and a martial tradition.  Purple for bipeds, green for quadrupeds.  Bipeds have the advantage of starting with two arms and can take the Warrior archetype to get Battle Creature twice.  Quadrupeds have to spend two talents and one more on Extra Limbs to get the same benefit.  Free magic weapons are good, but the martial tradition is better since it’s 4 combat talents.  Have it summon spiked gauntlets and use the Gauntlet Shield talent from Equipment Sphere for both offense and defense.  You could opt to not get arms for your quadruped and save a talent, but you’d miss out on the use of the weapons.  Some good spheres for backline support Warriors to take are:

  • Alchemy**** (Hippocratic Oath, Mana Chemistry, Narrow Toxicology (contact)) for a humongous variety of buffing, curing, and utility.  To use single-target formulae in combat, take the Vaporized Formula feat to make it AoE and ranged.  Buff with talents like Anesthetic Dosage, Performance Enhancer, Universal Alcohol, and War Paint (green and orange).  Cure with Elixir, Panacea, and Salve.  Improved Smoke Bomb and Instant Foam are excellent battlefield control.
  • Gladiator***** (Braggart) for Self Confidence and Exemplar.  Grant your entire party a reroll on attacks every round!  Add Motivational Audience and Spur Violence so that the companion can use its immediate actions to grant an ally a free attack!
  • Guardian Patrol package*** (Without Delay) for the ability to give allies in a 15 ft radius a lot of defensive benefits.  Make sure the companion summons a longspear!  Iron Wall grants 20% miss chance, and (zone) talents give more utility.
  • Scout*.  Advisory Scout can give the party a lot of buffs, but the problem is that the companion needs to successfully scout an enemy.  That’s unlikely.
  • Warleader**** for Aggressive Flanking.  The shout and tactics radius of a companion with 1 HD is only 10 ft, so if you want it to use shouts, add Projecting Voice.  Add on Harangue to give your allies more saving throws, or Focusing Cry and Focusing Formula (alchemy sphere) to recover an ally’s martial focus every round.
  • Wrestling*** for Hard Whip.  Grapple a willing ally, release and move them 10 feet, and give them a free attack with +4 damage!  Silly, but fun and effective!

Boon Companion (form)***:  Your companion treats your CL as +1 higher, +1 per 5 HD you have.  This will make your mount more durable and potentially get another feat.  Companions naturally increase HD at CLs 2, 3, and 5.  Taking the Gift for Magic (magic) trait increases your CL in Conjuration Sphere by 2, which makes all of your companions better and starts you out at CL 3.  Each one with Boon Companion will be CL 4 while you’re level 1 to 4, then become CL 5 and thus HD 4 when you reach level 5.  This is kind of bookkeeping-intensive, but hey, that’s what optimizing minionmancy is all about.

Extra Limbs (form)***:  Worth getting if your mount is a quadruped and you also give it Battle Creature x2.  Now it can have arms to use those weapons with!  Have it summon spiked gauntlets and use the Gauntlet Shield talent from Equipment Sphere.

Implement Bearer (form)*:  Gain a +1 implement at HD 3.  A lot of spells don’t improve until you have a certain CL, and many spheres are weak if you don’t have a high caster level.  The spheres that are good with low caster levels won’t benefit much from a +1 increase to CL, if at all.

Lingering Companion (form)****:  Spend +1 SP to make the companion last 1 hour/level or 1 day if you have Greater Summoning.  If you just use Mage Familiars to pre-buff or get some extra utility outside of combat, you don’t have to take Lingering Companion or Greater Summoning.  If you intend to use any companions in combat, however, as mounts or backline magical support, it’s a good idea to take one or both of these talents.  Mind your spell points, because using Lingering Companion costs 3 SP total for each companion:  1 to summon, 1 to have it remain without concentration, and 1 to increase the duration.

Magical Companion (form)*****:  Your companion’s charisma increases by ½ CL and it gains the ability to get spherecasting with Extra Magic Talent.  Mages have to take this.  A CL 1 Familiar Mage companion will have 3 SP and need to spend their first feat and their free (form) talent just to have a single magic sphere, but they can still use sphere-specific drawbacks to get other talents within that sphere.  Some good spheres for backline support Mages to take are:

  • Alteration*** (Fleshwarper, Unnatural Transformation) for Ranged Alteration and a talent with a trait you like.  Buff allies in close range for 1 minute with AC or initiative from Agile, and use concentration when the companion runs out of SP!
  • Destruction*** (Aligned Combatant, Shape Focus) for Rebuff and either Extended Range or Gather Energy.  Rebuff grants an ally evasion, AC, and reflex, and can be used with 1 SP (or full round action with Gather Energy for 0 SP) to buff all allies within 10 feet!  Pick Extended Range to change from close to medium range for more safety.
  • Enhancement*** (Marking Enhancements, optionally Bodily Enhancements) for 1 or 2 buffing (enhance) talents.  Enhance is inherently a close range spell!  Energy Enhancement can stack 4 types of damage onto your team’s multiattackers.  Enhance Focus gives a whopping +5 enhancement bonus to a skill!
  • Fate***** (Luckless/Neutrality/Sanctified/Tongue Of Ages) for 2 supporty consecrations, or 2 supporty words, or one of those and one motif.  Motifs are hour/CL buffs, some words offer rerolls like Bless, and Tug Fate is just beautiful.
  • Life*** (Limited Restoration (cure/invigorate), Slow Recovery, Unnatural Remedy) for Ranged Healing and 1 (vitality) talent.  Deal with bleed damage by applying fast healing, and grant a nice (vitality) buff whenever the companion casts invigorate.
  • Light**** (Lens Focus, optionally Flexible Lens) for 2 (lens) talents.  These have a range of medium right off the bat and are wonderful buffs!  1 hour/CL for 1 SP, and can be used with concentration for 0 SP!  There’s nothing safer.
  • Protection**** (Limited Protection (ward)) for Distant Protection and Barrier, or (Alternate Aegis, Crystalline) for 2 (aegis) talents and Barrier.  Throwing down a barrier in close range every round is a good form of battlefield control.  If you go with the aegises, some aegises provide nice bonuses without relying on CL.
  • Time*** (Altered Time (lose slow)) for Ranged Time and Haste.  A simple but useful buff.  Have your companion concentrate Haste on someone.
  • War**** (Alternate Rally/Alternate Totem/Commando/Small Unit Strategist) for two of the following: A rally, a totem, a mandate, or a momentum talent.  Or two mandates, or two momentum talents.  So much versatility here!  War has tons of support abilities!
  • Warp*** (no drawbacks) for Teleport.  Touch range teleport allies 25 ft.  This is risky because it’s touch range and you don’t have a free talent for Ranged Teleport, but using a CL 1 companion to move allies around is invaluable for offense and defense!

Mount (form)*:  Your companion gains a free saddle and shares your initiative, and you gain a +1 insight bonus to ride checks on it.  Don’t be fooled, you don’t actually require this talent in order to use a companion as a mount.

Final Ruling*****:  Using a Conjuration Sphere companion as a mount comes with a lot of downsides.  It has a duration, costs a lot of spell points and talents, and has a pitifully low survivability once you start reaching medium levels.  Its greatest upside is that it’s completely expendable.  If it dies, it reappears the next day with no penalty!  You can’t say the same thing about familiars, animal companions from Beastmastery Sphere, or cohorts from Leadership Sphere.  Still, it’s a giant hassle when your mount dies in the middle of combat since you have to roll a DC 15 ride check not to fall prone and take 1d6 damage.  Familiar Mage Warrior backline support companions are much more reliable because they can help your team while reasonably staying out of harm’s way.  And if an enemy decides to go out of their way to kill one of them, it’s an action they didn’t take to hurt your allies.  Another major positive is that Conjuration Sphere has so many good sphere-specific drawbacks that you get a lot of free talents!  With Elongated Summoning, Figment Companion, Material Weakness, and Object Bound, you get 4 talents!  The one talent it takes to pick up Conjuration Sphere gives you a lot to work with.

Creation

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Dark

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Death

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Destruction

Base Abilities:

Destructive Blast*:  Standard action, 0-1 SP, close range touch attack, 1d6 per odd CL or 1d6 per CL bludgeoning damage, can apply 1 blast shape and 1 blast type talent.  Nothing you can do with a low CL Destructive Blast can match a Sun’s Gleam PoW strike.

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Aligned Combatant****:  You deal half damage to neutral creatures and none to one alignment.  You usually won’t be fighting good creatures if you’re good yourself, and the riders of the blast types trigger regardless of whether they deal damage.  With a low CL, your goal isn’t to deal big damage, it’s to apply debuffs, so this is just fine!

Energy Focus*****:  Pick whatever blast type you want for free!  This is something that just about everyone who takes Destruction Sphere winds up getting.

Shape Focus*****:  Pick whatever blast shape you want for free!  Another hilariously free talent.  Who would want to stick with a single-target touch attack when other shapes exist?

Talents:

Epicenter****:  You ignore the negative effects of your own destructive blasts.  Now you can waltz around with a Crystal Energy Aura and not have to worry about difficult terrain!  If you’re a melee Zealot and got the Aligned Combatant drawback, grab this with the free talent.

Selective Blast****:  You can exclude one creature from your instantaneous destructive blasts.  This doesn’t make your ally immune to the difficult terrain of Crystal Blast, but it does help with other debuff blast types.  Use this with Energy Bomb.  You decide on all variables of the spell when you create an Energy Bomb, so you decide which ally you’re excluding when you make it.  Choose a teammate that likes to get thick in melee!  Use the free talent you got from Aligned Combatant to pick this up.

Energy Aura (blast shape)**:  Move action, 1 SP, gain a 5 ft aura for cha mod rounds that blasts creatures that end their turn in it, reflex negates.  The nice things are that this is merely a move action to use, it can affect multiple enemies, and it can last several rounds.  Unfortunately, your save DC is still super low, so it often won’t do anything.  It can also hit allies.  It can be handy with Crystal Blast or to make a bunch of difficult terrain and possibly entangle super unlucky enemies.

Energy Bomb (blast shape)****:  1 SP, create a potion/splash weapon.  What’s amazing about splash weapons is that they don’t allow a save!  An Energy Bomb will hit a 3x3 square area if you hit a creature, or a 2x2 square area if you target a grid intersection.  What’s even more amazing is that you can attach Energy Bombs to Vial Arrows (5 gp each) and Shatter Shots (15 gp each), adding an AoE debuff rider onto all of your ranged attacks!  Since your CL is low, you’ll still need to stick with blast types that debuff with no save, like Blistering Blast, Incandescent Blast, Numbing Blast, or Tenebrous Blast.  Crystal Blast is good as well for difficult terrain and rarely entangling enemies.

Energy Leap (blast shape)*:  Standard action, 1 SP, move and hit everyone in a close range straight line with destructive blast, but provoke AoOs and use overrun rules with your CL and cha instead of BAB and str.  Everything after the “but” is what really kills it.  Normally, Zealots love standard action abilities that let them simultaneously move and attack foes, especially multiple ones, but your damage and save DCs are pathetic and enemies can simply choose to avoid your overrun attempt unless you have the Stampede talent from Brute Sphere or the Trample feat.  And you’ll take AoOs.

Explosive Orb, Mutable Blast, Sculpt Blast (blast shapes)**:  These are the AoE blast shapes that cover a decent area if you spend +1 SP.  Combine them with Crystal Blast to create a patch of difficult terrain and possibly entangle unlucky enemies.  It’s an option over Energy Bomb if you don’t use a ranged weapon.

Blistering Blast, Incandescent Blast, Numbing Blast, Tenebrous Blast (blast types)*****:  These are the blast types that inflict a debuff without allowing a save, and don’t cost extra SP!  They’re -2 fort, -2 will and perception, -2 reflex, and -2 attack for 1d4 rounds, respectively.  Pick your favorite one and plop it into your Energy Bombs!

Crystal Blast (blast type)***:  Your target’s space and the blast’s AoE become difficult terrain for 1 minute, and your target must make a reflex save or be entangled.  Since your CL is so low, don’t rely on them failing the reflex save.  The difficult terrain can be very handy, though!

Final Ruling****:  Using Energy Bombs to add AoE debuff riders on ranged attacks for 1 SP is pretty great!  It’s not a no-brainer must-have, though, because there are a lot of things you can do with Vial Arrows and Shatter Shots.  Namely, Alchemy Sphere.  Melee Zealots will also enjoy a long-lasting aura that creates difficult terrain every turn.  Just don’t actually try to deal damage with Destruction Sphere, and its utility will serve you well!

Divination

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Enhancement

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Fallen Fey

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

None.

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Fate

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Illusion

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Life

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Light

Base Abilities:

Glow*****:  Standard action, medium range touch attack, 0 SP, 1 minute/CL, makes target glow with normal light up to a 20 ft radius, debuff target’s stealth by -20, and make target unable to benefit from miss chance.  Wow.  For a base ability, this does a lot of useful stuff, and for such a low cost!  Dealing with invisibility and miss chance is difficult, and can even be tricky for a lot of PoW builds.  But as great as this is, it’s just icing on the cake, because Light Sphere can do a lot more than simply beat stealthers.

Bright Light****:  Same as glow, except it costs 1 SP to use without concentration, the target glows with bright light up to a 30 + 5 per 2 CL ft radius, and works with talents that rely on bright light.  I’m impressed with the cleverness of the design of these abilities.  Splitting them into two different things lets the designers fine tune talents that use them and lets players decide what resources they want to use.

Lenses*****:  These are 1 hour/CL buffs, and a lot of them are really good.  You get one automatically when you get Light Sphere!  The long duration means easy pre-buffing and passive benefits.

Notes:  (Light) talents have four ways of affecting targets.  1) glowing with normal light, 2) glowing with bright light, 3) in the area of a glow, and 4) in the area of bright light.  Keep this in mind, because it’ll help you understand how each (light) talent targets creatures better.

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Flexible Lens*****:  This is simply another way to say “pick whatever (lens) talent you want when you get Light Sphere.”

Lens Focus**:  You can’t use glows.  This isn’t compatible with Touch of Light, but both Lens Focus and Touch of Light give a free talent of your choice, and Lens Focus restricts you more.  The only reason to choose Lens Focus instead of Touch of Light is if you want to use the Periscope (lens) talent.

Light Focus***:  You can’t use (lens) talents.  If you want to get both Glory and a (light) talent with the just talent you used to get Light Sphere, you have to take this drawback.

Nimbus Focus*****:  Your glows only work with a (nimbus) talent.  Get Weird Radiance, because it lets you put the areas of your glows wherever you want and avoid hitting allies with debuffs.  Great in combination with Irradiance’s bright light.  Honestly, there doesn’t seem to be any reason why a normal glow would be better than a Weird Radiance shaped glow!

Subtle Light****:  You have to use Black Light.  Now your Light spells don’t get turned off by magical darkness and don’t ruin your stealth or concealment.  Mandatory if you use self-buff (light) talents.

Touch of Light****:  You can only apply glows at touch range.  An easy free talent for Glory users.  You can still use Area Glow to reveal nearby stealthers if you have this drawback.

Talents:

Area Glow***:  Standard action, 1 SP, make everything in a 10 ft radius glow.  In regular Pathfinder, glitterdust is an awesome 10 ft radius spell not just because it blinds enemies, but because it reveals stealthers.  This won’t blind them unless you also get Blinding Light, but it does beat stealthers and nullify their miss chance defenses.  This talent is a handy tool to have in your back pocket when you need it.  If you also get Irradiance, you can make everyone you glowed sickened with no save!  But unless you get Dim Light (lens) and put it on your allies, it’ll make them glow as well, so be careful.

Black Light****:  Your glows can be non-invisible and not get turned off by magical darkness.  Get this via the Subtle Light drawback if you use self-buff (light) talents.

Glory****:  Make yourself shed bright light in a 5 ft radius with no SP or concentration requirements.  Now you can use (light) talents for no cost!  It makes it a nigh-permanent buff!  It’s not truly permanent, though, because glows still have a duration of 1 minute/CL, so you have to keep recasting it on yourself before it expires.  That means taking 1 standard action out of every minute if you’re CL 1.  Just something to remember.  Some GMs won’t care, and some will.

Lingering Glow***:  Your glows last 10 minutes/CL, and bright light remains for 2 rounds after you stop concentrating.  This is a good alternative to Glory if you want to buff yourself with (light) talents that cost an additional SP, like Encompassing Light.  Such talents will cost 2 SP total to use, compared to 1 with Glory, but you’ll have a bigger window of time to use them.

Style*:  Make paintings with light.  As delightfully fun as this is, it has no real practical use and can’t justify costing a talent.  Instead, buy a Gleam Brush for 200 gp and get the same thing!

Aiming Scope (lens)****:  Targets count as 1 range increment closer and you get +1 competence to ranged attacks.  Incredible for Firearms Zealots who have to deal with low ranges, and you can also give it to your ranged teammates.  Since it’s a competence bonus, it won’t stack with a Bard’s inspire courage or Bracers of Archery.

Chameleon (lens)***:  Add your cha mod to stealth, and hide in plain sight!  Fantastic for ranged Zealots who don’t move more than a 5 foot step each round, and your sneaky scout allies will love you for this as well.  Shoot, 5 foot step, stealth regardless of positioning, and avoid retaliation!  Combine with the Lurker in Darkness feat or Lurker talent from Scout Sphere so that special senses won’t auto-detect you.

Halo Effect (lens)**:  A rare circumstance to diplomacy, bluff, and some perform skills!  Sadly, it doesn’t include intimidate, so it won’t apply to many counters, unless your GM allows it to apply to perform (dance) for Mithril Current counters.

Infravision (lens)***:  Ignore miss chance less than total concealment vs living creatures, and track living creatures.  Having this lens means you won’t even have to make enemies glow in order to negate their miss chance!  Unless they’re fully invisible, that is.  Ignoring miss chance means your debuffing strikes hit more frequently, but not every enemy has miss chance.

Obscure (lens)*****:  Once per round, an attacker has to roll twice to hit!  This is like a free action counter!  And you can put it on all of your allies!  Mathematically, this gets an even bigger benefit on high AC targets than low AC targets, but I’m sure your squishy low AC teammates would still appreciate you increasing their survivability.  Even if an enemy rolls a natural 20, which is something that PoW counters cannot counter, Obscure still forces them to reroll, which can turn a crit into a regular hit or a miss!

Periscope (lens)**:  You can place a sensor within your glow range and see from it.  Don’t take this if you took the Touch of Light drawback.  On its own, it’s handy for reconnaissance, but it needs further investment in order to be useful in combat.  If you take the Narcissism feat and get The Sniper veil, you can use it to shoot around corners!  If you take Phasic Shot from Sniper Sphere, you can shoot through walls!

Telescope (lens)**:  +2 perception, and the perception DC for long distance becomes +1 per 20 ft.  It’s not much, but perception is the most used skill in the game.  Zealots aren’t good at perception, so it’s probably best to take different talents and leave this one to classes that optimize scouting better.

Encompassing Light (light)*****:  Make target glow with bright light, spend +1 SP, and target gains reach and damage as if they were 1 size larger!  Any melee Zealot would love the extra reach and control, and even ranged characters will deal more damage!  Sadly, since this costs an extra SP, you can’t simply keep it up all day with Glory.  You need to be judicious with timing when you pre-buff yourself.  Lingering Glow can give you more of a cushion by increasing the duration of your glows to 10 minutes/CL, but that requires spending another talent.  Still, if you’re an AoO using Zealot, it can be worth casting this on your first turn of a combat.

Irradiance (light)****:  Glow creatures and make them sickened with no save!  A nice rider to add onto your Area Glow bomb.  If you got Nimbus Focus and Weird Radiance, you can even use the bright light function to sicken multiple enemies with no save and possibly even nauseate a few, even though you have a low CL and thus low DC, simply by virtue of them getting unlucky and rolling low on their save!
