Revelation (light)*:  Glow a source of written information and let anyone viewing it as a free action instantly read it entirely and get a +2 circumstance bonus to knowledge about it for 1 hour!  Alright, it’s not super useful for adventuring unless you’re a superspy infiltrating an enemy base for crucial intel, but it’s so much fun!  Walk into a library, cast Area Glow to make every book in the place grossly incandescent, and instantly read them all!  Ask your GM if you can get an Apparatus or Spell Engine to mimic this, so that you won’t have to spend a talent on it.

Shining Arsenal (light)***:  Glow a piece of equipment to make it ghost touch, or glow with bright light to mimic the effects of a special material.  With Glory, this effectively gives you the answer to whatever enemy you might be facing, whether it’s a ghost, lycanthrope, or outsider!  If you’re a Mithral Current user, you won’t have to spend money on a silversheen weapon.  You can make your full plate adamantine or your breastplate mithril.  A very versatile talent.

Weird Radiance (nimbus)*****:  Arrange the area of your glow as 20 5-foot cubes, or 30 with bright light.  That means you can exclude allies from the areas of your harmful glows, and you can reach long distances further than what the normal radius of a glow could reach!  There really is no reason not to take this via Nimbus Focus.

Final Ruling*****:  One of the most versatile and surprisingly useful spheres, even with few talents and low CL!  With a one talent dip and CL 1, you can get some tools for foiling tricky enemies or becoming more tricky and elusive yourself!

Mana

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Weather

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Combat Talents

When you spend a talent to pick a sphere, you first gain the base abilities of that sphere, and then you use more talents to gain any other talent in the sphere.  You also can pick sphere-specific drawbacks that give you bonus talents at the cost of limiting your ability to use the sphere in some ways.  Remember that this is a Zealot guide, and ratings are based upon how good these talents are for Zealots who won’t use attack actions, because PoW strikes are not compatible with attack actions.

Alchemy

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Athletics

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Barrage

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Barroom

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Beastmastery

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Berserker

Base Abilities:

Berserking*****:  Free action at the start of your turn, gain BAB+3 THP and -2 AC until the start of your next turn.  This is a lot like the Martial Power feat, except the penalty is to AC instead of attack, doesn’t scale, and doesn’t require shields for maximum value!  Remember that temporary HP can stack as long as it’s from different sources, so you can take both Berserker Sphere and Martial Power!  If you have a delayed damage pool from Guardian Sphere, this is an incredibly low-investment, effortless way of negating BAB+3 damage every round, because your delayed damage pool will damage your THP first!

Brutal Strike*:  Special attack action, melee-only, target is battered until the end of your next turn, you can expend martial focus to increase your damage by +2 per BAB, and apply 1 (exertion) talent.  A gold standard for SoM characters, but definitely not for PoW characters.  Why invest in this when you get strike maneuvers that have better effects and deal more damage for free?

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Adrenaline Junkie**:  Lose brutal strike, gain an (adrenaline) talent.  When you use an (adrenaline) talent, you don’t get the THP from berserking unless you also have the True Rage feat, which is a problem because the THP is the main draw of berserking.  Taking this also precludes you from taking Unbattered.  But some (adrenaline) talents might be worth it.

Unbattered*****:  Your brutal strikes don’t inflict the battered condition, and you gain Sanguine Invigoration.  You don’t use brutal strikes to begin with, so this is just free THP whenever you land a killing blow!

Talents:

Deathless*****:  Level 5 Zealots gain Diehard as a bonus feat courtesy of the Defiance class feature.  Deathless has Diehard as an associated feat, so you can take this talent instead of getting Diehard.  You should, because it’s flat out better!  Now you can live with an amount of negative HP up to (2 * con) + (2 * zealot level)!

Reaper’s Momentum***:  When you land a killing blow with a melee or thrown weapon, get another for free.  Landing killing blows isn’t a Zealot’s job, but it will still happen, and free attacks are never something to complain about!

Sanguine Intervention*****:  When you land a killing blow with a melee or thrown weapon, gain BAB THP for 1 round, or cure fatigue.  It’s free THP!  This talent is only purple if you get it for free with the Unbattered sphere-specific drawback.  Otherwise, it’s probably not worth bothering for.

Executioner (adrenaline)**:  Expend martial focus, make an attack roll twice and take the better result.  It’s lovely that this doesn’t cost any actions, but you won’t be able to recover martial focus easily because it takes actions to do so, so you’ll probably only be able to benefit from this once per combat.  Take a look at Fate Sphere and War Sphere for long term reroll buffs.

Marauder (adrenaline)***:  Gain a +5 circumstance bonus to speed, +5 per 4 BAB, and +½ BAB competence bonus to acrobatics, climb, fly, and swim.  This is more for out-of-combat travel, or for getting around really humongous battlefields.  It’s not a bad option, because even Zealots need to move sometimes!

Heavy Swing (exertion)*****:  For Seize the Opportunity users only.  Your target must make a fort save or be staggered, and if they’re already battered, they’re staggered no matter what and might be dazed!  A pretty ludicrous way to inflict devastating disabling conditions on enemies when you AoO them.

Legendary Talents:

Warp Spasm****:  While berserking or raging, gain 25% fortification for every 5 BAB you have.  That frees up some WBL you’d otherwise spend on an armor enchantment!

Final Ruling*****:  One of the best possible base spheres to unlock.  Berserking is almost too good to put into words, but putting goodness into words is what guides like this are supposed to do!  There aren’t many options for Zealots here other than the base sphere, but that’s fine.

Boxing

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Brute

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Dual Wielding

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Duelist

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Equipment

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

None.

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Fencing

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Gladiator

Base Abilities:

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Talents:

Final Ruling:

Guardian

Base Abilities:

Delayed Damage Pool*****:  When you take damage, it goes into your delayed damage pool (DDP) up to a maximum of 3 x your BAB, then empties and damages you for real at the end of your next turn.  This one little ability can make you survive for the one more round you need to close out a fight!  And it’s entirely passive, requiring no actions to use!  Use this in tandem with Berserking to negate a bunch of damage every round for free!  Berserking gives you THP at the start of your turn, and your DDP empties at the end of your turn.  A perfect combo!

Challenge Package**:  Move action or swift action by expending martial focus, make an enemy you can see suffer -2 (-1 more per 4 BAB)  to attack others and +2 to attack only you for 3 + ½ BAB rounds.  You already use your move actions for Aid Another and swift actions for boosts/counters, and those tend to be better than what Challenge can do.  However, since you can use Challenge on anyone who can perceive you, it technically has no maximum range, so you could challenge an enemy if you’re way over on the other end of a battlefield.

Patrol Package**:  Full-round action while having martial focus, increase threatened area by 5 ft + 5 per 4 BAB and apply a (zone) talent.  It’s the Warder’s Defensive Focus ability, AKA the Zone of Nope.  A full round action is a steep price when you could do your strike + Aid Another routine, but sometimes you’ll be so swarmed with weak minions that it’s better to AoO them down.

Sphere Specific Drawbacks:

Indifferent Defender*****:  Lose your Guardian package but make your DDP bigger!  This makes a dip into Guardian Sphere completely passive!

Without Delay**:  Lose your DDP, gain the Swift Defender talent.  If you really want to challenge as a free action or be an AoO blender, this isn’t an awful choice, but it comes with actual costs.

Talents:

Cold Iron Call****:  Delay spells and SLAs into your DDP, treated as 1 damage per the attacker’s CL.  Patrol + Defend Other lets you redirect spells from teammates to yourself as an AoO, and Challenge lets you debuff enemy save DCs.  Now, you can’t even be stopped by save-or-die or crowd control spells!  You can even cure the spell’s effects while it’s in your DDP before it affects you, if you or a teammate has the ability to do so!  The package synergies let you further protect your allies in ways that don’t use your immediate action, enough to seriously consider getting them!  You might not face deadly disabling spells all the time, but when you do, you’ll wish you had this.

Defend Other****:  Immediate action, give an ally in your threatened area ½ your BAB to AC vs the attack, and you can take the damage if it still hits.  Your PoW counters tend to be much better than this, especially skill-based ones.  However, if you take 2 levels of Warden and get the Defend Ally reinforcement, you can use Defend Other as an AoO instead!  This can be combined with the Bodyguard feat!  Red if you don’t take Cold Iron Call or Durable, green if you do, blue if you dip 2 levels of Warden.

Durable****:  Delay non-spell conditions and other negative effects into your DDP, treated as 1 damage per the attacker’s HD.  Patrol + Defend Other lets you redirect spells from teammates to yourself as an AoO, and Challenge lets you debuff enemy save DCs.  The non-spell counterpart to Cold Iron Call!  It’s too bad that you need to take two different talents to cover all your debuff-protection bases, but it’s so game changing to be able to say “no” to debuffs.

Endure Pain****:  When your DDP empties, the damage becomes nonlethal.  This effectively doubles the size of your DDP if you have a reliable source of healing, because healing cures 1 nonlethal damage for every actual point of damage it heals!  Swing around some Radiant Dawn maneuvers and you’ll be utterly unkillable!

Expanded Guardian**:  Get a package you don’t have.  If you take this, you have to be prepared to really go all-in with a ton of Guardian talents to make it worth the action economy burden.  You already can sink a lot of talents into Guardian Sphere with just the ones that improve your DDP.

Greater Delayed Damage***:  Increase your DDP by 1 per BAB, can be taken twice.  If you took the Indifferent Defender drawback, you got this for free once.  A bigger DDP is nice, but there comes a point of diminishing returns where it might not be worth it.

Guardian’s Focus***:  You regain martial focus when an attack misses an ally benefiting from Defend Other.  Don’t even read the first paragraph of this talent, because it requires an immediate action.  This is a rare and juicy non-action way of recovering your martial focus, which lets you fuel more free action challenges or move action patrols with Swift Guardian.  The problem is that you can’t always depend on an enemy attacking and missing your ally.  Not everything is reliable as the Zealot’s maneuver recovery!

Iron Wall**:  Allies within your patrol get 20% miss chance, challenged enemies have 20% miss chance vs allies within close range of you, and both combine to 50% miss chance.  Protect even more while you AoO blend!  Unless you have a lot of talents and actions to spare, you probably won’t be able to have both miss chances apply.  It might be too much investment to be worth it.

Swift Guardian***:  Challenge becomes a swift action or free by expending martial focus, and patrol becomes a standard action or move action by expending martial focus.  This is decent with patrol since it lets you move, aid another, or even do a standard action strike along with the patrol.  With challenge, it’s a bit more dubious, because making a challenge as a free action uses your martial focus, and it’s hard to recover that without using actions to do so.

Swift Reflexes**:  You probably already have more than enough AoOs with the Impulsive Reactions conviction, but if you frequently go into mass battles with Guardian (patrol) and Shield Spheres, maybe you’ll want more!  I don’t think it’s likely, but the option is there.

Assist (zone)****:  Use aid another as an AoO to improve the attack, AC, or save of an ally in your patrol.  It’s like the Bodyguard feat, but Bodyguard only improves the AC of adjacent allies.  This is much more versatile and lets you aid a bigger area!  But, alas, it requires you to spend the action setting up a patrol, whereas the Bodyguard feat is completely passive.  If you plan to go bananas with Guardian Sphere talents and use patrol, it’s worth it!  Otherwise, just stick with the passive DDP talents and continue on your merry way.

Final Ruling*****:  Incredible, regardless of whether you’re just getting the base sphere with Indifferent Defender, or going in deep with patrols and challenges.  Just know that if you do decide to use patrol or challenge, you will need to invest a lot of talents in order to compete with what your PoW maneuvers can accomplish.

Lancer

Feats

Dipping, Multiclassing, and Prestige Classes

City of Seven Seraphs

This is a planar setting, kind of like Planescape, made by Lost Spheres Publishing (LSP).  It mostly builds upon the Akashic Mysteries system, but it also has a lot of support for psionics, spheres of power, and even a class template for Zealots!

Sample Builds

 

Dread Captain Alexandra

A boisterous privateer who rallies her crew and strikes terror into the enemy!  She’s the captain of the Mother-O-Pearl, a ship with a motley crew of salty sea dogs whose zeal for adventure and gems brings them together in a rambunctious collective despite their differences.  Her powerful debuffing strikes almost never miss, and she’s incredibly durable for a ranged character.  Firearms Zealot!

CN Half-Orc.

Starting Stats (25 PB):  Str 10, Dex 18, Con 12, Int 12, Wis 7, Cha 16

Traits:  Practiced Initiator, Irrepressible.

Martial Traditions: Cirque de la Fumée.

Level 1:  Warlord (Privateer) 1.  Point Blank Shot, Precise Shot, Salt in the Wound, Sea Combat.

Level 2:  Bard (Rubato) 1.

Level 3:  Barbarian (Primal Disciple, Savage Technologist) 1.  Martial Power, Ranged Martial Power.

Level 4:  Swashbuckler 1.

Level 5:  Zealot 1.  Lingering Performance.

Level 6:  Zealot 2.  Personality Fragment (Virtuoso, +3 sleight of hand).

Level 7:  Zealot 3.  Wasp Familiar.

Level 8:  Zealot 4.  Psionic Conviction (Psicrystal Containment) via FCB, Destruction Mission.

Important Maneuvers:  Dustcatching Breeze (TG 2), Deflecting Shot (TG 2), Sniper’s Eye Stance (TG 1).

Important Gear:  Reliable Dragoon Pistol, Heavy Darkwood Shield, Headband of Charisma, Belt of Dexterity, Gloves of Larceny, Mithril Chain Shirt, Familiar Satchel.

Dread Captain Alexandra is a diva who loves to whip her audience into a frenzy from a prominent spot and sometimes jump into the mosh-pit herself.  She’s equally comfortable staying just out of the fray and shooting with her pistol, or leaping into melee for a daring duel!  Her performance kicks her support abilities up a notch when she becomes a Rubato Bard, able to start a bardic performance as part of using a strike maneuver.  Never one to be tied down (except in the bedroom, she’s totally into that,) her savage but elegant nature shows itself with her level of Barbarian followed by a level of Swashbuckler, granting her rage which gives a bonus to dexterity and no penalty to AC, and panache with which to use Opportune Parry.  She can even replenish her rage rounds for greater longevity over the day.  Her durability is further improved by Martial Power, making her tough like an inspiring captain should be!

Entering Zealot at character level 5 with the Practiced Initiator trait, Cap’n Alexandra is immediately able to learn 3rd level maneuvers.  Dustcatching Breeze serves her well against just about anything, and thanks to Salt in the Wound, her dirty tricks require a standard action to remove.  Other than Deflecting Shot, which she uses to defend her crew, her maneuver selection is largely open, letting her pick from whatever utility maneuvers she likes.  Sniper’s Eye Stance increases her dirty trick and disarm CMBs massively.  Destruction Mission lets her and her crew ignore the damage reduction of her toughest enemies, like giant enemy crabs.  Her Dragoon Pistol has 3 shots and a range of 30, giving her more space to pick her targets than a regular pistol would.  Her shield makes her Martial Power stronger.  If her familiar is in danger of dying to ludicrous amounts of AoE damage, it hops into her familiar satchel for full cover.

Being raised by humans and naturally skilled to begin with, the cosmopolitan 12 intelligence half-orc has a whopping 3 extra skill points per level beyond what her class levels give her, and loads of class skills thanks to being a Bard!  She can talk about anything, putting on speeches that captivate her prey, inspire her crew, and terrorize her enemies.  Her two companions, Black Pearl the psicrystal and Yellow Jack the wasp “parrot”, sit prominently upon her hat, encouraging her to harangue friend and foe alike!  Crewmates quickly learn not to question why the parrot has bright yellow and black stripes, diaphanous wings, and a stinger.

A worshipper of Calistria, the goddess of lust, trickery, and revenge, Cap’n Alexandra loves making convoluted but shallow plots for excitement, and keeps her crew on their toes with unpredictable but enjoyable antics.  She regularly gets into lengthy arguments with Cobalt, the Asmodeus-worshipping bosun of the ship, over ideological differences in their approaches to carrying out their capers.  However, they both love a good scheme and one another's unquenchable passion, and their arguments continue long into the night in the soundproofed room of the captain’s cabin!

Bosun Cobalt Damianos

A methodical manager, adherent of Asmodeus, and second in command to Captain Alexandra!  He jealously, zealously guards his crew with long reach, strong AoOs, and several counters per round.  His devastating strikes ensure that enemies stay locked down and unable to oppose him.  He has a seemingly simple and reliable single-class build, but it’s rife with Machiavellian complexity and power beneath the surface.  Single-classed AoO Zealot!

LN Maenad.

Starting Stats (25 PB):  Str 18, Dex 12, Con 14, Int 8, Wis 10, Cha 16

Traits:  <2 Open Traits>.

Martial Traditions: Lords of the Wheel.

Level 1:  Zealot 1.  Extra Readied Maneuver.

Level 2:  Zealot 2.  Impulsive Reflexes.

Level 3:  Zealot 3.  Extra Conviction (Personality Fragment (Bully)).

Level 4:  Zealot 4.  Protection Mission.

Level 5:  Zealot 5.  Psicrystal Containment.

Level 6:  Zealot 6.  Psionic Conviction (Psicrystal Reservoir).

Level 7:  Zealot 7.  Eternal Hourglass.

Level 8:  Zealot 8.  

Important Maneuvers:  Armory of the Goddess (SG 4), Watchman’s Rebuke (EG 4), Chains of Doubt (SG 3), Flickering Defense (RH 3), Riven Hourglass Stance (RH 3), Chronal Aggression (RH 2), Fear the Reaper (EG 2).

Important Gear:  Heavy Shield, Headband of Charisma, Belt of Strength, Full Plate.

Sneering down his immaculate gem-studded nose at his toiling crew, Bosun Cobalt is always at the ready to lash out to administer some discipline.  Armory of the Goddess gives him tremendous versatility in weapon selection, as does his Maenad heritage.  He can create any martial weapon or flail he wants at a whim, with a hefty +3 bonus!  Outside of combat, it usually takes the form of a whip to tickle the backs of lazy crewmates, but when he suspects trouble, he has more options.  If he thinks he’ll be up against an army of mooks and get a lot of AoOs, he’ll choose a Flying Blade.  If he needs extra AC and isn’t worried about damage, he’ll choose a Scorpion Whip and ready his shield.  An Urumi is good for especially cramped quarters.  For most other situations, a tri-point double-edged sword works nicely, being a reach weapon and discipline weapon for Sleeping Goddess.

His strike of choice is Chains of Doubt which he uses every possible round.  If he’s in a situation where a ranged touch attack is needed, Chronal Aggression keeps him in the fight.  Unlike most other PoW builds, Cobalt can use almost all of his readied maneuvers in a single round.  He uses Eternal Hourglass with either Watchman’s Rebuke or Fear the Reaper as a free action once per encounter, and saves his immediate action for Flickering Defense.  Thanks to Echoes of Steel, he can grant Flickering Defense to another ally, and that’s most often his loyal psicrystal, Igneous.  Finally, Unbreakable Fortress from the Protection Mission lets him use yet another counter as a free action!  Altogether, that’s 4 counters in a single turn.  And even on the occasion that enemies do manage to land a hit, his Living Bastion, high Zealot level, and high number of power points let him reduce the damage significantly.  Psicrystal Reservoir lets Igneous use full round action to restore Cobalt’s psionic focus, letting Cobalt augment Chains of Doubt to daze a second target or use Living Bastion more often.

Maenads know better than anyone what pointless destruction unchecked emotions can wreak.  Zealots and Sleeping Goddess specialists, too, know full well how the power of determination and belief can move mountains.  As a Winter soldier in the Lords of the Wheel, Cobalt Damianos seeks to impose order where it is needed, with the subtlety and poise of an Asmodean.  It’s not always easy to keep one’s composure, however, when rambunctious characters like Captain Alexandra test one’s patience!  Still, it makes for an excellent test of his ability to maintain patience and harmony, and there’s no denying Dread Captain has a certain fiery allure.  Luckily, Cobalt gets to unleash the full ferocity of his emotions in battle and the bedroom!

Ship’s Doctor Jubilation Sunheart

A plucky paladin of Sarenrae who signed on with Dread Captain Alexandra’s crew!  Doctor Sunny Jube, as the crew likes to call him, uses the power of Sarenrae’s sunlight to make absolutely sure that nobody dies under his watch, friend or foe!  His attacks, while weak in damage, are extremely accurate and heal for gigantic amounts, and he himself is no slouch in durability.  Healer and Laser Beam Zealot!

LG Halfling.

Starting Stats (25 PB):  Str 6, Dex 18, Con 12, Int 8, Wis 10, Cha 20

Traits:  Practiced Initiator, Helpful (Halfling).

Martial Traditions: None.

Level 1:  Knight Disciple Paladin 1.  Symbol of Mercy, Improved Guardian’s Shield.

Level 2:  Knight Disciple Paladin 2.  

Level 3:  Knight Disciple Paladin 3.  Radiant Dawn Style, Merciful Shield (Shaken).

Level 4:  Knight Disciple Paladin 4.  Righteous Sanctuary.

Level 5:  Zealot 1.  Sunset.

Level 6:  Zealot 2.  Personality Fragment (Friendly).

Level 7:  Zealot 3.  Radiant Sunlight.

Level 8:  Zealot 4.  Psionic Conviction (Psicrystal Containment) via FCB, Creation Mission.

Important Maneuvers:  Lifeburst Imbuement (RD 4), Sunstroke (RD 4), Lifeburst Strike (RD 3).

Important Gear:  Darkwood Heavy Shield, Headband of Charisma, Belt of Dexterity, Parade Armor.

Combining the +50% healing from 4 levels of the Knight Disciple Paladin, the amazing maneuver recovery of the Zealot, and the incredible healing capabilities of Radiant Dawn, Jube has one of the best possible builds for healing output in all of Path of War.  Upon entering combat, he uses his first swift action to enter Radiant Dawn Style.  He doesn’t even need to bother with counters most of the time, as his healing is nigh unassailable!

With 24 charisma, he uses Lifeburst Imbuement and Lifeburst Strike every round with Sun’s Gleam, easily landing ranged touch attacks.  He invests 2 essence into Lifeburst Imbuement and 2 essence into Lifeburst Strike for maximum healing, dishing out 40 healing with the former and 31 with the latter before anything else.  Then he adds on +50% for a running total of 106 healing, divided amongst his allies.  Next, he adds 10 healing and 10 temporary HP to one ally from Radiant Dawn Style and Sunset.  Oh, and if any of his allies are already at full health, they gain stacking temporary HP thanks to Radiant Sunlight.  All of this happens every single round.  As the final cherry on top, he uses Guardian’s Shield as a free action to give an ally an extra 8 temporary HP and Protection from Evil.

Even if an ally dies under his care, the good doctor has the Creation Mission to render them still healable for 1 round.  And with his incredible Paladin + halfling save bonuses, he’s almost certain to make the DC 15 fortitude save when an ally dies in his collective.  In serious emergencies, he can use Martyrdom to negate damage, expend his psionic focus to blast an ally with 4 healing per power point with Creation Mission, or use Righteous Sanctuary to pull an ally out of harm’s way without even needing to make a skill check of any kind.

Why would a Paladin team up with such an unruly rapscallion like Dread Captain Alexandra and her less scrupulous crewmates?  Because the greatest victory over Evil is to show evildoers the light and convert them to Good!  Like many good Sarenites, Jubilation believes in the power of mercy and redemption.  He prefers to deal nonlethal damage, which he can do at no penalty with his Sun’s Gleam attacks, and uses Symbol of Mercy whenever a foe would die in order to save their life.  At first, many of his crewmates found this annoying, saying that dead men tell no tales.  But when additional ransom money started rolling in, Cap’n Alexandra starting singing a different tune!  The stern Bosun Cobalt saw the benefit of a Paladin on board, even being a worshipper of Asmodeus.  The crew also couldn’t deny that many of them owed him their life after he saved them.  Slowly but surely, Doctor Sunny Jube is showing the sailors the benefits of compassion.

Lookout Yumi

A humble tigress from Tian Xia who can bullseye a moth on a moonless night from 300 yards away!  Her shots are incredibly accurate, even though they’re not ranged touch attacks, and she can support allies from a tremendous distance while keeping herself out of harm’s way.  Mounted Long Range Archery Zealot!

LN Fanglord Skinwalker (small).

Starting Stats (25 PB):  Str 10, Dex 18, Con 10, Int 8, Wis 8, Cha 20

Traits:  Practiced Initiator, <Open Trait>.

Martial Traditions: Cirque de la Fumée.

Level 1:  Warlord (Bushi) 1.  Outrider’s Gambit, Unbreakable Gambit, Improved Initiative.

Level 2:  Warlord (Bushi) 2.  Respect bushido.

Level 3:  Bloodrager (Bloodrider, Urban) 1.  Celestial bloodline familiar (Hawk (Mauler)), Step Up.

Level 4:  Monk (Master of Many Styles, Sohei) 1.  Riven Hourglass Style.

Level 5:  Zealot 1.  Solar Wind Style.

Level 6:  Mage Hunter 1.  True Strike, Keep Watch.

Level 7:  Mage Hunter 2.  Riven Hourglass Eternity, Dancing Darkness, Glitterdust.

Level 8:  Mage Hunter 3.  Pyrotechnics.

Important Maneuvers:  Wind Tunnel (TG 4), Dazzling Solar Flare (SW 4), Tempest Gale Stance (TG 3), Blinding Ray Shot (SW 3), Intercepting Shade (SW 2), Battle Mantra (SG 1).

Important Gear:  Distance Composite Longbow, Flight Arrows, Incendiary Arrows, Headband of Charisma, Belt of Dexterity, Gloves of Arcane Striking, Mithril Chain Shirt.

Now, you might say, how can this possibly be a Zealot build?  She’s level 8 but only has 1 level of Zealot!  She doesn’t have Commitment, the class ability that lets her use aid another on collective members at a distance!  But thanks to the magic of Practiced Initiator and the way initiating prestige classes work, she still has IL 8 in Zealot.  Yumi uses aid another on herself every round, riding her familiar with a 70 ft fly speed, and her aid another bonus is equal to her massive charisma modifier thanks to the Respect bushido.  For an extra bonus to attack, she can use Outrider’s Gambit for a hefty luck bonus, and also grants all allies within 60 feet a bonus to attack if she hits.

With a Distance Composite Longbow and Flight Arrows, Yumi has a range increment of 240 and a maximum range of 2400 feet.  She and her familiar, Hazu, like to sit in the crow’s nest of Dread Captain Alexandra’s ship, The Mother-O-Pearl, and maintain Wind Tunnel to have no penalties whatsoever based on range or cover.  Battle Mantra is her usual stance for +3 insight to attack, but if she’s confident that she can already hit targets on a 2 or higher, she switches to Tempest Gale Stance for a little more damage.  Dazzling Solar Flare is her bread and butter strike, but if a certain enemy looks too risky to try a fortitude save on, then she can use Blinding Ray Shot for a no-save blind.  She uses her first swift action every combat to activate both style feats and can easily maintain Wind Tunnel thanks to Riven Hourglass Eternity, eliminating the need for things like Precise Shot or Deadeye Bowman.

Though she might seem aloof and selfish with no Martyrdom, Yumi has plenty of ways to support her allies.  The crew relies on her to keep watch all night with her incredible night vision.  Since she’s a Fanglord Skinwalker with See in Darkness, she can see all the way to the horizons on a pitch black moonless night!  And she can stay up all night with Keep Watch.  If facing particularly evasive or stealthy foes, she can light them up for her allies with Solar Wind Style, ensure they can’t teleport away with Anchoring Point, strip their magical defenses with Strike of Dispelling, and even chase them down with the incredible speed of her flying familiar.  Dancing Darkness keeps her safe by making it more difficult for enemy archers to hit her, without interfering with her own attacks.  One of her favorite tricks against distant foes, such as enemy pirate ships, is to shoot an Incendiary Arrow and cast Pyrotechnics, a long range spell, on the ensuing fire.  It’s difficult for an enemy cannon crew to aim when they’re all choking on smoke or blinded while The Mother-O-Pearl closes the distance!

Yumi is a creature of duality.  Light and dark.  Fury and serenity.  Stillness and speed.  Yin and Yang.  Compared to the many other highly expressive Zealots that make up Captain Alexandra’s crew, Yumi seems positively demure, despite having one of the most powerful personalities.  Still waters run deep, and silk hides steel.  The tigress came from Tian Xia, traveling with the Cirque de la Fumée, enamored with the contrast of comedy and tragedy in their performances, and was lucky enough to be instructed in the secrets of the Grimoire Serpentis Ferra.  When she came across the Dread Captain’s ship -- or more accurately, the crew of the Mother-O-Pearl boarded the luxury cruise ship she was performing on -- she was fascinated by their passion, diversity, and penchant for beautiful gems, and decided to join up!  An amused Captain Alexandra allowed it on the condition that Yumi teach her a few of those amazing Tempest Gale tricks and take up station as the ship’s lookout.

The Bronze Boar

A gamla-heritage ragebred skinwalker infused with ectoplasmic energies who becomes more resilient the more he rips into his foes!  He focuses on getting as many attacks as possible, unlike most Zealots who do one attack per round. WARNING, it’s not recommended to use this build in an actual game, because it’s just that freakin’ powerful.  Full Attacker Zealot!

NE Ragebred Skinwalker (Gamla-Heritage).

Starting Stats (25 PB):  Str 18, Dex 10, Con 18, Int 7, Wis 9, Cha 14

Traits:  Practiced Initiator, Adopted (Tusked).

Martial Traditions: Bloody Fangs.

Level 1:  Aegis (Aberrant) 1.  Extra Feature.

Level 2:  Aegis (Aberrant) 2.

Level 3:  Aegis (Aberrant) 3.  Student of the Astral Suit.

Level 4:  Zealot 1

Level 5:  Zealot 2.  Golden Lion Style, Impulsive Reactions.

Level 6:  Zealot 3.  

Level 7:  Zealot 4.  Golden Lion Charge, Destruction Mission.

Level 8:  Zealot 5.  

Level 9:  Zealot 6.  <Open Feat>, <Open Conviction>.

Level 10:  Zealot 7.  

Level 11:  Zealot 8.  Golden Lion Command.

Important Maneuvers:  Frenzy Strike (Primal Fury 3), Cornered Frenzy Strike (Primal Fury 5), Broken Blade Stance (Broken Blade 3), Time Skitter (Riven Hourglass 3).

Aegis Customizations (10):  Brawn (free), Darkvision (free), Flight, Hardened Strikes (free), Initiator’s Soul (Broken Blade Stance (Broken Blade 3), Time Skitter (Riven Hourglass 3), any other 1 maneuver each of Broken Blade and Riven Hourglass), Stalwart, Stinger, 4 Tentacles.

Important Gear:  2 Thorn Bracers, Armor Spikes, Boulder Helm, Barbazu Beard, 2 Sea-Knives, Amulet of Mighty Fists, Belt of Strength, Headband of Charisma, Full Plate, Amulet of the Blooded (Abyssal), Fleshwarped Scorpion Tail, Cloak of the Manta Ray, Dorje of Metamorphosis, Wand of Enlarge Person.

Since he’s a gamla-heritage skinwalker, The Bronze Boar starts out large.  He can Use Magic Device with a wand of enlarge person prior to combat to increase his size to huge, increasing his reach and thus his likelihood to hit more enemies at once with Cornered Frenzy Strike, and a dorje of metamorphosis to gain 2 more natural attacks, ideal for fights with few targets.  He could forego the wand and only use the dorje to grow to gargantuan for when he’s about to enter a fight where reach is more important.  Impulsive Reactions gives him several AoOs, and every AoO he makes gives him and his allies 5 more THP thanks to Golden Lion Command.

The Bronze Boar has 2 thorn bracers, armor spikes, a boulder helm, a barbazu beard, 2 sea-knives, 2 claws, 2 hooves, a bite, a gore, 4 tentacles, 2 stings, a tail attack, and 2 more natural attacks from his dorje of metamorphosis.  Outside of combat, he constantly recovers Time Skitter to have haste for the first few rounds of combat, granting him another attack.  Broken Blade Stance gives him 2 more attacks when using a full attack action, which Cornered Frenzy Strike counts as.  Altogether, that’s 25 attacks when using Cornered Frenzy Strike.

Every round, he alternates between two sets of actions.  He uses Cornered Frenzy Strike one round, and Aid Another + Frenzy Strike + Destruction Mission’s 2nd augment the next to recover maneuvers while hitting multiple foes.  Broken Blade Stance doesn’t give him 2 extra attacks with Frenzy Strike, though.  He doesn’t need the Two-Weapon Fighting feat chain, because these strikes don’t actually use the two-weapon fighting rules, so they don’t impose any attack penalties.  With Golden Lion Command and 25 attacks, he grants himself and all allies within 30 feet 125 temporary HP per enemy in reach with Cornered Frenzy Strike.

When he reaches level 13, he grabs Primal Frenzy (Primal Fury 7) and uses it in place of Frenzy Strike.  It counts as a full attack action, so it benefits from Broken Blade Stance, and attacks all enemies in reach as a standard action.

When he reaches level 15, he stops using Initiator’s Soul to gain Broken Blade maneuvers, and instead picks God of the Hourglass Stance (Riven Hourglass 8).  Now he has an extra standard action to use every round.  From now on, his actions every round are Aid Another + Primal Frenzy + Frenzy Strike + Destruction Mission’s 2nd augment.

It’s not every day you meet a giant wereboar-kin camel covered with ectoplasmic tentacles in civilized society, and The Bronze Boar is anything but civilized.  After being abandoned in the wilderness, he was found and raised by a tribe of orcs who held a fierce reverence for nature, and they inducted him into the Bloody Fangs martial tradition when he came of age.  Growing up, he was plagued by nightmares of aberrations from beyond the stars, and his body twisted and morphed into something grotesque.  However, a druid of Lamashtu and priest of his adoptive orcish tribe proclaimed his monstrous form and nightmares to be a blessing!  This acceptance encouraged a zealous devotion in the young skinwalker, earning him his first Zealot level.  He protects his chosen allies in the most direct, brutal, and destructive way possible, bolstering their resolve the more he tears bloody mutilated swathes through his enemies!

Nelly Nephilim

A fallen aasimar made by upho!  She is an EXTREMELY powerful build using many of the tricks found in this guide.  She stacks size increases for more damage and reach, dips several different classes for incredible benefits including Fiendish Marauder Warder to wield 2 Fiend’s Grips, and takes the incredible Awakened Blade prestige class for gigantic numbers, action economy, and manifesting progression.  Upho gave this build a truly mind-boggling amount of detail with itemized listings for every bonus, and you can find it all in this link!  He even went above and beyond, explaining her combos here!  WARNING, it’s not recommended to use this build in an actual game, because it’s just that freakin’ powerful.
